title: What Did One Comic Say to the Other? Read On
description: Veterans of acclaimed one-man shows in New York, Jackie Mason and Calvin Trillin will be back on stage this week and next for fresh runs in new solo performances. On Thursday, Mr. Trillin, the author, raconteur, writer for The New Yorker and columnist for The Nation, will open Off Broadway in ''Calvin Trillin's Words, No Music'' at the American Place Theater on 46th Street. On Oct. 17 ''Jackie Mason: Brand New'' will open on Broadway at the Neil Simon (previews begin Tuesday). Having lived and learned during their earlier shows - Mr. Mason in ''The World According to Me'' in 1986 and Mr. Trillin in ''Uncle Sam'' in 1988 - the pair recently got together to talk about their new acts and what works and what doesn't out there alone in front of the footlights. Here are excerpts from their conversation. Trillin: So what are you doing this time that's different? Mason: Everything I do is different. You have fans who come to see you again. Usually you can't depend on new customers because the new ones are guys who didn't like you in the first place or they would have come to the first show. So you're playing to the same people. It has to be a whole new show. I do the newest situations - politics, economics. I talk about the contradictions and the ridiculousnesses in the way people behave, about luxury apartment buildings that have fantastic lobbies without apartments. The new politics up to and including crime in New York and oil and the Gulf situation. Like how you can't find a cop to help you in New York, but if Iraq threatened to bomb the filling stations you'd have the Army here in a second.

title: Sports of the Times;   Can Joe Mac Find Happiness in the Sun?
description: So Joe McIlvaine is leaving New York to become the general manager in the alleged good vibrations of San Diego. He says he is tired of the personal backbiting and wanted his children to grow up in a better environment than suburban New York.

title: NASA's Failures End As Discovery Lifts Off
description: Ending a string of frustrating failures, NASA succeeded in sending the shuttle Discovery into space, and the orbiter's crew later dispatched the spacecraft Ulysses on a mission that will take it around Jupiter on its way to explore the poles of the Sun.

title: Review/Music;   The Art of Gagaku From Imperial Japan
description: The term gagaku refers to a set of rituals, primarily musical and choreographic, that were inspired by now-extinct continental Asian practices and have flourished and mutated at the imperial court of Japan for a thousand years.

title: Pirates' Owners Pleading Poverty
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates won a division title and set an attendance record this season. But financially, the Pirates' management says, the team is languishing in the second division, and could actually suffer from rather than be helped by its success.

title: A Call to Punish Patriot Players
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cool-Weather Care for Potted Plants
description: HOUSE plants should be inside now. Although October has some balmy days, plants that live their lives in pots should be not be out in them. They need a few weeks of transition after their summer vacation.

title: The Road to Ruin in New York
description: Lurching.

title: Corrections
description: A map caption last Sunday with an article about visitors to the Antietam battlefield referred incorrectly in some copies to the number killed in the Civil War battle there. About 4,800 troops were killed.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION Baseball? Forget It. Let's Talk Lawns
description: LEAD: I THINK that in the suburbs discussing lawn care is going to replace baseball as the quickest way for two men to have a bonding experience.

title: Sports People;   Clippers Sign Kimble
description: After a bit of brinksmanship, Bo Kimble, the high-scoring former Loyola Marymount star who was the eighth pick in the June draft, has finally come to terms with the Los Angeles Clippers on a contract his agent said would provide Kimble with lifetime financial security.

title: U.S. Agency Loses Boston Deportation Case
description: Two years after dozens of Hispanic people were rounded up at a racetrack, lawyers say they have won a major victory over government officials who tried to deport the people without proving they were illegal aliens.

title: In Domestic Soviet Trade, Russia Has the Most Chips
description: Casting himself as headmaster to the overexcited students of Capitalism 101, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ordered a recess while the experts decide how Soviet markets are to be liberated and when. But in the view of many Western analysts, class discipline cannot be restored for long.

title: Faculty Protests Military Recruiting
description: LEAD: THE State University at Stony Brook, in reaction to the armed forces ban on homosexuals, is moving to require outside organizations to sign nondiscrimination agreements before recruiting on campus.

title: When Singles Meet, They Do More Than Party
description: IN the strobe lights of the Long Island Exchange at the Huntington Hilton, throngs of men and women danced to rock music while hundreds jammed the bars and aisles, watching the dance floor.

title: Europe for Less: It Can Be Done;   Amsterdam
description: Take some carefully counted pennies, mix with a generous dose of music and art and sprinkle with lively, slightly accented conversation. In an easygoing setting, let it rise for three or four days. The recipe, so a proud citizen of Amsterdam insists, works wonders in the city, even in the winter.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Those who feel that choosing a color film is already much too complicated will find no solace in Agfa's recent announcement of a new family of color-print films. Dubbed the Triad system, the three Afgacolor films offer photographers the ability to match color intensity to subject matter.

title: In Frankfurt, an Annual Fair for Publishers
description: The day after the 42d annual Frankfurt Book Fair opened, Dieter Jungling's country and hometown officially ceased to exist. In the hurly-burly of the publishing world's most important annual event, however, the fact that German unification had erased East Germany and East Berlin from the map was a historical sidelight.

title: Scot Working in Kuwait Dies
description: A Scottish scientist working for the Kuwaiti Ministry of Health has died in Iraqi-held Kuwait, his family said today. The family of William Atack, 46 years old, said in a statement that they had learned of his death from the British Foreign Office on Sept. 30 and added: ''It is understood that he took ill but did not recover. The cause of his death is not known.''

title: Bronx Mugging Victim Dies of Heart Attack
description: A 65-year-old man suffered a fatal heart attack after being assaulted by two muggers on a Bronx street on Friday night, the police said yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES STOPGAP BUDGET; SHUTDOWN BEGINS
description: President Bush began selectively shutting down the Federal Government today to build pressure on Congress for a budget deal, but even as he attacked Congress he said he would be ''flexible'' in the details of a deal he would accept.

title: Follow-Up On the News
description: Suit Dropped On Frog Dissection

title: Palestinians Wait to Swallow Up Jordan
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleaner Charcoal Grilling Sought in California
description: Air quality officials in the Los Angeles area have ordered the makers of charcoal lighter fluid to devise a cleaner-burning product by 1992 or face having the barbecue fuel banned.

title: Lonesome Jane
description: BUFFALO GIRLS

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Lord help the President when he has to make that decision.

title: Works in Progress;   Back to Their Sunday Best
description: Since 1986, Yves Boiret, the Inspector General of French Historical Monuments, has been directing the restoration of the great Cathedral Notre Dame de Reims. Though the general structure is, as 700-year-old edifices go, fundamentally stable, old age, weather and pollution have combined to ravage many of the nearly 500 sculptures - ranging from 15-foot representations of kings to small stone faces - that adorn the exterior. Spot surgery is being performed where possible - fissures patched to keep water from further damaging the interior of the stone - but many of the sculptures have proven unsavable and must be replaced. As many as 100 of these have been stored, for what appears a rather melancholy eternity, in a nearby warehouse (shown above left), while sculptors, working from photographs and historical documents, replicate them (lower right).

title: Miss Rice Weds H. C. McDuff 3d
description: Luanne Rice and Henry Charles McDuff 3d were married yesterday at their home in Niantic, Conn., by the Rev. David W. Good, a Congregational minister.

title: Northeast Notebook: Kennett Square, Pa.;   High-End Speculation
description: Despite projections by real estate professionals that it will take more than five years to sell all the new million-dollar homes built in this southern Chester County community, a real estate developer has put up two estate-style homes on speculation and plans five more.

title: Dressing Up Fish and Chicken for a Twirl on the Grill
description: GRILLED fish is like a little black dress, a wardrobe staple that can be varied with accessories and seasonings. Salsas, flavored butters, chutneys, cream or wine sauces can dress it up or down. Grilled boneless chicken breasts can be treated much the same way. A bright, robust combination of sweet and hot peppers, onion, tomatoes and herbs is one of those all-purpose adornments that can enhance simple grilled tuna or other grilled fish or chicken. It is extremely quick to prepare, calling for ingredients that are readily available in most markets. Spread it over the fish or chicken and the dish is ready to serve.

title: Pastimes: Gardening;   Some Plants Can Be Aggressive
description: Beware of certain plants. They may look superb. But then they start to grow to the point where they become nuisances. Instead of enjoying this exuberance, gardeners wonder how to get rid of them.

title: David L. Hurwitz, 62, Lawyer in Manhattan
description: David Lyman Hurwitz, a lawyer and partner in the Manhattan firm of Hurwitz & Vail, died on Friday in New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Pianists Take Spotlight in New Season
description: FIRST-RATE pianists from Brazil, Spain and the United States will be in the solo spotlight next weekend as three orchestras open the new season, while keyboard virtuosos from the Soviet Union and Cuba are featured in solo recitals.

title: A Haitian Mayor's Credo: No Work, No Pay
description: Squatters can sometimes be seen bathing in rain puddles as flies swarm around mountains of refuse rotting under the sun in this capital's downtown streets.

title: Being Multilingual Has Its Rewards
description: It was with interest that I read Edda Joan Tenret's article ''Bilingual At An Early Age'' (Opinion, Sept. 9). My own life has shown how easy and rewarding it is to grow up speaking either two or three languages.

title: Q and A
description: New York Apartments

title: Lifestyle;   Last Refuge for Kibitzers and Patzers
description: A dozen knitted brows leaned over worn plastic chess sets at the Chess Shop in Greenwich Village on a rainy afternoon. The players nodded in animated contemplation, clopping chess pieces against the boards and thwacking speed clocks.

title: Katherine Ann Boyle Marries Thomas A. Sobolik
description: Katherine Ann Boyle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Boyle of Des Moines, was married yesterday to Thomas A. Sobolik, a son of Virginia E. Sobolik of Lake Ariel, Pa., and Donald E. Sobolik of Dingman's Ferry, Pa. The Rev. James Gilliom, a United Church of Christ Minister, officiated at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Des Moines. The bride graduated from the University of Missouri and is an associate producer for CBS News in New York. Her husband, a graduate of Boston University, is a photographer for the Black Star Publishing Company in New York.

title: State's Past Holds Saga Of 3d-Party Candidate
description: LEAD: IT was an unusual election with a maverick candidate.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Darien, Conn. $485,000

title: House Sale Affected By Radon
description: THE potential health risks posed by radon, a colorless, odorless gas that can collect in the home, may have become another item on the checklist of things that must be handled before a house sale is closed and the keys turned over.

title: A Tenor Who Helped to Set The Standard
description: Between them, Enrico Caruso (1873-1921) and Beniamino Gigli (1890-1957) set the standard for operatic tenors in the mainstream repertory in the first half of this century. Their recorded legacy endures; later this year, there will be a comprehensive Caruso collection from RCA on compact disks, while EMI has already released a bountiful package to celebrate the Gigli centennial. It contains eight complete operas built around the tenor between 1934 and 1946, as well as the Verdi Requiem and two generous collections of arias and songs.

title: New York, N.Y.
description: To the Editor: As Andrew L. Yarrow tells us, ''The chief down side to the Empire State Building and World Trade Center observatories is the crowds . . . On recent midweek summer visits, the ground-level wait for each building was 40 minutes'' (''Above It All,'' Travel, Sept. 9). Tourists and New Yorkers alike put up with high prices and the threat of crime in order to enjoy the beauties and pleasures of the city. They should not have to deal with lines as well. There used to be a third rooftop observatory in Manhattan, atop the R.C.A. (now G.E.) Building, which served two purposes: easing the crowds elsewhere and offering unique views of Central Park and northern midtown. It was closed a few years ago with no announcement and no discussion.

title: Good, Done
description: Rarely these days does noblesse take its oblige as seriously as Countess Albina du Boisrouvray of France seems to. The Countess was looking around last year for a medical facililty where children with AIDS were treated with an extra degree of empathy. Then she heard about Dr. James M. Oleske, who ran a financially strapped program that tried to do just that in Newark, N.J. The Countess said that when she saw all the toys around his office, ''I was confident he was the person I was looking for.'' Dr. Oleske, who for months knew her only as Albina, learned of her background only when she invited him to apply for a grant from the foundation she had recently helped start. He said he was thinking of asking for $10,000 when his staff urged him to ask for what he really needed. That was $2.25 million. He got it last week. ''I never suspected she was wealthy because she never wore jewelry,'' he said. ''Now I know why. She sold some of her family's jewelry to make up the gift.''

title: IN SHORT/NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: So It Parks Itself. Where?
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Not a Free Ukraine?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dismembered Body Identified
description: A dismembered body found near the Brooklyn Navy Yard has been tentatively identified as that of Mary Beal, 61 years old, of the Bronx, the police said yesterday. They said the body parts were found in two bags on Sept. 15, the day she was reported missing. Mrs. Beal, a Yugoslav immigrant and widow, had moved to the Norwood section in the north-central Bronx 25 years ago. She ran a real-estate business, M.G.B. Realty.

title: Three Faces of Richard III In a One-Man Display of Evil
description: In the course of his rollicking performance in ''Richard III,'' Stacy Keach comes close to accounting for that character's popularity with a single brazen gesture. For the saturnine creature is decidedly popular right now.

title: Sex Asks Its Due at Vatican Synod on Priests
description: Despite admonitions from church leaders that the topic was out of bounds, the troublesome theme of sex and the priesthood has insistently emerged in the first days of a monthlong synod of Roman Catholic bishops that began here this week.

title: WHY AMERICA FAILS ITS CHILDREN
description: As a member of the National Commission on Children, T. Berry Brazelton seems surprised that ''Americans have become numb to reports of the hopelessness of their children'' (''Why Is America Failing Its Children?'' Sept. 9). Brazelton should know that such commissions are appointed as a palliative, a substitute for taking action. This is the third national commission appointed in 10 years.

title: Pro Hockey;   Islanders' Start: Illness, Injury and a Loss
description: Battered by suspensions, an injury, a mysterious illness, road-weariness, an unresolved contract dispute and an opening-game defeat, the Islanders faced the North Stars here tonight in their second game of the regular season.

title:
Berlin Township Journal;

Community Receives National Recognition for Its Recycling
description: LEAD: LONG before it was a state mandate or a politically proper policy, recycling was a reality in this three-and-a-half-square-mile Camden County community.

title: Who Gets Fiscal Control of New York?
description: Mounting concern over New York City's fiscal problems has prompted state and city leaders to start to jockey for control over the city's troubled finances.

title: Study Finds AIDS Risk for Men in Oral Sex
description: A new analysis of the sexual behavior of dozens of men infected with the AIDS virus indicates that oral sex between men may be a greater factor in spreading the disease than many scientists assumed.

title: PRETORIA PONDERS U.S. CONSTITUTION
description: The American Constitution is being examined by the Government of President F. W. de Klerk as a possible model to carry South Africa beyond the end of apartheid.

title: Residential Auctions More Popular
description: RESIDENTIAL real-estate auctions, traditionally perceived as the last resort of desperate developers, are fast becoming an acceptable, sometimes preferable sales strategy, real-estate experts say.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   North of New York, Fall's Splendor Includes Color and Country Fare
description: On almost every road north from the metropolitan New York area, the Virginia creepers and the sumacs are turning bright red and deep purple, harbingers of the fall foliage season. Here and there a solitary sugar maple displays its vivid bronze and crimson, heralding the season's peak.

title: The Sound of Nineveh
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Welcomes New Jersey Plays
description: TUESDAY'S opening of ''About Time,'' a play about how an octogenarian couple cope with aging, will mark the first serious new work of Off Broadway's fall season. If Tom Cole's play, which was first seen in full-length form at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, succeeds, it will join a select lineup of diverse hits that are enlivening Off Broadway theater and have emanated from New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A chart entry with the Travel Advisory column on Sept. 23, about airport departure taxes, misstated the amount charged international passengers departing from French airports. It is 30 francs ($8.50), not 57.50 francs ($16.30). The entry also misstated the payment method. The tax is included in the price of an airline ticket, not paid at the airport.

title: Obstacles Snag Renewal in New Rochelle
description: TO hear city officials talk about it, their long-neglected downtown is a Sleeping Beauty. And if Prince Charming hasn't actually planted the kiss that magically restores signs of life, they say, at least his car has been sighted in the parking lot.

title: Agamemnon and the Guys at the Bar

title: Hearing The Cries Of Crack
description: The future of America's cities is lying in isolettes in the neonatal intensive care unit of Bronx-Lebanon hospital. The bright room is filled with baby misery: babies born months too soon; babies born weighing little more than a hardcover book; babies that look like wizened old men in the last stages of a terminal illness, wrinkled skin clinging to chicken bones; babies who do not cry because their mouths and noses are full of tubes.

title: Campus Life: Paul Quinn;   Hoping to Grow, College Makes 100-Mile Move
description: Paul Quinn College has packed its bags and moved north about 100 miles from Waco, Tex., replacing another predominantly black college.

title: Physician's Assistants Face Growing Need
description: LEAD: AS a biology major at Fairfield University, Fiore Soviero said, he expected to go on to medical school. But his part-time job as an ambulance assistant took him into hospital emergency rooms, where he heard interns and residents question their decisions to become physicians.

title: Computers Begin To Assume The Role of Critic
description: Can you teach a computer to be a music critic? Probably not, because computers can make only programmed (i.e., prejudiced) judgments, which is exactly what conscientious critics try to avoid. But efforts are now under way to use computers to help evaluate musical performances.

title: Matter of Law, Not Opinion
description: Somehow, I thought this was all over. I thought that at long last everyone had read the Constitution and the Civil Rights law and realized that equal access for female sportswriters was not a matter of opinion but the law of the land.

title: Correction

title: Syosset to Focus on 'Middle' Student
description: EVERY school district throughout Long Island has both mandated and voluntary programs for gifted and talented students, children with learning disabilities and foreign students whose second language is English.

title: Appraising African Art Through Western Eyes
description: ''Closeup: Lessons in the Art of Seeing African Sculpture'' is an attempt to deal with the paradox of the Western perception of African art. On the one hand, the visual refinement and sophistication of the European tradition has enabled Western artists to be highly responsive to the inventiveness and dynamism of African art. On the other, this visual orientation has a tendency to blind or distance Westerners from African art's essential and very different reality.

title: Mets Shaking Up Their Coaching Staff
description: Less than a week after ending their 1990 season in second place, the Mets have begun doing some spadework for 1991, hiring one new coach, reassigning three others and scheduling surgery for a couple of ailing pitchers.

description: Dr. Dorothy M. Hoyt, a daughter of Mrs. C. Douglas Hoyt of Fair Haven, N.J., and the late Dr. Hoyt, was married yesterday to Richard W. Rehm, the son of Mrs. Wendell Rehm of Shrewsbury, N.J., and the late Mr. Rehm, by the Rev. George Willis Jr. at St. George's by the River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J. Dr. Hoyt-Rehm, a graduate of Indiana University, received a degree in dentistry from Fairleigh Dickinson University and is a dentist in Fair Haven. The bridegroom, a graduate of the Delaware Valley College of Science and Agriculture, owns and runs Triple Brook Nursery in Colts Neck and Howell, N.J.

title: Sadly, a Salvadoran Will Leave His Country

title: Ms. McAvoy Weds Bart Landenberger
description: Jennie Van Pelt McAvoy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. McAvoy of Tappan, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bart Lawrence Landenberger, a son of Jane Hamilton Landenberger of Bedford, N.Y., and the late John Landenberger. The Rev. Norman E. Thornton performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Cambodian Dance: Grace and Tragedy
description: Legend has it that Cambodia was born when a heavenly dancer, or apsara, named Mera made love with the hermit Kumpu. Ever since, dance has been at the very core of Cambodian identity. In the first cultural exchange between the United States and Cambodia since 1971, the war-scarred inheritors of this ancient tradition, the Classical Dance Company of Cambodia, will perform at the Joyce Theater Tuesday through Sunday.

title: Tallow and Gaslight: What Did People Do Before Electricity?
description: LEAD: IN early Colonial days, people were forced to rise at the crack of dawn to take advantage of daylight. ''Before the Light Bulb,'' a thought-provoking exhibition at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center through March 10, explores how people in earlier times managed to light their world before the discovery of electricity.

title: Review;   Review/Dance Graham On Symbol And Myth
description: Since Martha Graham made her choreographic debut in 1926, she has created works in an extraordinary variety of styles, each of which has amazed some dancegoers and annoyed others. The Martha Graham Dance Company offered examples of several of these styles on Friday night at the City Center.

title: The Gadfly Who Audits Philanthropy
description: What Ralph Nader is to corporate America, Daniel Borochoff is fast becoming to the philanthropic world. Just ask Mothers Against Drunk Driving.

title: Nations Are Nuisances
description: LEAD:

title:
ART;

How Seven Artists Apply Expressions
description: LEAD: IN the current exhibition at the Smithtown Township Arts Council's galleries in Mills Pond House in St. James, the work of seven artists is grouped under a catchall title, ''Expressions.''

title: Mosquitoes' Threat Disrupting Florida Nightlife
description: Phyllis Capece, a nurse, forfeited four hours' pay and showed up at the game with her beeper. Her husband, Pete, left his athletic store, Active Feet, three hours early. Matt Parris, a college freshman in Orlando, cut his English class and made the 90-mile drive home in record time. Mary Ann Driskell was stuck: she had to babysit.

title: Food;   Mash Appeal
description: Growing up near the vineyards of California, I had little experience with whisky. As an adult, I jumped straight into chardonnay, with only a brief flirtation with rum and Coke. So it wasn't until some years ago, when I was cooking in Vicenza, near Venice, that bourbon and I got acquainted. Northern Italy may seem an odd place to discover this native American spirit, but I was staying with a very grand septuagenarian - originally from Texas - who adored Jack Daniel's. (All right, Jack Daniel's, a Tennessee whisky, isn't technically bourbon, but it's close enough.) And there was plenty of it around. Although I was never converted to drinking the stuff, I was sufficiently hooked on its flavor in cooking to try my hand at ''bourbonizing'' several dishes.

title: The Four Bikers of the Apocalypse
description: GOOD OMENS

title: Police Reinstate Rules on Bystander Arrests
description: The New York City Police Department moved last week to quell a growing controversy over so-called onlooker arrests, by reissuing a set of 13-year-old guidelines on the legal rights of bystanders who peacefully criticize police operations.

title: Cloth Diapers Don't Help the Environment
description: In a recent letter to the New Jersey editor entitled ''A Cup of Coffee, an Idea on Recycling,''the author suggested that an appropriate environmental alternative to a plastic foam coffee cup is a ceramic mug and that a canvas or string grocery bag is better than a brown paper bag.

title: Woman Is Killed in Bronx Drive-by Shooting
description: A 20-year-old Bronx woman was shot in the head and killed early yesterday morning on a sidewalk in a housing project by a bullet the police believe was intended for someone else.

title: Judith Leibholz Weds
description: Judith Ellen Leibholz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Leibholz of Rydal, Pa., was married last evening to Oliver Lincoln Frankel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Frankel of London. Rabbi David Wice officiated at the College of Physicians in Philadelphia. Mrs. Frankel, 28 years old, is a vice president in New York of the Industrial Bank of Japan. Mr. Frankel, 36, is a trader at Credit Lyonnais in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Europe for Less: It Can Be Done;   Vienna
description: In the minds of many travelers, Vienna ranks alongside Geneva and Tokyo as one of the most expensive cities in the world. In fact, recent travelers here have commented that it now seems cheaper than Italy. One thing is sure: the closer to the city center, the higher the prices.

title:
The Executive Life;

The Chain Letter Of the Rich and Famous
description: LEAD: ''I don't fly on Friday the 13th; I don't walk under ladders; when my favorite baseball team, the Philadelphia Phillies, are winning I don't change my underwear (thank God they've had a string of losing seasons), and I'll be damned if I'm going to break a chain letter.''

title: Fashion;   It's Hot!
description: At first, it was just one shot of color. The shock of something in brilliant purple, yellow, orange or acid green was stimulation enough. But now that the eye - and the psyche - have adjusted to that fashion jolt, designers are going a step further. Lots of the new holiday and resort styles combine, in one costume, two or more of these explosive colors. Bandings of black are often used to help delineate the overall silhouette. Dashes of dazzling white are another effective accent, either used as a trimming or worn as a bodysuit, t-shirt or tights underneath. These flashes of white seem to intensify the hot tones. And when one of these colorful ensembles is finished off with accessories dipped in even more dynamic hues, it adds up to one hot look.

title: New York, N.Y.
description: To the Editor: In the article on New York City bars (''Drinking in the View,'' Travel, Sept. 9), William Grimes stated that the River Cafe ''sits solidly on firm ground.'' It ain't necessarily so because the restaurant itself is mounted on a barge.

title: Calls for Holy War Reveal Fissures In Islamic World
description: When Saddam Hussein proclaimed that his confrontation with the Arab and Western countries that oppose his occupation of Kuwait was ''a holy war,'' the Iraqi leader's action testified not only to the power of Islam but also to its complexities and limits.

title: Group to Share $10 Million In Settlement of Jet Accident
description: The families of four people killed in the crash of a Continental Airlines jet in Denver in 1987 will share $10 million in an out-of-court settlement, a lawyer for the families said Thursday.

ART;

The Double Appeal Drawings Create
description: LEAD: DRAWINGS have traditionally appealed to artists as a way of investigating structure, and they have traditionally appealed to viewers for the insights they offer into the first phases of a creative idea.

description: Harry J. Halperin, a prominent New York lawyer for 66 years, died on Friday night at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 90 years old.

title: Paris
description: Paris seems in a hurry to prevail as Europe's cultural capital. Whoever said that the city had turned into a backwater of the arts should be having second thoughts. Glossier and more opulent than ever, Paris has been dedicating more money and more space to the latest or finest in sculpture, furniture, painting and photography. In a city that already has more than 400 art galleries, new ones are appearing faster than you can say Transavantgarde.

description: Tennis

title: The Songs of Therapy
description: IT IS TIME FOR MUSIC IN PATTI Wagner Tinder's classroom on the leafy campus of the New York Institute for Special Education in the Bronx. It's time for the ''hunga-bunga-bunga'' song, a thumping blues melody that Tinder made up a week earlier when two students barreled in shouting ''hunga-bunga-bunga'' over and over. This is no ordinary music class. It is music therapy. The boys, both 10 years old, are emotionally disturbed. They tend to be hyperactive and are often boisterous at inappropriate moments. But by improvising a song based on their rowdy hunga-bunga-bunga, a nonsense phrase that is probably a variation on something they heard in the playground or on television, Tinder was able to break through their hyperactivity and get them to pay attention. Now they are singing along as she plays the blues on her upright piano.

title: Tara G. Goldberg To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Tara Gwen Goldberg to Richard Aaron Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Weiss of Potomac, Md., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Laurence T. Goldberg of Fort Lee, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Anne Hutchinson: Puritan Rebel and Westchester Pioneer
description: IT was the most notorious murder in the history of Westchester, when the region included the Bronx and stretched northward as far as present-day Stamford. The victim was Anne Marbury Hutchinson, a 52-year-old English immigrant, the mother of 14 children, who was banished from Massachusetts on charges of heresy, political anarchy and witchcraft. She had fled first to Rhode Island and finally, in the spring of 1643, to the quiet marshes on the site of what is now Co-op City.

LONG ISLAND Q&A;: DR. PHILIP SOLOMON;

A Radio Astronomer Helps Track the Disappearance of Ozone

description: Richard Kessel, director of the New York Consumer Protection B oard, has given the most disgraceful performance of any politician that I have seen after having lived 27 years on Long Island.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: KEIO HIGH SCHOOL;

A Strong Academic Standard
description: LEAD: THE Matsushita Dining Hall at Keio High School here reflects the institution's Japanese and American culture. The big, contemporary, white-walled room is festooned with Oriental-style kites and banners. Chopsticks are stacked next to knives and forks. One recent day, the menu featured a lunch of spaghetti, sauteed green beans and tossed salad, while dinner was ebi furai - fried prawns - and steamed rice.

title:
FORUM;

We Need to Find More Domestic Oil

Iraq's takeover of Kuwait is obviously different in many respects from the 1973 oil embargo or the fall of the Shah of Iran in 1979, but we continue to be seriously, and, in my view, unnecessarily, vulnerable to such events.

title: Rejects' Revenge
description: In the heyday of the New York City club scene, menacing but chic bouncers would eye the crowd, using some mysterious inner logic to decide who was fashionable enough to get in. In recent years the custom seems to have spread to Los Angeles, which prides itself on a more relaxed social atmosphere. But some of the excluded are fighting back. Last week Kenneth Lipton, Jeff Stolzer, Teresita Dubrall and Stephen Ambrosini were each awarded $250 in damages by a small claims court after they were denied admission to a club called the Mayan. Mr. Lipton said he and his friends were forced to wait for an hour and a half while other people were waved right in. The club's owner said Mr. Lipton's party was ''mouthing off.'' The case was brought under the Unruh Civil Rights Act, which was passed to fight discrimination in business establishments. ''Even if Mr. Lipton is a nerd, he is protected by Unruh,'' said Carol Sobel, senior staff counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union in Southern California.

Long afternoon shadows play across the jagged red and green rocks that line her path, like sentinels in a forbidden planet landscape. She is deep inside the canyonlands of southeastern Utah. At the top of the climb and hardly out of breath, Taylor stops and stares.

Last week, however, even the normally insouciant Japanese Finance Minister expressed alarm at what is, by any measure, a vicious bear market that is not just savaging share prices but is threatening the financial system and altering the views some hold of the Tokyo market.

title: IN SHORT/NONFICTION
description: COMPUTER ETHICS: Cautionary Tales and Ethical Dilemmas in Computing. By Tom Forester and Perry Morrison. (MIT, $19.95.) Because computers have made their way into nearly every corner of our lives, the professionals who design computers may unwittingly possess as much control over our future as elected officials. Yet students preparing for careers in computer and software development often receive little - or no - instruction in the ethical problems they will create. Two Australians, Tom Forester, who teaches at the School of Computing and Information Technology at Griffith University in Queensland, and Perry Morrison, a lecturer in computing at the University of New England in New South Wales, offer a provocative look into the moral issues surrounding the world's most powerful machines. ''We argue,'' they write in ''Computer Ethics,'' ''that computer systems by their very nature are insecure, unreliable and unpredictable - and that society has yet to come to terms with the consequences.'' Computer crime could cost each of the top 300 companies in the United States $2 million to $10 million a year, they write, but only 35 percent of I.B.M. mainframes used security software by late 1988. London's computerized air traffic control system failed six times in 12 months. Perhaps even more frightening is the 10-year delay in warnings about ozone depletion; software employed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration called satellite ozone measurements spurious because they were so low. Mr. Forester and Mr. Morrison have chapters on computer crime, software theft, computer hacking and viruses, computer unreliability, invasion of privacy, artificial intelligence and computers in the work place. While their prose occasionally wanders toward flat assertion, the authors' stated goal is to provoke debate in an area too often dominated by dehumanized logic.

title: Big, Beautiful and Endangered
description: What weighs about six tons, stands roughly 12 feet high and has an appendage comprising 100,000 muscles that can hold two gallons of water and can detect odors five miles away? You guessed it: the African elephant, the largest land mammal on earth. These huge creatures, which can kill a man as effortlessly as a man can kill an insect, are the subject of ELEPHANTS OF AFRICA (Safari Press, P.O. Box 3095, Long Beach, Calif. 90803, $45), a beautifully designed book of paintings and drawings by Paul Bosman, a wildlife artist, with text by Anthony Hall-Martin, a wildlife biologist. Their years of observation and research, which took them the length and breadth of Africa in search of elephants in their varied environments, resulted in this informative scientific study. Centuries ago mammoths, the ancestral form of the modern elephant, were hunted by prehistoric men, who covered the walls of their caves with wonderful paintings of these great hairy beasts. Their ivory tusks, which were 10 to 13 feet in length, were like sweeping, curved scythes. One of the oldest ivory carvings known is at least 25,000 years old. Nowadays, with ivory poachers decimating the herds, the African elephant population has dropped by 50 percent in the last decade, and with its present rate of decline the elephant will disappear from the continent within 10 years. The preservation of these magnificent animals, as well as other species that share in their varied environments, is a must. ''Elephants of Africa'' should go a long way toward helping to achieve this goal.

title: The Learning Disabled: Challenge to Identify
description: ANN ''noticed something'' about the way her 5-year-old was learning basic concepts.

title: 'Buckwheat' Impostor Dupes Staff of '20/20'
description: The executive producer of ABC's ''20/20'' acknowledged today that researchers for the television program were duped by an impostor claiming to be the actor who played a character in the ''Our Gang'' comedies.

title: House Roll-Call in Vote Upholding Veto of Stopgap Budget
description: The following is the 260-138 roll-call vote by which the House today fell six votes short of the two-thirds majority needed to override President Bush's veto of a measure that would have provided money for one week to reopen government agencies shut by the budget impasse. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to override the veto. Voting yes were 235 Democrats and 25 Republicans. Voting no were 9 Democrats and 129 Republicans. X denotes those not voting. Present denotes those who voted they were ''present'' at the time of the vote but did not vote ''yes'' or ''no'' on the issue. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House.

title: A Scandal Of Artificial Insemination
description: EVERY YEAR MORE THAN 80,000 women are inseminated artificially with sperm from men they do not know. In their attempt to have a baby, they may unknowingly be putting themselves at risk of contracting infectious diseases, such as AIDS and hepatitis, and the baby at risk of genetic defects.

title: Managing;   The Benefit of Legal Advice
description: When Larry Emmons needed a lawyer to help with the purchase of his home, he called an 800-number telephone hotline. Referred to an attorney nearby, he got more than five hours of legal advice without ever seeing a bill.

title: Diaana Peyton Is Married
description: Diana L. Peyton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray S. Peyton of Pennington, N.J., was married yesterday to Eric J. Kollevoll, a son of Mrs. Bernard R. Deschaine and Olav B. Kollevoll, both of Easton, Pa. The Rev. William A. McQuoid performed the ceremony at the Pennington Presbyterian Church. Mrs. Kollevoll, 26 years old and a graduate of Princeton University, is a department manager at the Chubb & Son insurance company in White Plains. The bridegroom, 29, graduated cum laude from Hofstra University and is a sales representative for the Minolta Corporation in White Plains.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;

For the Adopted, the Issue Of Roots Grows Stronger
description: LEAD: Advocates for the rights of adoptees seeking their biological parents have become, in recent years, a powerful force lobbying for laws that will enable them to discover who these parents are.

title: FATAL ACCIDENTS ARE DOWN AS U.S. BECOMES VIGILANT
description: Gradually and with little fanfare, anxious Americans have reduced one measure of risk in their daily lives: In the last decade, the death rate from accidents has dropped 21 percent as more cautious conduct has been institutionalized in law and custom.

LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Rude Awakening? Not for a Dreamer

description: To the Editor:

title: Freewheeling in Provence
description: Though the hilltop towns of Provence show the world a stony face, there's something up there that incites people to indolence. Give up exercise, it says. Stuff your notions of self-improvement in a trunk and lose the key. Silence the only witness with a nice apple tart.

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: For Movie Molls It's Still Dirty Work
description: Question. What's a moll? Don' worry abahd it, I looked it up in Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable, and the Brewer guy says: ''Moll, Molly. An American term for a gunman's girlfriend.''

title: A-Fuel Rods Pose Problem at Indian Point 3 Plant
description: Workers using a crane to open the nuclear-reactor vessel at the Indian Point 3 plant on Thursday accidentally lifted two bundles of highly radioactive fuel, and are not certain how to lower them again without damaging them.

title: Review/Theater;   One Night, Near That Other Paris...
description: One of the most instructive lectures that a popular English professor at the University of Texas used to give taught that literature knew no geography. ''People in Paris, Texas,'' the lesson went, ''experience the same joys and sorrows, cherish the same hopes and confront the same fears as people in Paris, France.'' Obviously the prof never dreamed of ''East Texas,'' a new play by Jan Buttram at the York Theater Company that brings a new depth of meaning to banality.

title: In Danbury, a Casual Place Is Hopping
description: DANBURY, the beneficiary of more than a few of the state's new restaurants in the past 10 years, has welcomed another newcomer. Fox & Fox, familiar to northwest Connecticut residents, has moved south from Gaylordsville into the heart of downtown Danbury.

title: Athens by Bouzouki
description: Among the things that most sun-and-sea tourists miss in Greece -the mountains, the forests, the unspoiled interior - is Athens by night in all its glitter. The city offers much more than the traditional tourist spots in the Plaka, and it's said that in order to keep up with the night life Athenians ''sleep in the afternoons and take a little nap before breakfast.'' Here is a short introduction to the Athens night scene, a possible itinerary for three packed evenings during which you probably won't spy another non-native. Come equipped with plenty of kefi, or high spirits; Athens will supply everything else you need for a splendid time.

title: Stephanie Scherer Marries Eric Young
description: Stephanie Susan Scherer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Scherer of New York, was married last evening to Eric David Young, a son of Paula Young of Oceanside, L.I., and Carl Young of White Plains. Rabbi Gerald L. Zelizer performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: WHY AMERICA FAILS ITS CHILDREN
description: I wonder if it might be possible for the American Association of Retired Persons to launch a Grandparents Guardianship adjunct to its organization, along the lines of Plan International U.S.A. (formerly known as the Foster Parents Plan).

title: WHY AMERICA FAILS ITS CHILDREN
description: Small-scale local programs for troubled families, like the ones in Tacoma, Wash., and in New Haven, certainly should be encouraged. However, the leadership and resources needed to make a substantial start on these problems must come from the Federal Government.

title: Fabric Treasures in London
description: A corner of London long treasured as a source for decorative antiques has become a trove for 18th- and 19th-century printed furnishing fabrics, all reproduced from original antique scraps by the dealers who discovered them.

title: Tech Notes;   Fitting a PC's Circuitry on One Thumbnail-Sized Chip
description: When the International Business Machines Corporation introduced its PC/AT personal computer in 1983 - incorporating Intel's powerful new 80286 computer chip - the machine was the sensation of the rapidly growing desktop computer business. The AT was expensive and powerful, but it was also bulky. The 80286 chip, which functions as the computer's brain, resided on one large circuit board about the size of a dinner plate. Since then, the 80286, now known simply as the 286, has been eclipsed by newer computer chips. But the 286 has become so widespread that it is almost a generic computer chip, as are the I.B.M. personal computer clones based on it. Reflecting this, Advanced Micro Devices, a chip manufacturer based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has now brought out a chip that has shrunk the 286 - and all the other AT control circuitry - onto a single chip the size of a thumbnail.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 19-year-old house needs a new roof and improved ventilation in the attic area. This area only has gable vents now, and we want to add to this when the new roof is put on. Are we better off with ridge-mounted roof vents or with a roof-mounted vent fan?

title: Rumblings on the Right
description: Chalk Van Niekirk, a retired tobacco farmer, wanted me to understand that he had no respect for President F. W. de Klerk.

title: Time to Leave Planet of Jocks
description: DEAR Fellow Scribes, None of us should go into the locker room. It's the Planet of the Jocks.

title: Easing an Overhead Garage Door
description: STRUGGLING with a balky overhead garage door is a nuisance; worse, it can lead to back strain or a pulled muscle.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Maybe they're accidental and maybe they're preordained, but casual happenings do influence a good part of our lives.

title: Design;   Risky Business
description: As showrooms are being readied for the international Home Furnishings Market in High Point, N.C., talk in the industry centers around the poor housing market, slow sales in retailing and the uncertain economy in general. ''Most manufacturers are running scared because business has been so bad,'' says Carl Levine, senior vice president of home furnishings at Bloomingdale's. ''Conservative styling and keeping prices down are very important now. Personally, though, I'd like to see some creativity for a change.''

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   With Prix-Fixe Menus, The Choices Are Varied
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some restaurants that offer prix-fixe menus.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Learning to Share the Woods
description: LEAD: THINGS strike home in the funniest way.

title: Under My Skin
description: So Frank is 75 this year, and what does that mean? I remember what it meant when he was 68 in June 1984. He was at Carnegie Hall singing ''Pennies From Heaven'' and ''Fly Me to The Moon'' and he was in great voice. When he did ''Come Rain or Come Shine,'' a woman in a box called out to him, ''Frankie, baby, you're the best.''

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Potatoes, Then a Bit Of Chicken
description: Those who prefer meat to potatoes may find this meal a little backward. It calls for only about five ounces of chicken per person, but with a hefty serving of sweet potatoes and apples.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;

Airport Hotels: Up and Down
description: LEAD: Just as a 10-year boom in air travel subsided, hotel construction has taken off around Philadelphia International Airport, but it may soon be grounded.

title: Soul Food Reconsidered
description: PEOPLE CONCERNED WITH THEIR health think nothing of eating a variety of ethnic foods, such as Japanese, Middle Eastern and Indian. But soul food? After all, doesn't it conjure up images of fatty pork, chicken deep-fried in lard (pork fat) and high-cholesterol desserts like sweet potato pie? Nutritionists have even gone as far as to hold soul food partially responsible for inflicting ill health on a whole race of people. But there is actually much that is healthful about soul food. A number of black chefs are now devising ways to cut down on its high salt, fat and cholesterol content - without cutting out its soul. And whites, Asian-Americans and members of other ethnic groups are discovering the pleasures of both cooking and eating traditional African-American foods.

title: December Bridal For Miss Chorney
description: December wedding plans for Jacqueline Eve Chorney and Matthew Miller, the son of Marianne Miller of Greenwich, Conn., and Tilden E. Miller of New York, have been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Chorney of Denver.

title: Ms. Wagner Wed To E. B. Morley
description: Katheryn A. Wagner, a daughter of Barbara Wagner of New Canaan, Conn., and Edward Wagner of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday to Edward B. Morley, a son of Marie Morley of Stamford, Conn., and Dr. H. Barclay Morley of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: Women in the Locker Room;   Controversy in the C.F.L.
description: The Winnipeg Blue Bombers of the Canadian Football League barred all members of the news media from their locker room after Friday night's game rather than allow a female radio reporter to enter.

title: Focus: Lake Tahoe;   Resorts' Residential Listings Growing
description: ''Whenever the Bay area gets a cold we get pneumonia,'' observed Doug Rosner, owner-broker of Century 21 South Tahoe Realty.

description: In the heavily Irish community of Woodside, Queens, they are already celebrating new immigration legislation approved in the House last week, as if it were raining green cards.

title:
ART;

Abstract Expressionism: Carrying the Torch
description: LEAD: ABSTRACT EXPRESSIONISM is synonymous with the coming of age of American painting. The movement lasted from the end of World War II until the late 1950's, when it was succeeded by various others, including Pop Art and Lyrical Abstraction.

title: How One Family's Mementos Made the Journey to Ellis Island
description: FEELINGS of deep love and pride in his family led Stanley Mirel of Mahopac to answer a call for memorabilia he saw in a magazine several years ago. The notice was from the Metaform Company of the Liberty/Ellis Island Collaborative, which was looking for immigration artifacts - dating from 1880 to 1920 - to include in the ''Treasures From Home'' exhibition the firm was designing for the new museum on Ellis Island.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: It's a great thing to get back to the fundamental simplicities of the game, but the trouble is, they are not so simple. Oh, yes, the simple themes that are taught to beginners are entirely valid for anyone - grandmasters and world champions included - but the path to applying them is fraught with complexity.

title: Bill on Victims' Rights Is Pressed by Coalition
description: LEAD: A BILL to amend the State Constitution to put the rights of victims of violent crimes on equal footing with those of defendants is being pressed by a statewide coalition of victims' rights groups in New Jersey.

title: Arts Presentation Grants for 6 Colleges

These are the recipients: Buffalo State College in Buffalo, for a modern-dance suite with choreography, music and storytelling by American Indian artists.

title: About Cars;   Let's See, 10 Percent of $190,100 Is ...
description: Bill Hoglund and I were sitting in a Manhattan restaurant, talking about this and that - that being mostly cars - when the question first occurred to me. This was some years ago and it seems obvious now, but then the question sort of bubbled up and surprised both of us.

title: Review/Music;   Classical Crossover<
description: A grim evening seemed to lie ahead when the Frankfurter Kurorchester took the stage of the Great Hall at Cooper Union on Thursday evening for its United States debut. For a concert that promised repertory ranging from Bach and Debussy to the Beatles and Tom Waits, four musicians appeared, the three men in white tie and tails. Yet another evening of classical musicians slumming in crossover land? Not exactly, as it turned out. The Kurorchester (the name translates as health-spa band) was founded in Frankfurt in 1981 by Frank Wolff, a cellist whose almost constant impish grin belied his cherubic demeanor from the outset. He was not immediately convincing when he sprang to his feet to belt out ''Sergeant Pepper'' in the Prelude, but by intermission he was wailing ''A Little Help'' with the compelling maniacal fervor of Janis Joplin or Joe Cocker.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: JACK K. HASEGAWA;

Fighting Racism, Subtle and Not So Subtle
description: LEAD: JACK K. HASEGAWA is an authority on racism, both by inclination and by birth. A fourth-generation Japanese-American whose parents were interned during World War II, he said that he has been told more than once, ''You seem like a nice guy, but I still remember Pearl Harbor.''

title: Review/Film Festival;   A Schoolgirl Seeks Her Nation's Past
description: In the opening sequence of Michael Verhoeven's satiric German comedy, ''The Nasty Girl'' (''Das Schreckliche Madchen''), it's made clear that the good citizens of Pfilzing aren't keen about examining the past.

title: Wall Street;   The Stock the Market Sneered At
description: To Wall Street, the Tandy Corporation has become the Rodney Dangerfield of the technology scene. The Radio Shack people? (The sniggers start.) Selling computers to giant Japanese companies? (Roars of laughter.) And yet, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company quietly announced last week that it will be selling, under its own brand name, a new ''notebook'' computer made by Tandy. Matsushita already sells larger Tandy personal computer models in the United States under its Panasonic nameplate.

description: Nancy Labouisse, a daughter of Erica Cutler Labouisse of New Orleans and the late F. Monroe Labouisse Jr., was married yesterday to George Peter Kostakos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter G. Kostakos of Utica, N.Y. The Rev. Hill C. Riddle officiated in the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption with a review of ''The Time of My Life'' by Denis Healey Sept. 23 misidentified the building Mr. Healey was shown leaving. It was the residence of Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, not the Prime Minister's house.

title: WHAT HILL & KNOWLTON CAN DO
description: I was perhaps not as much puzzled as I was chagrined at the decision of the U.S.C.C. to retain the services of a public relations firm to promote its position on abortion. It's not lost on me that some very large corporations find it necessary to turn to image-making institutions, but I find it distasteful that Catholic bishops are so devoid of confidence in their own ability to get the message out that they turn to a secular institution to do the job for them.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley;   Shock and Anxiety After a Killing And a Fatal Fire
description: Shock, sadness and anxiety have swept this campus community after three students at the University of California died in a fraternity house fire and one was shot to death by a gunman who held 33 people hostage in an off-campus bar.

title: Silber Voters Showed Their Disillusionment
description: To the Editor:

title: The 60's Very Soul
description: In the 1960's, Southern soul music merged gospel and blues and turned them into rock. In hindsight, the style seems as natural and hardy as granite, with its chugging beat, terse riffs and voices poised between pain and exultation. Although Southern soul has been commercially eclipsed, the oldies are still current on television soundtracks and commercials. The style also continues on a few independent labels, in gospel music and among revivalists like Michael Bolton (who shows how hard it is to re-create the style's apparent spontaneity). Two 1990 albums, Robert Cray's ''Midnight Stroll'' (Mercury/PolyGram 846 652; all three formats) and Etta James's ''Stickin' to My Guns'' (Island 842 926; all three formats), can stand alongside the best of 1960's soul.

title: East End Avenue
description: To the Editor:

Sears, a United Church of Christ minister. The bride is a daughter of Georgianna S. Middlebrook of Washington, Conn., and the late Robert W. Middlebrook. title: Postings: North Side of East 96th;   A 421a Qualifier
description: New York City developers who complain about their problems in getting construction loans these days could borrow a page from the Relatedfinancing for its new rental project by making a silk purse out of what some builders would have called a sow's ear of a location: the north side of East 96th Street.

title: CINCINNATI MUSEUM QUIET AFTER TRIAL
description: It was eerily quiet in the stylish museum above the Walgreens Department Store in downtown Cincinnati today. There were no crowds, no sheriff's deputies, little hint of the turmoil that has polarized this city in the seven months since the photographs of the late Robert Mapplethorpe were shown at the Contemporary Arts Center here.

title: Excerpts From President's News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today in front of the White House.

title: Postings: Brooklyn 'Coke' Plant;   Bubbling Up
description: When Eric S. Miller was a boy, he walked with his father, Arnold, past the Coca-Cola Bottling Company plant at 1900 Linden Boulevard, between Georgia and Sheffield Avenues, in the East New York section of Brooklyn. ''I gave my father a look like we were in Wonderland,'' he recalled, ''and said, 'Wouldn't it be nice if we were one day in that building?' '' His father laughed. Surely the family seltzer business - known for its Best Health brand - would never have need of a 160,000-square-foot plant suited to the likes of Coca-Cola.

title: Campus Life: Dayton;   Condom Giveaway Leads to a Plan To Limit Products
description: Administrators at the University of Dayton have proposed a policy that would prevent students from distributing or selling campus services and products that are not consonant with Roman Catholic doctrine or that are considered unsafe.

title: Ex-Rulers of Kuwait to Meet With Exiles
description: The Crown Prince of Kuwait said today that his Government-in-exile would confer next week with more than 450 prominent Kuwaiti exiles on alternatives for their Iraqi-occupied country.

title: IN SHORT/FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: When Hollywood Got Real
description: MEDIUM COOL: The Movies of the 1960s. By Ethan Mordden. (Knopf, $24.95.) Ethan Mordden is what we don't have much of anymore, especially in film criticism. He is an old-fashioned belletrist, with all the virtues and shortcomings. ''Medium Cool'' is a lively, knowledgeable and eminently readable guide to films of the 1960's, from ''Psycho'' to ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.'' Mr. Mordden's theses, such as they are, are unexceptionable: films in the 60's pushed at and expanded the boundaries of the permissible; defying genre, they were self-conscious, adversarial and director-driven. The author, whose previous books include ''The Hollywood Studios'' and ''The Hollywood Musical,'' understands the revolutionary significance of 60's movies and describes well the sea change they represented for Hollywood, which was still reeling from the disintegration of the studios. He has an affectionate few paragraphs on a curiosity like ''One-Eyed Jacks'' (the only film Marlon Brando directed) and he even has seen (and appreciated) the Roger Corman quickies. But after we have finished the book, we're still hungry: Mr. Mordden tells us what we already know. To say that 60's films struggled toward naturalism - his overriding thesis - is at least partly true, but not very interesting. He makes no more than a rudimentary attempt to connect the movies to the age or to the changing fortunes of the studios, even though assumptions about these relationships underlie his premises. Then there is the seemingly obligatory occasional 60's-bashing, wherein, scolding like a fussy schoolmarm, Mr. Mordden criticizes films of the decade for their alleged sympathy for the devil, and at one point even blames the excesses of the flower children for the ascent of Ronald Reagan. Nevertheless, for all its faults, this survey is an engaging, if not particularly provocative, read.

title: Bear Market: Gentle Ben Or Real Grisly?
description: Just as the world has accepted the fact of a bear market, Wall Street is facing a new puzzle: What kind of bear is it?

title: Europe for Less: It Can Be Done;   Rome
description: With the dollar at around 1,150 lire, the would-be visitor to Rome doesn't have an easy time finding relatively inexpensive accommodations. A telephone canvass of 20 modest but reasonably comfortable hotels, each with two stars in Italy's official one-to-five-star rating system, showed that the prevailing price for a double room with private bath or shower in that category is $125 to $150 a night. The top-rated five-star hotels charge $350 to $550.

title: Florie Seery Weds Marc Bryan-Brown
description: Florence Ranney Seery, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Seery of Huntington Station, L.I., was married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in New York to Marc Bryan-Brown, a son of Deirdre Bryan-Brown of Shillingford, Oxfordshire, England, and Dr. Christopher Bryan-Brown of New York.

title: Language Law Stirs Pride and Anger in Moldavia
description: Luda Gryaznopolsky has lived in Moldavia all her life and never learned to speak the local language, Romanian. She did not have to, because for the last half-century, since the Soviet Union annexed the territory in 1940, the way to get around and get ahead in this tiny republic tucked along the border of Romania was to speak Russian.

title: Lynn Loftus Wed To F. S. Elliott 3d
description: Lynn Margaret Loftus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Loftus of New York, was married yesterday to Frederic Sutton Elliott 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Jr. of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: College Football;   Lions Come Up Short
description: It took 14 quarters for the Columbia offense to wake up this season. Even when it finally did, scoring 31 second-half points yesterday, it was too late to prevent another loss: this time to Lafayette, 41-34.

title: New Rochelle Debates Its Charter
description: LEAD: DISSATISFACTION with the way local government is working has led to a debate about whether New Rochelle should switch from a city manager to a strong mayor form of government and whether other changes are needed in the City Charter.

title: Don't Blame the Rules, Learn the Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Voodoo Demographics
description: To the Editor:

title: Ashley Merriam Engaged to Lieut. James Pyatt
description: The engagement of Ashley Jean Merriam to Second Lieut. James Lloyd Pyatt of the Army has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Brower A. Merriam of Stamford, Conn. A January wedding is planned.

title: 'Seventy Years on the Road to Nowhere'
description: THE RUSSIAN REVOLUTION

title: Thinly Disguised Hostility
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Games;   Chinese Athletes Stun Their Foes
description: For a country that has lately grown accustomed to the agony of defeat, the Asian Games under way here have been a rare joy. China has rebounded from its disappointing performance in the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, to overwhelm nearly all comers and stack up an enormous number of gold medals.

title: IN SHORT/FOOTBALL
description: LEAD:

title: Horse Racing;   Meadow Star Steals The Show
description: Flying Continental and Fly So Free won the richest races at Belmont Park yesterday, but the heroine of the year's best afternoon of racing was Meadow Star.

title: 'Crooked Hearts' Probes the Pain of Family Life
description: Every major United States studio rejected the idea of making Robert Boswell's 1987 first novel, ''Crooked Hearts,'' into a movie. Too intelligent, too intellectual, too esthetic and too painful - those were the reasons given to the producer Dale Pollock when he went in search of backing for this story about a family in the midst of emotional crisis.

title:
Your Own Account;

Your Pension May Be at Risk
description: LEAD: In the last few years, Congress and the Internal Revenue Service have steadily decreased the amount of money that highly compensated employees - professionals, say, and middle and top managers - can receive from standard company pension plans. To make up the difference, most American companies have set up supplementary employee retirement plans, or SE

title: College Football: West/Southwest;   Arizona Intercepts U.C.L.A. by 28-21
description: Darryl Lewis returned an interception 70 yards for a touchdown with 50 seconds remaining today to give Arizona a 28-21 victory over U.C.L.A.

title: The man Who Kept the Secret
description: From the OSS to the CIA.

title: No Headline
description: Ms. Storin Weds Craig Summerhill

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE parking lot at Cape May Point State Park was crowded, the distance considerable, but the striding and smiling figure coming my way could only have been Victor Emanuel. There is something of the prophet in him, and something of a child, too. You never know, when you are in his company, whether he is going to reach for the stars and snare a bit of universal wisdom or reach into his pocket and produce a bullfrog.

title: 4 Gay Men Beaten in 2 Attacks
description: Four men were assaulted early yesterday morning in separate incidents in Manhattan that the police have classified as anti-homosexual bias. None of the victims was seriously injured.

title: Sipping and Snacking at Cozy Taverns
description: In the 15th century, Venetian dining - backed by the enormous wealth of the city's bankers and spice traders - had a reputation for excellence and sophistication. Nowadays, except for some famous and expensive restaurants and a few moderately priced trattorias, the food is often disappointing.

title: Cuban Communist Party Is Moving to Slash Its Bureaucracy by Half
description: Cuba's ruling Communist Party has moved to streamline its bloated bureaucracy, slashing national and provincial party posts by 50 percent and reorganizing the powerful Central Committee Secretariat.

title: College Football;   Miami Romps in Ground Attack
description: Threatened with the possibility of their worst start since 1979, the Hurricanes of the University of Miami underwent a transformation this afternoon. The school that won three national championships in the 1980's by turning the forward pass into an art form today resorted to an approach that has worked in other places since the Stone Age.

title: Shelley Lynn Sporleder Marries Michael J. Carr
description: Shelley Lynn Sporleder, a daughter of Joan D. Francis of Solana Beach, Calif., and Edward Sporleder of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Michael John Carr, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard T. Carr of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. Canon Dan Gerrard and the Rev. Charles S. Foss officiated at St. James by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in La Jolla, Calif.

title: Are Plazas Public Boons, or Nuisances?
description: In New York, a city of jostling crowds and manmade canyons, one might think the residents of the Parc Vendome condominium would have nothing but praise for the Sheffield Plaza, a bright public space just west of their building, on Ninth Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets.

title: Soviets Would Return 2 of 4 Isles to Japan
description: The Soviet Union was reported today to have offered to return to Japan two of the four small islands claimed by Tokyo in a bitter territorial dispute that has blocked improvement of relations between the two countries.

title: Police Plan Puts Safety In Numbers
description: A request from Mayor David N. Dinkins to his Police Commissioner two months ago seemed simple: Rather than just agreeing to hire 5,000 more police officers, as many crime-stung New Yorkers and politicians were demanding, why not survey the department to see what was really needed?

title: 4 Editors Appointed at Times
description: Four appointments to senior editing positions at The New York Times have been announced by Max Frankel, the paper's executive editor.

title: Unser Takes Title Despite a Crash
description: Al Unser Jr. was waiting in the treatment room at Easton (Pa.) Hospital today when he officially clinched his first CART PPG Cup Indy-car championship.

title: Holly Ann Bernson Weds James Matthew Bogin
description: Holly Ann Bernson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Bernson of Norwalk, Conn., was married at Temple Shalom there yesterday to James Matthew Bogin, a son of Merle G. Bogin of New York and Bruce M. Bogin of St. Cyprien, France. Rabbi Larry J. Halpern and Cantor Mark Lipson officiated.

title: Jane Forster Weds Howard Berman
description: Jane E. Forster, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Forster of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Howard Berman, a son of Marion Berman of Woodland Hills, Calif., and the late Seymour Berman. Rabbi Bruce Cole officiated at the couple's summer home in Quogue, L.I.

title: Approve DDI, DDC
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: The only piece of artwork the actress KATHARINE HEPBURN ever donated for charity failed to bring a high enough bid to sell at an auction in New Haven to benefit a 24-hour wildlife shelter.

title: Elizabeth A. Boey Weds Frank Chau
description: Dr. Elizabeth Ann Boey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chew Wan Boey of Stony Brook, L.I., was married yesterday to Frank Chau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kwing Tong Chau of Brooklyn. The Rev. Thomas Murtagh performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Jack Klein Wed To Ms. Goldman
description: Carol Landow Goldman, an insurance broker, and Jack Klein, a retired executive, were married yesterday by Rabbi David Widom at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I. The bride is the daughter of Frances L. Landow of Far Rockaway, Queens, and the late Harry Archie Landow. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Klein of New York.

title: Review/Music;   Mahler and Schumann By the Concertgebouw
description: The last visit to Carnegie Hall by the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam with its former music director, Bernard Haitink, five years ago, produced two performances that stick in the memory as imposing wholes, grand conceptions polished to the finest detail: Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and Mahler's Seventh Symphony. From the orchestra's Carnegie concert on Saturday evening, the second of three under its current music director, Riccardo Chailly, only individual moments are likely to prove memorable in any good sense, despite consistently fine playing by the orchestra.

title: Soybean Meal to Soviets
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 205,000 metric tons of United States soybean meal under a long-term grain agreement, the Agriculture Department said Friday. It was the second meal order last week, with 150,000 tons announced Wednesday. Officials said both orders are for delivery through Dec. 31. Soybean meal has recently sold in the Midwest for around $198 a metric ton, which suggests the latest purchase is worth more than $40 million.

title: Nutrasweet Decision
description: Canada's Competition Tribunal ruled last week that the Nutrasweet Company, a wholly owned Canadian subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, could no longer demand that its customers buy all their aspartame exclusively from Nutrasweet. Competitors, including Tosoh Canada Ltd. of Japan, had complained that Nutrasweet had a monopoly of 95 percent of the artificial sweetener used in soft drinks and diet food in Canada. The tribunal ruled that Nutrasweet could not enter into any contracts with exclusive terms or offer discounts or allowances that induced Canadian customers to buy only from the company.

title: Ivies Overpowered By Patriot League
description: When Ivy League officials, including the eight university presidents, encouraged the founding of the Colonial League in 1984, they hardly intended to create a monster.

title: Tokyo Stocks Up at Midday
description: Tokyo stocks were sharply higher at midday today on optimism over the yen's strength and the easing of short-term interest rates. Investors were buying up high-technology blue-chip stocks, as well as and interest-sensitive large capital issues in moderate trading, brokers said.

title: Accounts
description: * Fujisankei Communications International Inc., New York, to Deutsch, New York for the Ultima Exodus and Ultima Quest video games accounts. The total budget is $2.5 million.

title: University Links Its Future To a New Face in Hartford
description: Administrators at the University of Connecticut well remember the euphoria of Husky fever that swept through the campus and much of the state last spring as the men's basketball team clinched its first-ever Big East championship. It was just about the same time that the janitorial staff stopped cleaning most buildings because of state budget cutbacks.

title: Penguins' Barrage Deflates Devils, 7-4
description: The Devils fell completely apart in the late stages of the third period tonight, allowing four goals in 2 minutes 27 seconds, including three goals in 75 seconds.

title: Karen Polley Hall Marries Steven James Halls
description: Karen Polley Hall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Hall of Riverside, Conn., was married at St. Paul's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Steven James Halls , a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Halls of Minneapolis. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins officiated.

title: Florence Griffith Joyner Has Some Great Expectations
description: DESPITE that teary retirement announcement she made more than 18 months ago, Florence Griffth Joyner is pondering a return to track and field after the birth of her first child next month and some experience with the joys of motherhood.

title: INSIDE
description: Israelis Get Gas Masks

title: Bills Hand Raiders Their First Loss
description: The Buffalo Bills returned a blocked kick for a touchdown in the fourth quarter for the second consecutive week, highlighting a 24-point rally for a 38-24 victory tonight over the previously unbeaten Los Angeles Raiders.

title: Winslow Ames, Writer And Museum Head, 83
description: Winslow Ames, an art historian who wrote widely about drawings, architectural history, decorative arts and genealogy, died on Wednesday at the South County Hospital in Wakefield, R.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Saunderstown, R.I.

title: Anchorage Journal;   Alaska Gasps Over Sale Of Oil Cleanup Leftovers
description: Alaskans are bracing for the biggest shopping event in state history: a multimillion-dollar sale of 50 acres of surplus gear left over from the cleanup of the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

title: Socialists Win Austrian Elections
description: The governing Socialist Party won the Austrian parliamentary elections today. Its conservative partner, the People's Party, lost sharply but is being invited to continue in the coalition.

title: People
Jennifer Mackenzie, a Therapist, Weds
description: Jennifer Evans Mackenzie, the daughter of Elizabeth Diggs of New York and Chatham, N.Y., and Will Mackenzie of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Charles Loughridge Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Loughridge of Livingston, Mont. The Rev. Charles A. Baldwin, a Congregational minister, officiated at the bride's mother's home in Chatham.

title: Review/Music;   Ensemble Translating the Nonclassical
description: The Turtle Island String Quartet of Oakland, Calif., is among many young ensembles that have taken on the challenge of translating jazz, bluegrass and other nonclassical idioms into a vocabulary that one associates with some of the greatest works of Beethoven and Mozart.

title: International Growth
description: THE institution of two international events involving amateur golfers from the metropolitan area this fall reflects the game's growth and popularity among amateurs in the United States and overseas.

title: Carnival Cruise's Chief Adds Chairman's Title
description: Ted Arison, an immigrant from Israel who founded Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. in 1974 with one ship, is turning over the title of chairman to his son, Micky, 41 years old, the company's president and chief executive.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Klaus Tilmes, Economist, Weds Ms. Heslin, Intern
description: Sheila Nora Heslin, a daughter of Margaret C. Heslin of Mahopac, N.Y., and the late Eugene F. Heslin, was married yesterday in Mahopac to Klaus Tilmes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans-Walter Tilmes of St. Tonis, Germany. The Rev. Joseph P. Tierney officiated at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church.

title: Inez Pagnotta Is Married
description: Dr. Inez Lilla Pagnotta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gaetano Pagnotta of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in New York to Dr. Andrew Leonard Macina Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Macina of Great Neck, L.I.
