description: The United States Soccer Federation president, Alan Rothenberg, has been named chairman of the World Cup 1994 Organizing Committee, the Soccer Federation announced yesterday.

title: Final Chapter in Milken Inquiry
description: The final chapter in the four-year investigation of Michael R. Milken begins today with a hearing to address a crucial question: Were the crimes of the former financier part of a wide scheme to manipulate markets illegally for his own gain, or were they simply isolated cases of going too far to help a client?

title: An Engine Out, New York's Plane Makes Another Sudden Landing
description: Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine became the latest official to experience an emergency landing on the troubled state plane today after a cockpit warning light indicated there was a fire in the right engine.

title: Gulf Impact: Hurting U.S. Over Time
description: The dramatic political changes in the Middle East in the two months since Iraq's seizure of Kuwait are likely to advance American interests in the region in the short run, but over time could threaten them, Middle East experts say.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Teamster Chief Won't Seek Re-election in '91
description: William J. McCarthy, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, announced today that he would not run for re-election in next year's Government-supervised elections, the first in which the union's leaders will be chosen directly by the rank and file.

title: Chip Indicator Shows Decline
description: The semiconductor industry's key business indicator fell in September to its lowest level since last November, another sign that business conditions in the industry are getting softer.

title: Justices Listen to Arguments On Fetal-Protection Policy
description: One of the most important sex discrimination cases in recent years came before the Supreme Court today as the Justices heard arguments on whether employers can legally exclude all fertile women from jobs involving exposure to substances likely to harm a developing fetus.

title: Review/Dance;   Gentle Artistry of a War-Torn Land
description: The Classical Dance Company of Cambodia triumphed over turmoil to present a program on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater that was an extraordinary example of choreographic refinement.

title: Space Shuttle Back From Near-Flawless Mission
description: The space shuttle Discovery made a picture-perfect landing at sunrise here today, ending a nearly flawless four-day mission that raised the spirits of space agency officials.

title: An Idea With Legs
description: In 1940, Nelson Rockefeller invited 130 Latin American journalists to visit the United States, just to see how this country lived and worked. Mr. Rockefeller, then Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Affairs for the American Republics, could hardly have guessed that his idea would ultimately bring 100,000 visitors from Latin America and many other countries around the globe.

title: INDONESIA MILITARY WEIGHING ITS ROLES
description: The Indonesian military is undergoing an unusual period of self-examination.

title: A's Win the Pennant as Red Sox Lose Loudly
description: Dave Stewart threw a four-hit victory and Roger Clemens threw a second-inning temper tantrum yesterday as the Oakland Athletics beat the Boston Red Sox, 3-1, to win the American League pennant and advance to the World Series for the third straight year.

title: Shift Urged In Banking
description: The banking industry needs fundamental change to stay competitive with foreign financial institutions, according to a draft report from a House Banking Committee study group. ''It is clear that the relative competitive position of U.S. banks has deteriorated significantly as the U.S. banking system has remained static in a changing world,'' the report said.

title: The $290,000 Job Nobody Wants
description: WANTED: Top-notch policy maker with firm grasp of accounting theory/ business practice. Needed to make accounting rules for Corporate America. Bucolic Connecticut setting, three-and-a-half-year commitment preferred. Starting salary $290,000.

title: Air Canada Layoffs And Route Cuts Set
description: Air Canada will lay off about 2,900 of its 23,000 employees and cut routes to Europe and the Far East because of rising fuel costs and fewer passengers, the airline announced.

title: New Advisory On Bond Rating
description: A day after one Wall Street credit-rating agency threatened to lower New York City's bond rating if it did not act aggressively to close budget gaps, another agency said yesterday that the city's recent actions had been responsible for ''increasing the level of concern'' about its credit rating.

title: Layoffs by Hasbro
description: Hasbro Inc., the nation's largest toy maker, said it had laid off 90 workers. Hasbro said it had made the cuts because of the ailing economy and its need to remain competitive. The company, which employs 8,000 worldwide, said administrative costs had grown at a greater rate than sales. The layoffs affected workers in marketing, research and development, sales and administration. Hasbro's shares fell 37.5 cents today, to $12.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Pennsylvania Campaign Fizzles, but Not Quietly
description: At the outset, the race for Pennsylvania governor had promised to be an interesting, perhaps nasty, conflict between a tenacious incumbent and a fiery challenger whose views on abortion and taxes clashed not only with each other's but also with the traditions of their respective parties.

title: Soviets Seek Meeting of U.N. Military Panel
description: The Soviet Union is seeking a meeting of the military chiefs of staff of the five World War II victors with permanent Security Council seats to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, a senior Soviet diplomat says.

title: Take Plain Brown Paper, Add Some Gold Trim . . .
description: ALL Manolo Blahnik, the London-based shoe designer, wanted for his Manhattan boutique at 15 West 55th Street was a ''clean, anonymous environment.'' He got that and a little bit more.

title: Israelis and Americans Reach a Point Where Their Interests May Veer Off
description: The decision of the Bush Administration to sponsor a United Nations resolution condemning Israel for excessive use of force in Jerusalem has brought into stark relief the strains being put on the United States-Israel relationship as a result of Washington's need to maintain an Arab alliance against Iraq.

title: Study Disputes Coffee's Tie to Heart Disease Risk
description: Contradicting other recent findings, a large new study has found that drinking coffee does not make people more likely to develop heart disease.

title: Westinghouse Profit Rises
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its earnings rose nearly 9 percent in the third quarter as the company's broadcasting, electronics and energy divisions posted gains.

title: Havens for Youths in Anti-Crime Plan
description: In Seth Sackey's Harlem neighborhood, drug dealers sit on his church steps on Sunday morning. Munesu Chinhenzva never talks to police officers because she believes that drug dealers shot her 15-year-old girlfriend for doing so. The girls on Tiffany Crouell's block on 115th Street told her to try crack to lose weight.

title: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, Mayor Of Princeton and Ex-Teacher, 51
description: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, the Mayor of Princeton and a member of one of the nation's best-known political families, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 51 years old.

title: Sox Complain as Clemens Is Biggest Out
description: Roger Clemens, the Boston Red Sox pitcher who usually prefers to let his pitching do all his talking, let loose a stream of profanity today in the second inning of Game 4 of the American League Championship Series. To Clemens's shock and to the dismay of his teammates, the home-plate umpire Terry Cooney considered himself the target and threw Boston's top pitcher out of a game the team had to win in order to stave off being swept by the Oakland A's.

title: Dow Falls 37.62 Points In Wild Day
description: Stock prices fell yesterday after fluctuating wildly amid nervousness over inaction in the Persian Gulf, inaction on the deficit, depressing earnings and an almost daily diet of Middle East rumors.

title: At Issue in the Sentencing Hearing
description: In the pre-sentencing hearing of Michael R. Milken, the Government plans to present evidence about what it contends are illegal actions in three transaction. The accusations have all been denied by the defense. They involve these charges:

title: Big Board In Soviet Pact
description: The New York Stock Exchange signed an agreement today with the Soviet Union to help introduce financial markets here.

title: Review/Film;   It's Dark. It's Night. It's Deadpan.
description: On a long, dark night of the soul, of the sort that can be photographed so nicely in black and white, three wanderers roam the streets of Berlin. Chief among them is a young man named Jack (Noah Taylor) who has just arrived from Leningrad, where his love of Russian literature has led him to tackle an elderly woman and stage epileptic seizures.

title: Personal Health
description: With all the fuss that is being made these days about cholesterol, it is easy to lose sight of the fact that this fatty substance is far from the only cause of heart attacks.

title: Guerrillas in India Burn Train, Killing 47, Press Reports Say
description: Left-wing guerrillas bolted the doors of a coach of a speeding train and set it on fire, killing 47 passengers, news reports said today.

title: Growing Concern Over Pelvic Infection in Women
description: Pelvic inflammatory disease, an infection of a woman's fallopian tubes or uterus, strikes many more women than previously believed, and now must be counted as the most important sexually transmitted disease affecting women, excepting only AIDS, public health officials say.

title: Psychiatrist Testifies in Surrogate Birth Case
description: A psychiatrist testified Tuesday that the relationship between a child and the woman who gave birth to him should be paramount in determining whether a surrogate mother or a childless couple should be awarded custody of the child.

title: Books of The Times;   Enduring a Dickensian Childhood
description: A Hole in the World

title: U.S. Financial Industry Could Use a Road Map
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Suspect in Slaying Sentenced in Robbery
description: A black man once suspected of killing a pregnant white woman and wounding her husband after the couple left a Boston hospital last fall has been sentenced to 12 to 25 years in prison for robbery.

title: By the Way, Stewart Leads A's Into Series
description: In the heat of the afternoon, while Roger Clemens threw a temper tantrum and the Boston Red Sox became unraveled, Dave Stewart kept his cool.

title: Tax-Exempt Yields Fall
description: Yields of tax-exempt money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday, while yields on taxable money market funds were unchanged.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Teledyne Net Plunges 79%
description: Teledyne Inc. said today that its third-quarter earnings plunged 79 percent as slowdowns in the military, aviation and electronics industries affected its sales.

title: It's a Boy! It's a Girl! It's Time To Shop
description: CONSIDER the newborn infant. So small. So wrinkled. Above all, so helpless.

title: U.S. Move in U.N. to Condemn Israel Angers Jewish Groups
description: Leaders of American Jewish groups expressed anger yesterday at the decision of the Bush Administration to sponsor a United Nations resolution that would censure Israel for the shooting deaths of at least 21 Palestinians on Monday in disturbances in Jerusalem.

title: Vietnam Says 38 Expatriates Tried to Topple Government
description: Vietnam charged 38 men with treason or other acts of subversion in Supreme Court today. Prosecutors said that they got help from Thai intelligence and Vietnamese in the United States to try to overthrow the Government.

title: Q&A
description: Accumulation on the Roof

title: 21 South Africans Are Released Under Political-Prisoner Amnesty
description: The Government released 21 political prisoners today, and the African National Congress, while welcoming the move, responded by insisting that all political prisoners still behind bars be released immediately.

title: 300 Due in U.S. From Iraq on Evacuation Flight
description: An Iraqi airliner chartered by the United States made a stopover here early today carrying what American diplomats said could be the last group of American citizens from Kuwait to be evacuated aboard a special flight.

title: Sony to Help Make Times Square Brighter
description: The Camel may puff and the neon signs may glow, but they will seem like faded soldiers in the world of display advertising come November when the Sony Corporation erects a two-story video screen at One Times Square as part of the continuing redevelopment effort.

title: Syrian Chief Risks Anger at Home Over Policies
description: As he positions himself in a hazardous and uncharted era, President Hafez al-Assad is courting the disapproval of many Syrians by moving away from the harsh anti-Americanism that once underpinned his claim to pre-eminence in the Arab world, diplomats and other specialists say.

title: Pension Shift For Teachers Is Questioned
description: Most of the funds used to pay for a new 5.5 percent contract for New York City teachers will come from a pension change based on earnings projections that are unusually optimistic for a public employee pension plan, experts said yesterday.

title: University Officials From 22 Lands Give Environment Pledge
description: Underlining ''the urgent need to move toward an environmentally sustainable future,'' a group of university presidents from around the world have pledged to greatly increase the amount their schools teach about environmental issues, and urged other universities to do the same.

title: Redskin Backup Could Mean Woes for Giants
description: The Giants are preparing for a game Sunday against a Washington Redskins backup quarterback who has started only once in the National Football League. History says the Giants should be concerned.

title: Japan's Urban Underside Erupts, Tarnishing Image of Social Peace
description: On the surface, most Japanese view their country as a classless society prizing harmony and consensus among its many contending forces. Every once in a while, however, an incident occurs that exposes stresses, conflicts and anti-social behavior underneath the placid exterior.

title: Royals' Executive Joins Braves' Front Office
description: John Schuerholz, who has headed baseball operations for the Kansas City Royals for the last decade, was named the executive vice president and general manager of the Atlanta Braves yesterday.

title: Robert F. Murphy, 66, Professor Of Anthropology and an Author
description: Robert Francis Murphy, a professor of anthropology at Columbia University, died on Monday at his home in Leonia, N.J. He was 66 years old.

title: 2 Men Are Arrested in the Shooting of 10 in a Bronx 'Turf' Brawl
description: Two young men were arrested yesterday in the shooting of 10 people, most of them teen-agers, outside a Bronx housing project on Tuesday night, when a ''territorial dispute'' between two groups of youths turned into a brawl, the police said.

title: Housing Program Aids Poor and Near Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dawson Trip Veto
description: Andre Dawson, the Chicago Cubs' outfielder with fragile knees, has been denied permission to join an all-star team that is scheduled to leave in three weeks on a 10-day tour of Japan.

title: Hard Work Found Not to Harm Pregnancy
description: Long hours and hard, stressful work do not adversely affect the outcome of a pregnancy, a study has found.

title: Principal Puts a Halt To Slap-Bracelet Fad
description: Children in this suburb of New York will just have to suffer being unfashionable, at least during school hours, because the slap-bracelet has been banned at two elementary schools.

title: Love of Chess Lacking on TV Networks
description: In an age when synchronized swimming and marathon walking can find ample space on the buffet table of daily television, chess fans are wondering why there has been barely a sound bite for the 1990 World Championship, which opened this week in New York.

title: Survey Gives Magazines Edge vs. TV
description: Magazine publishers winding up the three-day American Magazine Conference here got some good news today. Preliminary results of a reader survey show that in 8 of 10 households, at least one person buys and reads magazines.

title: Reclaiming the Small Adjustable Mirror
description: LEAD: The small adjustable mirror, whose wooden frame pivots between two uprights, was English by adoption rather than origin. With a base containing small drawers, it was designed to stand on a dressing table and be used for shaving or dressing, and was usually known as a toilet glass or mirror.

title: Commodities Trader Starts His Own Firm
description: Gene D. Donney, former president and chief executive of Elders Futures Inc., a commodity futures trading company, has set up his own commodities research and portfolio management firm and claims a unique status for it.

title: New Babylon Is Stalled By a Modern Upheaval
description: More than 2,500 years ago, a fabulous city rose here on a bend in the Euphrates River. Under King Nebuchadnezzar, Babylon and its hanging gardens became as fabled, and as much a seat of imperial power, as Rome became later.

title: Caterwauling
description: In New York City lives a person who has never been wakened by a sanitation truck in full grind, a car alarm in full throat or an Uzi at full blast. Instead she sleeps the sleep known only to those who live in the back of their buildings. Not only that but her building backs onto gardens, which means that the loudest noise she ever hears is that of bluejays quarreling over a tree. Until now.

title: Reviews/Music;   Czech Philharmonic With Its New Leader
description: The conductor Jiri Belohlavek's association with the Czech Philharmonic goes back to the early 1970's, when he spent two years with it as an assistant conductor. He has returned to the orchestra frequently since then, and he led it in a memorable performance of Smetana's ''Ma Vlast'' when the orchestra last visited New York City, in 1987.

title: Face Up to the Fairness Issue
description: The American people voted in 1988 for a reduction in the rate of growth of government and taxes. They did not vote to mortgage their future to the whims of undisciplined politicians. They did not vote for ostrich politics and depression-inducing economics.

title: Chronicle
description: MATTHEW KENNEDY, the ninth of 11 children of ETHEL KENNEDY and the late Robert F. Kennedy, will marry VICTORIA ANNE STRAUSS a fellow law student at the University of Virginia. The wedding is scheduled for July in Philadelphia.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cheque Products, a division of American Express Co., New York, appointed Carl B. Lehmann senior vice president.

title: Chronicle
description: JIMMY CONNORS will not be playing tennis for a while after undergoing surgery on his left wrist on Tuesday. The operation, at the Santa Barbara (Calif.) Cottage Hospital, was to reconstruct a tendon, said Dr. RICHARD SCHEINBERG, his orthopedic surgeon. The left-handed tennis star, who was treated as an outpatient, will wear a cast for about six weeks.

title: Review/Music;   Jane Jarvis At Zinno
description: When the pianist Jane Jarvis played her first engagement at Zinno, the restaurant at 126 West 13th Street, seven years ago, her bassist was Milt Hinton, one of the jazz greats. Since then Mr. Hinton has been with her for at least part of the time during her appearances at Zinno and he is once again her partner this week through tomorrow night. She will continue through Oct. 20 with Lynn Seaton on bass. Seven years ago Miss Jarvis had only recently given up simultaneous careers lasting almost two decades as an executive of Muzak, producing programs of piped-in music for supermarkets, restaurants and elevators, and as organist for the Mets games at Shea Stadium. As she moved into jazz full time, Mr. Hinton was a strong support while she sorted out the influences on her playing - Earl Hines, Art Tatum, Erroll Garner - and found her own individuality within those earlier jazz styles.

title: Israel's Second Blunder
description: In Israel, Sunday's bloody blunder has now been magnified by a brazen one. The first brought death to at least 21 Palestinians when Israeli police fired live ammunition into rioting crowds - a startling use of deadly force. The second, the Israeli Government's cold reaction to the tragedy, does violence to its credibility.

title: Costly New Drug Vital to Parkinson Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The state of Iowa, with a relatively small bridge population, has rarely made an impact on the national scene. But it did in Boston in July, when the Iowa team of Judy Hughes, Karen Miller, Robert Seaholm, John Morano, Guy Chakraborty and Kris Maillacheruvu won the Non-Life Master Team Championship, an event that had begun at grass-roots level 10 months earlier.

title: Sales of Trump's Book Are Lagging
description: Donald J. Trump's new book, ''Surviving at the Top,'' has not survived at the top very long, and some booksellers believe its publisher, Random House, printed far too many copies of the book.

title: The Stuff Of Dreams, Printed On Sheets
description: WICKER, maps, native American blankets, Russian rugs, psychedelic colors of the 60's and the striated green of malachite have found their way onto bed sheets, judging from visits to bed, bath and linen showrooms on the Avenue of the Americas during the trade's market week, which ends tomorrow. Gingham is back for those with simpler, homier tastes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Treasury Issues Decline Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved sharply lower and interest rates rose again yesterday, pushed by continuing concerns about the Middle East and the Federal budget as well as a disappointing auction of seven-year Treasury notes.

title: Rap Group's Lawyer Challenges Selection of Jury
description: The lawyer for the rap group 2 Live Crew has challenged Florida's method of jury selection at the group's trial on obscenity charges, contending that the method would produce predominantly white middle-aged jurors who would not be representative of the community.

title: BMW, the Motorcycle, Gears Up for a Big Run
description: TURNING attention to its neglected stepchild, BMW is trying to pep up its motorcycle division by hiring a new advertising agency, raising ad expenditures tenfold and adding cheaper entry-level vehicles to its high-performance line. With new management from Germany in place, the company's American division is introducing a new ad campaign later this month by Burkhardt & Christy Advertising Inc. of New York.

title: House Fails to Overturn Bush Veto of Import Bill
description: The House failed today to overturn President Bush's veto of a bill cutting imports of textiles, apparel and shoes.

title: Oklahoma City Journal;   Police Officers Step In On Truant Officer Beat
description: It was midmorning and Sgt. Douglas Hawkins of the Oklahoma City police had just heard over his radio that the day's first cases were about to arrive.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A FEW intelligent lighting choices around the house or apartment can conserve energy (and money) with no risk of inconvenience or eyestrain. In most cases, it is just a matter of choosing the right bulbs.

title: Review/Dance;   A Demanding Graham Role
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company's final two days in a week of packed houses at the City Center brought major cast changes in ''Herodiade'' and a single performance of Miss Graham's ''Temptations of the Moon.'' After Takako Asakawa's earlier performance as the heroine who confronts destiny in ''Herodiade,'' Christine Dakin and Terese Capucilli took their turns in one of the most demanding roles in the general dance repertory.

title: Upstate Banks in Talks
description: The National Savings Bank of Albany said today that it was holding talks with the Trustco Bank Corporation of Schenectady, N.Y., about a possible business combination. A National Savings Bank spokesman said the talks were preliminary and any proposal would have to be acted upon by the board, which will meet on Tuesday. The stock of National Savings Bank jumped $2.75 today, to $22, while Trustco's shares dropped $1, to $27. Both are traded over-the-counter.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are sick and tired of Washington. It's the same spectacle of inaction.''

title: Speedy Turcotte Sparks Rangers
description: Pure speed, a relentless offensive greed and a gloriously gifted touch. They are Darren Turcotte's talents. And for another night, they were the difference in a game.

title: Davis Cup Dispute Heating Up
description: Geoff Pollard, the president of Tennis Australia, said yesterday that the International Tennis Federation had lost control of the Davis Cup final between the United States and Australia, to be held in St. Petersburg, Fla., Nov. 30-Dec. 2. He said the United States Tennis Association had failed to adhere to an extended deadline for announcing the court surface for the final.

title: Account From Spain On Jackson
description: Does Mark Jackson want the Knicks to trade him? Does he feel powerless to unseat Maurice Cheeks as the Knicks' starting point guard? Or was something lost in translation when Jackson spoke to a contingent of Spanish reporters?

title: For Cuomo Bashing, Just Call 1-900-Rinfret
description: Trying to counter Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's $2 million advertising blitz and his own fund-raising difficulties, Pierre A. Rinfret yesterday began a modest $52,000 advertising campaign, but with a twist.

title: Europe Stalls On Farm Policy
description: The European Community today failed for the second time this week to endorse a plan designed to break a deadlock with the United States over farm-subsidy policy.

title: A More Pessimistic View of Bank Deposit Insurance Fund
description: New projections by the Bush Administration show the fund insuring bank deposits shrinking to less than half its current size within three years, a senior House Banking Committee member said today.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the Supreme Court referred to Justice David H. Souter incorrectly in some copies. He is the nation's 105th Supreme Court Justice, not the 205th.

title: Underwriting Angola's Agony
description: Angola's civil war lingers on, a stubborn relic of the cold war - despite efforts by Moscow and Washington to end it. Fifteen bloody years have claimed 200,000 lives. The warring camps say they're willing to submit to elections, but cannot agree on when and how. The least Congress can do is give President Bush the authority to suspend covert aid to Angola's rebels the moment Angola's Government fixes an election timetable.

title: In Guatemala, a Taste for Strongmen Lingers
description: When the tanks rumbled into the streets last year, the prominent right-wing lawyer Carlos Acevedo was photographed with soldiers taking part in the coup attempt. When it failed, he represented the plot's leaders in court.

title: Schick Shows Its New Razor
description: The Warner-Lambert Company, whose Schick brand is a distant No. 2 to Gillette, introduced a new razor yesterday that it hopes will challenge Sensor, Gillette's successful new razor.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: CBS Earnings Fall 30%; Sports Costs Cited
description: CBS Inc. announced yesterday that its net income had fallen 30 percent in the third quarter.

title: The Umpire Upstaged The Game
description: It's one of baseball's oldest sayings: If you don't notice the umpire, he's doing a good job.

title: THE PLAYOFFS: How It Happened;   In Strategy Battle, Leyland by a Decision
description: If all a manager had to do was write out a lineup each night, the job wouldn't be much fun. It's the decisions he has to make during a game that makes a manager's job more intriguing than an accountant's or a salesman's.

title: Senate Kills Moynihan's Proposal To Reduce Social Security Taxes
description: The Senate today killed a proposal for a Social Security tax cut that Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan had made something of a personal cause for nearly a year.

title: Life Insurers Jolted By Sharp Downturn In Real Estate Value
description: With real estate values going downhill and banks nationwide struggling to avoid being buried in the slide, anxieties are focusing on another group of lenders: life insurance companies.

title: Drabek, Bonilla Combine To Keep Pirates Alive
description: Doug Drabek, the man who pitches the Pittsburgh Pirates out of losing streaks, pitched them out of a big one tonight and even pulled them back from the brink of losing the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: INSIDE
description: German Counterspy a Spy

title: Mother Gets 2 Months To Treat Daughter, 7
description: A Chinese woman who has fought state attempts to use surgery to treat her 7-year-old daughter has won the right to try traditional Chinese medicine but may be forced to agree to surgery later.

title: If Today Is Thursday It's Designer's Saturday
description: Designer's Saturday, the annual event that is the equivalent of a debutante ball for interior designers, architects and home furnishings showrooms, starts today.

title: Marvel Entertainment Names a New President
description: The Marvel Entertainment Group, publisher of Spider-Man, the Incredible Hulk and other comic books, has named Terry C. Stewart president and chief executive.

title: Houston Industries
description: Houston Industries, an electric utility holding company, adopted an employee stock ownership plan that will buy about 10 million of the company's 128 million shares outstanding. The company said it had adopted the plan to finance its obligations to make matching contributions under an employee savings plan. Houston's shares were up 12.5 cents today, to $33.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SPY FOR BONN SAYS HE'S DOUBLE AGENT
description: A senior West German counterintelligence officer who used to run East German double agents has confessed to being a double agent himself, the Federal Prosecutor's Office announced today.

title: Miami Votes to Accept Big East's Bid
description: The future of the Big East Conference was solidified this afternoon when the University of Miami's board of trustees voted unanimously to have the school become the conference's 10th member and agreed to immediately pursue a football relationship with the three other members that compete at the major college level.

title: House Votes Bill For Puerto Rico To Decide Status
description: The House of Representatives today passed a bill calling for a referendum next year under which the people of Puerto Rico, governed for nearly a century by the United States, could choose statehood, independence or a continuation of their commonwealth status.

title: U.N. APPEARS CLOSE TO A RESOLUTION REBUKING ISRAELIS
description: After a significant policy shift by the Bush Administration, the United Nations Security Council appeared to be moving toward agreement tonight on a resolution condemning Israel for the deaths of at least 21 Arabs in Jerusalem on Monday and giving the Council a new role in the future of the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Chronicle
description: For her 90th birthday yesterday, HELEN HAYES traveled to Washington, where she was born and where her theatrical career began in 1906 at the Columbia Theater. She was her own guest of honor at a dinner to benefit the Helen Hayes Awards, which she gives annually to people in the theater in Washington. She was even given an award, named for her.

title: Silversmiths Exhibit Wares in Boston
description: With the mass production of sterling silver objects in the late 19th century, silversmithing gradually shifted from being one of America's more important crafts to a peripheral one. Now, in an exhibition in Boston called ''Reflections of the Past and Present: Contemporary American Silver,'' silversmiths from around the country are reasserting themselves as artisans.

title: Socialists Ponder a Changed World
description: Buoyed by the collapse of one of its oldest foes, the Communist movement, but uncertain about its own role in the post-cold-war world, the Socialist International gathered in New York this week to set a course for the future.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the criminal case against Michael R. Milken, the former financier, misstated the likelihood that the judge in the case will interview one of the key prosecution witnesses. Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood can ask for testimony from Ivan F. Boesky, the former arbitrager, even if Government prosecutors do not call him for their presentation.

title: Bush Trips, Capital Reels
description: The headlines around the country today used words like ''flip-flop,'' ''waffle,'' ''blink,'' ''retreat,'' ''zigzag'' and ''fickle'' to describe George Bush's erratic course on taxes - none of them exactly calculated to please the President, who is as eager as his predecessors to be seen as a strong leader.

title: Expansion Too Pricey for Some
description: When Milwaukee withdrew its application for a National Hockey League expansion franchise this week, nine groups in eight cities were left vying for the six remaining openings.

title: KEY RATES
At the Circus
description: Not since the tall ships has there been national esprit as great as that inspired by the budget negotiations. In bank lines, drugstores, supermarkets and parking lots Americans have gathered in a spirit of grand unanimity to discuss the possibility that the people who run the Government are completely out to lunch.

title: China's Prime Minister Losing His Hold?
description: To the Editor:

title: Noisy Escape Attempt Foiled
description: An attempted jailbreak was foiled when the two inmates trying to escape made so much racket that other prisoners complained to guards, who caught the men in a crawl space, officials said. The two were using a piece of metal to chip through an eight-inch-thick concrete wall at the Okanogan County Jail on Monday night when they woke up other prisoners, an official said Tuesday. The inmates, Billy Dale Anderson and David Cabarett, face charges of attempted escape.

title: Lobbyists Flock to Capitol to Save Their Projects
description: Lawmakers sometimes describe them as vultures, but the hundreds of lobbyists who jammed the long marble corridor on the first floor of the Capitol today and perched beneath the bronze statutes of statesmen from bygone eras were more like a flock of hungry pigeons.

title: Yale Students to Protest Racist Acts on Campus
description: A group of Yale University graduate students is organizing two daylong moratoriums on classes to protest recent racist acts on campus, including an anonymously circulated hate letter and derogatory graffiti.

title: BHUTTO UNDER FIRE AS ELECTION NEARS
description: Two weeks before scheduled national elections, the Government arrested the husband of Benazir Bhutto today, thus striking another blow against her campaign to regain the post of Prime Minister from which she was removed in early August.

title:
Talking Deals;

Risks in Ventures With the Japanese
description: LEAD: AFTER trying for years to break into the supplier network for Japanese auto plants in the United States, Elco Industries finally succeeded by using the same method as a growing number of American auto-parts companies. It found a Japanese partner.

title: Months of Surveillance Lead Agents to $13 Million Tied to Drugs
description: For months, agents of the New York Drug Enforcement Task Force periodically checked out a big gray-shingled ranch house on Long Island. The blinds were usually down and no one seemed to be home.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE 6-year-old boy loved watching professional football. He noticed that when players like something a teammate has done, they sometimes quickly pat him on the rump. So when his first-grade teacher did something that the boy really appreciated, he acknowledged it by casually walking over and patting her. She immediately referred him to a child psychiatrist.

title: Metro Matters;   Why Dinkins Seems to Draw So Many Critics
description: One year ago, David N. Dinkins was just weeks away from a historic victory as New York City's first black mayor. That his margin would be the narrowest in any of the city's mayoral elections since 1905 made his election no less conclusive, though there were concerns that the questions about his personal finances that nearly cost him the race had also drained the reservoir of credibility and good will that help any official govern.

title: Portman Mortgage Holders To Control Atlanta Project
description: John C. Portman Jr., the Atlanta architect and developer, said today that he would surrender to mortgage holders a controlling interest in the Peachtree Center office complex here, the keystone of his worldwide real estate holdings.

title: Chronicle
description: Amid the predictable visits she makes to promote British industry, the Princess Royal, a k a PRINCESS ANNE, will have lunch today at the new headquarters of the Seamen's Church Institute in Manhattan.

title: Senate Panel Approves a Major Cut in AIDS Relief for Cities
description: In a tangle that pitted one needy group against another, the Senate Appropriations Committee today approved less than 20 percent of the money authorized for disaster relief to the cities hardest hit by the AIDS epidemic.

title: Partial Acquittals In Sundstrand Case
description: A Federal judge acquitted three former executives of the Sundstrand Corporation on charges of lying to the Government in connection with the military contractor's admitted Pentagon fraud scheme. The judge is expected to rule on the remaining charges of conspiracy and scheming to conceal the conspiracy next week.

title: Kasparov Wins on 44th Move In 2d Game of Championship
description: Gary Kasparov brilliantly showed why he is so feared last night as he won the second game of the 1990 World Championship Chess Match against Anatoly Karpov at the Hudson Theater in the Hotel Macklowe in Manhattan. After excellent preparation, he launched a sacrifice that set off a smashing attack. He now leads in the series 1 1/2- 1/2. Playing into Kasparov's Ruy Lopez, Karpov predictably chose the Flohr-Zaitsev Variation, 9 . . . Bb7, which is prized for allowing Black a nice balance of flexibility and solidity. It had been his standby in his final match with Jan Timman in March in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, the one that made him the official challenger.

title: Ornamental Gourds Have Uses, Too
description: THE American Gourd Society held its 28th annual World's Largest Gourd Show in Mount Gilead, Ohio, last week. More than a thousand gourd growers, craft artists and collectors showed up to celebrate the wonders and uses of these ancient inedible plants, which are colorful, hard-shelled and often highly ornamental.

title: Clarke's 'Species' to Close
description: ''Endangered Species,'' a theater piece created and directed by Martha Clarke, is to close at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Majestic Theater, after the evening performance on Sunday. It had been scheduled to run until Nov. 4. To exchange unusable tickets, call (718) 636-4100. Refunds can be obtained only by mailing the tickets back to the academy at 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217.

title: Fryar Is Arrested
description: A scuffle outside a nightclub in Providence, R.I. early this morning ended with the New England Patriots' Hart Lee Dykes hospitalized with an eye injury and Irving Fryar, his teammate, booked on a weapons charge.

title: Gas-Electric Hybrid Cars Can Be Built Now;   For Health's Sake Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Class for Young Sitters
description: For years, young baby sitters received on-the-job training. But now some teen-agers are taking a course that teaches them everything from how to handle a medical emergency to more routine child-care skills like feeding, disciplining and toilet training.

title: Seagull Energy in Deal With Pickens Group
description: Mesa L.P., the partnership headed by the corporate raider T. Boone Pickens, agreed today to sell a portion of its oil and gas properties and undeveloped land to the Seagull Energy Corporation in a deal that could reach $476 million.

title: Appeal Refused For Keating
description: The California Supreme Court declined today to hear an appeal by Charles H. Keating Jr., who seeks reduction of his $5 million bail.

title: Dynamics Corp. And Gabelli in Deal
description: The Dynamics Corporation of America agreed to allow Mario J. Gabelli's Gamco Investors Inc. and Gabelli Funds Inc. to acquire up to 25 percent of Dynamics, or 970,350 of its shares. The Gabelli entities now own on behalf of their clients about 19.6 percent of the shares. Under the agreement, the shares will be bought for investment purposes.

title: Gas-Electric Hybrid Cars Can Be Built Now;   The Mini-van Loophole
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Picks Panel to Investigate Killing of 21 Arabs
description: The Government appointed a high-level commission today to investigate the violence in Jerusalem's Old City on Monday in which soldiers shot and killed at least 21 Palestinians.

title: Surviving a Short Stay: White Decor Helps
description: SOME people have trouble moving from one place to another. Others can pick up, reorganize and move all their belongings to a new location with very little effort.

title: Review/Theater;   'About Time,' A Couple With a Past
description: Onstage in ''About Time,'' James Whitmore and Audra Lindley are an endearing couple, as they act their way through and around the slight play that Tom Cole has created for them. Portraying two people generically identified as Old Man and Old Woman, they chat, argue and begin to ameliorate their differences.

title: Italian Communists Remodeling at Last
description: After nearly a year of intense soul-searching, the Italian Communist Party today joined the political changes that have swept across Europe and gave itself a new name, a new symbol and, it hopes, a new chance to improve its sagging electoral fortunes.

title: Youth Gets Prison Sentence For Rape on Brooklyn Roof
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was sentenced yesterday for his part in the rape of a woman who was also robbed and thrown from the roof of a four-story building last year.

title: 3 Are Indicted In Embezzling Of Elderly Aid
description: The fiscal officer of a private agency serving poor elderly East Harlem residents was indicted yesterday on charges of embezzling almost $1 million in public funds to buy vintage automobiles and gamble in Atlantic City.

title: U.N. Journal;   In a Polyglot Place, the Most Welcome of Voices
description: The United Nations building would be little more than a glass Tower of Babel without them.

title: The Next Best Thing To 'Rockaby Baby'?
description: EVEN insomniacs who normally wouldn't find anything to smile about when it comes to sleep might respond to Count Sheep, a series of books and a 30-minute tape that are meant to alleviate sleepless nights.

title: Tokyo Stocks Decline Sharply
description: Japanese stocks dropped sharply today.

title: Of Stones And Walls
description: On the eve of the Hebrew holy time called Succoth, as thousands of Jews prayed at the sacred site known as the Western Wall, a double desecration took place.

title: People
description: * Marjorie Levin has joined Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, as vice president and director of sales promotion.

title: Matich Selected by Jets To Replace Cadigan
description: Working on the theory that it would be better to go with what they have than try to acquire an offensive lineman from somewhere else, the Jets today named Trevor Matich to step into the starting right guard position opened by the season-ending knee injury to Dave Cadigan.

title: Market Place;   Pain of Leverage In Unlikely Spot
description: GIBSON GREETINGS INC., the nation's No. 3 maker of greeting cards and top producer of Christmas gift-wrapping paper, now knows the pain, as well as the joys, of leverage.

title: La Quinta Is Urged To End Rights Plan
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., which controls 15 percent of the stock of La Quinta Motor Inns Inc., said the San Antonio-based hotel chain should rescind its shareholder rights plan. The plan - commonly known as a ''poison pill'' - was adopted last month.

title: Livery-Cab Driver Shot Dead; 31st New York Victim in '90
description: A livery-cab driver was shot dead early yesterday in Brooklyn, the 31st livery- or gypsy-cab driver killed in New York City this year, the police said.

title: Congressional Negotiators Agree On New Curbs on Car Emissions
description: Staff members of the House-Senate conference committee rewriting the Clean Air Act reached agreement today on an array of new standards for reducing air pollution from motor vehicles that will begin to take effect in the mid-1990's.

title: Britons Said to Train Khmer Rouge Forces
description: A television documentary has reported that British soldiers have been training the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas of Cambodia.

title: Irene Mayer Selznick Dies at 83; Producer of Broadway 'Streetcar'
description: Irene Mayer Selznick, who produced Broadway plays that included the 1947 hit ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' died yesterday at the Pierre Hotel, where she lived. She was 83 years old.

title: For Bush, the Campaign Must Go On
description: Jesse Helms has not been very supportive of his President this year. The conservative Republican Senator has crossed swords with President Bush on an education bill, a textile bill, the Clean Air Act, a hate-crimes bill and several foreign service appointments.

title: Despite Feud, Gwynn Says He'll Play With Clark
description: Despite having one of ''the most difficult years of my life,'' which included harsh criticism from his San Diego Padres teammate Jack Clark, Tony Gwynn says he is prepared to play with Clark next year.

title: Calendar: Folk Art, New Art And Quilts
description: Japanese Art, Paine Webber Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas (52d Street); (212) 713-2885.

title: Max Bloom, 81, Judge; Led the Liberal Party
description: Max Bloom, a retired associate justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court and a founder of the state's Liberal Party, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Given Choice, Suffolk May Take Tax Rise
description: Last month, faced with a possible $103 million gap in his 1991 budget, Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin took an unusual step in these difficult economic times: He did not propose raising taxes.

title: Evergreens To Counter Winter Blahs
description: THE trees are letting go of their leaves, and soon the radiance of fall will fade. But it is still possible to plant the evergreens that provide the silhouettes and tones to counter winter's gloomy grays.

title: Oil Down $1.71 After Big Swings
description: Oil prices fell yesterday after bouncing up and down on war worries and then on rumors that Saddam Hussein had been assassinated.

title: Rwandans Report Killings of Suspected Rebel Sympathizers
description: Rwandan peasants accused of supporting a rebel invasion force have been massacred by Government troops and members of the majority Hutu tribe, villagers fleeing to Uganda said today.

title: Here's to Queen Catherine, Who Gave Queens a Name
description: For admirers of royalty, Queens has never offered much. Donald Manes, the King of Queens? Prince Donald of Trump?

title: U.S.-Canada Stock Plan
description: In a first step toward developing a cross-border securities market, the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved for comment a revised plan to make it easier for Canadian companies to sell stock to United States investors and vice versa.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: I HAVE come from where clothing, linens and leather goods gather for the last roundup. Corralled in stores on the main street of an old New England town, they are stared at, pawed over, sometimes even purchased by an army of men and women in sensible shoes. Nikes and Adidas and Reeboks, these shoes are, worn not for running and jogging but to encompass the corn, the bunion and the flattened arch. Some in this army are very old. No matter. When stores bear signs like Factory Outlet, Discounts! and Designer Outlet, the blood runs young again; when the sign reads L. L. Bean, it even races. L. L. Bean is to this corner of Maine what Lourdes is to southeastern France.

title: A Tax Cut That Deserves to Die
description: President Bush's obsessive campaign to cut the capital gains tax may finally have been buried by his fellow Republicans.

title: Coleman's Agent Expresses Optimism
description: Derrick Coleman's agent is flying into New Jersey to meet with Nets' executives today and he is optimistic that the two sides will finally be able to agree on a contract for the team's No. 1 draft pick.

title: First Fidelity Payment Approved
description: A Federal judge in Newark has approved a plan for distributing $30 million to shareholders of the First Fidelity Bancorporation, a New Jersey banking company, and 25 law firms that represented the shareholders in a class-action lawsuit. The banking company agreed earlier this year to pay $30 million to settle claims that in 1988 it improperly concealed problems with bad loans.

title: Plan Offered to Fix Indian Point Fuel Rods
description: The New York Power Authority said yesterday that it had developed a plan to safely cut loose two highly radioactive fuel bundles that are dangling over the core of the Indian Point 3 nuclear plant in Buchanan, N.Y., after they were inadvertently hoisted out of place.

title: TV Directors, an Unsung Group, Sing the Praises of Continuity
description: For Joel Zwick, the change was something like trading in a Maserati for a 10-year-old station wagon. Sure, it starts up every morning and is loaded with personality, but sometimes it leaves an oil spot on the driveway.

title: 3 Bears Find a Place For Play in Central Park
description: SOON after his wife, Pat, died in January 1988, Samuel N. Friedman, an executive in a furniture company, met John Manship, the son of Paul Manship, the sculptor who is probably best known for his heroic sculpture of Prometheus that is a focus of Rockefeller Center. ''John showed me one of his father's bronzes - a trio of big bears - and I thought it was terrific,'' said Mr. Friedman of the sculpture that was created in 1958.

title: Remotes: On Fast Forward
description: THERE is something peculiar about the latest generation of audio and video equipment: the more it is used, the less it is touched. The buttons and knobs are still there, but they are vestigial. Nearly everything is operated using remote controls.

title: In San Juan, Question Is No Longer If but When
description: Heartened by the House's approval of a referendum that would enable this island of 3.6 million people to redefine its relationship with the United States, political leaders here said today that the long-awaited vote was inevitable and the only question now was when.

title: Suit Is Settled By MGM/UA
description: MGM/UA has settled a $200 million shareholders' lawsuit for $35 million, and the troubled entertainment company said on Tuesday that it would file suit against insurers that it said had forced MGM/UA into the settlement.

title: In a Worried Economy, Impasse Adds to Unease
description: The budget stalemate, coinciding with the Persian Gulf confrontation, is worsening the economic slump and increasing the chances of another jolt to the financial markets, various analysts say.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Asea Brown Boveri A.B., the Swiss maker of power and automation equipment, said it would sell its Sprout-Bauer unit to Maschinenfabrik Andritz Actiengesellschaft of Austria. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holiday of Shemini Atzereth, which concludes the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today. Those rules will also be suspended tomorrow for Simhath Torah, which ends the annual cycle of the public reading of the Torah.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 13 about a study on AIDS patients by the New York City Task Force on Single-Disease Hospitals omitted the names of three members of the panel. They are Dr. Thomas Killip of Beth Israel Medical Center; Dr. Sheila M. Rothman of Columbia University, and Dr. Eileen A. Tynan, the panel's executive director.

title: Nucor Expansion
description: The Nucor Corporation said it plans to build a $300 million steel mill that could produce a million tons of sheet steel a year. The company said options had been obtained on sites near Blytheville and Osceola, Ark., in the northeastern part of the state, and a decision should be made in three months. The mill is expected to be in operation by mid-1993.

title: Looking Beyond the Buffoonery In a Classic Farce by Moliere
description: ''It is an odd calling,'' wrote Jean Baptiste Poquelin, ''to make decent folk laugh.'' However odd it may be, Poquelin did a particularly good job of it under his better-known pseudonym, Moliere, writing classic comedies that poked fun at the follies, vices, hypocrites and hypocrisy of his less-than-perfect society.

title: Putting a Shine On Handbags
description: FASHION models may have been the first to use the sleek aluminum photographic-equipment cases as luggage. Now, Zero-Halliburton, of Pacoima, Calif., has introduced two new versions of its lightweight carrying cases. They happen to be handbags.

title: Dinkins's Troubles Are Tied To Aides' Conflicting Advice
description: When Mayor David N. Dinkins announced last week that he might have to lay off at least 15,000 city workers, his chief political aide and longtime adviser, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, learned that such a specific warning was in a news release only after it was issued.

title: Gas-Electric Hybrid Cars Can Be Built Now
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Buyers Are Selected in Reserve Oil Auction
description: The Energy Department said today that it had selected 11 companies to buy nearly four million barrels of crude oil from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. It also said that about a million barrels also included in the auction had not been sold because bids for various blocks of that oil were either too low or had not been submitted.

title: BUSH SHIFTS STAND ON TAX RISE AGAIN; CONGRESS BAFFLED
description: The White House shifted course again today on tax policy, baffling the Congressional tax committees and leaving Congressional leaders confused about which way to turn.

title: Frames Without the Art (Technically, Anyway)
description: TO celebrate the opening of its new framing and furniture restoration store, Lowy East, the long-established Lowy company is presenting ''Historical Perspectives: The Frame, 1450-1950,'' an exhibit of about 30 antique frames. They happen to be empty, which allows the impressive array of frames to stand on their own as rare art works, with price tags to match.

title: Missouri Seeks to Quit Case of Comatose Patient
description: The State of Missouri, which fought all the way to the Supreme Court to prevent the removal of a feeding tube from a comatose patient, has asked to be allowed to withdraw from new court proceedings on the case.

title: 2 Witnesses Fail to Link Charges to Milken
description: Government witnesses in the criminal case against Michael R. Milken testified yesterday in public for the first time, providing details of numerous transactions between Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the stock trading firm of Ivan F. Boesky, the fallen arbitrager.

title: Putting Idealism to Work;   The Community Service Investment
description: A visionary piece of legislation has survived Washington's budget chaos and is making its way toward the President's desk. The Community Service Act of 1990 calls for very little money, and dollar for dollar it is one of the wisest expenditures this Congress has yet suggested.

title: Leader of Panama Invasion, Ill With Leukemia, Is Retiring
description: Gen. Maxwell Thurman, the field commander who led the invasion of Panama last December, is retiring, the Pentagon has announced.

title: Robert L. White, Ex-Head of Kent State, 81
description: Robert L. White, who was president of Kent State University when National Guardsmen shot to death four students and wounded nine during a protest against the Vietnam War, died Wednesday at Robinson Memorial Hospital in Ravenna, Ohio. He was 81 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. Mr. White's career at the university spanned 44 years. He was president from 1963 to 1971 and retired in 1975.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Economic Scene;   A Terrible Time For a Deadlock
description: PRESIDENT BUSH's flip-flop on whether or how to raise taxes to reduce the widening budget deficit - leaving the problem for Congress to work out as he hits the campaign trail - is a stunning blow to public confidence in the nation's leadership. It could scarcely have come at a worse time, with the economy sliding toward recession, the markets in turmoil, the dollar falling to new lows, speculators driving oil prices up, down and up, and the United States carrying the heaviest military burdens in the Persian Gulf.

title: Hudson Riverkeeper Seeks Funds
description: The Hudson Riverkeeper Fund is seeking donations for its fourth annual fund-raising auction in Cold Spring, N.Y., on Oct. 28, according to its president, Robert Boyle.

title: TV Weekend;   A Garcia Marquez Tale
description: Having basked in the limelight for a few days with its original production of ''The Civil War,'' public television now returns to business as usual. That means tight budgets, which in turn spell more international co-productions and acquisitions. Not insignificantly, two of this weekend's major PBS presentations come with English subtitles, fully so in ''Miracle in Rome,'' at 9 tonight on Channel 13 and partly in the four-part ''The Ginger Tree,'' the first installment of which is to be shown at 9 P.M. on Sunday. The first one's subtitles translate Spanish, the second Japanese.

title: Businesses Must Do Their Part to Fight Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 519 money market mutual funds increased $1.48 billion, to $411.35 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 159 institutional funds increased by $967.4 million, to $99.85 billion.

title: Review/Fashion;   Armani: Dresses Need Shorts
description: Giorgio Armani showed a four-star collection Wednesday night, bringing the spring and summer ready-to-wear openings to a rousing conclusion.

title: At the Movies
description: Sorvino the Don

title: Northern Ireland Doesn't Need Reuniting
description: To the Editor:

title: House Approves Compromise Bill To Continue the Arts Endowment
description: After hours of emotional debate over what is art and what is pornography, the House of Representatives tonight overwhelmingly approved a bill to extend the life of the National Endowment for the Arts for three years and leave judgments about obscenity to the courts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 27 about Philadelphia's fiscal problems misstated the number of homes burned in the police confrontation with the radical group Move in 1985. Sixty-one homes were destroyed, not 250.

title: BATTLE AT THE U.N.
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization is straining the American-led international coalition against Iraq by pressing ahead with its own Security Council resolution condemning Israel.

title: Changes at the Top Of Aubrey G. Lanston
description: Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Government securities brokerage house, announced yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, John B. Ford, plans to retire at the end of the year and that he will be succeeded by Richard M. Kelly.

title: Illinois Journal;   Where an Irish Name Wins Everyone's Vote
description: This is the County of Cook, not Cork. And contrary to rumor, the election ballots in Illinois next month will not be printed in Gaelic.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARGARET THATCHER turns 65 years old tomorrow and will spend her birthday at the Conservative Party Conference in Bournemouth, England. When she arrived there yesterday, according to Reuters, she indicated that she hoped to be Prime Minister when she was 70.

title: Putting Idealism to Work;   Still Time for the Police Corps
description: High-quality police recruits at a bargain rate - that's the promise of a measure imbedded in a crime bill the Senate passed last summer. Residents of New York and other crime-beset cities have special reason to hope it survives a conference with the House.

title: Company News;   Enron Names New President
description: The Enron Corporation, operator of the nation's largest natural gas transmission system, said yesterday that it had named Richard D. Kinder president and chief operating officer.

title: Walter J. Vetro, Monsignor, 73
description: Msgr. Walter J. Vetro, founder and chairman of the St. Nicholas Neighborhood Preservation Corporation in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, died on Monday in the rectory of St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Church, where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: Review/Piano;   Daniel Barenboim Unravels 33 Changes
description: Lives there a music lover whose heart does not sink just a little when a pianist sits down to the task of unraveling Beethoven's ''Diabelli'' Variations? Experience has taught that the 33 extraordinary changes rung on its ordinary little theme can easily exhaust an audience's patience: the end generally comes like a release from duty, not an epiphany. Even as technically proficient and musically sound a pianist as Daniel Barenboim must sometimes have felt, in the course of a strenuous hour at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, like Laocoon wrestling the sea serpents.

title: Ozone Hole Reopens Over Antarctica
description: A gaping hole in earth's protective ozone layer has again opened over Antarctica, and scientists reported yesterday that the depletion of ozone there seemed to be nearly as severe as it was in the worst previous years, 1987 and 1989.

title: Europe Jobless Rate Up
description: Unemployment in the European Community rose one-tenth of 1 percent, to 8.4 percent, in August from the previous month, the European Community Executive Commission said this week. The rise was the first in the 12-nation trade bloc since February. Overall unemployment in August 1989 was at a rate of 9.2 percent.

title: California Is Poised to Let Paralegals Go It Alone
description: California appears poised to become the first state to grant independent paralegals - those who work for themselves, not for a law firm -the right to practice law in limited situations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On the eve of the premiere of her first feature film in 11 years, SOPHIA LOREN is to receive a lifetime achievement award today at the Chicago International Film Festival, when her new movie, ''Saturday, Sunday and Monday,'' has its premiere.

title: Thousands Rally in Prague to Denounce Communists
description: Tens of thousands of demonstrators jammed the Old Town Square here today to denounce the Communist Party, which has begun to reassert itself politically for the first time in a year.

title: EGYPT VOTE ISSUE: A NEW ASSEMBLY?
description: As President Hosni Mubarak promised a ''new era'' in his country's politics, Egyptians voted today in a referendum that could lead to early elections.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - ADDENDA;

People
description: LEAD: * Jim Thompson has been named an executive vice president at Leo Burnett Company, Chicago.

title: How the Survey Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 8 to 10 with 960 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Curson and Friends

title: Quebec Indians Ponder True Cost of Electricity
description: Chief Robbie Dick has seen the future and he wants no part of it. Neither do most of the 500 Cree Indians he represents in this remote northern Quebec village on the eastern shore of Hudson Bay.

title: New Budget Ideas Offered as Tug-of-War Goes On
description: The budget impasse grew even more complex today as Congressional Democrats and Republicans pushed rival plans, and conflicting statements at the White House added to the air of confusion.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about possible tax increases in Suffolk County misidentified the man speaking in some copies. He was Joseph R. Caputo, the County Comptroller, not Patrick G. Halpin, the County Executive.

title: Reviews/Film;   Taxidermy and Temptations: Dennis Hopper's Dark World
description: It goes without saying that there is no one quite like Dennis Hopper, an actor with an incomparable ability to bewilder, amuse and generally rattle an audience simply by presenting himself on screen. It is also beginning to go without saying that the films Mr. Hopper has directed, from his 1969 ''Easy Rider'' to his 1988 ''Colors'' to his current ''Hot Spot,'' cannot easily be compared with anything except one another.

title: U.S. Is Trying to Avoid a Council Fight on Israel
description: American diplomats are working frantically to prevent a developing split over the Palestinian issue in the United Nations Security Council from causing severe damage to the anti-Iraq alliance.

title: Israelis Starting To Doubt Story Of a Staged Riot
description: Several thousand Orthodox Jews, enveloped in religious fervor, danced and sang holding Torah scrolls at the base of the Western Wall tonight, celebrating the end of a religious holiday as hundreds of Israeli soldiers stood guard from all sides.

title: Report of Layoffs At Burger King
description: Burger King, the fast-food chain, is planning ''substantial layoffs'' nationwide, according to a report today in The Miami Herald. Quoting unnamed Burger King employees and restaurant franchise owners, the newspaper said reports were circulating within the company that between 300 and 400 workers would be affected. A Burger King spokeswoman, Cori Zywotow, declined to comment on The Herald's report.

title: A pre-emptive strike against Laurence Tribe, by those who do not care to call him 'Mr. Justice.'
description: It can only be described as a dia-Tribe.

title: On Stage
description: New Life for Hemingway Play

title: Downgradings at Record
description: The credit quality of American corporations declined at a record pace in the first three quarters of this year, Moody's Investors Service Inc. has reported, with a third of the downgradings affecting financial institutions like banks, savings and loans and insurance and finance companies.

title: Apple Harvest Festival
description: Decorated pumpkins, cider-making, corn husk dolls and old-fashioned games will be among the attractions at the Apple Harvest Festival and Birdseed Sale at the New Pond Farm Education Center in West Redding, Conn., tomorrow from 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Bongo the Clown, a juggler and magician, will appear. In case of rain, the festival will be held at the same time on Sunday. Admission is $1.50 for adults and $1 for children. New Pond Farm, a 102-acre working farm with two and a half miles of hiking trails, is a nonprofit educational center at Marchant and Umpawaug Roads, West Redding, off Route 53. Information and directions: (203) 938-2117.

title: Dow Slides 42.82 Points, To 2,365.10
description: Stocks fell again yesterday, partly in reaction to a 63 percent dividend reduction by Chemical Banking, the nation's sixth-largest banking company. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day down 42.82, at 2,365.10, a 17-month low.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Review/Art;   Virtuoso Italian Drawings From the 18th Century
description: A small yet stunningly diverse show of 18th-century Italian drawings is now on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The 116 sheets by around 40 artists, all from the museum's permanent collection, are ripe with a virtuosity, even a decadence, that is to be expected from Italian art in the twilight of its greatness.

title: Mediobanca Buys Continental Stake
description: Italy's leading merchant bank, Mediobanca, emerged as a backer of the Pirelli group in its bid for the German tire company Continental. Mediobanca's annual report disclosed it had bought 5 percent of Continental for $92 million on June 30.

title: THE BUDGET BATTLE: Washington Talk;   Modifying Medicare: No Dice Once Again
description: Of all the fiscal powders that turned the recent budget summit to budget bomb, perhaps none proved more explosive than the plan to cut Medicare. In the resulting detritus lie lessons of budgetary politics.

title: Free Speech and Civil Rights Clash in Racism Trial
description: Six years after winning a lawsuit in Alabama that literally bankrupted a major faction of the Ku Klux Klan, civil rights lawyers who brought that case are waging a similar battle here in search of an even bigger damage award. This time they are trying to ruin the leaders of the White Aryan Resistance, a loosely knit group of several thousand white supremacists and skinheads who advocate racial separatism and anti-Semitism.

title: Brazil Proposes $60 Billion Shift
description: The Government of Brazil proposed today to convert $60 billion of its debt to private foreign creditors into medium- and long-term government bonds.

title: Church Leaders Voice Doubts on U.S. Gulf Policy
description: Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders are beginning to raise moral questions about American policy in the Persian Gulf, edging away from the general support they voiced for it two months ago and opening up a gap with their Jewish counterparts.

title: Mud-Slinging Elevated to an Art Form
description: HERE is what political analysts today call ''negative campaigning'': an advertisement by the incumbent Governor of Michigan suggesting that his Republican opponent supports big business.

title: Wally Moses, 80, Baseball Player
description: He died of a stroke, a family member said.

title: U.S. Effort On Computer For Israel
description: State Department and Commerce Department officials are pushing to loosen restrictions on the power limits of computers that can be sold to an Israeli military research laboratory that may be making nuclear weapons.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Thompson Follows B.S.B. In Creating a Radio Group
description: LEAD: MAGAZINES and newspapers are struggling. Television continues to rack up disappointments. So what is there to get excited about in advertising? How about radio?

title: In Spain, Knicks Are Shaky But Hold On
description: The Knicks opened their preseason schedule in this improbable site on the Mediterranean today by squeezing out an overtime victory over a determined Italian team that dogged the heels of the American players throughout the game.

title: Magnavox Guilty Plea
description: The Magnavox Government and Industrial Electronics Company, a supplier of military electronics equipment, pleaded guilty in Federal court in Boston yesterday to a charge that it unlawfully acquired and conveyed confidential Government documents about an Air Force procurement contract.

title: 3 ON FISCAL BOARD PRESS FOR ACTION ON DINKINS BUDGET
description: Reflecting their heightened concern over New York City's fiscal condition, members of the State Financial Control Board urged Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday to act more swiftly to detail his plans for keeping the city's budget balanced, participants in the meeting said.

title: As Fiscal Ills Grow, Dinkins And Unions Prepare to Talk
description: Under the growing urgency of New York City's fiscal troubles, the Dinkins administration and union leaders are preparing for intensified contract talks in a drive to settle municipal labor contracts next week.

title: Finance/New Issues;   Sallie Mae Offering Totals $200 Million
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million in fixed-rate notes due in 1995 through Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday in The Home Section about a new shoe boutique in New York City misidentified the man in the picture. He was the boutique's designer, Michael Formica, not its owner, Manolo Blahnik.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF

title: Plea in Tokyo Stock Trial
description: Mitsuhiro Kotani, a stock trader at the center of a widening financial scandal, pleaded not guilty today as his trial began here on charges that he manipulated the shares of a leading company in a conspiracy involving a number of individuals, banks and securities firms.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - ADDENDA;

Pro Bono
description: LEAD: An international advertising campaign for the United Nations will be handled by Affiliated Advertising Agencies International, Denver. The agencies will donate $4 million in time for this nonpolitical public-service campaign, which will be used worldwide.

title: Councilman Morgan, A Microbiologist, 70
description: Councilman Morgan, a microbiologist, educator and former administrator at the National Academy of Sciences, died on Wednesday at Anne Arundel Hospital in Annapolis, Md. He was 70 years old and had moved to Annapolis from Teaneck, N.J., about a year ago.

title: So You Want a Black Director for Your Movie?;   Welcome to Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Will Interview Dancers Of Cambodia on Defecting
description: The State Department said today that it had demanded that a group of Cambodian dancers on tour in the United States be interviewed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to determine if more of them may want to defect.

title: Quiet for 4 Years, Board Is Child of Crisis
description: The State Financial Control Board, which has been all but dormant and forgotten in the budgetary quietude of recent years, was created in 1975 to impose fiscal austerity on New York City - then at the brink of bankruptcy - and see it through its worst financial crisis in history.

title: The Bolshoi Spins Off A Troupe
description: Yuri Grigorovich, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow, announced yesterday that he had formed a new touring company, named the Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company, which is to make its debut next month. The group, of 60 young dancers, is the only major dance troupe in the Soviet Union to exist entirely independent of state subsidy; instead, it will derive its income from performances and touring seasons.

title: Rinfret and Republicans Join for a Show of Unity
description: Amid celebrity defections and escalating intraparty strife, the leaders of the New York Republican Party staged an awkward show of unity today with a gubernatorial candidate who has spent much of his campaign calling them names.

title: Harold Gottfried, 77, Discount Merchandiser
description: Harold Gottfried, an accountant who was a leader in mass discount merchandising, died on Tuesday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 77 years old.

title: Girl, 2, Is Reported Abducted in Queens
description: The police searched a Jamaica, Queens, neighborhood last night for a 2-year-old girl and the woman they believe abducted her from her godmother earlier in the day, the police said.

title: Soviet Rocket Is Lost in Blast
description: A Soviet booster rocket, carrying what an American specialist believes was a spy satellite, exploded seconds after liftoff last week, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: Surprising Flight Disclosed 135 Million Years Ago: A Bird
description: Paleontologists have assembled the nearly complete skeleton of a 135-million-year-old sparrow-sized creature and found that the earliest known modern birds were skilled fliers, not just gliders or land-dwelling animals, as some scientists have contended.

title: Drive Mounted for Environment Vote
description: Amid signs that a far-reaching environmental measure on the California ballot is faltering, three national leaders of the environmental movement declared today that the state faced an environmental crisis. They announced the start of a door-to-door drive for the measure.

title: Only 4 Embassies Hold Out In Kuwait as Food Dwindles
description: One by one, the foreign embassies defying Iraqi orders to shut down their operations in occupied Kuwait are closing for lack of water, electricity and food.

title: So You Want a Black Director for Your Movie?
description: To the Editor:

title: Estelle Stein Hartman; Volunteer, 96
description: Estelle Stein Hartman, a volunteer in organizations in the Hartford area, died on Monday at her home in West Hartford, Conn. She was 96 years old.

title: Let Oil States Pay With Excess Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: Macy Units To Be Sold In G.E. Deal
description: R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its consumer credit business to the General Electric Company, allowing the department store chain to erase about $1.5 billion in debt from its balance sheet. Macy remains heavily in debt from a management buyout in 1986.

title: Tumbling Stocks
description: A 42-point drop in the Dow yesterday extended a broad three-month market slump. Page D1.

title: N.F.L. Matchups;   Rison Is Blooming In New Falcon Offense
description: At Michigan State, Andre Rison spent much of his career in the shadow of Mark Ingram, now a Giants receiver. Last year, in his first pro season, Rison was one of three Indianapolis Colts to catch 50 or more passes. Rison was the 22d player selected and the second receiver chosen behind Hart Lee Dykes in the 1989 draft. For most of his football career, he has been a key weapon for an offense but not the chief one.

title: The Israeli Tragedy
description: The killing of Palestinians on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem was more than just another turn in an endless cycle of violence. The event, and Israeli handling of it, have terrible implications for Israel's future.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life Insurance Co., Hartford, said it had completed its purchase of 20 percent of the Bay Pacific Health Corp., San Bruno, Calif., a health-care organization. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Rhone-Poulenc to Cut 3,500 Jobs in Brazil
