title: CHRONICLE
description: BARBARA ORBISON, widow of the rock singer Roy Orbison, is collaborating with STEVE TISCH on a movie about her husband's life. He died of a heart attack in 1988, when he was 52.

title: Intel Profit Rises; Loss For Rival
description: The Intel Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc., Silicon Valley's feuding semiconductor companies, today reported vastly different financial results for the third quarter. Intel's profits more than doubled while Advanced Micro suffered a large loss.

title: John P. Fadden, Athletic Trainer, 91
description: John P. Fadden, a trainer at Harvard for more than 50 years whose patients also included such notables as Babe Ruth, Ted Williams, Bob Cousy, Arthur Fiedler and John, Robert and Edward Kennedy, died of prostate cancer Wednesday at the Neville Manor nursing home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91 years old.

title: Hazard to Babies' Hands
description: Government officials have issued warnings about baby strollers that have caused severe injuries to children's hands.

title: German Interior Minister Is Shot at Political Rally
description: Wolfgang Schauble, the German Interior Minister and one of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's closest advisers, was shot and seriously wounded tonight at a campaign rally, his ministry reported.

title: The Golden Door, Ajar
description: Congress, having transformed the law on illegal immigration in 1986, is on the verge of another remarkable achievement: the first major reform of legal immigration in 25 years.

title: Review/Television;   In Which an Unhappy Wife Is Unhappier as a Concubine
description: The ''Masterpiece Theater'' four-part production of ''The Ginger Tree'' on PBS is an ambitious undertaking with few rewards. The first installment is to be shown at 9 P.M. Sunday on Channel 13.

title: Cooney Showed Courage
description: In the hallowed Halls of Congress on Thursday morning, the Representative from the First District of Massachusetts, Silvio O. Conte, a Republican, stood up and called Terry Cooney ''loony'' for evicting Roger Clemens - ''Clem,'' as he called him - from a baseball game the other day.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One of the earliest talk show hosts of radio and television, TEX McCRARY turned 80 today. With his wife, JINX FALKENBURG, he started ''The Tex and Jinx Show'' in 1946.

title: INSIDE
description: Egyption Official Slain

title: CHRONICLE
description: HUME CRONYN and JESSICA TANDY finally won permission to build an apartment above their garage in Easton, Conn. In August, the town Zoning Board of Appeals turned down their request, but the board reversed itself Thursday.

title: Review/Music;   10th Season Of Offering New Works
description: Confusion and poverty are the customary watchwords for this city's independant orchestras. The Riverside Symphony, which played Prokofiev, Sibelius and Robert Helps at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, suffers from neither.

title: After Court Rebuke, Refac Hints at a Retreat on Suits
description: In the wake of a stinging rebuke from a Federal appeals court here, the Refac Technology Development Corporation signaled a retreat today in its efforts to sue thousands of companies over patent infringement.

title: Bridge
description: When a bunch of New York experts are gathered together they are usually out for each other's blood, technically speaking. An exception is the annual Experts Night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, when the atmosphere is social and the stars of yesteryear mingle with their juniors.

title: Distracted by High Honors
description: LEAD: The 19th of October, the saint's day of Peter of Alcentara 1989, they gave me the Nobel Prize for Literature. During this time I have experienced the most benevolent, comfortable stupor on the one hand, and also the most monotonous and administrative wearings on the other. Having had very little practice in the ins and outs, the ups and downs and the rounds of such high honors, I was caught unawares, even a bit distracted and off balance, by the event.

title: Missing Girl Found in Queens
description: A 2-year-old girl who was abducted in Jamaica, Queens, on Thursday was found safe in front of a motel near John F. Kennedy International Airport early yesterday, the police said. The girl, Shakima Harkles, was shopping with her godmother when the woman discovered her missing. About 1:30 A.M. yesterday, a Port Authority police Officer, Donald Firehock, saw the child and Rachel Forestal, 24, of 550 Fulton Street, Hempstead, L.I. Ms. Forestal was charged with kidnapping. The child did not appear to have been injured, the authorities said.

title: 'Cosby' Over 'Simpsons'In Thursday's Ratings
description: ''The Cosby Show'' beat ''The Simpsons'' in the ratings on Thursday night, the first time the two shows have gone head to head with new episodes.

title: New Assistant Coach For Knight and Indiana
description: Norm Ellenberger just wanted to talk fishing, but Bobby Knight ended up luring him to Indiana. Ellenberger, who spent the last three college basketball seasons working for Don Haskins at Texas-El Paso, said Thursday that he had accepted a job as an assistant coach at Indiana.

title: Software Issue Kills Liberal Amendment To Copyright Laws
description: A long campaign by writers and publishers for a bill that would allow authors to quote liberally from letters, diaries and other unpublished material has collapsed in Congress just as a compromise appeared to have been reached.

title: Olya Margolin, Jewish Women's Leader, 81
description: Olya Margolin, the Washington representative of the National Council of Jewish Women for more than 30 years before her retirement in 1978, died yesterday at the Washington Hospital Center. She was 81 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Karpov Found All Exits Shut
description: The fine points of Mr. Kasparov's play in Game 2 are going to be debated for weeks and, in private, Mr. Karpov and his analysis team will be searching for a way out. Here are two critical moments, where both players had major alternatives to consider. In each case, the champion had spectacular ripostes for what could have confronted him.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS BACK DEFICIT PLAN FOR TAXES ON RICH
description: House Democrats on Friday embraced a deficit-reduction plan intended to portray their party as the champion of the poor and middle class, while a battered White House sought to reassert some influence over the budget process.

title: KLM Airlines To Cut 500 Jobs
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines announced it was cutting 500 jobs and warned that rising jet fuel prices and a weak dollar could wipe out profits this year. The company may also cut part of its foreign network as part of a $231 million cost-cutting plan in the next three years, a KLM spokesman, Hugo Baas, said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ASK Computer Systems Inc., Mountain View, Calif., extended until next Friday its offer for common shares of Ingres Corp. ASK said it had received more than 4.3 million, or about 38 percent, of Ingres's shares so far.

title: Tunisians Discussed Gulf Solution in Baghdad
description: To the Editor:

title: John Barr Joins Padres
description: John Barr, director of scouting for the Baltimore Orioles for the last two years, was named yesterday as assistant general manager of the San Diego Padres. The move to San Diego reunites Barr with Joe McIlvaine, the former Mets executive hired Oct. 2 as the Padres' general manager. Barr, 33 years old, spent three years in New York working under McIlvaine as an administrative assistant in scouting and minor league operations. (AP)

title: New Cars, Rebates And Warranties
description: The 1991 automobile models have arrived amid economic conditions gloomy enough to dishearten buyers. But a silver lining for consumers is the significant cash rebates that have been available on many new models since Sept. 26, the day they were introduced.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Medical Insurance Claims
description: When an insurance company refuses to pay for a medical expense or denies part of a claim you believe should be paid in full, one expert offers this advice: ''The insurance company owes the claim unless it can affirmatively demonstrate why it should not be paid.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: One of the earliest talk show hosts of radio and television, TEX McCRARY turned 80 today. With his wife, JINX FALKENBURG, he started ''The Tex and Jinx Show'' in 1946.

title: Patents;   Europe Still Uncertain About Harvard's Mouse
description: After long deliberation, the European Patent Office's appeals board has decided to duck the question of whether Harvard University's genetically engineered mouse qualifies for a European patent.

title: Taxi Commission Investigates Medallion Pricing and Loans
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission and three other city agencies are investigating complaints that taxi-medallion brokers and lenders are selling the medallions at prices far above the prevailing market rate to unsuspecting buyers.

title: Eric Show a Free Agent
description: Eric Show, the winningest pitcher ever for the San Diego Padres, has become a free agent. The 34-year-old right-hander was set loose Thursday when the Padres elected to exercise a $250,000 buyout clause in his contract rather than pick up Show's $1.1 million for 1991. Show picked up his 100th career victory by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers in his team's Oct. 3 season finale. He finished the season with a 6-8 record and a 5.76 earned run average, having pitched in 39 games, including 12 starts. (AP)

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Health Officials Say 'Harmless' Snakes May Be Venomous
description: The New York City Department of Health issued a warning yesterday to anyone who recently bought what appeared to be a harmless garter snake: Don't touch it. It may just be a venomous Oriental water snake.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about a funeral for Alvin Rivera, a 15-year-old who was killed in a random shooting, misstated the youth's home address. It was 540 Southern Boulevard in the Bronx.

title: Storms Batter the East Coast From Georgia to Delaware
description: A hurricane and the remnants of two tropical storms battered the East Coast yesterday from Georgia to Delaware, with gale-force winds whipping the Outer Banks of North Carolina and up to a foot of rain falling in South Carolina and Georgia.

title: A Hopelessly Trendy Killer
description: THE MURDERER NEXT DOOR

title: Final Bow?
description: For many people who hoped to catch one more performance by Leonard Bernstein before he put away his baton, this has been a year of disappointments. In May, poor health caused him to cancel his appearance at the Spoleto U.S.A. Festival in Charleston, S.C. Then he withdrew from the Pacific Music Festival in Japan. After his last conducting appearance, at Tanglewood on Aug. 19, John Rockwell wrote in The New York Times that he ''seemed truly exhausted, even in pain, as he walked off the stage amid the concluding ovations.'' Last week, Mr. Bernstein announced his retirement in a statement that included a medical diagnosis, which said the 72-year-old conductor, who is known to have been a heavy smoker, has progressive emphysema complicated by a pleural tumor and pulmonary infections. But he held out hope for at least one more hurrah. He said he still planned to participate in Music for Life, an AIDS benefit concert on Oct. 28 in Carnegie Hall.

title: Q and A
description: Succession Rights

title: Regina L. DeFeo Weds F. J. Wahl
description: Regina Louise DeFeo, the manager of marketing analysis at Tiffany & Company, and Frederick John Wahl, a vice president at Morgan Stanley & Company, were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;

Lunch With Her Demon Lover
description: LEAD:

title: Latin Immigrants Turn to South Fork
description: LEAD: THOUSANDS of young Spanish-speaking immigrants, many of them illegal aliens, are flocking to the South Fork. There they work in motels and restaurants and for landscaping companies. On Sundays newcomers play soccer in Montauk.

title: Fate and Luck Keys to Maestro's Success
description: LEAD: TO say that luck has played a major role in shaping Arthur Fagen's career might be a disservice to the talented young conductor, who last week shepherded two major new productions to the stage of the New York City Opera within eight days.

title: Fashion;   Metropolitan Nights
description: Virtue is clad in puffed sleeves and pearls, while its dark opposite, of course, wears black. In the movie ''Metropolitan,'' a bittersweet recollection of New York's debutante scene in the late 1960's, a group of young socialites dresses according to character. The vamps are sheathed in velvet, but most of the other women persist in wearing coquettish party frocks. In hotel ballrooms, taxis and Park Avenue apartments, they drink, flirt and talk about the decline of their class. The good life, as they know it, is about to fade away. In real life, however, many of its artifacts have gracefully survived. Pearls, if not a badge of virtue, remain a sign of breeding. Black endures as a siren's favorite color. And, as members of the movie's cast demonstrate here, when the occasion is festive, satin and velvet are still preferred.

title: Not the Cheapest Form of Transportation
description: To the Editor:

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Can Nutmeggers Turn Into Tarheels?
description: LEAD: THEY are arriving in unprecedented numbers, a sort of Underground Railroad in reverse, a North-to-South exodus with no end in sight.

title: Sports People;   Dickerson Signs
description: In what might be the most important huddle of the season for the Indianapolis Colts, officials of the National Football League team and Eric Dickerson met most of yesterday outside Indianapolis. When they broke up, player and team had patched up their differences and the bickering running back had signed a four-year contract extension.

title: Let Arms-Sale Profits Aid Poor Countries

description: North and South Korea have agreed in principle to field a single Olympic team for the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona and for other international sports events.

title: 2 'Ben-Hur's Return to Big Screen
description: LEAD: BEN-HUR is coming to Peekskill.

title: Heather Stiers Weds Jonathan A. Dorn
description: Heather Allison Stiers, a daughter of the Rev. Dr. Brenda J. Stiers and the Rev. Dr. Thomas Lowell Stiers of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Jonathan Andrew Dorn, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Dorn of Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Duggan, a Presbyterian minister who is the bride's godfather, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Horse Racing;   Buy the Firm Wins In Muddy Athenia
description: Buy the Firm completed a dreary afternoon of heavy favorites, romping through the mud at Belmont Park yesterday to beat just three rivals and win the $87,750 Athenia Handicap.

description: Horseback Riding in Japan

title: Meeting the Parents in 'Greetings'
description: ARE things not working for you? Are you misunderstood? Do you need a better understanding of others? Are you carrying around a little or a load of guilt, hostility, prejudice? Are you being controlled by those old demons?

title:
All About/Car Rental Companies;

Airline and Vacation Blues Spell Trouble
description: LEAD: After nine years of rapid growth and improving profits, car rental companies have hit a pothole. The air travel boom that propelled car rentals for most of the 1980's contracted slightly late in the decade and is now seriously threatened by the rising air fares resulting from increasing fuel costs.

title: Evening Stars
description: ANCHORS

title: Wall Street;   Those Dow 'Bargains' Are Getting Even Cheaper
description: After the panicky 190-point sell-off of Oct. 13, 1989, some people thought the 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average looked very cheap. Well, most of those stocks are even cheaper now.

title: Bankers Hoping for End To Steep Decline in Profits
description: AS Connecticut banks release their third-quarter financial results this month, industry experts say the long slide in profits should be halted although perhaps not reversed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's a trigger-quick readiness to think something terrible is about to happen again. In everybody, there's an anxiety that wasn't there before.''

title: A Dissent on Deficit Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts Face Lean Times as Patrons Retrench
description: BATTERED by cutbacks in corporate contributions and audience belt-tightening, arts groups are facing hard times.

title: Gold and the Yen Continue to Slide
Museum Show of State Talent
description: ALTHOUGH teapots by craft artists are not expected to hold hot water these days, and contemporary art quilts rarely warm chilled toes, the decades-old maxim ''Form follows function'' still possesses an underpinning of truth in the craft world. Clay continues to be shaped into vessels; fabrics are cut, stitched and quilted, while molten glass is blown into glistening bowls.

title: KIDS AND SCHOLARS AT WORK
description: What a wonderful feeling of nostalgia I had when I opened the pages of Bruce Weber's article ''Shhh! Kids and Scholars at Work'' (Sept. 23). The Hunts Point branch of the New York Public Library was where, more than 30 years ago, I first developed a love of books. How well I still remember the day when I was old enough to get a card to the adult section of the library and was able to go downstairs and browse in the cavernous and hushed room, with shelves full of books that reached from the ceiling to the floor. It was one of the milestones of my youth.

title: Old Torment Revives in Italy: the Moro Killing
description: Ghosts from Italy's most traumatic episode of political terrorism have suddenly emerged to torment the national soul once again.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;

IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Where and How to Insulate
description: MOST homes have insulation in the attic and walls, it having been included during construction or added later. Insulation between an unheated basement or crawl space and the main floor is important, too; in winter, unheated areas beneath rooms can act like a block of ice.

title: Murder Most Tidy
description: AGATHA CHRISTIE

title: Campus Life: Hofstra;   Students Protest A Limit on Ads For Alcohol
description: To promote what it calls ''responsible'' drinking, Hofstra University has moved to limit advertising of alcohol on campus and in campus publications.

title: Fair Days in Palm Springs
description: ''The desert,'' observed J. Smeaton Chase, a British inhabitant of what was then the tiny village of Palm Springs, ''is the opposite of all that we naturally find pleasing.''

title: Supreme Court Should Protect Economic and Civil Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Yachting;   Powerboat Racers Ponder the Risks
description: Competitors on 35 offshore powerboat teams are feeling a heightened sense of danger today as they prepare for the national championship in Marathon, Fla. Their uneasiness stems from the death two weeks ago of Stephano Casiraghi, husband of Princess Caroline of Monaco, who was killed while racing a 42-foot powerboat on the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Music's New Catatonia: Don't Bother Getting Up
description: Galaxie 500 is named after a 1960's-model Ford, but the songs on the Boston band's third album, ''This Is Our Music,'' seldom exceed the pace of heavy traffic. It's music to sit still by. Dean Wareham's thin, tentative voice can inflate without warning into an eerie falsetto. His lyrics reflect a reluctance to participate, an unsureness about even the most casual social situations. ''I stayed at home on the fourth of July/ And I pulled the shades so I didn't have to see the sky,'' he sings in ''Fourth of July.''

title: Baseball;   Managers' Consensus: Game 2 Was Critical
description: Jim Leyland, the Pittsburgh Pirates' manager, said the second game was the key to the National League championship series. Lou Piniella, the Cincinnati Reds' manager, called the second game the turning point.

title: Source Reduction And Choice
description: While I strongly agree with Judy Keenan that the Legislature in New Jersey has been uninformed and misguided in its handling of recycling in this state (''Cutting Down on Trash,'' Opinion page, Sept. 2), I cannot agree with her conclusion that source reduction is the Legislature's bailiwick.

title: Stop Mowing, Start Digging
description: Any of us have had an extra-room dream. Perhaps it has not been examined in the great psychoanalytic case histories; it is more likely to have been discussed by architects and decorators whose clients have experienced it. In this particular fantasy, the dreamer opens a door to a vast and beautiful space that has gone undetected all the years he has suffered in his cramped abode. It is a simple image, and one that inflames some people with a longing more powerful than sexual desire. An extra room, right here, and we never knew it! This is not a dream that comes true very often within the confines of most contemporary interior spaces, at least not without considerable ingenuity and a bank account to back it up. But many home dwellers who would like to make a garden in a small lot could have this experience simply by opening their front doors and stepping outside.

title: Cutting the Cord
description: One of the more unusual approaches to saving household space is to take all the furnishings out of a room and hang them on your body. This is the idea behind the new portable home office: If the equipment fits, wear it.

title: Some Plants Are Doubly Rewarding
description: EERYONE likes to have a double dividend. And some plants are worth the gardener's time and investment for their flowers in spring as well as their showy foliage or berries in fall.

title:
Style Makers;

Franco and Grazia Landi, Candle Makers
description: LEAD: It may come as a disappointment to some to learn that a real Roman candle doesn't explode - that it lies flat in a dish with hardly even a sputter. But to Franco and Grazia Landi, the owners of the Cereria Costantino Pisoni at 127 Corso Vittorio Emanuele, they are the best way to light up any event.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;

Kid Shrink Nabs Schoolyard Sniper
description: LEAD:

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

When an Operator Reached Out, and Touched Me
description: LEAD: I HAVE discovered that the telephone world is not total desolation after all. It isn't just selling-machines talking to answering-machines, not just little turquoise phones offering special buttons for instant contact with eight pizza companies, not just ''directory assistance'' that won't tell you an address you could easily look up if you owned the right directory.

title: 13 Are Killed in El Salvador In Blast of Water and Rocks
description: A geyser-like blast of boiling water and hot rocks leveled homes and killed at least 13 people today in a western Salvadoran village.

title: Letting All Schools Share in the Dream
description: The article ''Schools Preparing for Changes in Financing'' (Sept. 2) filled in many of the cracks in the current controversy over rich school-poor school educational financing.

description: Lisa Rae Leffert and Lee H. Schwamm, who expect to graduate from the Harvard University Medical School in June, were married last evening at the Rosecliff estate in Newport, R.I., by Rabbi Leslie Gutterman.

title: Sarah Bittle Wed To John H. Dritz
description: Sarah Elizabeth Bittle, a daughter of Sandra Peterson of Iowa Falls, Iowa, was married in Des Moines last evening to John Harris Dritz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Dritz of Armonk, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Fink performed the ceremony at the Marriott Hotel.

title:
Food;

It's Thyme for Dessert
description: LEAD: For all of its sticky-sweet attractions, dessert is pretty basic stuff. Or so it has always seemed to me. Recently, however, I've encountered creative concoctions that go way beyond the classic sugary combinations - oddities like a moist chocolate cake, for example, with a bay-leaf syrup, or lace cookies with thyme-macerated raspberries.

title: Ann Elizabeth Halan Weds L. Crawford Brickley Jr.
description: Ann Elizabeth Halan and L. Crawford Brickley Jr., associates in the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Edward J. Howley and the Rev. Edward Danks, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title:
FORUM;

How a Corporation Reveals Itself
description: LEAD: Products from companies competing globally are becoming similar. That means a company's identity can be the deciding factor for success in the marketplace. From my experience, American managers do not seem to understand this as fully as their European counterparts - even though it was in the United

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Up in the Air Against His Will
description: These days, I am on the road during the week, but I always have to get back to New York on the weekend to work. So I spend a lot of time in the lines at the airline counters. Most people who have to go somewhere in America nowadays wait in those same lines. I can remember when people in those lines laughed and chatted, anticipating the exciting trips they were about to make up above the clouds. Now, they wait glumly and check their watches. This is because airline travel has changed, and they know they're not going to have any fun up there.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Why One New Yorker Is Leaving Home
description: LEAD: I'M leaving home. After 31 years as a New Yorker, I am getting out. Although I have been happily married for four years, I still feel like I never left home. But this is the big move; this is so final. This is the first real separation between me and my family. After sitting down one night together, my husband and I made the grim discovery that we would never achieve in New York what our parents had.

title: Developers Shrink Stake in 5th Avenue Tower
description: Two of New York's high-flying real-estate developers have been squeezed out of one of their most ambitious projects, a 53-story office tower at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, real-estate executives say.

title: To Be Young Again at 78: A Carousel Is
description: Four-year-old Hannah Goodwin happily bobbed up and down on her pale gray horse, but 3-year-old Jonathan Hausch preferred the bright orange lion with the bushy mane to his colorful wooden steed.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;

Lunch With Her Demon Lover
description: LEAD:

title: Doing Something About How We Drive
description: In her New Jersey Opinion piece, ''Changing Our Driving Habits'' (Sept. 9), Linda Muhlhausen says it is time for us to start thinking about the way we drive. She's absolutely right - and some of us have started thinking.

title: A Little Lonelier Than in 70's, New York Faces Fiscal Crisis
description: Fifteen years after its costly and humiliating brush with bankruptcy, New York City is edging into fiscal straits that seem painfully familiar.

title: Seattle Induces Office Builders to Include Child Care
description: The city of Seattle is beginning to get experience with the use of zoning incentives that encourage builders to provide day-care centers for the young children of office workers. The results so far suggest advantages, but at a substantial cost to users for a substantial benefit to builders.

title: Verse Prize
description: After years in which the awarding of the Nobel Prize in Literature has been followed by grumbling over the recipient's obscurity, the world of letters was all smiles last week when the name Octavio Paz popped out of the envelope. Mr. Paz, whose half-century of poetic exploration of the Mexican soul is marked by a sensuous surreality, has for years been regarded as one of the greats for whom the Nobel was more or less inevitable. He is the first Mexican to win the prize, which carries a cash award of about $700,000. His career as a poet has been twinned with those of diplomat and social commentator. In recent years he has described himself as a ''disillusioned leftist.'' After the prize was announced, Mr. Paz, who was visiting New York, commented, ''The Academy does very well when they choose especially for literary reasons, regardless of popularity of political ideas.'' His publisher, James Laughlin, was more direct. ''I've been expecting this to happen for the last 10 years,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: In the Style Makers column last Sunday, the picture credit with the photograph of Januwa Moja, who makes clothing influenced by African tribal designs, misidentified the photographer. It was Richard A. Green, not Kim Garnick.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Should Win M.V.P., Cy Young Awards?
description: M.V.P.: George Brett. At age 37, he led the A.L. in batting and doubles. Bobby Bonilla. No explanations needed. Cy Young: It will be Welch, but it should be either Clemens or Eckersley. In the N.L., who was better from June on than Gooden (16-1)? However, Drabek will get it.

title: Contemporary Objects Use Icons of Past
description: ''SPIRIT images'' borrowed from petroglyphs and ancient ceremonial artifacts lend the stamp of tradition to an assortment of pottery, baskets, jewelry and wall pieces by 25 artists at the Craftsman's Gallery here.

title: Review/Recital;   A Tenor Comfortably Challenged
description: Carnegie Hall did well, in planning its grand centennial season, not to overlook the intimate. One promising series in Weill Recital Hall, more modest than its title, ''Great Singers,'' implies, got off to a splendid start on Friday evening with the New York City debut recital of the American tenor John Aler.

title:
MUSIC;

Concert to Honor Temple's 40 Years
description: LEAD: REINFORCING its ties to the Westfield community, the Westfield Symphony Orchestra will open its 1990-91 season with two concerts next weekend. The first, at 8 P.M. Saturday in the Westfield Presbyterian Church, is part of the orchestra's subscription series, and the second, next Sunday at 2 P.M., is sponsored by Temple Emanu-El and the Jewish Federation of Central New Jersey.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Imagining Our Ancestors

title: The P.L.O. Will Lose, Even if Iraq Wins
description: LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization appears to have gained a temporary windfall from the Temple Mount killing of at least 21 Palestinians. The Palestinian cause returned to the international agenda, with a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel. The Saudi Foreign Minister has secured a commitment from President Bush to increase efforts to resolve the Palestinian problem.

title: Meanwhile, the Bad News From Albany Is Released Quietly
description: So loud was the clamor of bad news from New York City last week that the pessimistic din in Albany was barely audible.

title: A Town Full of Miracles
description: THAT TIME IN MALOMBA

title: Students' Art Speaks When Words Fail
description: LEAD: PETER HENRY was sure the student in his English class had read ''Ethan Frome,'' but the young man's severe learning disability made it impossible for him to express his understanding of the novel in the essay that had been assigned.

title: Wet Year Is Boon For Fleas
description: LEAD: FLEAS enjoyed a banner season this summer on Long Island pets, and with the onset of colder weather the problem may continue inside.

title: Kathy Norton and John McGowan Are Married
description: Kathy Ann Norton, a daughter of Mrs. T. Philip Norton of Bel Air, Md., and the late Mr. Norton, was married yesterday to John Joseph McGowan, a son of Mrs. John J. McGowan of Wayland, Mass., and the late Mr. McGowan. The Rev. Charles L. Lafferty officiated at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Bel Air.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MOSTLY MUSICALS

title: Pro Football;   Giants, Redskins Plan Few Surprises
description: The Giants are one of only two unbeaten teams (the other is the San Francisco 49ers) in the National Football League. They lead their division by one game over the Washington Redskins.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Travelers Face Shortage of Blood Serum

title: The Shalt Nots
description: Like the chorus at a revival meeting, four children are sitting in the back seat of the car, swinging and swaying and singing along with Tom Chapin, longtime folkie and inveterate environmentalist: ''Someone's gonna use it after you. Someone needs that water when you're through.'' These are the adults of the 21st century, and they know all the shalt nots by heart. Here are the bad things: Pollution. Litter. Smoking. Drugs. Drinking. Homelessness. Wasting water. Killing trees. They save whales and rain forests with their allowance. They have donned their social consciences early, taking them from school projects and television. ''Be smart; don't start,'' they sing idly on the swings, ''drinking hurts.'' They are the children who come into the kitchen, look at an egg frying, and say with certainty, ''That's your brain on drugs.'' Except for the few precocious ones who have been known to remark, ''There's lots of cholesterol in that thing.''

title: Trenton Studies Proposals to Cut Health Costs
description: LEAD: TWO weeks after the Governor's Commission on Health Care Costs called for a new payroll tax to finance the rising cost of hospital care for the uninsured poor, neither the Governor nor key legislators have endorsed the proposal. Although early reaction to the commission's report focused mainly on the tax, attention is now shifting to other recommendations by the group.

title: Pro Basketball;   Knicks Win Title In Spain
description: In 1493, Columbus returned here to tell the King he had discovered the riches of the New World, and almost five centuries later, the New York Knickerbockers tonight showed Barcelona an example of those riches: a professional basketball team from America paid $12 million a year and earning its money.

title: Japan's Shrewd New Investment Strategy . . .
description: From time to time over the last five years, economists played an intellectual game of calculating what might happen if Japanese institutions halted their massive purchases of United States Treasury bonds, issued to finance the yawning Federal budget deficits. It seemed a flight of fancy, since Japan's appetite for the securities seemed so vast. But last week the United States got a taste of the real thing.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIMITED PARTNER. By Mike Lupica. (Villard, $18.95.) Mike Lupica, a columnist for the daily sports newspaper The National, is back with his third mystery featuring Peter Finley, a street-smart, wisecracking New York television journalist. In ''Limited Partner,'' Finley decides to launch an investigation after his friend Bobby Wyman is found dead of a drug overdose. Wyman, a recovering addict and alcoholic, was also part owner of a fashionable Upper East Side watering hole. If he had any doubts, Finley is certain of foul play after Wyman's girlfriend is found dead the day after Wyman's funeral, also of an apparent overdose. The body count builds as Finley's search for his friend's killer takes him from trendy uptown bistros to an after-hours club in Greenwich Village. The trail eventually leads to an Upper West Side substance abuse center, where Finley encounters B. J. Remick, a fireballing New York Mets pitcher who happens to have a cocaine problem, and whose confessions point Finley toward a mildly surprising solution to Wyman's murder. Unfortunately, Mr. Lupica's Borscht-Belt one-liners mar ''Limited Partner,'' and his incessant name-dropping detracts from what might otherwise have been a pretty fair whodunit.

title: View of Sport;   Fifth Down or Not, It's Over When It's Over
description: Yogi Berra said it ain't over til it's over.

title: Campus Life: Princeton;   New Dorm Locks To Foil Intruders? Students Object
description: Many students at Princeton University are objecting to new electronic locks at all entrances to Forbes College, one of the university's five freshman and sophomore residential halls.

title: Accord Expected Soon on Farm Bill With $13 Billion in Savings
description: The House and Senate conference committee that is writing a new farm bill is close to agreeing to significant changes in the Government's commodity price support program that would save more than $13 billion over the next five years.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Making It Easier to Buy a Starter Home
description: LEAD: To stimulate sales at his 144-unit Fisherman's Wharf co-op in babylon, Steven Klar of East Meadow is offering a financing package that lets people buy the one- and two-bedroom units with no cash down.

title: Ann Tobin Is Married
description: Ann Tobin and W. Allen Churchill were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation in New York. The Rev. J. Douglas Ousley officiated. Mrs. Churchill, 52 years old, is a daughter of Edward J. Tobin of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Elizabeth K. Tobin. A graduate of the University of Washington, with an M.B.A. from Baruch College, she is a project coordinator at the New York University Medical Center. Mr. Churchill, 52, is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William R. Churchill. A graduate of Amherst College with a law degree from Columbia University, he is an independent real-estate consultant. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: 'Rational' Research Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: KIDS AND SCHOLARS AT WORK
description: What a wonderful feeling of nostalgia I had when I opened the pages of Bruce Weber's article ''Shhh! Kids and Scholars at Work'' (Sept. 23). The Hunts Point branch of the New York Public Library was where, more than 30 years ago, I first developed a love of books. How well I still remember the day when I was old enough to get a card to the adult section of the library and was able to go downstairs and browse in the cavernous and hushed room, with shelves full of books that reached from the ceiling to the floor. It was one of the milestones of my youth.

title: Fine Law Needs Fine-Tuning
description: The success of New York City's new campaign financing system in last year's mayoral election set a worthy example for Congress. That makes the City Council's sluggish response to proposed refinements all the more disappointing.

title: Perspectives: Modulars;   The Navy Yard Hosts a Housing Factory
description: The huge space known as Building 294A at the Brooklyn Navy Yard industrial center has seen assorted ship builders and repairers come and go. Now it is lending the services of its overhead cranes to residential construction.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Meteorology Becomes a Morality Play
description: LEAD: I DO not know about anyone else, but I'm getting to the point where I can't take the hassle of watching the local nightly news on television. Wars, uprisings, economic roller-coaster rides, gruesome crimes - none of that stuff pushes me over the edge. All of these things have been around since Mesopotamian days and unfortunately seem likely to continue.

title: Woman Wins Contest Then Is Disqualified

description: The Crown Prince of Kuwait suggested today that the country's defunct Parliament would be revived and free elections held if Kuwait is liberated from Iraqi troops.

title: Review/Music;   Remembering Britain's Finest Hour
description: Fifty years ago, Britain's Royal Air Force and the German Luftwaffe fought for air supremacy over the British Isles. The British prevailed despite being outnumbered three to one. To commemorate the Battle of Britain the BBC Concert Orchestra, the Central Band of the Royal Air Force, the BBC Singers and a handful of soloists put together an extravagant program of period pieces, marches, patriotic choral settings, music from war movies and new works. The massed forces - 129 performers in all - presented their tribute at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: Finding a reasonably priced restaurant with excellent food in the heart of Paris is almost a contradiction in terms. However, three trips to Paris in the last year demonstrate that a few steps from the main avenues are some first-rate eateries.

title: Abuse of Elderly a Hidden but Growing Issue
description: LEAD: ANNE, a woman in her 70's who has just returned home after surgery, pleads with her daughter, Patti, to help her stand up so that she can get to the bathroom.

title: Minnesota's Artful Indian Crafts
description: Minnesota's Native American population is largely invisible to travelers. Since little effort is made to promote local Indian culture, it is not surprising that few tourists visit the 11 reservations (4 Dakota, 7 Ojibway), attend annual powwows, or see anything for sale other than occasional tourist trinkets.

title: SWEPT AWAY
description: THIS SPACE WAS ORIGINALLY A DINGY HALLWAY AND NONDESCRIPT room in the designer Tom Britt's Manhattan apartment. ''I wanted to make it a guest room, but didn't want to spend the money on construction or on reparing the damaged walls to ready them for a good paint job,'' Britt explains. ''Tenting was the most econcomical solution.'' And tent the designer did. He used 350 yards of inexpensive cotton to drape the walls and ceilings, then trimmed the material with heavy black-and-white ribbon to lend an architectural outline. Strategically placed mirrors enforce a feeling of symmetry. Concealed behind some walls of fabric are storage areas, including room for a television and indirect lighting in the alcove. ''This was planned like a boat,'' says Britt. ''Every inch of space was used.''

title: Patricia Kopec Is Married
description: Patricia Talt Kopec and Herbert J. Kett were married in New York yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Louis I. Newman. Mrs. Kett is the president of the Buchanan Pharmacy in Peekskill, N.Y., and an adjunct professor of jurisprudence at the Albany College of Pharmacy. She and the bridegroom are former chairmen of the New York State Board of Pharmacy. Her first marriage ended in divorce and annulment. The bridegroom is the vice chairman and a director of Genovese Drug Storesin Melville, L.I. He was a widower.

Helping the Deaf in Fighting Addiction

title: Volume Buys
description: Playing symphonic music on a stereo system in your living room can defy the natural order of things. You have a hundred musicians fiddling, blowing and banging away in an area barely big enough for a small dinner party. Acoustically, this arrangement just doesn't add up. After all, the music was meant to be appreciated in a space large enough to hold an orchestra and perhaps a couple of thousand listeners. Hearing it in a scaled-down domestic setting creates a contradiction between sonic and architectural dimensions.

title: THE MAN BEHIND IRAQ'S SUPERGUN
description: If the details presented in Kevin Toolis's article ''The Man Behind Iraq's Supergun'' (Aug. 26) are correct, King Hussein of Jordan is akin to the boy who killed his parents and then threw himself on the mercy of the court because he was an orphan.

description: A lawyer representing the American hosts of a troupe of Cambodian dancers says he will file a lawsuit if the Government insists on interviewing the dancers to see if they wish to seek political asylum here.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED: Multiple Murder and the Elusive Search for Justice in an American Town. By Alan Gelb. (Dutton, $19.95.) The frustrating thing about nonfiction is that sometimes reasonable questions - like, why would a successful high school senior murder his family? - simply do not have reasonable answers. The novelist Alan Gelb lives in East Chatham, N.Y., on the very street where four people were killed in December 1986. In ''Most Likely to Succeed,'' Mr. Gelb eloquently conveys the sense of a town both secure and small; for example, the town justice who presided over a preliminary hearing is also a real-estate agent who later tried to sell the dead family's home. Through it all, however, 17-year-old Wyley Gates, the accused murderer, remains a shadow. Despite being vice president of his high school class, the boy was emotionally alone. His parents were divorced, Mr. Gelb writes, and Wyley resented his father's blue-collar work ethic. Compulsive about computers, Wyley was required to mow the lawn and get his hands dirty at his dad's machine shop, without pay. He especially disliked Cheryl Brahm, his father's longtime companion. Wyley was not close to his older brother, and objected to sharing a room with his 3-year-old orphaned nephew. In retrospect Wyley Gates's mental difficulties are obvious; dozens of better adjusted classmates apparently knew of and ignored Wyley's violent plans, Mr. Gelb writes. Although Wyley confessed to police within hours of the crime, procedural errors by investigators cast doubt upon his statement, and a jury acquitted Wyley Gates of murder.

title: Church Leaders Declare A 'Holy War' on Drugs
description: Churches have been havens in New York's poorer neighborhoods from the drug war raging on its ever-more violent streets. This weekend, 200 pastors and lay members of the United Methodist Church spent the weekend discussing how they can do even more.

description: As a public librarian of a library serving a distressed area, I was interested in the article ''Schools Preparing for Changes in Financing. ''

description: ALTHOUGH six judges are to be elected on November's ballot, four of the contests have already been settled. description: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED: Multiple Murder and the Elusive Search for Justice in an American Town. By Alan Gelb. (Dutton, $19.95.) title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JOYCE ANN BROWN: Justice Denied. By Joyce Ann Brown with Jay Gaines. (Noble Press, 213 West Institute Place, Suite 508, Chicago, Ill. 60610, Paper, $11.95.) In 1980, Joyce Ann Brown walked into a nightmare from which she did not emerge for nine years. Arrested and convicted of robbery and murder in connection with the holdup of a Dallas furrier, Ms. Brown was sentenced to life imprisonment. That she was innocent, that co-workers testified that she was at work during the crime, counted for nothing. The furrier's wife identified Ms. Brown in a lineup as one of two black women who had robbed the store and killed her husband; during her trial, an inmate Ms. Brown had befriended in jail after her arrest testified that Ms. Brown had bragged to her about the robbery. An all-white jury convicted Ms. Brown despite inconsistencies in testimony and a lack of fingerprints and other evidence linking her to the crime. In ''Joyce Ann Brown: Justice Denied,'' Ms. Brown and the freelance writer Jay Gaines outline her life before and during prison, the banal indignities guaranteed to dehumanize prisoners, and her survival through faith in God and a constant assertion of her innocence. Readers get a kind of crash course in life in a women's prison; what Ms. Brown does not voice is an obviously very controlled woman's inner feelings about being caught in a sinkhole in the justice system. Only once, when she is waiting to hear the verdict that will put her in prison for nine years, does she reveal her feelings: ''They wanted to find me guilty. I could see it in their eyes. I saw hatred for me on their faces.'' The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals overturned Ms. Brown's conviction in 1989, after her lawyers filed a writ alleging that prosecutors suppressed evidence and presented perjured testimony. Eventually, charges were dropped and Joyce Ann Brown was a free woman - minus nearly a decade of her life taken from her by the State of Texas.

title: Lisa Biagiarelli and Dave Pelland Are Married
description: Lisa Anne Biagiarelli was married yesterday at St. Emery's Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn., to Dave Pelland. Msgr. Bernard S. Scanlon and the Rev. Robert Nemeth officiated. The bride, who is keeping her name, is the daughter of Anne Biagiarelli of Easton, Conn., and the late Peter A. Biagiarelli. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pelland of Stratford, Conn. Ms. Biagiarelli, 26 years old, is a graduate of Fairfield University with a law degree from the University of Connecticut. She is the Easton tax collector and the president of the Easton Republican Women's Club. The bridegroom, 25, is a graduate of the School of Visual Arts. He is the communications specialist at the Corroon & Black Corporation, an insurance brokerage in New York, and the editor of the company's magazine, Commentator.

title: Does the Start Foretell the Finish?
description: Well begun is half done. That scrap of folk wisdom was imprinted on my tiny tabula rasa one dreary afternoon in childhood by a penmanship tyrant who required that it be copied out a hundred times in a fine, round Palmer Method hand. Experience has taught, however, that such copybook rules are more often hopeful than true. Certainly, anyone who has observed the foundering of many young musicians after spectacular debuts might want to rewrite the maxim: Well begun is well begun.

title: WHEN LIFE IS TOXIC
description: As a ''conventional'' physician who rejects the diagnosis of multiple chemical sensitivities as unscientific and unproved, I would refer your readers to a paper published Aug. 16 in The New England Journal of Medicine. The paper describes a study in which clinical ecologists administered either a suspected environmental toxin or a salt solution to patients. Neither doctors nor patients knew which substance was being given. Injections of salt solution ''provoked'' symptoms of chemical sensitivity as often as the suspected toxin, and ''neutralizing doses,'' given following a response, were determined to be equally efficacious whether the substance or salt water was injected.

title: History Lessons
description: In design, luxury takes many forms. At times, sheer grandeur has been the ideal, and we have fallen under the spell of rare woods, extravagant marbles and glimmering gold leaf. In other, perhaps more spiritual, times, harmony and proportion have been valued more highly than costly materials. But today, ask a resident of New York, London, Tokyo or any high-density city to define luxury, and the answer will be the same. True luxury is more room.

title: Some Plants Are Doubly Rewarding

And if they fulfill these criteria, they can be just about anything, from a silver nutmeg grater to a matchbox made out of the remnants of a samurai sword.

title: Works in Progress;   Picassos of Pachydermia
description: Certain artists can be fairly described as heavy. Suti, for example. The 6,500-pound African elephant wielding her trunk in the photograph above is one of three elephants in Chicago's Lincoln Park Zoo, all of whom have exhibited an inclination toward, if not exactly a talent for, painting. (Suti's work is shown below left; below right, a distinctly different sample from Bozie, an Asian elephant.) ''In the wild, animals will spend most of their time foraging for food,'' says Dr. Lester E. Fisher, director of the zoo. ''An elephant will spend a day just moving around eating. In captivity, we've restricted the size of their environment, so current zoo philosophy is to try and give them things to do. We give climbing animals a place to climb, swimming animals a place to swim.'' And painting animals? ''The painting is just another thing for them to do,'' Fisher says. ''We have people who spend most of the day with the elephants, basically just to keep them occupied.'' Indeed, keepers often teach them small tricks - picking one leg up, for instance - or involve them in activities like dragging carts around by a harness, so that they're used to interacting with humans and can be managed easily when they need medical treatment.

title: 3 Arab States Still Pursuing Peaceful Iraqi Pullout

title: Joint Venture
description: The doormat outside of number 36 is the only clue. indeed, unsuspecting visitors would believe that these adjoining houses are exactly as they were meant to be - two separate homes. But when the artist Frank Faulkner bought this 1840's building in upstate New York, he knew he needed lots of space in which to live and paint. ''These houses had been bought by a real estate developer as a speculative project,'' Faulkner recalls. ''One of them had been renovated, the other hadn't.'' Trying to make two houses into a coherent whole can be a tricky undertaking. Rather than make the union noticeable, Faulkner opted to take a subtle tack. The front of the building he left just as it had always been. The artist even kept the two main staircases, which run parallel to each other and share a wall. ''I was going to combine them into one large stair hall,'' Faulkner explains. ''But it would have been terribly expensive, and, in the end, the proportions would have seemed at odds with the rest of the house. So I decided to let it be exactly as it was, a quirky old Greek Revival house.'' The structural change Faulkner did make was to remove the front part of the main wall that divided the houses. He also combined the two narrow kitchens. As a result, it is obvious from the back of the building that the halves have been consolidated. Here, a porch supported by four columns extends into the garden. This outdoor space is Faulkner's summer living room, where he entertains and dines in warm weather.

title: Video Prepares For Life Minus A Few X's
description: For video the new NC-17 rating designated by the Motion Picture Association of America is made to order. The rating replaces the X, which, multiplied to XXX, had been usurped by pornographers. ''Under the old guidelines, the triple X confused the public about what the X was intended to mean,'' says Jack Messer, president of the Video Software Dealers Association. Rather than accept an X, violent or sexually explicit films of artistic merit like ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'' (reviewed at left) were released unrated in theaters. In the public's eye no rating means an X, and X usually means pornography.

title: Stretching Space
description: Space is like money. no matter how much you have, it never seems to be enough. Rooms have a magical way of shrinking as we demand more of a dwelling than was originally intended. Families grow, office clutter comes home to roost, possessions multiply while the dimensions of their surroundings do not. There are ways to stretch space, however, tricks to make every inch count. In some cases, simply reconfiguring a floor plan or using clever color and fabric schemes opens up an area. In others, construction may be necessary to enlarge or subdivide a room. Furniture designers are cutting corners by offering utilitarian objects scaled down for cramped interiors. Outdoors, combinations of plants help create a sense of bigness. Forgotten frontiers, such as front yards, can be transformed into colorful, chaotic cottage gardens. In fact, useful space often lurks in the most conspicuous spots. This issue looks at some obvious, as well as unconventional, approaches to stretching space, in ways that make the world seem like a bigger place.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: AN AMERICAN ROMANCE, by John Casey. (Avon, $9.95.) In his first novel, the author of ''Spartina'' told the story of Mac and Anya, two outsiders in love who go to Iowa for a brief attempt at regional theater and life on a commune. When it was published in 1977, John Leonard said in The Times: ''It respects characters. It swims in the language. It is knowing and rich. . . . Mr. Casey in his lavish way makes me feel better about the future of the novel.'' Avon has also reissued Mr. Casey's 1979 collection of short fiction, TESTIMONY AND DEMEANOR ($8.95). Mr. Leonard said it is written with ''intelligence, verve, suppleness and lyric precision.''

title: Japanese Pickles or Preserves: So Nice With Rice
description: The heart of a traditional Japanese meal is a bowl of hot, freshly cooked rice and a side dish of tsukemono, or pickled vegetables. Tsukudani, which are varieties of fish, shellfish and seaweed that have been preserved by slow cooking in soy sauce and sugar, are also a popular accompaniment to rice. While pickling and preserving certainly prolong the goodness of fresh foods, these techniques transform the flavors and even the textures of vegetables and seafoods, giving them a gustatory appeal that often far surpasses that of the original ingredient.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DEADLY TRIPLETS: A Theatre Mystery and Journal. By Adrienne Kennedy. (University of Minnesota, $14.95.) For her first novel, the talented playwright Adrienne Kennedy has had the intriguing idea of infusing her theatrical experiences in London with a Gothic sensibility and transforming them into a mystere a clef. With a protagonist who appears to be a thinly disguised substitute for the author, the narrative circles around a female playwright's relationship with a troubled film actor trying his hand at a modern revenge play called ''Deadly Triplets.'' The actor promises to help the playwright unearth the secret of her adopted mother's apparently mysterious death, but instead involves her in his own demise. In spite of Ms. Kennedy's avowed admiration for Conan Doyle, Christie and du Maurier, and in spite of the book's echoes of Charlotte Bronte, even a casual reader of mysteries may sense the author's discomfort with the genre. Omens, portents and presages abound in a volume of just 124 pages; whenever there's a need to heighten tension, a character leaves the country. The mystery of the mother's death is cast aside almost as a red herring, and the central character's present-tense life is left largely undramatized and unexplored. In the end, most of the book's interest turns out to be voyeuristic: one wonders just how much of it is autobiographical. Running throughout is an obsession with fame and famous people, which eventually finds its rightful place in a series of thumbnail sketches appended to the end of the novel. In this ''journal,'' Ms. Kennedy paints precise portraits of such luminaries as Edward Albee, Joseph Losey and Fay Weldon, and tells a classic story of betrayal in the theater. It seems that she had adapted John Lennon's ''nonsense books'' into a play that was eventually given a tryout at the National Theater. Laurence Olivier held her hand throughout the performance, then decided that Lennon, not she, should do the adaptation when the project was resumed a few months later. It is in these sharp sketches and telling anecdotes that Ms. Kennedy's considerable talents are most evident.

Gibson, around second, is in trouble. Van Slyke is up and throws a strike to Jay Bell who whirls, and with crucial accuracy duplicates Van Slyke's perfect peg, to double up Gibson by a wide and humiliating four or five feet! Russell Baker's recent comment, that ''heroes are pretty well all washed up in America these days,'' arose from his contemplation of the tarnished public image of Washington Mayor Marion S. title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ONE FELL SLOOP. By Susan Kenney. (Viking, $16.95.) Forgive the puns, the novel's title being the least painful, with its double - no, triple - meaning. Ignore the parenthetical remarks that pockmark, and often pothole, every page. Overlook the repeated descriptions of the heroine's lover, with his ''tall, broad figure'' and his ''much-too-clever, faunlike face.'' What is left at the heart of Susan Kenney's new mystery is a pleasant howdunit. The third in a series featuring an English professor named Rosamund (Roz) Howard, ''One Fell Sloop'' sets this reluctant sleuth to battle an overbearing Scotsman, Alan Stewart, an intellectually and physically well-endowed paleobotonist, and her own highly developed insecurities during a holiday sail around Maine's Penobscot Bay. It is after a ''flaming row'' (''she had gone up in smoke; he had simply gone ashen'') that the two find a murdered body on the beach of a deserted island, with one set of footprints, apparently those of the deceased. The timing couldn't be better. While local authorities dismiss the death as accidental, Roz and Alan can stow their personal angst and concentrate on solving the who, what, when, where, why and, most important, how of the murder. They do this by engaging in seemingly endless theorizing; interviewing the obligatory eccentric Maine characters; confronting one suspect in an amusing, martini-laced scene, and staging a lovers' reconciliation that signals the start of the novel's worthwhile, action-filled ending.

title: A Time of Confusion Draws the Arab World Into Soul-Searching

The massacre at Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem last Monday, in which the Israeli police killed at least 21 Palestinians during a riot, has further inflamed Arab emotions already driven to new peaks by the Gulf crisis. But it has done little to clarify the entanglements, confusion and discord unleashed by the invasion of Kuwait and the arrival of an enormous American-led military force in Saudi Arabia, clearly prepared for battle with Iraq.

But you did not describe what it's like for the family of such a person - the strain of living with an always increasing set of rules, the guilt when you cause a loved one to suffer because a rule was forgotten or because no rule yet existed. I wasn't up to the life and now live alone.

title: Chipping Away at the Disk Drive
description: COMPUTER chip makers have long been hoping that silicon chips would one day supplant disk drives. The Intel Corporation last week moved a step in that direction by introducing a card packed with memory chips that it hopes will be used in place of disk drives on laptop and notebook computers. Unlike the semiconductor memory chips built into computers, the 16 chips embedded into Intel's memory card do not lose their data when the power is turned off. The memory cards, each about the size of a credit card, are far faster, smaller and more energy efficient than disk drives. Intel is charging $300 for a memory card that can store one megabyte. A card that holds 4 megabytes costs $1,200. A 20-megabyte hard disk drive sells for as little as $150.

description: THE name a Small Company in America defines only two aspects of this theater group in Sea Cliff. As its current production of two one-act American operas proves, the company has big ambitions and the talent to move ahead.

title: Call of the Wildmen
description: It was Spring in the Emerald Hill country of North Texas, a region of rolling fields clotted with purple asters, mustard and black-eyed Susans. Signs that hung beside the white-rail fences of prosperous-looking ranches boasted of the breeds of cattle raised there, Brangus and Herefords and Santa Gertrudis. One sign, as vast as a billboard, said, ''Polled Herefords: the Big Bold Breed.'' At a freshly plowed field, I turned off the blacktop onto a muddy ranch road, following directions to something called the Wildman Gathering, a weekend of outdoor living that, the brochure promised, would put me in touch with my ''deep masculinity.''

title: Le Duc Tho, Top Hanoi Aide, Dies at 79
description: Le Duc Tho, the chief North Vietnamese negotiator at the Paris talks that led to the 1973 Vietnam cease-fire agreement and the withdrawal of the last American troops from Vietnam, died yesterday at Army Hospital 108 in Hanoi, the press attache of the Vietnam's United Nations mission, Le Dong, said yesterday. Mr. Tho was 79 years old.

title: Mixed Response Over Campaign To End Smoking
description: The sweeping anti-smoking campaign started recently by Mayor David N. Dinkins is being hailed by health groups, derided by tobacco lobbyists and greeted with a wait-and-see chorus from other groups.

description: Two of the three most coveted titles in world play are the Olympiad Teams and the Open Pairs. In the past 15 years United States representatives have won three titles out of a possible eight. But matching this record, and beating all the European countries put together, is Brazil.

description: Lynn Anne Pantano, a daughter of Mrs. Lester L. Coleman and Carl A. Pantano, both of New York, was married yesterday to Stuart Charles Dale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Dale of Medfield, Mass. The Rev. Henry A. Boyle performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in York.

title: College Football: Local;   Hofstra Steamrolls To 7th Victory
description: Wayne Morris, Al Hagofsky and Brian McGee each scored two touchdowns as undefeated Hofstra, No. 1 in the East in Division III of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, crushed Catholic University, 43-6, yesterday afternoon in Washington.

title: Improved Routes Sought for Hikers
description: LEAD: HIKERS on the Long Island Greenbelt Trail where it crosses Sweetbriar Farm in Smithtown normally find themselves walking in a field of three-foot-high goldenrod and in a forest filled with chipmunks and cardinals.

title: Cut the Deficit, Not the Dividend
description: After years of pretending that the Federal budget deficit wasn't much of a problem, Congress is poised to plunge fanatically in the other direction, as though it had no other duty than deficit reduction. But Americans can walk and chew gum at the same time. They need to see the deficit reduced, but they also need to invest in disadvantaged children, rebuild dilapidated infrastructure and save the despoiled environment.

title: Pro Hockey;   Injuries Mar Trottier's Return
description: For Islander fans, it was nice while it lasted, and the good part lasted for about half an hour.

description: I am moved to respond to the article ''The Role Slides Play in Judging Art'' [Sept. 30] , since my work was mentioned and I have also given thought to this very matter.

title: Style Makers;   John Frieda, Hairdresser
description: A good hair style is more than a good cut, says John Frieda, who has three salons in London and recently opened one in New York.

Rabbi Reuven Siegel performed the ceremony at the Union League Club. The bride, 28 years old, is keeping her name. A graduate of the University of Michigan with a law degree from New York University, she is an associate at the law firm of White & Case in New York. Her father is a nuclear project engineer at Westinghouse in Pittsburgh. Her mother, Phyllis Oper, is a teacher.

description: In his previous stint in another town, he always seemed to be waiting for the phone to ring. Or the other shoe to drop. Or the sky to fall.

Northeast Notebook: Owings Mills, Md.;

Houses Start A 429-Acre 'New Town'
description: LEAD: After four years of planning and financial reverses, houses are at last going up in Owings Mills New Town, a 429-acre planned unit development just northwest of Baltimore.

title: He Shot the Corpse
description: THE LAST FRAME. By Jim Wright. (Carroll & Graf, $16.95.) It takes an intimate knowledge of the newspaper business to create an authentic tough-guy news photographer like Will Carver. Accused of dressing like an overturned dumpster and living life hiding behind his camera, the hero of Jim Wright's first novel, ''The Last Frame,'' leaps moral quandaries and midlife crises in a single bound. When one of his good friends is shot dead, Carver climbs on a counter and takes pictures of the corpse. A cop at the scene pulls him away and asks how he can do such a thing. Carver gives the perfect news photographer's reply: ''When he was alive, Officer, he was my friend. . . . When he died, he became news.'' This funny and quick-paced mystery takes a disrespectful but loving look at both New York and the news photographers who eke out a living there. Carver's ethics are so borderline that no newspaper will hire him full time, but one of the tabloids uses him on a freelance basis. This is the photo equivalent of piecework: no pictures, no money. Need, combined with a genuine journalistic curiosity, entangles Mr. Wright's hero with a sleazy crowd of blackmailers and murderers. Carver's New York is Manhattan - the Strand bookstore, McSorley's Old Ale House, Greenwich Village. He sleeps regularly under a desk in a Lower East Side station house. What gives the book its kick is the way Mr. Wright, the metropolitan editor of The Bergen Record, understands the business of news photography. So when Carver finds himself in the nightmarish position of witnessing a murder without his camera in hand, it's a sure sign that, at age 40, something is going wrong with his life. But no matter how much Carver questions, no matter how much he threatens to quit the photo game, no one should believe him. He is truly addicted. Readers should be, too.

title: Leafy Refuges Near Jakarta
description: Low-Lying Jakarta is not noted for its salubrious climate, especially in the hot season from May to September, and things were considerably worse during the early days of Dutch occupation. Starting around 1730, the capital (then known as Batavia) was devastated by a series of malarial epidemics, and for the better part of a century - until the population began moving out of its original walled center - both rulers and ruled filled the local cemeteries in appalling numbers.

title: Max Kennedy to Wed Victoria Strauss
description: July wedding plans for Victoria Anne Strauss and Matthew Maxwell Taylor Kennedy, a son of Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy of McLean, Va., and the late Mr. Kennedy, have been made known by Ms. Strauss's parents, Bonnie Strauss Gould of Los Angeles and Benjamin Strauss of Haverford, Pa.

title: Virginia Governor Baffles Democrats With Crusade for 'New Mainstream'
description: With the fervor of an evangelist and with his eyes seemingly on a larger prize, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder has embarked on a nationwide crusade for the political moderation that helped him become the first black ever elected chief executive of an American state.

title: Take 6 Spreads the Gospel - Pure and A Cappella
description: With a harmonic blend of jazz, pop and church-inspired traditions, the a cappella gospel singers Take 6 have single-handedly revived the creative joy of the vocal group.

title: 'L'Atalante,' a Slow Boat Bound for Lasting Fame
description: When Jean Vigo's ''Atalante'' opens Friday at the Lincoln Plaza, a new generation of Americans will finally have the chance to see the film that Francois Truffaut, among other directors, called ''a masterpiece'' - but in a restored print rather than one of the cut versions that have been circulating since 1934. For until Gaumont, the original French distributor of ''L'Atalante,'' undertook its restoration in 1989, Vigo's poetic tale of newlyweds on a barge had a rocky distribution history.

description: Pinpointing superior design is the aim of the annual Grand Prix Awards sponsored by Audio-Video International, a prominent trade journal. An earlier column discussed the winning television sets. The spotlight now turns to the video recorders singled out for their special merit in a nationwide poll of video dealers.

title: Change in California Loosens Congressman's Grip
description: When George E. Brown Jr. first entered Congress 27 years ago, orchards of oranges covered the Inland Empire of Southern California, the air was so clear one could see the San Gabriel Mountains on most days and Democratic victories were as reliable as the warm desert sun.

title: A City Carousel
description: ''The magic is back'' reads a poster announcing today's reopening of the colorful hand-carved carousel in Brooklyn's Prospect Park. And the vibrant result of the yearlong face-lift is magical indeed.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Meteorology Becomes a Morality Play
description: LEAD: I DO not know about anyone else, but I'm getting to the point where I can't take the hassle of watching the local nightly news on television. Wars, uprisings, economic roller-coaster rides, gruesome crimes - none of that stuff pushes me over the edge. All of these things have been around since Mesopotamian days and unfortunately seem likely to continue.

title: Recession Signs
description: To the Editor:

title: College Football;   Ga. Tech Outlasts Clemson
description: Georgia Tech and Clemson played one of those top-this-if-you-can football games today in which every big play was followed by another big play. Surely the spirited, colorful and record crowd of 46,066 donning bright yellow and orange was weary and so were both teams when with 59 seconds left, Clemson's Chris Gardocki booted a 60-yard field-goal attempt. It sailed and spun and fluttered wide right before falling just short of the goal post.

title: After the Volcano Exploded
description: A STAR among volcanoes, Krakatoa, in Indonesia, erupted in 1883. The explosions were heard thousands of miles away; a tidal wave 120 feet high devastated the shores of neighboring islands, Java and Sumatra, killing 36,000 people.

Cantor Wayne Siet and Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum of FederAL District Court, Manhattan, a cousin of the bride, officiated. The bride, who is keeping her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Cherney of Merrick, L.I. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bernstein of Forest Hills, Queens.

description: With the World Series only two days away, it seems appropriate that at this moment a very hot fashion item is the baseball cap, though one with a difference.

title: If Only Ducks Were Sold in Parts
description: NO one thinks twice about buying chicken in parts, but few places will sell you duck legs or breasts separately. This is too bad, for when it comes to cooking duck, most people do it one way: in the oven. The problem with roasting is that when the legs are done, the breast is often dry. If the breast is pink, the legs are red.

title: WHEN LIFE IS TOXIC
description: Reinhold points out in his article that 70 to 80 percent of patients seeking treatment for environmental illness are women with histories of psychological problems. That women may be more chemically sensitive should come as no surprise: women bear most of the chemical exposure of contraception, in the form of the pill and spermicidal jellies and foams. They are more likely to handle household-cleaning and laundry products. They are exposed daily to cosmetics, perfumes and hair-grooming products.

It drives me absolutely nuts.'' His performance of Noel Coward's song ''Nina'' would probably give his music professors conniptions.

But such political ammunition is being hauled out in the Fifth District battle between a popular three-term Waterbury Alderman, Gary A. Franks, the Republican candidate, and a former Congressman and television newscaster, Toby Moffett, the Democratic nominee.

title: T. C. Nelson Weds Anna Spangler
description: Anna Wildy Spangler and Thomas Craig Nelson, 1988 graduates of the Harvard Business School and partners in the Wakefield Group, a venture capital firm in Charlotte, N.C., were married yesterday. The Rev. Stephen Elkins-Williams performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Chapel of the Cross in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: OUT OF SIGHT
description: IN ANY NEW YORK APARTMENT, STORAGE IS THE KEY,'' explains Fred Imberman, one of the owners of the Kentshire Galleries, a Manhattan antiques shop. ''This was originally a formal dining room, but then we had two kids and began running out of space.'' With the help of the New York decorator Hariet Eckstein and Ray Coggins, an antiques dealer in Westbury, England, the room was reconfigured to include a library as well. Architectural columns were imported from an old house in Bath, England, and pine bookshelves were designed to incorporate them. Cabinets hold electronic equipment. Even the columns open up, revealing the family's record collection.

title: Samuel Brownell, 90, Ex-Education Official, Dies
description: Samuel M. Brownell, a one-time Nebraska high school teacher who became the United States Commissioner of Education in the 1950's and later served as Superintendent of Schools in Detroit, died Friday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in New Haven.

title:

Reducing Jail Costs By Helping Accused
description: LEAD: ABOUT 16 years ago a new group began turning up at the local and county courts: representatives from the Pre-Trial Services Institute of Westchester, there to give the judges advice on which of the hundreds of accused criminals should be released without bail.

title: Corrections
