title: 2 People Injured in Subway In Separate Attacks Friday
description: Two people were injured in separate attacks at subway stations in Manhattan and Brooklyn on Friday, the police said.

title: Susan Bernhardi, Lawyer, Marries
description: Susan Mary Bernhardi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Bernhardi of Seaford, L.I., was married last evening in New York to David Evan Sternberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius R. Sternberg of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Robert Allman , a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Bennett Hermann performed an interdenominational ceremony at the Westbury.

title: Latin Immigrants Turn to South Fork
description: LEAD: THOUSANDS of young Spanish-speaking immigrants, many of them illegal aliens, are flocking to the South Fork. There they work in motels and restaurants and for landscaping companies. On Sundays newcomers play soccer in Montauk.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WEST HAVEN;

Shrubs and Dreams Are Nurtured in Rhododendron Revival
description: LEAD: WEST HAVEN is a city with horrendous sewage problems, a budget deficit, one of the highest tax rates in the state and a moribund downtown. It is also a city without a label. It lacks the sort of pretty epithet that makes Norwich the Rose City, Middletown the Forest City or Bridgeport the Park City.

title: Raising the Architectural Ante In California
description: Few careers in architecture are as vexing as that of Michael Graves. From academic modernist in the 70's to post-modernist superstar in the 80's, he could turn in the 90's into a venerable elder statesman or a tired has-been. It's a matter not only of Mr. Graves's architecture but of our architectural culture, of which his career has for years been a kind of crucible. He rode the wave of architectural celebrity as it mounted in the early 1980's, becoming almost a cult figure after his first large-scale works, the Portland Building in Portland, Ore., and the headquarters of Humana Inc. in Louisville, Ky., were completed. He argued persuasively for an expanded role for the architect, designing everything from furniture to teakettles, although when he turned to Bloomingdale's shopping bags, he seemed less like a man eager to broaden the arena of serious design than one willing to put his name on anything that could be sold.

title: A Land of Immigrants Gets Uneasy About Immigration
description: The incidents span a decade and a continent: Gulf Coast fishermen in Texas harass Vietnamese competitors who are catching more shrimp. A Florida supermarket manager suspends a cashier for speaking Spanish at work. Residents of a Maryland community protest the establishment of a Japanese junior college near the Chesapeake Bay. Two Los Angeles suburbs try to require Chinese store owners to put up English signs. A Massachusetts gubernatorial candidate, John Silber, asks, ''Why should Lowell be the Cambodian capital of America?''

title: Nets Stopped By Rain
description: A basketball game postponed by rain? Unless it is played outdoors, it could never happen. Try again. Anything is possible with the Nets, including the cancellation of a game because of precipitation.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: On Language;   Larger Than Life
description: Charlton Heston was on the phone. ''I'm having an argument with Michael Korda about the copy on the dust jacket of my book, 'Beijing Diary,' '' he began, in the most sonorous voice you ever heard. Mr. Korda, author of ''Success,'' ''Power'' and other books (he hasn't used ''Happiness'' yet - presumably, a non-selling title), is editor in chief of Simon & Schuster, and not a man to lightly joust with on jacket copy.

title: Israelis Jail Officer Who Declined to Serve
description: An Israeli officer who told his soldiers his conscience would not permit him to serve in the occupied Gaza Strip was jailed for 35 days beginning today.

title: What on Earth Is the Guggenheim Up To?
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City is to all outward appearances on hiatus, closed to visitors for another year, until construction ends on an annex. But in fact a kind of revolution is under way there, one that could have an impact well beyond the walls of Frank Lloyd Wright's spiral building - one that it is no exaggeration to say could alter the way art museums across the country do business and visitors experience these places.

title:
DINING OUT;

New Owner for a Stylish Bistro in Nyack
description: LEAD: THIS Hudson House should not be mistaken for another restaurant in the area bearing that name. Any confusion comes from Matthew Hudson's determination to use his family name for the stylish bistro (last occupied by Raoul's) that he and his wife, Amy, own in the heart of downtown Nyack.

title: Dr. Gail Sorrel Weds Gary Mosk
description: Dr. Gail Patrice Sorrel and Gary Alan Mosk were married last evening at the Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y., by Cantor Raymond Smolover. Mrs. Mosk is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome M. Sorrel of Scarsdale, N.Y. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mosk of West Hills, Calif.

title: In Some Fights, Quitting Is Harder Than Joining In
description: Of the panoply of issues the United States and the Soviet Union still face if they are to put the Cold War completely behind them, none appear more nettlesome than resolving the longstanding civil wars fought by their clients in Afghanistan, Angola and Cambodia.

title: What's Adultery? A Little Sex, A Lot of Politics
description: What Jane Austen did for marriage in the 19th century, film makers are doing for adultery today. In the past few weeks alone, eight films from seven countries have offered a view of infidelity around the world. It is an unmistakable sign of a turbulent social era.

title: Older Pilots Take to the Skies
description: LEAD: WHEN Peter Reilly retired as a corporate executive, he turned full time to his passion for flying. That interest has grown into Cardinal Aviation Limited, a flying school, at Sikorsky Memorial Airport, in Stratford.

title:
ART;

'On Home Ground': Recalling Era of American Impressionism
description: LEAD: WHAT the Catskill Mountains are to the monumental Hudson River School of painting, the Connecticut shore is to American Impressionism. The Bruce Museum, in Greenwich, is advantageously located for presenting exhibitions that recall the Impressionist period from the turn of the century into the 1920's.

title:
DINING OUT;

Dishes in the Elegant Hong Kong Style
description: LEAD: ON the business card of Hunan Kitchen II are the words ''Uncommon Chinese cuisine presented in an Oriental wonderland.'' Restaurants often resort to hyperbole, but in the case of this Mercer County Chinese restaurant the words are nearer the truth than in many other restaurants.

title: Review/Music;   Schumann And Antics Of a Sad Poet
description: One hears much lamentation these days to the effect that the art of lieder is either moribund or dead. Although that may seem an alarmist view, it could certainly be argued that fewer singers are devoted to the art than in the past; that today's large concert halls are not the ideal places for performances so intimate, and that the form appeals, increasingly, to an audience with very specialized tastes.

title: Tenderhearted Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: Travelers are advised that the electrical power in Mexico is the same as in the United States and that they can bring their traveling appliances. There is, however, a problem, which we encountered on a recent trip to Manzanillo and Ixtapa.

title: Elsa Delgado Is Married
description: Dr. Elsa M. Delgado, a research fellow in ophthalmology at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, and Dr. Keith B. Raskin, a hand and microsurgeon, were married last evening at the Rainbow Room Pavilion in New York by Rabbi Joel Goor. The bride, 29 years old, is the daughter of Dr. Lucie Delgado and Dr. Francis Delgado of Neuchatel, Switzerland. Dr. Raskin, 33, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Raskin of Madison, N.J.

title: Hanoi's Foreign Minister Works the U.S. Circuit Seeking End to Trade Ban
description: Like a salesman opening up a new territory, Nguyen Co Thach, Vietnam's peripatetic Foreign Minister, is knocking on doors and seeking friends among America's members of Congress, diplomats, scholars and bankers, in the hope of ending Washington's trade embargo against his country.

title: Ellen G. Glazer and Paul Feinsot Wed
description: Ellen Gaye Glazer, the daughter of Barbara Glazer of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Louis Glazer of Memphis, was married last evening in New York to Paul Feinsot, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Feinsot of New York. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated at Delmonico's restaurant. Mrs. Feinsot graduated from New York University and is a law student at Hofstra University, where she is an editor of The Property Law Journal. Her father is an anesthesiologist. Her mother is a New York City school teacher.

title: Bevy of New Magazines That Look at the Local
description: LEAD: DO you ever wonder what happened to the Fordham Baldies, a group of toughs from the Bronx of the 1950's and 60's? Or does an environmental scavenger hunt interest you? Perhaps you are a newly arrived Japanese business executive who wants to learn more about Dolley Madison. There are local publications, begun recently, that could meet each of these needs.

title: Years Later, Actress Finds She's in a Hit
description: LEAD: IN 1898, Sarah Christie decided she wanted to act. So at the tender age of 5, she organized a theater troupe; the children who did not perform paid a dozen straight pins to watch.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Woodridge, Ill.;

A Housing Mix For 395 Acres
description: LEAD: So far, more than 100 of a projected 304 single-family houses have been built and sold.

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Should Win M.V.P., Cy Young Awards?
description: In the American League, Rickey Henderson. He led the league in on-base percentage (.439), runs scored (119), stolen bases (65); was second in batting (.325) and slugging average (.577); fourth in walks with 97 and sixth in home runs with 28. Roger Clemens (21-6) deserves the Cy Young. Bob Welch (27-7) allowed more than a run per nine innings more than Clemens, and Clemens had 82 more strikeouts (209 to 127) and 23 fewer walks (54 to 77) than Welch. Welch's winning percentage was only 15.8 percentage points higher than the A's winning percentage, while Clemens' winning percentage was 23.8 percentage points higher than that of the Red Sox.

title: Chronology of 15 Years Of Civil War in Lebanon
description: July 1, 1978 Syrian troops attack Christians in the worst fighting in two years.

title: If Only Ducks Were Sold in Parts
description: NO one thinks twice about buying chicken in parts, but few places will sell you duck legs or breasts separately. This is too bad, for when it comes to cooking duck, most people do it one way: in the oven. The problem with roasting is that when the legs are done, the breast is often dry. If the breast is pink, the legs are red.

title: Jogger Knocked Down; Attack Is Called Racial
description: A jogger from Los Angeles, in New York on her honeymoon, was knocked to the ground in Central Park yesterday by three girls in what the police are calling a racial-bias incident.

title: Dinkins Aide Denies Image of 'Confusion'
description: The Dinkins administration has a firm grip on New York City's fiscal and labor problems, despite the impression of ''some confusion,'' an aide to the Mayor told municipal union officers yesterday.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Where to Seek a Meal Downtown
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some places to dine in lower Manhattan.

title: An Aversion to Taxing Taxable Substances
description: Canadians routinely pay more than $30 for a carton of cigarettes. Italians pay more than $5 for a gallon of gasoline. Danes not only pay $1.50 plus deposit for a store-bought bottle of beer but face such high prices for cigarettes - close to $4 a pack - that a Danish embassy spokesman, Bent Skou, says ''nobody in his right mind'' buys a whole carton at once.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: The ritual has begun: rake or blow leaves off the lawn; start a new compost pile. Finish planting of container-grown perennials and evergreens. Bulb planting goes on. Keep mowing as long as the grass is growing. Water evergreens and young fruit trees. Allow some leaves to accumulate over flower borders as a mulch.

title: WHEN LIFE IS TOXIC
description: The several case studies of people with multiple chemical sensitivities, described in Robert Reinhold's article ''When Life Is Toxic'' (Sept. 16), show not so much the pathos of their condition as the eccentricities, the socially aberrant personalities that result. Reinhold goes to considerable lengths to report their bizarre coping strategies (eating bear meat, wearing ''Canary Clothes'') and the equally bizarre (I would agree) treatments being used in some cases - controversial therapies to reduce intolerance to chemicals.

title: WHEN LIFE IS TOXIC
description: As a ''conventional'' physician who rejects the diagnosis of multiple chemical sensitivities as unscientific and unproved, I would refer your readers to a paper published Aug. 16 in The New England Journal of Medicine. The paper describes a study in which clinical ecologists administered either a suspected environmental toxin or a salt solution to patients. Neither doctors nor patients knew which substance was being given. Injections of salt solution ''provoked'' symptoms of chemical sensitivity as often as the suspected toxin, and ''neutralizing doses,'' given following a response, were determined to be equally efficacious whether the substance or salt water was injected.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: Finding a reasonably priced restaurant with excellent food in the heart of Paris is almost a contradiction in terms. However, three trips to Paris in the last year demonstrate that a few steps from the main avenues are some first-rate eateries.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SAVING THE FALCONS

title: Question Of the Week;   Who Should Win M.V.P., Cy Young Awards?
description: In the American League, Rickey Henderson. He led the league in on-base percentage (.439), runs scored (119), stolen bases (65); was second in batting (.325) and slugging average (.577); fourth in walks with 97 and sixth in home runs with 28. Roger Clemens (21-6) deserves the Cy Young. Bob Welch (27-7) allowed more than a run per nine innings more than Clemens, and Clemens had 82 more strikeouts (209 to 127) and 23 fewer walks (54 to 77) than Welch. Welch's winning percentage was only 15.8 percentage points higher than the A's winning percentage, while Clemens' winning percentage was 23.8 percentage points higher than that of the Red Sox.

title: No Lenin, No Marx and, Just Maybe, No Communist Party in Prague
description: In his faded jeans and blue, short-sleeved polo shirt sporting a ''Levis'' label, Vasil Mohorita, a tall 38-year-old, looks nothing like his grizzled, somber-suited predecessors.

title: For a Bold Approach to Parking
description: An article in the Sept. 23 issue [''At Larchmont Station, Angry Out-of-Towners''] once again pointed out the problem of parking at Metro-North stations, particularly in Larchmont.

title:
RECORDINGS;

More Than a Soupcon Of a French Musical Menu
description: LEAD: Exponent of lyre, lute and love poetry, the French record label Erato has joined with Radio France to produce compact disks illustrating five centuries of French music. The first 10 titles (of which five are discussed here) do indeed stretch over 500 years of French musical culture. Plans are already afoot to extend the series into the Middle Ages, so that the final scope will be more like eight centuries.

title: 'The Ice-Shirt'
description: Imagine a performance of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle directed by Sam Peckinpah, with a new libretto by J. R. R. Tolkien and occasional music by Aaron Copland, and you'll be getting the feel of this ambitious, often enthralling novel about the Vikings' arrival in North America, in the blissful place they called Vinland, circa A.D. 1000. ''The Ice-Shirt'' contains notes and glossaries indicating that William T. Vollmann has drawn on medieval Norse sagas, legends of the Micmac Indians and Greenland Inuit, and his own travels along the North Atlantic seaboard. But his main source seems to be his powerful imagination, with which he imposes a unifying theme on this mass of material.

title: Stalking Fate With a School Bell and Clock
description: Among the more irritating creatures in a world full of them are those theatergoers who tell you, just after the curtain has come down, ''You really should have seen the London production.'' Or, ''It was a lot better before the producer moved it uptown.'' Or, ''Trust me. With the original lead, it was a different show entirely.''

title:
All About/Car Rental Companies;

Airline and Vacation Blues Spell Trouble
description: LEAD: After nine years of rapid growth and improving profits, car rental companies have hit a pothole. The air travel boom that propelled car rentals for most of the 1980's contracted slightly late in the decade and is now seriously threatened by the rising air fares resulting from increasing fuel costs.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Stack's, one of New York's premier coin dealers will celebrate its 55th anniversary with an auction of the Allen F. Lovejoy collection of dimes. Mr. Lovejoy began his collection in the 1930's and preceeded to garner dimes of each date and mint from 1796 to 1940.

title: Fair Trial at Issue In Courtroom TV
description: LEAD: A STATE law allowing cameras in courtrooms is being tested on Long Island, where the decision of a Suffolk County Court judge to ban television coverage of the trial of a man from Stony Brook charged with raping and murdering a 14-year-old has raised questions about balancing the guarantees of free speech with the right to a fair trial.

title: Monster of Irony
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: Full-Nesters;   Playground Time
description: The glacial-rock formations that gave Martin Ginsburg the idea of calling his condominium development in Greenburgh, N.Y., the Boulders do not, at first sight, suggest an easy playing field for children. But then, Mr. Ginsburg explains, the idea was for the Boulders to attract empty-nesters who would move into his quarter-million-dollar-and-up condominiums only after their kids had grown up and left home.

title: Mazeroski's Moment
description: Of the millions of youths who dreamed about it, of the hundreds of thousands who played professional baseball, of the thousands who made it to the major leagues, only one player has ever hit a home run to win the seventh game of a World Series.

title: Remembering a Tortured Child Who Lived in the Streets of Guatemala City
description: The marble tombstone erected here last week for Nahaman Carmona Lopez says more about his death than his short life: ''I only wanted to be a child and they wouldn't let me.''

title: Marianne Tracy Has a Wedding
description: Marianne Kathleen Tracy and Richard Mark Vandervoorn were married yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. S. B. Matarazzo.

title:
DINING OUT;

Dishes in the Elegant Hong Kong Style
description: LEAD: ON the business card of Hunan Kitchen II are the words ''Uncommon Chinese cuisine presented in an Oriental wonderland.'' Restaurants often resort to hyperbole, but in the case of this Mercer County Chinese restaurant the words are nearer the truth than in many other restaurants.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JOYCE ANN BROWN: Justice Denied. By Joyce Ann Brown with Jay Gaines. (Noble Press, 213 West Institute Place, Suite 508, Chicago, Ill. 60610, Paper, $11.95.) In 1980, Joyce Ann Brown walked into a nightmare from which she did not emerge for nine years. Arrested and convicted of robbery and murder in connection with the holdup of a Dallas furrier, Ms. Brown was sentenced to life imprisonment. That she was innocent, that co-workers testified that she was at work during the crime, counted for nothing. The furrier's wife identified Ms. Brown in a lineup as one of two black women who had robbed the store and killed her husband; during her trial, an inmate Ms. Brown had befriended in jail after her arrest testified that Ms. Brown had bragged to her about the robbery. An all-white jury convicted Ms. Brown despite inconsistencies in testimony and a lack of fingerprints and other evidence linking her to the crime. In ''Joyce Ann Brown: Justice Denied,'' Ms. Brown and the freelance writer Jay Gaines outline her life before and during prison, the banal indignities guaranteed to dehumanize prisoners, and her survival through faith in God and a constant assertion of her innocence. Readers get a kind of crash course in life in a women's prison; what Ms. Brown does not voice is an obviously very controlled woman's inner feelings about being caught in a sinkhole in the justice system. Only once, when she is waiting to hear the verdict that will put her in prison for nine years, does she reveal her feelings: ''They wanted to find me guilty. I could see it in their eyes. I saw hatred for me on their faces.'' The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals overturned Ms. Brown's conviction in 1989, after her lawyers filed a writ alleging that prosecutors suppressed evidence and presented perjured testimony. Eventually, charges were dropped and Joyce Ann Brown was a free woman - minus nearly a decade of her life taken from her by the State of Texas.

title: By the Board
description: For all of the excitement attending a world championship chess match, the fact is that in recent years most of the games have ended, just like tick-tack-toe, in draws. Little wonder, then, that the grandmaster analysts who assembled in New York City last week for the start of the match between the champion, Gary Kasparov, and Anatoly Karpov (at left) were as animated as Superbowl fans by the end of the second game. After drawing the first game, the charismatic Mr. Kasparov unleashed some moves in the second that were so innovative that the experts at first misunderstood them. But after postgame analysis, the consensus was that he had created a brand new strategy to overcome one of the classic chess defenses and hand Mr. Karpov a crushing defeat. The challenger, who is Mr. Kasparov's political as well as stylistic opposite, called for a postponement of the third game the next day. The 24-game match, with a record $3 million purse, is to resume tomorrow.

title: Homage to 50 Years of Live Opera Finds Its Producer
description: WHEN Texaco decided to present a special series of programs to commemorate its 50 years of sponsoring live radio broadcasts from the Metropolitan Opera, the Harrison-based company had no trouble finding a producer. It was agreed that probably only one person in the country had the knowledge and background - not to mention the personal record collection - to do the job: George Jellinek.

title: Movies That Fit Like a Glass Slipper
description: Forty years and a sexual revolution separate Cinderella's fairy godmother singing ''Bibbidi, bobbidi, boo'' from Richard Gere offering Julia Roberts $3,000 to spend a week with him. But Disney's classic animated CINDERELLA (1950, $29.95) is simply an older sister of PRETTY WOMAN (1990, Touchstone, $19.99), the film about a sweet-natured streetwalker that has made more than $170 million at the box office and has just become available on video.

title: Boilerplate
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Be a Competitor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting All Schools Share in The Dream
description: As a public librarian of a library serving a distressed area, I was interested in the article ''Schools Preparing for Changes in Financing. ''

title: WHEN LIFE IS TOXIC
description: Reinhold points out in his article that 70 to 80 percent of patients seeking treatment for environmental illness are women with histories of psychological problems. That women may be more chemically sensitive should come as no surprise: women bear most of the chemical exposure of contraception, in the form of the pill and spermicidal jellies and foams. They are more likely to handle household-cleaning and laundry products. They are exposed daily to cosmetics, perfumes and hair-grooming products.

title: Let Arms-Sale Profits Aid Poor Countries
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: THESE days we are locked in a national debate about whether women should have the right to obtain abortions. Seventy-five years ago this month, the people of New Jersey were arguing a different question: Should women have the right to vote? The debate was every bit as tangled, bitter and divisive.

title: About Men;   Not Exactly The Best Man
description: There ought to be a rule, a matter of social etiquette, entered into any updated guide to planning wedding parties. It should read something like this:

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

Congregations Cope With Demography
description: LEAD: A Mount Vernon synagogue is negotiating the sale of 3.5 of its 6 acres to a Greenwich, Conn., developer to help it meet a yearly $100,000 operating deficit.

title: A Savage and Demeaning Ritual
description: PLEDGING ALLEGIANCE

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Photokina, the every-other-year trade show in Cologne, Germany, took place at the beginning of this month, which helps explain why practically every camera and film maker has introduced at least one new product this fall. As usual, the major news was revealed prior to the event. What follows is a summary of the latest and newest culled from a multitude of press briefings and releases.

title: Miss Jones Weds T. D. Cunningham 3d
description: The marriage of Pamela Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Winthrop Jones of Lebanon, N.J., to Thomas D. Cunningham 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cunningham of Bedford, N.Y., took place yesterday in Gladstone, N.J. Canon John T. Morrow officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: THE WORLD: Japan's Shrewd New Investment Strategy . . .;;   . . . Moves Beyond Rockefeller Center and Pebble Beach
description: If all goes as planned in the next few weeks, E.T., the cuddly extra-terrestrial, will have a new parent. Matsushita, the giant consumer electronics maker known in the United States as Panasonic, is negotiating what may be a $7 billion takeover of MCA, the owner of Universal Studios and one of the recording industry's biggest labels. And sometime in the next few months, the faltering American automobile industry will have a new car plant: Toyota executives are mulling over the politically proper site for a huge new plant, which has scores of Toyota suppliers here and politicians in several state capitals salivating.

title: Room to Grow
description: Thirteen-year-old freddy victoria had outgrown his room. What the Riverdale Country School eighth grader needed now was more space for working and less for playing. A proper desk and bookshelves were crucial; so was storage. Esthetically, the young Victoria had definite tastes, too. ''I wanted my room to look very different from the rest of the apartment,'' he explains. The son of Anthony and Susan Victoria, owners of Frederick P. Victoria & Son Inc., a Manhattan antiques gallery, Freddy had been brought up in a home filled with 18th- and 19th-century French furniture. A sleek black-and-white scheme, he felt, would be a refreshing change. When his parents asked the architect Russell Riccardi, the president of the New York firm Riccardi & How Architects, to help with the alterations, Freddy became involved. He was present at every design meeting and even spent Friday afternoons at Riccardi's office learning to build an architectural model. ''We tried lots of different stuff,'' says Freddy, including the mildly fantastic. ''At first I wanted catwalks going across the room, but then we got the column idea. That gave me a place for a desk and bookshelves below.''

title: Dawn C. F. Smith to Wed This Fall
description: Dawn Carol Fabiola Smith and Elbert L. Robertson are planning a November wedding. Miss Smith, 29 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Smith of Ocala, Fla. Mr. Robertson, 33, is the son of Beatrice Robertson of Summit, Miss., and the late Elbert Robertson.

title: Ed Woolard Walks Du Pont's Tightrope
description: A big part of the future of America's largest chemical company can be found on a conveyor belt in an old warehouse here.

title: Miss Mather Wed To R. E. Ix Jr.
description: Dorothy MacGregor Mather and Ramond Edward Ix Jr. were married yesterday at the Memorial Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Philadelphia by the Rev. Dr. Maurice A. Coombs, who was assisted by the Rev. James W. Moore, a Roman Catholic priest. Mrs. Ix is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mather 3d of Philadelphia. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ix of Lancaster, Pa.

title: Postings: Downtown Architecture;   History on View
description: To illustrate the architectural development of lower Manhattan, the historian Andrew S. Dolkart assembled 120 objects: renderings, lithographs, etchings, models, furniture and a gargoyle from the Woolworth Building. They are on view through Friday in the Whitney Museum of American Art Downtown at Federal Reserve Plaza, 33 Maiden Lane, at Nassau Street. The show, ''Forging a Metropolis,'' was co-sponsored by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.

title: Campus Life: Swarthmore;   Governing Board Lifts the Curtain On Its Decisions
description: In an effort to demystify decision-making at Swarthmore College, the school's board of managers last weekend opened its doors for the first time to designated student and faculty observers.

title: In U.S. Schools, A War of Words
description: In a well-worn classroom at the San Fernando Elementary School, 30 miles north of Los Angeles, Aracelis Tester, a second-grade teacher, is reading ''Cuidado, un Dinosaurio!'' - ''Watch Out, a Dinosaur!'' - with her diminutive pupils. This could just as well be Mexico City or San Salvador, Grenada or Seville: a roomful of Hispanic children and a Hispanic teacher speaking Spanish.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: Travelers are advised that the electrical power in Mexico is the same as in the United States and that they can bring their traveling appliances. There is, however, a problem, which we encountered on a recent trip to Manzanillo and Ixtapa.

title: If Only Ducks Were Sold in Parts
description: NO one thinks twice about buying chicken in parts, but few places will sell you duck legs or breasts separately. This is too bad, for when it comes to cooking duck, most people do it one way: in the oven. The problem with roasting is that when the legs are done, the breast is often dry. If the breast is pink, the legs are red.

title: Sports People;   Then Jack Said . . .
description: San Diego fans who have been following the everlastingly unfolding developments of the Jack and Tony Show may have to look elsewhere for a rip-roaring feud to tide them over until spring training. This one seems to be fizzling fast.

title: Yielding to the Spell of Death Valley
description: LEAD: Death Valley National Monument - the hottest, driest, most barren piece of the California desert - may not be high on your winter getaway list. But when you've had all you can take of blizzards and the flu, it can be more restoring than a tropical isle, particularly for those who have only a few days to spare.

title: Seattle Induces Office Builders to Include Child Care
description: In four other cities that give developers density bonuses for child care -- Irvine, Calif., Portland, Ore., Cincinnati and Hart ford -- proposed projects have been put on hold until sluggish real estate markets im prove.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Rejuvenating Atlantic City's Downtown
description: LEAD: While flashy casinos and modern condominium towers have sprouted around it for the last 12 years, Atlantic City's downtown business district has remained a grubby neighborhood of tired storefronts, vacant, weed-choked lots and worn-out buildings, many of them empty.

title: Improved Routes Sought for Hikers
description: LEAD: HIKERS on the Long Island Greenbelt Trail where it crosses Sweetbriar Farm in Smithtown normally find themselves walking in a field of three-foot-high goldenrod and in a forest filled with chipmunks and cardinals.

title: A Fresh Look Graces Larger Quarters
description: AT a time when restaurant closings seem to be a fact of business life, it is refreshing to see a new restaurant succeed. Nantucket Cafe opened its doors more than three years ago in a minuscule spot in New Canaan and evidently filled such a need for an informal place serving pleasant, reasonably priced food that it burst its seams and sought larger quarters.

title: 'Phone My Wife. They Finally Got Me.'
description: LOUD AND CLEAR. By Lake Headley with William Hoffman. (Donald Hutter/Holt, $22.50.) Just before noon on June 2, 1976, Don Bolles, a 47-year-old investigative reporter for The Arizona Republic, stepped into his automobile in the parking lot of the Clarendon Hotel in downtown Phoenix, where he had been lured by a small-time criminal and sleazy informant named John Adamson. Moments later, just as he began to pull away from the lot, his car exploded. To those who rushed to his aid, Bolles, near death, uttered, ''Telephone my wife. They finally got me. The Mafia. Emprise. Find John Adamson.'' Bolles remained alive for 11 days, but spoke no other words. A cry went up, especially in journalistic circles, for the culprits to be found, tried, convicted and hanged. The Phoenix police did, indeed, find John Adamson and arrested him for the bombing. Faced with a death sentence, he promptly fingered a local businessman, Max Dunlap, and a plumber, Jim Robison. All three were convicted (Mr. Adamson, against whom the evidence was overwhelming, at first received a sweetheart deal for naming names; it later was revoked when authorities determined he had lied, and he is now appealing a death sentence), but it was only Mr. Dunlap and Mr. Robison who found themselves on death row. Two and a half years after the murder, Lake Headley, a private investigator, was hired by a group of prominent Phoenix citizens who believed that Max Dunlap was innocent, with the express purpose of finding evidence that would exonerate Mr. Dunlap and reopen the case. In fact, as Mr. Headley shows in ''Loud and Clear,'' the case against Mr. Dunlap and Mr. Robison was remarkably flimsy. As Mr. Headley dug he found that evidence involving some pretty prominent Arizona citizens involved in some nefarious doings had been either ignored, suppressed or conveniently ''lost.'' Despite many roadblocks, which included threats and harassment, Mr. Headley persevered and, due in large part to his efforts, the convictions against Mr. Robison and Mr. Dunlap were finally overturned in 1980. With the able help of William Hoffman, whose books include ''Beyond Reach: The Search for the Titanic,'' Mr. Headley, who is not afraid to name his own list of suspects, provides the reader with a fascinating account of Arizona corruption, along with what amounts to a step-by-step primer on the investigation of a murder case.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Campus Life: Brown;   Parties On Ethnic Themes are Halted
description: After a complaint about a ''South of the Border'' Mexican party, the mostly white residential fraternities and sororities at Brown University have voted to end ethnic-minority theme parties.

title: Commercial Property: Office Report Card;   New York's Business Conditions Get a 'Poor' Rating
description: In the eyes of executives around the country, New York City has grown markedly worse this year as a place to locate offices, according to a new survey.

title: Where and How to Insulate
description: MOST homes have insulation in the attic and walls, it having been included during construction or added later. Insulation between an unheated basement or crawl space and the main floor is important, too; in winter, unheated areas beneath rooms can act like a block of ice.

title: Some Plants Are Doubly Rewarding
description: EERYONE likes to have a double dividend. And some plants are worth the gardener's time and investment for their flowers in spring as well as their showy foliage or berries in fall.

title: Campus Life: Bucknell;   Feminist Graffiti Prompt Debate On Free Speech

title: An Immigrant's Pain in Concrete
description: ''I DIDN'T plan to be a writer,'' said Pietro Di Donato, the author of 50 short stories and 6 books, including the 1939 best seller ''Christ in Concrete.''

title: Baseball;   Mets Move Hunsicker To Key Executive Post
description: The Mets today formally named their director of minor league operations, Gerry Hunsicker, as the ''man on the fast track'' who would replace Joe McIlvaine as their chief baseball executive and perhaps as the heir apparent to Frank Cashen as general manager.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Sept. 30 about the engagement of Melanie Borden Falk to Roderick Ian Vere Nicoll misidentified the bank of which the prospective bride's stepfather, William J. McDonough, was vice chairman until his recent retirement. It is the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: Bronzes Conjure Up Images of a Fabled Past
description: The ancient bronze objects on view at the Merrin Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue at 56th Street, have more in common than the material from which they were made. The 44 objects presented in ''Bronze!,'' running from Thursday through Nov. 10, include portrait heads, mythological figures, lamps, ax heads, vessels, amulets and furniture fragments. All were made between 2300 B.C. and A.D. 300 in lands bordering the Mediterranean, and all are figural in shape, decoration or both, representing human, animal or botanical images.

title: Lighten Up
description: LUXURY IS HIGH CEILINGS AND A LOW OVERHEAD,'' says the decorator Tom Scheerer. In Manhattan, both are rare. Which is why Scheerer, a partner of Bilhuber Inc., a New York-based design company, decided to redecorate rather than move out of his East Side studio. Three years ago, the space had glazed aubergine walls, an 18th-century screen and, in the middle of the room, a bed that doubled as a sofa. ''I wanted to pare down,'' he explains. The decorator also felt it was time to introduce a new color scheme. Now the walls and furniture are in shades of beige, sand, brown and white, which appear to enlarge the room. ''The apartment in its first incarnation was really a nighttime place,'' says Scheerer. ''This way, it works well during the day, too.'' Changing the traffic pattern also helped open up the space. The designer has placed the bed to one side, perpendicular to the fireplace. On the other side of the hearth, a lacquered plywood table, which he designed and made, serves for both work and dining. In addition, he expanded the size of the mirrors covering the fireplace wall. ''They visually enlarge the space,'' he says. ''And they reflect light from the one window.''

After each shot, she looks toward Neil Jordan with an expression of hope and bemusement, wondering if this time, at last, the director will say ''O.K., that's a wrap'' or whatever it is these movie people say.

Investors in mutual funds are showing their anxiety by monitoring their accounts more closely than usual: Telephone calls from investors surged in August and are still coming in at higher-than-normal levels at many funds, marketers at many large fund groups say. What follows is a sampling of the most commonly asked questions and an amalgam of answers from fund managers, economists and other experts.

The systems store and display information about streets and even individual buildings in a community.If a fire is reported at a factory, for instance, the computer can display a floor plan plus a list of hazardous materials and recommended protective measures.

title: Review/Ballet;   Students in Dances Choreographed by Dancers
description: The Barnard College Dance Department, which has often presented examples of various dance forms, offered its first all-ballet program on Thursday afternoon at the Minor Latham Playhouse. The event featured students in works by experienced ballet dancers who have begun to pursue choreographic careers. Sean Lavery, a former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet who has become the assistant to the company's director, contributed a charming piece called ''Twinkliana.'' That title pays homage to George Balanchine, the New York City Ballet's founding choreographer, who created works called ''Ivesiana,'' ''Mozartiana'' and ''Glinkaiana.''

title: Behind the Painted World of 'Once On This Island'
description: In a time when sets for Broadway musicals can bump and grind with expensive mechanical wizardry and special effects, the design for ''Once on This Island'' is notable for its almost total reliance on extreme simplicity and hand-painted surfaces. The set for this fable-like Caribbean musical, which arrives on Broadway at the Booth Theater on Thursday, consists primarily of three walls and a floor painted with motifs of tropical vegetation. This framework exudes a sense of handmade and homemade more usual to a small, lovingly impastoed canvas or a spontaneously decorated folk art object in an intimate art gallery setting than to theater's communal space.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DEADLY TRIPLETS: A Theatre Mystery and Journal. By Adrienne Kennedy. (University of Minnesota, $14.95.) For her first novel, the talented playwright Adrienne Kennedy has had the intriguing idea of infusing her theatrical experiences in London with a Gothic sensibility and transforming them into a mystere a clef. With a protagonist who appears to be a thinly disguised substitute for the author, the narrative circles around a female playwright's relationship with a troubled film actor trying his hand at a modern revenge play called ''Deadly Triplets.'' The actor promises to help the playwright unearth the secret of her adopted mother's apparently mysterious death, but instead involves her in his own demise. In spite of Ms. Kennedy's avowed admiration for Conan Doyle, Christie and du Maurier, and in spite of the book's echoes of Charlotte Bronte, even a casual reader of mysteries may sense the author's discomfort with the genre. Omens, portents and presages abound in a volume of just 124 pages; whenever there's a need to heighten tension, a character leaves the country. The mystery of the mother's death is cast aside almost as a red herring, and the central character's present-tense life is left largely undramatized and unexplored. In the end, most of the book's interest turns out to be voyeuristic: one wonders just how much of it is autobiographical. Running throughout is an obsession with fame and famous people, which eventually finds its rightful place in a series of thumbnail sketches appended to the end of the novel. In this ''journal,'' Ms. Kennedy paints precise portraits of such luminaries as Edward Albee, Joseph Losey and Fay Weldon, and tells a classic story of betrayal in the theater. It seems that she had adapted John Lennon's ''nonsense books'' into a play that was eventually given a tryout at the National Theater. Laurence Olivier held her hand throughout the performance, then decided that Lennon, not she, should do the adaptation when the project was resumed a few months later. It is in these sharp sketches and telling anecdotes that Ms. Kennedy's considerable talents are most evident.

title: Reversal of Image: Watching Someone Playing Yourself
description: When I attended the premiere of ''Reversal of Fortune'' at the recent Toronto Film Festival, I anticipated few surprises. The new movie, directed by Barbet Schroeder, is based on my own book about how my students and I had reversed Claus von Bulow's conviction for twice trying to kill his wife. My son Elon, who works in the film business, had come up with the idea of making a movie out of the von Bulow story.

title: Yet Another 'Me and My Girl'
description: THERE is no jollier musical around than ''Me and My Girl.'' For a peripatetic critic who has not only endured but also enjoyed four productions of the revamped 1937 show in six weeks, not to mention four visits to the Broadway production (1986-89), is there any other musical around? Intimations of overexposure aside, ''Me and My Girl'' -now at the Darien Dinner Theater - is reaffirming and unfailingly winning, even in productions that do not measure up to a considerable built-in appeal of a beguiling score and an endearing book.

title: Taking a Fall
description: In the world of big business, they didn't come any bigger than Hisashi Shinto when he was chairman of Nippon Telephone and Telegraph, the world's largest company. Then came the Recruit scandal, which not only brought down a government but also laid low Mr. Shinto. After a 20-month trial on bribery charges, he was convicted and sentenced last week to two years in jail and fined $170,000. The verdict was regarded as a major victory for the prosecution, but Mr. Shinto won't be seeing the inside of a cell. The judge suspended his sentence, citing his age, 80, and his ''past contributions to the business world.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: Make Room For Daddy
description: The birth of our second child was an event we anticipated with joy. We had a daughter, and now we were about to have a son. The family would be complete. How could it be otherwise? Middle-class Manhattanites are almost as inflexible about family size as the Chinese: They are allowed one child; we are allowed two. That's all the so-called ''classic six'' prewar apartment can accommodate, and for those who choose to live in this city the classic six is our lot.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIMITED PARTNER. By Mike Lupica. (Villard, $18.95.) Mike Lupica, a columnist for the daily sports newspaper The National, is back with his third mystery featuring Peter Finley, a street-smart, wisecracking New York television journalist. In ''Limited Partner,'' Finley decides to launch an investigation after his friend Bobby Wyman is found dead of a drug overdose. Wyman, a recovering addict and alcoholic, was also part owner of a fashionable Upper East Side watering hole. If he had any doubts, Finley is certain of foul play after Wyman's girlfriend is found dead the day after Wyman's funeral, also of an apparent overdose. The body count builds as Finley's search for his friend's killer takes him from trendy uptown bistros to an after-hours club in Greenwich Village. The trail eventually leads to an Upper West Side substance abuse center, where Finley encounters B. J. Remick, a fireballing New York Mets pitcher who happens to have a cocaine problem, and whose confessions point Finley toward a mildly surprising solution to Wyman's murder. Unfortunately, Mr. Lupica's Borscht-Belt one-liners mar ''Limited Partner,'' and his incessant name-dropping detracts from what might otherwise have been a pretty fair whodunit.

title: Thefts
description: To the Editor: In reference to John D. Mitchell's letter (Travel, Sept. 2), I, too, was assaulted by the prettiest pickpocket in Milan. Disarmed by a sleepless flight and the excitement of returning to Italy, I let this red-chiffoned, nursing mother distract me with her proffered paper under which her fingers unzipped three inches of my waist pouch. She unshielded my passport, $300 in lire, charge cards and my return airline ticket. Luckily, she got only my goat.

title: Review/Theater;   Hypocrisies in the Name of Love
description: Politics and business have long been known to make very strange bedfellows, but they are nothing compared with the bizarre alliances formed in the name of love. And no playwright in the past century, or very likely any other, has been so adept at exposing the absurdities of our most cherished romantic notions as George Bernard Shaw. As its first offering of the season, the Jean Cocteau Repertory is staging a diverting if somewhat uneven revival of ''Misalliance.''

title: Penn State Wins As a Series Ends
description: Syracuse pursued Penn State through a long afternoon but never caught up today in the last scheduled game between these emotional rivals. The Nittany Lions, who never made a damaging mistake, scored 10 points in the fourth quarter to win, 27-21, before a crowd of 86,002, the third largest ever at Beaver Stadium.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SAVING THE FALCONS

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Beauty in a Dark and Gloomy Place
description: LEAD: I DRIVE north along Route 9 toward Ossining. Normally I would pause to appreciate the beauty of the late afternoon sun sifting through trees, but today I hardly noticed. I was on my way to Sing Sing - the State Correctional Facility for men - where I would be teaching a college composition class twice a week, and my mind was filled with matters other than sunshine on leaves.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ONE FELL SLOOP. By Susan Kenney. (Viking, $16.95.) Forgive the puns, the novel's title being the least painful, with its double - no, triple - meaning. Ignore the parenthetical remarks that pockmark, and often pothole, every page. Overlook the repeated descriptions of the heroine's lover, with his ''tall, broad figure'' and his ''much-too-clever, faunlike face.'' What is left at the heart of Susan Kenney's new mystery is a pleasant howdunit. The third in a series featuring an English professor named Rosamund (Roz) Howard, ''One Fell Sloop'' sets this reluctant sleuth to battle an overbearing Scotsman, Alan Stewart, an intellectually and physically well-endowed paleobotonist, and her own highly developed insecurities during a holiday sail around Maine's Penobscot Bay. It is after a ''flaming row'' (''she had gone up in smoke; he had simply gone ashen'') that the two find a murdered body on the beach of a deserted island, with one set of footprints, apparently those of the deceased. The timing couldn't be better. While local authorities dismiss the death as accidental, Roz and Alan can stow their personal angst and concentrate on solving the who, what, when, where, why and, most important, how of the murder. They do this by engaging in seemingly endless theorizing; interviewing the obligatory eccentric Maine characters; confronting one suspect in an amusing, martini-laced scene, and staging a lovers' reconciliation that signals the start of the novel's worthwhile, action-filled ending.

title:
The Executive Life;

Office or Golf Course, The Game Is the Same
description: LEAD: Managing a company is really like one big game of golf.

title: Streetscapes: The Alley at 4 East 43d Street;   An 1864 Stable-Path Survivor
description: The Mehlin Piano building, an odd little, mid-block structure at 4 East 43d Street facing onto a deep, narrow alley, was acquired last spring by a developer as part of an assemblage reaching to the northeast corner of 42d Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Jean Hammond Bender Is the Bride Of Craig Sabina in Saratoga Springs
description: Jean Hammond Bender, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Bender 4th of Albany, was married yesterday to Craig William Sabina, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Sabina of Denver. Mayor Almeda C. Dake of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., officiated at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs.

title: Michele Wolk and Allan Mordkoff, Lawyers, Wed
description: Michele Wolk, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allan Wolk of New York, was married yesterday to Allan Robert Mordkoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Mordkoff of Port Jefferson Station, L.I. Rabbi Steven Graber officiated at the Marvello Country Club in Stony Point, N.Y.

title: Yes, Francesca, There Are Fish, Real Fish, in the Hudson
description: Francesca Bynes always knew the Hudson River was home to sandwich wrappers, wood chips, castoff soda cans and other refuse.

title: British Curbs On Inflation
description: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, says that he will keep tough curbs on the economy to fight inflation despite hopes that the pound's entry into Europe's currency system would provide some relief.

title: Iran and Iraq Resume Ties
description: Iran and Iraq resumed direct diplomatic relations today and reopened their embassies, the Iranian Foreign Ministry said. A ministry statement quoted by the Iranian press agency said that the Iraqi charge d'affaires began his assignment in Teheran today and that an Iranian charge d'affaires would leave for Baghdad shortly. The two countries broke off diplomatic ties during their eight-year war.

title: Crux of Tax Debate: Who Pays More?
description: As the budget fracas continued last week, often in a cloud of confusion, perhaps the clearest point of contention became the question of who should bear the greatest financial burden of increased taxes: rich or poor or the people in between.

title: Judith LaBella Is Married
description: Judith LaBella of Bloomfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Henry Kornhauser of New York by Mayor Timothy McDonough of Hope, N.J., at Water's Edge at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Mrs. Kornhauser, 49 years old, owns Sam & Judi's Restaurant in East Newark, N.J. Her first marriage ended in divorce, as did her husband's. The bridegroom, 57 and a graduate of City College, is the chairman of Partners & Shevack, a New York advertising agency.

title: What Kind of People Are We?
description: The budget deficit facing Mayor David Dinkins has been estimated at between $1.5 and $2.5 billion for next year. While the city's budget appears to be huge - $29 billion in its fiscal year 1992 - in fact, only $20 billion are city funds. The rest are Federal and state monies over which the Mayor has little control.

title: Lots of Words, but Are They True?
description: ACROSS Manhattan, in a variety of luxurious apartments, similar scenes are played out night after night. The sun is setting, cocktails are being served and the battered spirits of weary book publishers are being revived by a combination of alcohol, flirtation and chat. And, as the noise level rises, the publishing rumor mill begins to whir.

title: Montana and Rice Sparkle
description: The Atlanta Falcons enjoy living on the edge. They wear black and they are proud. Their take no prisoners slogan mirrors the image of Jerry Glanville, who has already brought the Falcons a long way in a short span.

title: Randy A. Gilman, Gemologist, Weds
description: Randy Allyn Gilman, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert Gilman of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Mr. Gilman, was married yesterday at the Pierre in New York to Henri Zvi Bolimovsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moisha Bolimovsky of Tel Aviv. Rabbi Sol Roth and Cantor Joseph Malovany performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Carol Cohn Marries A. I. Meyer in New Jersey
description: Susan Carol Cohn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Cohn of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Arnold Ira Meyer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Meyer of Philadelphia. Rabbi Barry R. Friedman and Cantor Bruce M. Benson officiated at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J.

title: Hindu Revivalist's Challenge To Muslim Shrine Stirs Fears
description: With the beat of drums, the bold dashes of saffron belts and headbands and the sight of sword-brandishing men, Lal Kishen Advani, India's most prominent right-wing leader, brought his revivalist campaign against a Muslim shrine at a Hindu holy site to a crucial phase today.

title: Far to the East of Moscow, A Brazen Rush to Capitalism
description: The islanders call their beloved outsider ''E. T.,'' for Valentin Fyodorov has proved to be a boon-producing alien, rocking the governance of Sakhalin Island with strange events in defiance of the law to make people imagine themselves more and more in a free-market world apart from the rest of the Soviet Union.

title: April Rooker Is Married
description: April Ashley Richards Rooker, the daughter of Carolyn K. Hodges of Darien, Conn., and Dr. Donald W. Rooker of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Mark Steven Gronich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Gronich of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, officiated at the Estherwood mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The bride, 24 years old, is keeping her name. A Barnard College graduate, she is a software consultant in New York. The bridegroom, 26, has a bachelor's degree and an M.B.A. from Columbia University. He is a corporate banker in New York for the Finnish bank Kansallis-Osake-Pankki.

title: Chessmanship: The Fine Art Of Sounding Like a Master
description: As soon as Gary Kasparov moved his king's pawn to start the second game of the World Chess Championship, the kibitzers thought something was up. They had been expecting an opening on the queenside. Clearly this called for instant analysis. So, as the players quickly proceeded with the Flohr-Zaitsev Variation, the kibitzers next door at the Hotel Macklowe sought out Eric Schiller, an American player. Mr. Schiller had not only just published a treatise on that variation, he had also recently spent a week at Mr. Kasparov's training camp on Martha's Vineyard.

title: Navajo Bribery Case Almost Ready for Jury
description: After nine days of testimony in a trial that had been expected to last four to six weeks, the case of Peter MacDonald, the Navajo tribal leader accused of bribery, is expected to go to the jury on Monday.

title: Rule of Thumb for Negotiating A Budget: 'Don't Tax Friends'
description: While the big battles over Medicare, capital gains and income tax rates have been blocking a budget agreement between Congress and the White House, dozens of backroom deals and horse trades on lesser matters have helped shape the deficit reduction packages lawmakers will vote on this week.

title: Soviet Buses to Carry Colgate Toothpaste Ads
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company has become the first company to buy space for toothpaste ads on Soviet buses. The New York-based consumer products company signed a contract for the ads with Transportation Displays Inc., a company that places ads in transit locations.

title: Syracuse Track Team's Bus And Luggage Stolen by Driver
description: A group of Syracuse high school students visiting New York City were left stranded in the rain when their bus driver abondoned them and stole their luggage, officials said.

title: Review/Opera;   A Lady-in-Waiting Goes Slumming in 'Martha'
description: When it comes to getting no respect, Rodney Dangerfield is a novice and a piker compared to the 19th-century German composer Friedrich von Flotow. Poor Flotow took another pie in the face on Saturday evening with a new production of his only remembered opera, ''Martha,'' at the New York City Opera.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The incoming chairman of the New York Stock Exchange took to the pulpit at a Manhattan cathedral on Sunday to denounce the materialism of the 1980's and the gap between rich and poor.

title: Ms. Grossman Weds Dr. Gary Alweiss
description: Gayle Amy Grossman, a medical student at Harvard University, and Dr. Gary Steven Alweiss, a neurologist, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Mordechai Waxman.

title: With Big Plays in a Big Game, Giants Beat Redskins
description: From the beginning, when the Redskins seemed invincible, until the end, whtn the Giants proved invincible, it was a typical Giants-Redskins game.

title: At the United Nations, One Seat for Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers Get Revenge But Don't Flaunt It
description: The Houston Oilers enjoyed the present too much to think about the past today.

title: What's in a Name? For Some Publishers, Celebrity Novels
description: The celebrity memoir is a staple of publishing, and some publishers are now getting ready to bet millions of dollars that the public will also buy novels by celebrities, even those that are actually written by other people.

title: Discount Brand Promotion Likely if Beer Taxes Rise
description: IF Congress raises the excise tax on beer, which appears likely, that means brewers may be pushed into uncharted territory and forced to promote discount brands with more advertising.

title: Both Kabul and Rebels Report Battle Gains
description: Muslim guerrillas said today that they had captured strategic security outposts and killed more than 200 Afghan troops in their latest attempt to capture the capital, Kabul.

title: A Cost-Free Boost for Justice
description: Here's a way for New York City to improve supervision of convicts once released, speed processing of criminal cases and free up thousands of jail cells - all without spending a cent. It requires only a modest change in Probation Department procedure.

title: Bush Discovers Free Speech on Kids' Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Light Wed To D. F. Abrams
description: Wendy Ellen Light, a daughter of Gerald P. Light of Floral Park, Queens, and the late Mary Light, was married yesterday to Danal Frederic Abrams, a son of Dr. Martin W. Abrams and Lynn Epstein Abrams, both of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated at Temple Beth-el in Great Neck.

title: Celtics Experiencing Change
description: FOR so many years, the Boston Celtics were the organization against which all other National Basketball Association franchises were measured. They won championships. They had mystique. They had stability. That tradition makes the whirlwind off-season events involving the Celtics more startling than if they had occurred with another franchise. They dismissed their coach in May. They hired a new coach, Chris Ford, and a new senior executive vice president, Dave Gavitt, in June.

title: Market Place;   Heritage Media's Bid for POP Radio
description: IT takes a gutsy investor to step in and buy a stock just as a takeover seems to be falling apart. Or one who knows more than the public.

title: 1989 Ruling Spurs New Tack in Civil Rights Suits
description: In response to a 1989 Supreme Court decision, courts across the country are reopening old civil rights cases and allowing white men to challenge the hiring and promotion of blacks under court decrees issued up to 20 years ago.

title: Voter Registration Try Ends in a Cuomo Loss
description: Voter registration for next month's elections in New York State is over, along with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's unsuccessful attempt to require state agencies to take an active role in helping register voters.

title: Important Intel Chip Improved
description: In a significant advance for the production of small ''notebook'' computers, the Intel Corporation said today that it had developed a vastly shrunken, power-saving version of the chips that form the processing power of some of the most advanced personal computers.

title: Venezuela Pushing 'Liquid Coal'
description: With oil prices surging, some electric power company managers are seeing some relief through the huge bitumen reserves here in eastern Venezuela.

title: White House Urges Decrease In Short-Term Interest Rates
description: The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, said today that he hoped the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates sharply should an agreement be reached with Congress to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: CHRONICLE
description: IAN WOODNER is an architect by training but a collector by passion. And he's being honored as a collector tomorrow, with the Citation of Merit from the National Arts Club. He has a collection of drawings that has been exhibited in the world's great museums. He also collects Odilon Redon, the French Symbolist, and Greek antiquities.

title: Get New York's Fat Out of the Fire
description: How can New York City's government climb out of the current fiscal mess? By promptly taking two steps: First, keep matters from getting worse by delaying further labor negotiations immediately. And second, find a way to withhold part of the alarmingly large raise granted the teachers' union.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the mistrial in the latest Bensonhurst trial reversed the identities of the two men shown in some copies.

title: Carson City Gains A Quick Victory
description: Carson City, who outran a quick field of older sprinters to win the Fall Highweight Handicap last month, did the same thing to an even quicker field yesterday at Belmont Park to win the $114,000 Boojum Handicap.

title: Miss Greenberg, Lawyer, Married
description: Pamela Ellen Greenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Greenberg of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Philip Gold, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Gold of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Raphael Gold, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains.

title: Ike's Foreign Policy Wasn't Always Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Adding Book Unit In Bid to Be a Top Publisher
description: The Walt Disney Company plans to establish a unit to publish books for adults as part of a long-term plan to become a leading book publisher.

title: Spanish Papers Thrive as Hispanic Market Surges
description: The Spanish-language newspaper market in the United States seems like a pinata being whacked on all sides by entrepreneurs and media companies. All are eager to reap the profits from the surging Hispanic population, which may reach 30 million by the turn of the century.

title: U.S. Aides Say Move by Israel Hampers Relations
description: Administration officials say they are deeply concerned that Israel's decision to reject a United Nations inquiry into the shooting of 21 Palestinians in Jerusalem last week could worsen already tense American-Israeli relations and continue to divert attention from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

title: High Pakistan Court Upholds Dismissal of Bhutto
description: A high court in Lahore today upheld President Ghulam Ishaq Khan's dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government on Aug. 6.

title: Islanders Plagued by Injuries and Suspensions
description: The Islanders, who played in a figurative fog Saturday night, practiced in a literal one today at Cantiague Park.

title: Review/Television;   The Political Journey Of an Archetypal Loner
description: The rises and falls and falls and rises of Richard M. Nixon have been so chronically chronicled that three more hours may not seem strictly necessary. Still, the fascination remains, like an old wound that the body politic cannot leave alone, and there is always a new generation to be edified or mortified by the man's career. Which is reason enough for ''Nixon,'' tonight's absorbing three-hour profile of the former President, from his emergence as a national figure in the 1948 Alger Hiss case to his departure from the White House in disgrace in 1974. You can find it at 8 on Channel 13.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Hitting the Open Trail For a Varied Workout
description: LEAD: FOR amateur athletes stuck in offices all day, a chance to exercise outdoors is ideal. And fitness trails, or parcours as they are known in Switzerland where they were first developed in the late 1960's, provide a complete workout in your local park or beach.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 15:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You can get away with saying that a move gives 'a spatial edge' or 'a powerful attacking position' as long as you don't specify what edge or what attack. Or you can just generalize with something like, 'Black seems rather defensive here.'

title: Battle Over Assault Weapons Bill
description: If the sponsors of a bill to ban assault weapons have their way, the bill will not come to a vote in the House this year.

title: Kathryn Turck Is Married
description: Kathryn Mary Turck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Delaney of Lakewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen Jon Rose, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold J. Rose of Dorset, Vt. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel and the Rev. Fanny Erikson, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated in the ceremony at Delmonico's restaurant in New York. Ms. Rose, 40 years old, is the director of corporate insurance in New York for the I.T.T. Corporation.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Home Schooling Offers Parents a Viable Education Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Ravaged by Chargers, 39-3
description: There were 13,580 no-shows announced at Giants Stadium for the Jets' game against the San Diego Chargers today if you don't count the Jets' offense, their defense and their special teams units.

title: At the United Nations, One Seat for Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: Bridge
description: One of the oldest competitors at the World Championships in Geneva last month was Dave Treadwell of Wilmington, Del. Playing with Jim Becker of Manhattan in the Open Pairs, he celebrated his 78th birthday with skillful play on the diagramed deal.

title: Citicorp Seems Optimistic
description: Citicorp plans no dividend cut or huge addition to its reserves to cover loan losses anytime soon, the banking company's chairman, John S. Reed, said this weekend.

title: Hans Namuth, Photographer, Is Dead at 75
description: Hans Namuth, a photographer and film maker best known for his portraits of American artists, died on Saturday in East Hampton, L.I. He was 75 years old and lived in New York City and Water Mill, L.I.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As thanks for his sensitive portrayal of their people, the Sioux Nation will adopt KEVIN COSTNER as a brother of Sinte Gleska College, where he and his crew were given a crash course in Lakota, the Sioux language. As the co-producer, director and star, Mr. Costner shot most of his new film, ''Dances with Wolves,'' around South Dakota, the heart of Sioux country. The college is on the Rosebud Reservation in Rapid City, S. D. About 30 percent of the film is in Lakota, with subtitles.

title: Alison D. Keel Is Wed To Stephen E. Kimmel
description: Alison Dixon Keel, the daughter of Susan T. Danin of Chapel Hill, N.C., and Dr. William A. Keel of Fountain Valley, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen Edward Kimmel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Kimmel of Upper Montclair, N.J. Rabbi Joshua S. Chasan and Cantor Adina Klein officiated at Congregation Shomrei Emunah in Montclair, N.J.

title: U.S. Plans Farm Trade Concession
description: In an effort to find a compromise with the European Community over the sticky issue of farm subsidies, the United States will present a plan in Geneva on Monday that modifies its call for an end to such aid.

title: G.O.P. Senators See Politics In Pace of Keating 5 Inquiry
description: In rare public criticism of the panel that polices their behavior, several Republican Senators have suggested that the Senate Ethics Committee has let politics interfere with its investigation of five lawmakers for their links to the savings and loan debacle.

title: Where First an Op-Ed Page Was Seen
description: To the Editor:

title: Tipping New York Senate Balance: Abortion Issue May Carry Weight
description: Anita Maxwell, a Democratic candidate for the State Senate, said with a smile that it might seem a bit incongruous for her to be campaigning at a Planned Parenthood clinic here last week.

title: Leonard Bernstein, 72, Music's Monarch, Dies
description: Leonard Bernstein, one of the most prodigally talented and successful musicians in American history, died yesterday evening at his apartment at the Dakota on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: Business and the Law;   U.S. Treatment Of Milken Brother
description: WHEN Michael R. Milken entered a Federal District courtroom in Manhattan last week for the start of his pre-sentencing hearing, he was accompanied by his brother, Lowell, who was once indicted on racketeering charges but is now a free man.

title: Warming Is Killing Coral Reefs, Scientists Say
description: Warming trends are causing the deterioration of the world's coral reefs, a panel of research scientists told a Senate committee last week.

title: Miss Sellnow Marries A. L. Krieger
description: Stephanie Sellnow and Arthur Louis Krieger were married yesterday at Halloran House in New York. Rabbi Thomas K. Weiner and Cantor Richard Botton officiated.

title: On His Centennial, They Still Like Ike
description: They came to Gettysburg this weekend as they had come when Dwight D. Eisenhower lived in retirement here, this time to honor the man with the big grin on the 100th anniversary of his birth.

title: China Opens Grain Market
description: In one of its few efforts this year to overhaul its economy, China opened a national wheat market last week to replace central allocation of the nation's 85-million-ton annual wheat harvest.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's auction of three- and six-month bills. On Thursday the Treasury will auction a record $10.75 billion in one-year bills to raise $975 million in new cash.

title: For 2 Producers, Their Way Is the Right Way
description: In 1986, the producers Steve Golin and Joni Sighvatsson, frustrated by the slow pace and high cost of making movies the Hollywood way, founded Propaganda Films and vowed to take a different approach. Having just foisted ''Hard Rock Zombies'' and ''American Drive In'' on an indifferent public, they were certain they were capable of bigger and better things, if only they could be free to follow their own instincts.

title: Ann Kirschner Weds D. P. Hawkins
description: Ann Judith Kirschner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul A. Kirschner of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to David Peter Hawkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Hawkins of Ridgewood, N.J. Jean Kotkin, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, officiated at La Belle Epoque in New York.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Dana J. Larson Is Wed To Adam Howard Sher
description: Dana Jean Larson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. William Larson of Williamsville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Adam Howard Sher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Sher of New York, by Rabbi Joseph Gelberman at the Hasbrouck House Inn in Stone Ridge, N.Y. The bride, 31 years old and a Middlebury College graduate with a master's in education from Columbia University, studies meditation at the SYDA Foundation, a retreat in South Fallsburg, N.Y. The bridegroom, 26, graduated from Wesleyan University and is a partner in the Signature Construction Group, a construction company in East Hampton, L.I. The couple met at a SYDA workshop.

title: Menotti and Spoleto Split On Issue of Artistic Control
description: Gian Carlo Menotti, the 79-year-old founder of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., said yesterday that he had resigned as the festival's artistic director, but would return if its board gave him unchallenged artistic control.

title: Roosevelt Aide Called an Unwitting Spy
description: A new book by a prominent Soviet K.G.B. defector names Harry L. Hopkins, an architect of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal and his closest personal adviser, as an unwitting ''agent of major significance'' for the Soviet Union.

title: 5 Years After Duvalier, Haiti Is Still in Shambles
description: Like many other people in business here, Richard Morse pegged his hopes on plans for democratic elections in 1987 that were meant to put a definitive end to the long Duvalier family dictatorship.

title: Fined Abortion Clinic Closes
description: The best-known abortion clinic here has closed after the authorities seized its equipment for its failure to pay Federal fines. Federal prosecutors sued the Delta Women's Clinic in July 1989, saying that three doctors had illegally prescribed sedatives and painkillers. In March, United States District Judge Adrian Duplantier ordered fines of $337,000 against the clinic, which opened in 1973. Clinical Leasing Services Inc., which owns the clinic, filed for protection from its creditors in May, but the petition was dismissed on Thursday.

title: Go Ahead Penn State, Gloat!
description: Besides his weekly call-in radio show, Joe Paterno takes other pulse readings for perceptions of Penn State football.

title: ISRAEL'S CABINET DENOUNCES STUDY BY U.N. INQUIRERS
description: The Israeli Cabinet today officially denounced the United Nations decision to send a delegation to investigate the deaths of 21 Palestinians at Al Aksa Mosque last week and declared that it would not cooperate with the mission.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The incoming chairman of the New York Stock Exchange took to the pulpit at a Manhattan cathedral on Sunday to denounce the materialism of the 1980's and the gap between rich and poor.

title: Abused Children Find the Strength to Testify Against Their Father
description: The nine children of Herman and Frances McMillan lived in a one-bedroom apartment within sight of Yankee Stadium, but they didn't know a thing about baseball. For that matter, they barely knew what daylight was all about: looking out the window was forbidden by their father.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As thanks for his sensitive portrayal of their people, the Sioux Nation will adopt KEVIN COSTNER as a brother of Sinte Gleska College, where he and his crew were given a crash course in Lakota, the Sioux language. As the co-producer, director and star, Mr. Costner shot most of his new film, ''Dances with Wolves,'' around South Dakota, the heart of Sioux country. The college is on the Rosebud Reservation in Rapid City, S. D. About 30 percent of the film is in Lakota, with subtitles.

title: Home Schooling Offers Parents a Viable Education Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: Shanghai Center Opens
description: Shanghai's largest and most elaborate hotel and office complex opened on Friday after nearly five years of delays, cost overruns and political turmoil. The new Shanghai Center was developed by the Portman Companies of Atlanta, the Kajima Corporation of Japan, the American International Group of New York and the Shanghai Exhibition Center. The center, a triple-tower complex with a 628-room hotel, offices, apartments, theater, shops and exhibition hall, was originally scheduled to open in June 1989. Problems in obtaining materials, pro-democracy demonstrations and construction delays set back the opening.

title: Bring on C.S.C.E.
description: Upon hearing that the transcendentalist Margaret Fuller had said ''I accept the Universe,'' the historian Thomas Carlyle delivered this withering put-down: ''By God, she'd better!''

title: Dr. Niusia Shimrat, 71, A Child Psychologist
description: Dr. Niusia Shimrat, a child psychologist with Mount Sinai Medical Center for two decades before retiring in 1985, died on Saturday at the Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Medical Center. She was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Beat Thirst While Biking
