Nazif Borman, the Finance Minister of the self-proclaimed Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, said his Government had bought the stake in the Salamis Bay Hotel for $:6.15 million, or about $12 million. The Northern Cyprus Government had already owned 7 percent of the hotel.

title: Rwandan Army Says Rebels Were Defeated in Northeast
description: The Rwandan Army ousted rebels from a district center in the northeast in fierce fighting over the weekend, an army spokesman said today.

title: The Wrong Russian
description: This certainly was the year for the Nobel people to honor the peace hero of the Soviet Union - but they picked the wrong Russian.

title: Gorbachev Gets Nobel Peace Prize For Foreign Police Achievements
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union was named the 1990 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize today in recognition of his initiatives in promotion of international peace, including championing political change in Eastern Europe and helping to end the cold war.

title: U.S. Optimistic That Oil Windfall Will Make Iran Honor Embargo
description: Bush Administration officials say they are optimistic that Iran, enjoying an economic and diplomatic windfall from the Persian Gulf crisis, will continue to abide by the United Nations embargo on Iraq.

title: In Comptroller's Race, Bellamy and Regan Take Off Kid Gloves
description: The genteel veneer over the race for state comptroller is eroding. Carol Bellamy, the Democratic challenger, is questioning the effectiveness of Edward V. Regan, the Republican incumbent, and he is challenging her independence.

title: Rio Journal;   Forbidden Love and Politics Mingle, Explosively
description: Tales of forbidden love are making Brazilian politics as torrid this season as the coming Southern Hemisphere summer.

title: New York City Moves Against Cigarette Machines
description: New York took a major step yesterday toward becoming the first large city in the United States to ban cigarette vending machines from most public places.

title: Anthony D'Elia, Administrator, 70
description: Anthony D'Elia, executive director of the Adirondack Park Local Government Review Board, died of bone-marrow cancer on Saturday at Champlain Physicians Hospital in Plattsburgh. He was 70 years old and lived in Loon Lake.

title: Bridge
description: Four decades ago B. Jay Becker and Sam Stayman were often team-mates - they won two world championships together - and more often opponents. Becker died three years ago, but Becker-Stayman confrontations still occur occasionally.

title: 100,000 Ukrainians March, Insisting That Leaders Quit
description: About 100,000 Ukrainian students marched through the center of Kiev today demanding the resignation of the republic's Communist government.

title: Apple by Apple
description: AFTER months of speculation, Apple Computer Inc. finally unveiled three new models of the Macintosh yesterday, including the first Macintosh to carry a list price of less than $1,000 and a low-cost color Macintosh.

title: Saddam Hussein Is Nothing Like Saladin
description: To the Editor:

title: Unisys-Navy Pact
description: The Unisys Corporation said its Defense Systems unit had received a fixed-price contract from the Navy with a basic value of $170.2 million. The pact is for upgrade kits for the MK-92 fire control system for Navy ships and for several new MK-92 systems for foreign allies. The company said the contract called for deliveries from 1992 to 1994.

title: Eristus Sams, Civil Rights Advocate, 77
description: Eristus Sams, a former Mayor of Prairie View who led an effort to win students the right to vote, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: U.S. Urges Britain to Ease Bid for Reparations by Iraq
description: The United States is urging Britain to tone down a resolution it plans to introduce in the Security Council that would require Iraq to pay compensation for damage resulting from the invasion of Kuwait, diplomats say. They say Washington fears that the third world would demand similar action against Israel for its occupation of land claimed by Arabs.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO FOOTBALL

title: Power Shortage Becomes Factor
description: The Oakland Athletics said today that Jose Canseco had largely recovered from his injuries and would open the World Series with his home-run power restored. But the Cincinnati Reds reported that Eric Davis was still suffering from his injuries and might be switched to the leadoff spot in the batting order to minimize the demands on his home-run power.

title: Torborg and Lasorda Talk of Power, Punch and Title Predictions;   Reds Scouting Report
description: First, an opinion from a man with lots of them.

title: New Law Will Expand TV Captions for the Deaf
description: More than a decade after television stations began broadcasting coded signals that can be translated into subtitles, Congress has passed legislation that will enable millions more viewers who are deaf or hard of hearing to take advantage of the technology.

title: Treasuries Inch Up in Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher, and interest rates inched lower, in quiet trading yesterday, as credit market participants shrugged off a big drop in the price of leading commodities, including oil.

title: Eugene Sachs, Professor, 57
description: Dr. Eugene Sachs, who taught psychology at Queens College since 1964, died on Saturday at his home in Jamaica, Queens. He was 57 years old.

title: Yields Increase On Bank Issues
description: With banks vulnerable to poor earnings and reductions in their credit ratings, there are clear signs that investors are demanding higher interest rates on some securities.

title: Policing the World
description: A peculiar convergence of critics on the left and right has begun to emerge as Americans digest the enormity of the Persian Gulf crisis. It came as such a surprise and built up so rapidly that many thought it a passing storm at first, a nasty adventure like Panama that could be put in its place and then out of mind.

title: Corrections
description: The Publishing column of the Media Business page on Monday misstated the title of Peter Osnos at Random House. He is the associate publisher, not associate editor.

title: Campaign Trail;   Trapped on Capitol Hill, Democrats Fight by TV
description: ''Where we are is hell, and where hell is, there must we ever be,'' as Mephistopheles puts it in ''Doctor Faustus.'' So it is with members of the House and Senate and the 1990 campaign. The campaign is where the lawmakers are, and the lawmakers are trapped on Capitol Hill by the budget impasse.

title: Chronicle
description: A. S. BYATT won Britain's most prestigious literary award yesterday for ''Possession,'' her novel of two young scholars whose research uncovers a clandestine affair between two fictional Victorian poets.

title: Economic Scene;   Russia Rules, But Gently
description: STANISLAV SHATALIN, principal economic adviser to Mikhail Gorbachev, finished a whirlwind tour of America last week. And while the visit was unofficial - Mr. Shatalin was a guest of Belka International, an American consulting firm serving Western business in the Soviet Union - his comments in an interview suggested that he was not about to say anything that would embarrass his besieged employer.

title: Douglas Campbell, World War I Air Ace And Executive, 94
description: Douglas Campbell, the first American-trained air ace in World War I, who was later a general manager of Pan American Grace Airways, died yesterday at his home in Cos Cob, Conn. He was 94 years old.

title: For the Two Pennant Winners, The Arrival of Another Flag
description: It was the Admiral who said why don't we run this one up the flag pole and see if anyone salutes. But by the time Don Fehr of the Major League Baseball Players Association snapped to attention and Commissioner Fay Vincent gave the order to advance, it was Tony Angilecchia and his staff at the Nu-Look Cleaners in Cincinnati who ended up doing the patriotic scut work: sewing American flags on the upper right chest of the home white and visiting gray World Series uniforms worn by the Reds and the Oakland A's last night.

title: Two Raiders Stay Put
description: As the National Football League trading deadline passed yesterday, the Los Angeles Raiders' running back Marcus Allen and the backup quarterback Steve Beuerlein, both rumored to be going elsewhere, stayed put. But Vann McElroy, a two-time Pro Bowl performer who was a Raider for nine years, did not. The 30-year-old safety was traded to the Seattle Seahawks for an undisclosed future draft choice.(AP)

title: Marshfield, Vt.
description: WHEN Katherine Clark and her husband, Steven Wallach, entertain weekend house guests, they call ahead to Rainbow Sweets Cafe to reserve extra cherry-cheese Danish pastries, which are made only on Sunday mornings. They ''come out of the oven at 9:15 and are gone by 10,'' Ms. Clark said.

title: Grand Met and Elders Blocked on Beer Deal
description: Britain today blocked a venture between Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Elders IXL Ltd., but the Government gave the companies time to come up with a scaled-down proposal that would not threaten competition in the beer industry.

title: Stovall Gets Job At Louisiana Tech
description: Jerry Stovall, the former all-American at Louisiana State who was dropped as head football coach at the school seven years ago, was named athletic director at Louisiana Tech University in Ruston yesterday.

title: Byatt Wins the Booker Prize
description: A. S. Byatt won Britain's most prestigious literary award yesterday for ''Possession,'' her novel of two young scholars whose research uncovers a clandestine affair between two fictional Victorian poets.

title: Macalester's Endowment Rises to $320 Million
description: Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., has almost quintupled its endowment, moving into the ranks of the nation's liberal arts colleges with the largest endowments, including Swarthmore, Wellesley, Amherst and Williams.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Celebrating the Harvest

title: Securities Laws Are Toughened
description: President Bush this week signed two bills giving Federal securities regulators significant power to detect and crack down on fraud in the nation's financial marketplace.

title: U.S. Asking U.N. Chief to Send His Inquiry Team to Israel Quickly
description: The Bush Administration is urging Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations to send a fact-finding mission to Jerusalem soon, despite Israel's objections. In doing so, Washington is trying to head off a possible new campaign to condemn Israel here, an effort that would further deflect attention from the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Downers
description: A New Yorker for whom the simple explanation never suffices has been wondering why she's been so down lately. Way down. It's too early in the season for anyone to be afflicted with SADD - that curious mood disorder that's said to arrive when the sun is low in the sky - and she is unaware of any curious conjunction of the planets. Saturn, in other words, is behaving itself.

title: Brazil Won't Sign Atom Pact But Plans Curbs, Aide Says
description: Brazil intends to tighten civilian control over its nuclear sites and restrict exports of nuclear materials and advanced military technology, but it will not sign the 20-year-old nonproliferation treaty that requires adherents to forsake the development of atomic weapons, a senior Brazilian Government official said today.

title: Noble Pretzels for a Penny
description: To The Living Section:

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;

People
description: LEAD: * William R. Kelly has been named president and chief operating officer of BBDO, Chicago, replacing Eric Harkna, who becomes chairman and remains chief executive. In the New York office, Anthony Lenge has been named director of strategy and business development, and Bruce Meyers has become director of finance and operations.

title: Romania in Deal With Caterpillar
description: Caterpillar Inc. plans to sell 212 earth-moving machines to the Romanian Government for use in coal mining. Caterpillar released few details, but an analyst said the deal could be worth $50 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Can a Mall at a Toxic Dump Revive an Ailing Syracuse?
description: Just moments from the heart of downtown oozes Oil City, an industrial wasteland of oil tanks, junkyards, toxic dumps and corroded buildings hugging the shore of Onondaga Lake, itself a hazardous waste site.

title: Jorge Bolet, Pianist, Is Dead at 75; Specialist in Romantic Literature
description: Jorge Bolet, a Cuban-born virtuoso considered one of the leading contemporary exponents of Romantic pianism, died early Tuesday afternoon at his home in Mountain View, Calif., south of San Francisco. He was 75 years old.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The evidence is irrefutable.

title: Daniel Guilet, Violinist, Is Dead; Beaux Arts Trio Founder Was 91
description: Daniel Guilet, a violinist who was concertmaster of the NBC Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini and a founding member of the Beaux Arts Trio, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Hospital Cuts Aren't Hurting Care for Elderly, Study Says
description: A comprehensive national study has found that measures to limit Federal health costs have not reduced the quality of hospital care for the elderly, as many experts had feared.

title: Richard J. Hummler A Variety Editor, 47
description: Richard J. Hummler, the theater editor and critic of Variety, a weekly newspaper of the entertainment industry, was found dead yesterday afternoon at his home in Manhattan. He was 47 years old.

title: Sweetbreads: Loved But Misunderstood
description: SOMETIMES people have no idea what they are eating, and more often than not it is probably better that they not ask.

title: Labor Talks Begin With Charges of Meddling
description: Negotiations between New York City and its labor unions began yesterday on a bitter note with union leaders assailing what they called meddling by two prominent public figures.

title: Guatemalan Church Fights Evangelical's Rise
description: The campaign for the presidential election in November has intensified a bitter theological battle here that pits Christian against Christian in a war for this country's nine million souls.

title: Learning to Turn Dimes Into Millions
description: A TALL, regal woman with a shock of white hair and a swath of Joan Crawford-red lipstick swept into the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel at 6:30 P.M. Monday, a cyclone of Fracas perfume in her wake. Elaine Whitelaw, the grande dame of the March of Dimes, had arrived. She was wearing a shimmering silver and black striped dress and carrying an unlighted Camel filter cigarette. As usual, everything stopped.

title: Albany Panel Urges Only a Tiny Phone Rise
description: A panel of administrative judges for the state board that regulates New York's utilities recommended today that an $830 million rate increase sought by New York Telephone be denied and a much smaller increase be granted instead.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SHE was an up-to-date Little Red Riding Hood. She was young - no more than 20 - and truly lovely. Instead of a picnic basket, she carried a briefcase, as she hurried down the marble corridor of a midtown office building about 5 P.M., high heels clicking.

title: Doing Summer Right
description: It was disconcerting to learn the other day that some of the discomfort everybody suffered last summer was caused not by heat or humidity but by a newfangled thermometer. The thermometer, the Weather Service has explained, suffered from what it calls aspiration problems brought on by a faulty fan. It registered temperatures several degrees higher than they actually were and its delirious reports all the way from Albany to Arizona made susceptible people feel much hotter than they actually were.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: A's ('Yes, We Lost') Look to the Future
description: With the calm to be expected of reigning World Series champions, the Oakland Athletics didn't make excuses and were already looking to Game 2 after having been shut out by the Reds, 7-0, in tonight's opener.

title: Flea Markets Mean Lost Sales-Tax Revenue
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Reports First Death From Encephalitis Epidemic
description: The recent epidemic of St. Louis encephalitis has claimed its first fatality in Florida, the state's first death caused by the virus in 13 years, a state health official said today.

title: Manuscript From 1513 Is Returned to Germany
description: A second manuscript from the Quedlinburg treasures, missing since the closing days of World War II in Europe, has been returned to Germany by an anonymous collector. The manuscript is in Berlin undergoing restoration, a spokesman for a private German foundation said yesterday.

title: Goldsmith And Hanson Plan Swap
description: Hanson P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed with Sir James Goldsmith to swap its 49 percent interest in the Newmont Mining Company for Cavenham Forest Industries. Cavenham, a large United States forest products company, is controlled by the British-French financier.

title: Honeywell Posts Profit
description: Honeywell Inc. today reported a 12.2 percent earnings increase in the third quarter on a strong gain in its space and aviation business. Including a $3.3 million loss from the spinoff of a large portion of its defense business, the controls maker posted profits of $83.5 million, or $2.21 a share, in the quarter, compared with $74.4 million, or $1.73 a share, for the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose 4.1 percent, to $1.56 billion. Operating profit for the company's space and aviation sector was $55.2 million.

title: A Highly Touted Ranger Import Is Making Little Impact
description: There are moments, a couple of months worth of moments, when Milo Horava's difficulty with the English language is as much a blessing as a burden. What joy, after all, there would be in discovering all the different words for disappointment, what thrill there would be in mastering the conjugation of the verb to regret. ''But I'm not complaining,'' said Horava. There is much that Horava, the Ranger defenseman who arrived from Czechoslovakia in the spring of 1989, is not doing and has not done, and the fact that he is not complaining is an achievement of estimable humility and admirable courage.

title: Girl, 13, Hit by Stray Bullet
description: A 13-year-old girl was hit in the stomach by a stray bullet accidentally fired through the floor by two young men playing with guns in a three-family house at 9535 Lefferts Boulevard in Richmond Hill, Queens, the police said. The girl, whose name was withheld by the police, was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital. Two suspects, Eduardo Ortiz, 23, of 2420 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn, and a 14-year-old boy, whose name was not released, were charged with assault and criminal possession of a deadly weapon.

title: Review/Recital;   Russian Works for Piano
description: Vladimir Viardo's three-recital survey of the Russian literature for solo piano, which the Soviet artist initiated on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall, began on an unscheduled somber note. In homage to Leonard Bernstein, the Soviet musician prefaced his program with Scriabin's Prelude in E minor (Op. 11), whose slow, limping pace and muffled harmonies perfectly evoked the mourning mood.

title: To Oslo, Via Vilnius
description: Few Champagne corks popped in Lithuania at the news of Mikhail Gorbachev's Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Kansas Journal;   Russians and Americans Bury an Era
description: The Russians are conquering the hearts of people in America's heartland, if the warm receptions given so far to a Soviet delegation here for a weeklong series of conferences with American citizens are any indication.

title: Kuwaitis Tell of New Round of Terror
description: Kuwaitis who have managed to leave their country in recent days say Iraqi security officers have been executing Kuwaiti prisoners in the presence of their families in what appears to be a new round of terror.

title: Camera Class Puts Life Of Homeless in Focus
description: Claire Flanders, a professional photographer, and 10-year-old Charlene Williams huddled together over a magnifying glass, scanning a contact sheet of photographs taken by Charlene.

title: Agency Reports Little Oversight Of Adult Homes
description: New York State authorities failed for 12 years to eliminate widespread abuses in private adult homes for the mentally ill, and the state has no idea how $150 million in public money is being spent annually in these institutions, a state monitoring agency asserted yesterday.

title: Administration Is Lobbying To Dilute El Salvador Aid Cut
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other senior Administration officials are making a strenuous, 11th-hour lobbying effort to persuade the Senate to water down legislation that would cut military aid to El Salvador by half.

title: French Defy Lebanon; Aoun Kept in Embassy
description: Lebanese Government troops ringed the French Embassy in East Beirut today after France said it would not hand over a renegade Christian general, Michel Aoun, to the Lebanese authorities to stand trial.

title: Digging Into the Greek Tragedy of George Polk
description: In Greece, she has provoked a storm. On one side, the conservative president of parliament has accused her of ''vulgar lies'' and is threatening to sue her. On the other, a former Socialist minister says he will use her book to seek a retrial in the case of George Polk, the distinguished CBS foreign correspondent murdered in northern Greece in 1948.

title: Questioning Completed In One Milken Charge
description: The last witness to testify in the first part of the pre-sentencing hearing of Michael R. Milken implied yesterday that a Government witness had lied in his earlier testimony.

title: Deployment, Fast; Procurement, Hasty
description: The Pentagon has spent $2.6 trillion in tax dollars over the past decade. What have Americans been getting for their money? Many weapons needed for security, to judge from the Persian Gulf crisis. But also some that can only make taxpayers wonder how much has been well spent.

title: Douglas Aircraft Cutting 1,200 Jobs
description: The Douglas Aircraft Company will lay off 1,200 workers at its Long Beach and Torrance, Calif., operations this year. An executive of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation unit said the company also wants to cut its work force by an additional 1,500 workers in 1991.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;

Accounts
description: LEAD: * NBC and the Cablevision Systems Corp.'s pay-per-view account to DMB&B; Entertainment, Los Angeles, for all media planning and buying, with undetermined billings. Other agencies are handling the creative aspects of the account, which has a budget of more than $40 milion.

title: Colts Sign Ferguson
description: The Indianapolis Colts have reached an agreement with the veteran quarterback Joe Ferguson as a backup to the starter, Jack Trudeau, Coach Ron Meyer said yesterday. The quarterback move was prompted by injuries to the rookie Jeff George and the veteran Mark Herrmann.

title: Creditor Ends Campeau Pact
description: The Campeau Corporation, the Canadian owner of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, said yesterday that the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, a big developer that lent the Canadian company $480 million in 1988, had refused to renew an agreement not to seize collateral from Campeau without prior notice.

title: Profits Up at Microsoft and Down at Lotus
description: The Microsoft Corporation today reported strong gains in revenues and earnings, while the Lotus Development Corporation reported declining earnings on essentially flat sales, which it attributed to upgrading its most popular product.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Capital and Research Corp., Farifax, Va., an environmental consulting company, named Marilyn F. Meigs vice president and director of government relations for its ICF Kaiser Engineers subsidiary.

title: Bush, a Washington Insider, Stumps As an Outsider Against Washington
description: Twenty days before his first set of midterm Congressional elections, George Bush has settled on a message: the President of the United States is campaigning as an outsider against Washington.

title: Fuel Rods Dropped at Indian Point But Tests Show No Radiation
description: Technicians at the Indian Point 3 power plant accidentally dropped a highly radioactive bundle of nuclear fuel about 10 feet yesterday, and immediately evacuated the reactor building as a precaution. But tests of air and water in the building did not show any release of radiation, so workers re-entered the building last night and began securing the fuel.

title: Jersey to Propose Locker-Room Ban
description: Reacting to the recent national controversy over female sportswriters in locker rooms, a New Jersey legislator proposed today to prohibit all news media interviews for 30 minutes after the conclusion of sporting events.

title: Oops, It's Not Like Old Times As Stewart Hits a Roadblock
description: Dave Stewart had won his last six post-season starts, limiting the opposition to 1.88 earned runs per nine innings.

title: Sundstrand Fraud Case
description: A Federal judge today acquitted three former Sundstrand Corporation executives of wrongdoing in a scheme by the aerospace contractor to defraud the Pentagon.

title: Charlie Hustle: Only Human
description: As the World Series began last night at Cincinnati's Riverfront Stadium, on Pete Rose Way, Charlie Hustle was in uniform, olive-green khaki pants and shirt, and he was wearing his number. Peter Edward Rose, formerly No. 14 of the Cincinnati Reds, is temporarily Federal prisoner No. 01832-061 at the minimum-security prison at Marion, Ill.

title: Bluefish Fans Know This: The Only Good Fish Is a Fresh Fish
description: ONE of the joys of a New England fall is to fish for bluefish. Very often, I drag net from the shore to pick up the four- to five-inch specimens we call snapper blues. These tiny fish are terrific pan-fried or sauteed.

title: Chronicle
description: Four educators and health professionals have won the Charles A. Dana Awards for Pioneering Education. Dr. NORBERT HIRSCHHORN, a public-health consultant, helped develop oral rehydration therapy, used for children suffering from acute diarrhea. Dr. JOHN W. FARQUHAR, professor of disease prevention at Stanford University Medical School, is being honored for demonstrating the effectiveness of health education campaigns on heart disease. DAVID A. MICKLOS, director of the DNA Learning Center at Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., developed a program to give high-school biology teachers experience with DNA technology. And DAVID P. BILLINGTON, an engineering professor at Princeton University, has developed curriculums and text integrating the study of the sciences and the humanities.

title: Singapore Recruiting
description: A group of employers in Singapore, seeking to ease a shortage of skilled workers, will send recruiters abroad next spring to interview Singapore natives and other Asians studying in British and North American universities. Officials estimate that up to 80,000 workers are needed to supplement Singapore's work force of 1.2 million.

title: Chronicle
description: PETER USTINOV was knighted yesterday, an occasion that he viewed with irreverance. After his visit to Buckingham Palace, Sir Peter said, ''The Queen said she was glad, and I said I was touched.''

title:
Real Estate;

San Diego Area to Get New Resorts
description: LEAD: THE long-dormant luxury resort market in the coastal area north of San Diego has sprung to life in recent months, as two international resort operators move ahead with building plans.

title: GORBACHEV OFFERS HIS PLAN TO REMAKE SOVIET ECONOMY, BUT INCLUDES NO TIMETABLE
description: After months of wavering, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent the Soviet Parliament a compromise economic reform program today that calls for dismantling the state's economic monopoly, but set no timetable.

title: INSIDE
description: 3 Nobel Laureates In Economic Science

title: State of Art Machines Cut Mammogram Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants' Banks Sidelined After Wrist Surgery
description: Carl Banks, the Giants' Pro Bowl outside linebacker, underwent surgery today on his dislocated left wrist.

title: Davis Does an Effective Job of Destroying the Doubts
description: Eric Davis, the stoic left fielder of the Cincinnati Reds, always ponders one of his sensational nights at the plate as if it were a humiliating four-strikeout affair, holding his emotions and thoughts very close to his heart.

title: Pontiac, Mich.
description: THE vicissitudes of the United States auto industry have been tough on once-thriving factory towns like Pontiac. Not many people test Pontiac's seemingly lifeless downtown, a 40-minute drive from downtown Detroit.

title: Bridge
description: At the World Championships in Geneva last month, players of different nationalities were for the first time permitted to be partners in the minor events. Two of the few who took advantage of this were Jean Besse of Switzerland and Boris Schapiro of Britain, who have both played major roles in the game's history.

title: William Minshall, 79, Ex-Ohio Congressman
description: William E. Minshall, who served as a Republican Congressman from Ohio for 20 years before he retired in 1974, died Monday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 79 years old.

title: Iraq's Seesaw Diplomacy: Threats and Entreaties
description: Saddam Hussein is sending decidedly mixed political signals about his intentions toward Kuwait, thus causing Arab and Western moods and expectations to shift and complicating efforts by the United States and its allies to forge a coherent strategy for getting Iraqi forces out of Kuwait.

title: Agricultural Trade Snag
description: The United States is not alone in its determination to walk away from global trade talks if the European Community continues to block broad agreement to cut farm subsidies, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS

title: More Woes at Sumitomo
description: The giant Sumitomo Bank Ltd., whose chairman, Ichiro Isoda, resigned last week in the wake of a stock manipulation scandal involving a branch manager, received more setbacks today.

title: The Status of Some of the Major Pieces of Legislation Before Congress
description: Child Care

title: One Team Does Dominate in Game 1: the Reds
description: The Oakland Athletics, heavily favored for one more coronation as the ruling family of baseball, suffered a rude jolt tonight when the Cincinnati Reds rose up, hammered Dave Stewart for four innings and bushwhacked the Athletics, 7-0, in the opening game of the 87th World Series.

title: Reds 7, Athletics 0
description: Yes, it was a mismatch.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Archer Communications Inc., Calgary, Alberta, said Warner Brothers Records will issue an album in November using Archer's patented Qsound process.

title: Maine Asks U.S. to Deny License to Dam Owners
description: Gov. John R. McKernan of Maine broke off talks today with the owners of the Edwards Dam, one of the oldest hydroelectric dams in the state, and asked Federal officials to deny the owners' request for relicensing.

title: Dow Drops by 35.15, Despite Late Rally
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday as oil prices rose, but rallied slightly in the final 15 minutes on a report that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq might accept a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis.

title: 300 Are Laid Off By Burger King
description: The Burger King Corporation has laid off 300 employees nationwide and plans to close more than a third of its field offices in a move to streamline the company and pay more attention to franchisees.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: India Temporizes, Violently, in Kashmir
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday showing how taxes would change for various incomes under three Federal budget proposals misidentified the kind of taxes involved. The percentage changes were for all Federal taxes, not just income taxes.

title: Bank Yields Are Mixed In Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were narrowly mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: His Long Timeout Over, Rohan Tries to Revive Columbia Basketball
description: Imagine this: A former basketball coach nearing retirement who has absolutely nothing left to prove is offered his old job 16 years after he decided to step down. The school won only 4 of 26 games the previous season and has not had a winning season in almost a decade.

title: Political Careerism Is the Bane of True Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;

Ray Charles Stars As Blackglama Legend
description: LEAD: Ray Charles is the latest spokesman in the Blackglama fur campaign, and all the company had to do was to give him a coat off its back -in this case a custom-made mink trench coat worth an estimated $15,000.

title: Cold Days? Warm Stew, Hot Debate
description: LIKE stubborn leaves finally falling, cooks drift into the season of slow cooking. Cool weather sends society scurrying from the campfire to the fireplace. A communal cauldron full of slow-simmered stew seems to swing gently over any thought of dinner. Yet cooks stickle against the stew state of mind.

title: Gold Prices Plummet Again On Mine Companies' Woes
description: Gold prices dropped again yesterday, with the latest burst of selling attributed largely to mining companies that are selling future bullion output because of their increasing inability to obtain bank financing.

title: Robert Leonard; Voice Teacher, 49
description: Robert Leonard, a voice teacher whose pupils included opera and theater singers, died Thursday in London. He was 49 years old and had homes in London and New York. Friends in New York said Mr. Leonard died of tuberculosis. Among his students were June Anderson, Michele Lagrange, Ashley Putnam, Patti LuPone, Kevin Kline and Linda Ronstadt.

title: Senate Roll-Call on the Civil Rights Bill
description: Following is the 62-to-34 roll-call vote by which the Senate tonight approved a civil rights bill to combat job discrimination. A yes vote was a vote to approve the bill; a no vote was a vote against it. Voting yes were 53 Democrats and 9 Republicans. Voting no were no Democrats and 34 Republicans. Senators not voting are denoted by xxx.

title: IRAQIS ARE HINTING AT A COMPROMISE; U.S. REJECTS TERMS
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had indicated tentative interest in a compromise settlement of the Kuwait crisis but that Washington considered the terms unacceptable and continued to insist that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait before any talks begin.

title: Mack Trucks' Chief to Resign
description: Ralph E. Reins will resign as chairman, president and chief executive of Mack Trucks Inc., a company spokesman said today.

title: Reappraising Home Ec
description: To The Living Section:

title: Regan Sees Large Rise In Budget Gap
description: Providing the first hard evidence of how severely the state's fiscal fortunes may be sliding, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, announced yesterday that New York State ran up a budget gap of almost $250 million for the first half of the fiscal year.

title: Japan's Leadership Backs Plan to Send Soldiers to the Gulf
description: The Japanese Cabinet approved a plan today to send troops to the Persian Gulf in the country's first military foray abroad since the end of World War II, but it immediately ran into a storm of opposition at home and among Japan's Asian neighbors.

title: EARLIER HARM SEEN IN GLOBAL WARMING
description: After two years of study, an international group of scientists working under United Nations auspices has found that global warming could cause serious environmental damage starting in the early years of the next century, long before the maximum temperature levels predicted by many scientists are reached.

title: Crowder of Devils Not the Retiring Type; The Forward Makes His Presence Felt
description: Thirteen months after he gave up on hockey, Troy Crowder of the Devils has become an enforcer in the National Hockey League as well as a player with skills good enough to enable him to take a regular shift.

title: Senate Passes Rights Bill, but Vote Is Not Enough to Override Veto
description: The Senate approved the final version of a major civil rights bill tonight but not by enough votes to overturn a threatened veto by President Bush.

title: Late Rally Lifts Treasury Issues
description: A late rally pushed up prices of Treasury securities and moved interest rates lower at the end of a generally slow session yesterday.

title: Review/Film;   Exploring the Underside of the Upper Class
description: ''That was my body,'' says the voice of the comatose Sunny von Bulow (Glenn Close) on the sound track at the beginning of ''Reversal of Fortune.'' Looking as still as death but serene and, somehow, very rich, she lies in bed in a hospital room, attached to machines that efficiently feed and cleanse her system.

title: Market Place;   Contrarian Bets On Soviet Future
description: THERE have been shortages from cigarettes to bread. The troubled Government is still seeking the right plan for a quick, but still painful, transition from the centrally run Communist economy to a market system. And the staying power of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, despite his Nobel Peace Prize, is in doubt.

title: The People's Shilling
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Decides Not to Reopen Plant That Makes Plutonium for Bombs
description: In an announcement that effectively takes the Government out of the business of making plutonium for nuclear bombs, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said yesterday that his department would not reopen a chemical processing plant near Richland, Wash., for weapons work.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Occupy a 2d Provincial Capital
description: Fighting between the Soviet-backed Government and fundamentalist Muslim guerrillas has flared up in southeastern Afghanistan, and there were reports today that Kalat, the capital of Zabul Province, has fallen to the rebels.

title: Coke Bottler's Net Up 80.8%
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises, the world's largest Coca-Cola bottler, said yesterday that third-quarter profits rose 80.8 percent, to $15 million, or 13 cents a share, from $8.3 million, or 6 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title:
Books of The Times;

A Chance for America To Discover Columbus
Jerusalem Mayor Splits With Israel on Inquiry
description: A few small cracks are beginning to appear in Israel's blanket rejection of the United Nations mission charged with investigating the shooting deaths of 21 Palestinians at Al Aksa Mosque last week.

title: Quebec Hydropower Battle Entangles Utilities in U.S.
description: New York and New England power officials have become reluctant participants in a dispute over whether one of Canada's biggest utilities should expand its generating capacity.

title: Brazilian Airline In Boeing Order
description: The Brazilian airline Varig has placed orders for as many as 26 Boeing aircraft in a deal valued at up to $2.6 billion, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said. The order came a day after United Airlines placed what could be the largest commercial aircraft order in history: $22 billion for as many as 128 planes.

title: Sallie Mae Named in Suit
description: Two former managers of the Student Loan Marketing Association, which is known as Sallie Mae, have filed suit charging that the big purchaser of student loans engaged in loan fraud and a cover-up. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it was investigating the charges.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;

Albuquerque, N.M.
description: LEAD: NEW MEXICANS debate the merits of rival green chili dishes as fervently as Texans debate barbecue or Louisianians crayfish. The fiery pepper, grown 175 miles south of Albuquerque in the Hatch Valley, can be served with nearly anything, even fast-food hamburgers, and bragging rights among restaurants are hard won.

title: Early Release Possible
description: Bruce Kimball, the former Olympic diver, has served 21 months of a 17-year prison term on two manslaughter convictions caused when his car killed two people and injured five others after crashing into a crowd in Brandon, Fla., in 1988. Tests showed that Kimball had a level of alcohol twice that of legal drunkenness.

title: A Festival From India At Seaport
description: LEAD: Imagine a holiday that combines all the festivities of Christmas, New Year's Eve and the Fourth of July in one gigantic celebration. Dewali, India's great Festival of Lights, is just such a celebration, a grand jubilee bright with fireworks, spectacular pageants, elaborate decorations, sumptuous feasting and seemingly endless merrymaking.

title: In Cities of Iraq, Food Abounds, Not Spare Parts
description: More than two months after the United Nations imposed a trade embargo on Iraq, Baghdad and other large cities are enjoying an unexpected bounty of fruit, vegetables and canned goods. As a result, diplomats here believe it will be many months, perhaps a year or more, before food shortages begin to put pressure on the Government of President Saddam Hussein.

title: Police Dramas on TV Were Always Popular; Now They're Real
description: Police work is portrayed on television more often than any other profession. It has been that way since the cowboys rode off into the television sunset.

title: Dinkins Orders Agencies to Draft Plans for $1 Billion in Cutbacks
description: The Dinkins administration told city agencies yesterday to prepare to cut more than $1 billion in programs and services from their operating budgets over the next 21 months to help close expected budget gaps.

title: G.E.'s Net Rises 9% In Quarter
description: Although its performance was hampered by the weakening of the economy, the General Electric Company said yesterday that its net income climbed 9 percent in the third quarter, to $1.03 billion, from $945 million in the 1989 period.

title: Plan Would Revise Farm Subsidies
description: House and Senate conferees reached agreement today on a $41 billion, five-year farm policy that changes the structure of commodity price supports and includes the strongest environmental provisions of any farm legislation in history.

title: Another Change at Top At Fieldcrest Cannon
description: Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., the maker of bedroom and bathroom textiles, rugs and carpets, has made another change in its top management, choosing James M. Fitzgibbons as chairman and chief executive. He succeeds Joseph B. Ely 2d, who is retiring from the company.

title: Obscenity or Art? Trial on Rap Lyrics Opens
description: The obscenity trial of the rap music group 2 Live Crew began here today, with the volatile ingredient of race added to already complex arguments about artistic freedom and a community's right to restrict sexual material.

title: Excerpts From Gorbachev's Economic Program
description: Following are excerpts from the proposed economic program submitted today to the Soviet legislature by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Fooling Around With Taxes
description: The House is on the verge of passing a $500 billion deficit reduction package. But it is hard to take the bill seriously. It includes amendments imposing stiff tax increases, aimed at the rich, that are unlikely to pass the Senate and that President Bush is sure to veto.

title: 3d Chess Game a Draw After Early Fireworks
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov struggled through 13 moves of a thorny, problem-ridden endgame to a draw last night in the third game of their World Championship Chess Match in Manhattan.

title: Charles S. Garland Jr.; Investment Executive, 63
description: Charles S. Garland Jr., managing director of the Baltimore securities firm of Alex. Brown & Sons, died Saturday at his home in Baltimore. He was 63 years old. His family said he died of cancer.

title: John Adams Bross, 79, Lawyer and U.S. Aide
description: John Adams Bross Sr., a lawyer and former Federal aide, died yesterday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 79 years old and also had a home in Peterborough, N.H.

title: Book Notes
description: Paz a Known Quantity

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT may just be my personal preferences at work, but it seems that pork is making a comeback among American home cooks. For one thing, the pork industry has made great strides in producing a leaner product. And it has effectively conveyed that message to the consumer.

title: Boris B. Piotrovsky, Archeologist; Director of the Hermitage Was 82
description: Prof. Boris B. Piotrovsky, the director of the Hermitage in Leningrad, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in that city on Monday, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. He was 82 years old.

title: Volvo Cutbacks
description: The Swedish auto maker Volvo A.B. said it wanted to cut production of its main large models by about 7 percent, or 18,200 cars, in 1991 from this year's level because of declining sales forecasts. A Volvo spokesman said the cuts would be in the 700 and 200 series, while production of the new 900 series would continue as planned.

title: Raines Wants Trade
description: Tim Raines, who has spent a dozen seasons in a Montreal Expo uniform, has informed General Manager David Dombroski that he would not object to a trade to one of five National League teams that play on natural grass: the Mets, the Atlanta Braves, the Chicago Cubs, the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Diego Padres.

title: Occidental Net Rises Slightly
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that its net income rose a mere nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $109 million, or 36 cents a share, in the third quarter, compared with $108 million, or 39 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. The earnings a share figures reflect an increase in the number of shares to 295 million, from 275 million.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

The Man Behind the Voice of Commercials
description: LEAD: FEW know his name, but Thom Sharp, a 42-year-old former copywriter from Detroit, is one of the busiest voices in commercials, and perhaps one of the most familiar.

title: WINE TALK
description: FOR many years, there was an excellent Greek restaurant on Eighth Avenue between 43d and 44th Streets, just around the corner from my office. It was called the Parthenon, and some of the freshest fish in New York came from its kitchen. For the regulars there was always a simple oinos lefkos, an expensive Greek white wine, with just the right acidity to match the oil in the fish. What was the name of it? What difference? The restaurant is gone now, and with it, one of the few chances to find decent Greek wines in New York. Oh, they turn up now and then, but almost exclusively in other Greek restaurants. They are considered an ethnic item, like taramosalata or sweet coffee with the grounds in the cup.

title: Old Marxist Returns, With Hope for South Africa
description: In the world of emerging political movements Joe Slovo is an anachronism, an avuncular white man lionized in South African black townships as a symbol of resistance against apartheid, a committed Marxist with an ideology that many thought had collapsed with the Berlin wall and a politician glad-handing his way across South Africa after years as a clandestine guerrilla leader.

title: Citicorp Earnings Drop 38%
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, announced a 38 percent decline in its earnings for the third quarter yesterday, with strong profits in consumer banking but large losses in real estate lending.

title: Foreign Workers Leaving Eastern Germany
description: When she thinks back to her days in Dresden in the 1970's as an electrical-engineering student, Nguyen Lien's eyes glow.

title: Two Airlines to Raise Fares Again
description: Continental Airlines and Northwest Airlines announced another round of fare increases yesterday to help offset the soaring cost of aviation fuel. If the increases stick, airline fares will have risen at least 15 percent in the two months since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, one of the steepest rises in the industry's history over such a short period.

title: Census Spot-Checks Disclose Mistakes in Cities' Counting
description: Early spot-checks by Census Bureau workers have found that some cities, including New York and Boston, have made the same kinds of mistakes that the bureau has been accused of making: putting some houses where they do not exist.

title: England Loses Miami-Arkansas
description: The Miami Hurricanes' 1991 season opener against Arkansas will not be played in Manchester, England, as had been scheduled.

title: Revenue Bonds For Illinois Project
description: The Village of Hoffman Estates in Cook and Kane Counties in Illinois has tentatively priced $111.5 million in tax-increment revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Korea Talks Resume; Seoul Sees Reasons for Caution
description: The Prime Ministers of North and South Korea today formally began their second round of negotiations to reduce tensions as South Koreans cautioned against expecting any sort of breakthrough on the military and political issues dividing them.

title: Cureton Taking His Chances With Knicks
description: The Knicks have a major problem as they open the preseason portion of their National Basketball Association schedule against the Philadelphia 76ers on Thursday night in Albany. They have 15 players on the roster, 13 of whom have guaranteed contracts. By the start of the regular season, Nov. 2, the team must cut down to 12.

title: Albert J. Harris, 82, Professor of Education
description: Albert J. Harris, an education professor and a leader in the teaching of reading, died on Monday at White Plains Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in West Palm Beach, Fla., and New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Action in Congress
description: AGRICULTURE Negotiators approved a package of $13.6 billion in cuts in farm programs.

title: Court Says Job Hazards May Be a Crime
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that state prosecutors can file criminal charges, including murder and assault, against employers for injuring their employees at work.

title: About New York;   On Baseball, Too, A Maven Seeks The Last Word
description: The last time we saw David Shulman, a little over a year ago, he was kibitzing the National Scrabble Championship. As always, he had proffered a fragment of knowledge. He suggested that the word ''Manhattan'' was an Indian phrase meaning ''the place where we all get drunk.''

title: Merrill Lynch Net Up; Schwab Has Big Gain
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest broker, yesterday reported a 12.4 percent rise in its third- quarter earnings from last year. The company said, however, that the Middle East crisis and ''inconclusive Federal budget deliberations'' led to declines in investment banking activity and retail commissions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about fighting in Lebanon reversed the descriptions of East and West Beirut. East Beirut is predominantly Christian, West Beirut mainly Muslim.

title: HOUSE APPROVES DEMOCRATIC PLAN TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: Eleven days after it rejected the budget compromise struck by President Bush and Congressional leaders, the House of Representatives voted tonight for a new Democratic plan that would sharply raise the income taxes of the wealthy.

title: Student Protest Movement Expands, and Its Voice Is That of the Consumer
description: It was a situation guaranteed to warm the heart of any campus radical of the 1960's.

title: Hackett Stars in Goal; Sutter Sparks Offense
description: The struggling Islanders played like world-beaters tonight. The struggling Winnipeg Jets played as if they would rather be watching the World Series on television. The result was a 4-1 Islander victory that featured notable performances by several members of the home team.

title: Del Monte President Gets Chief's Post, Too
description: Del Monte Foods said yesterday that it had promoted its president, A. Ewan Macdonald, to the additional position of chief executive. He succeeds Robert J. Carbonell, 63, who will continue as chairman.

title: Net Dips at United Telecom; GTE, Southwest Bell in Rise
description: United Telecom, which owns 80.1 percent of U S Sprint, reported a small drop in third-quarter earnings yesterday, while GTE and Southwestern Bell posted earnings increases that were slightly higher than expected.

title: Holes in the Fish Safety Net
description: While meat and poultry have long been subject to mandatory Federal inspection, there is no comparable program to protect the public from contaminated fish - despite a marked rise in fish consumption by consumers seeking to cut down on dietary fat. Legislation set for a vote today in the House would begin to close this gaping hole in the food safety net.

title: A Storm Wider Than Earth Forms Abruptly Over Saturn
description: A gargantuan storm one and a half times as wide as the Earth has developed in Saturn's atmosphere, and the Hubble Space Telescope may be used to watch it, astronomers said today.

title: 'Baby Boomers' Donate More, a Survey Says
description: Americans in the 25-to 44-year age group have substantially increased their contributions of money and volunteer time to charities, belying the popular perception that they are an ego-centered generation, a new survey shows.

title: China's No. 2 Didn't Invoke Jack Kennedy
description: If Dan Quayle ever gets annoyed at the jokes made about him, he should hear what is said about China's Vice President.

title: Nasty Boys Making Their Farewells
description: No matter what happens in this World Series, take a good look at the Nasty Boys. They won't be back, at least in their present form.

title: Dole, in Twist of Fate, Leads Charge for Bush, The Rival He Scorned
description: On the private balcony that adjoins his office and commands a sweeping view of Washington's monuments, Bob Dole is squinting into the autumn sun and plotting a budget strategy to save face for George Bush's White House.

title: Tokyo Journal;   Tatami or Colonial, a House Is Wishful Thinking
description: Hiroshi Akizuki, a 27-year-old computer programmer, wandered into a Queen Anne-style model house with his girlfriend the other day, peered up the giant central staircase, inspected the elegant brick fireplace in the parlor and pondered the question of whether he would ever live like this.

title: A Lawmaker Breaks Ranks Over Fairness
description: ''I was with two groups of conservative Republicans in rural Vermont last weekend,'' said Representative Peter Smith, a Republican who represents the entire state. ''I asked them whether anyone opposed creating a new tax bracket for people who earned more than $150,000 a year. Nobody raised his hand.''

title: Review/Music;   Bob Dylan and His Ever-Changing Oldies
description: In three years of continuous touring, Bob Dylan has been retraining his audience along the lines of the Grateful Dead's Deadheads. Fans have learned to expect uneven but improvisatory concerts in which some songs are throwaways, some are near misses, a few are set pieces and some glean new insights from well-worn words and music. Uptempo songs bring dancers to the aisles.

title: Five Big Drug Companies Show Strong Income Gains
description: Riding high in the face of economic weaknesses that have reduced profits in other industries, five major pharmaceutical companies reported strong gains in quarterly earnings yesterday.

title: Top Executive Ousted At New Haven Register
description: The top executive at The New Haven Register was dismissed Monday night by the paper's owner, the Journal Register Company, after he resisted the second round of layoffs in a month, reportedly on the ground that they would seriously damage the newspaper.

title: Rinfret's No. 2 Hopes for Nibble from Voters
description: Some politicians give out campaign buttons or bumper stickers when they take to the hustings. George F. T. (Geff) Yancey Jr. hands out cheese.

title: Harnessing Hundreds of Computers to Improve Speed and Efficiency
description: In the 1960's and 1970's, dozens or hundreds of users shared a single large computer - one computer, many users. In the 1980's, the growing availability of inexpensive microprocessors ushered in another era -one computer, one user. Now researchers at more than four dozen laboratories and universities in the United States and Europe are reinventing software to harness the power of hundreds or even thousands of computers - one user, many computers.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;

Miscellany
description: LEAD: * Ogilvy & Mather Direct, New York, has opened two offices. One, in Coral Gables, Fla., will be run by George Machun; the other, in Seattle, by Larry Rinaldi.

title: KEY RATES
The Pop Life
description: Vanilla Ice Crosses Over

title: Marguerite Wagstaff, Painter, Is Dead at 91
description: Marguerite Falkenburg Wagstaff, a painter and a former tennis champion in Brazil, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old. She died of pneumonia, her family said. Mrs. Wagstaff, who was known as Mickey, met her first husband, Eugene Falkenburg, on a tennis court in Spain, where he was chief engineer for Westinghouse. They were married in Barcelona and their daughter, Eugenia, the model and television personality known as Jinx, was born there.

title: Catalyst Selling Energy Unit Stake
description: The Catalyst Energy Corporation, a privately owned power producer, hired Lehman Brothers to seek a buyer for its 83.5 percent stake in the United Thermal Corporation, a producer and distributor of steam and heat. Catalyst was taken private in a 1988 leveraged buyout led by Thomas B. Pickens 3d, the youngest son of T. Boone Pickens.

title: EATING WELL
description: UNTIL the 1980's, calcium was viewed as a rather pedestrian nutrient. But that all changed when health experts said eating more calcium could prevent osteoporosis, a debilitating condition resulting from a progressive loss of bone. Osteoporosis affects 25 million people in the United States, 80 percent of them women.

title: India Temporizes, Violently, in Kashmir;   Strength in Secularism
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas That Changed Wall St. And Fathered Mutual Funds
description: Few Nobel awards in economics, it is safe to say, will be as enthusiastically received within the profession as this year's award to Harry M. Markowitz, Merton H. Miller and William F. Sharpe.

title: Cracking the Coalition
description: The deaths of 21 Palestinians from Israeli police gunfire have made it clear that the U.S. could not keep Arab nations in its shaky Middle East military coalition if it launched a military offensive against Iraq and Saddam Hussein.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: A Crime Victim Asks, 'Where Is Justice?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Blakey, Jazz Great, Is Dead; A Drummer and Band Leader, 71
description: The drummer and band leader Art Blakey, one of the most influential figures in jazz for the last 40 years, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 U.S. Economists Win Nobel
description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science was awarded today to three Americans whose pioneering work provided new tools for weighing the risks and rewards of different investments and for valuing corporate stocks and bonds.

title: Dukakis Still Buoyant Despite Tough Times
description: This has not been a good year for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Chronicle
description: CARLOS SANTANA sued the Miller Brewing Company and its advertising agency for producing a television commercial that he said imitates his version of ''Black Magic Woman,'' a signature song. While Mr. Santana did not write the song, he popularized it in the late 1970's and has sung it on several albums. The suit was filed in San Francisco Federal Court on Monday.

title: Professors With Influence Far Beyond Their Schools
description: Harry M. Markowitz

title: 3 Strong California S.& L.'s Raise Loan-Loss Reserves
description: Three of the nation's largest and healthiest savings institutions said today that they were substantially increasing their reserves for possible losses on real estate loans.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of dividend meetings in Business Day on Monday misstated the date for Ryder System Inc. It is Friday; it was not yesterday.

title: Quake-Damaged City a Year Later: A Slow Recovery Amid Grim Ruins
description: The downtown of this seaside city still resembles a war zone - empty lots surrounded by cyclone fences. Frustrated with the pace of recovery from the huge earthquake a year ago, townspeople compare what remains of the Pacific Garden Mall to downtown Beirut.

title: Classic Oversubscribed;#25 Entered for 14 Spots
description: Swelled by a record 25 entrants for the $3 million Classic and a huge contingent of European imports, the seven Breeders' Cup races at Belmont Park on Oct. 27 attracted 110 preliminary entries yesterday.

title: Alaska Is Top Oil State
description: Alaska has surged ahead of Texas as the nation's leading oil producer, topping the two million barrels-a-day mark for the first time since Prudhoe Bay production began to decline in 1988, state officials said this week. Texas, with daily output of 1.7 million barrels, is now the No. 2 producer. Last summer, Alaska's crude oil production dropped to a low of 1.6 million barrels a day. But nearly every oilfield in the state has increased production in the last month, said Dudley Platt, petroleum economist with the Revenue Department.

title: Home Building Off 8th Month in Row
description: Construction of new homes fell in September for the eighth straight month, the Commerce Department said today. The slide is the longest in more than 30 years, as activity slowed to a recession-era pace.

title: Critic's Notebook; Presidential Popularity And the Role Of the Media
description: When a President's popularity goes into decline, he is not likely to blame either himself or the abstraction that politicians in their pious mood call ''the American People.'' To blame oneself, besides being hard on the ego, means giving grist to the opposition; to blame the American People may signify a death wish. So who does one blame? Why, naturally, the media, by which is mainly meant television.

title: 1st Bancorp (Ind) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Snap-On Tools Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: Year-ago periods ended Sept. 30.

title: Knicks, Back in U.S., Routed By Philadelphia in Albany
description: Playing as if they still aren't sure what country they are in, the Knicks were routed, 115-96, by the Philadelphia 76ers tonight in a game that wasn't as close as the final score indicated.

title: Overconfidence, Not Jets, May Be Bills' Big Worry
description: Because the Buffalo Bills drew a bye last weekend, Thurman Thomas dropped from second place to fourth place among rushers in the American Football Conference. But he's expected to regain lost ground on Sunday. After all, Buffalo is playing the Jets again.

title: Nobel Winner Salves a Bruised Baruch
description: The award of a Nobel Prize to a faculty member would bring pride and joy to any campus but for Baruch College, the award of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science on Tuesday to Dr. Harry M. Markowitz had a special poignancy.

title: Handgun Bill To Be Delayed
description: Congressional action on legislation that would require a seven-day waiting period to buy handguns will be put off until next year, Speaker Thomas S. Foley said today. The legislation is known as the Brady bill for the former White House press secretary, James Brady, who was shot and disabled by John W. Hinckley Jr. in the 1981 assassination attempt against President Ronald Reagan.

title: La Petite Academy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NCNB's Net Tumbles 60.3%
description: The NCNB Corporation today reported sharply lower third-quarter earnings, citing problem loans and deterioration in the economy.

title: Another Worry for Baghdad: Kurdish Nationalists at the Back Door
description: As President Saddam Hussein masses troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq, Iraqi security commanders are watching for fresh signs of dissent and rebellion on the country's vulnerable northern flank, in the deserts and valleys of Kurdistan.

title: New Dow Jones Chief Has an Impish Streak
description: Over his lengthy career at Dow Jones & Company, Peter R. Kann has made a lot of mischief, and he just hasn't been able to help it.

title: Callable Bonds For Farm Credit
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced $100 million in callable consolidated systemwide bonds, due 1993, through Lehman Brothers.

title: Stanley Works reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included a gain of $4 million, or 6 cents a share, and $5.4 million, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, due to reductions in LIFO inventories.The net for the 9 months also included a gain of $10 million, or 14 cents a share, from the sale of the company's drapery hardware business in Europe, offset by expenses of $7.1 million for contingent liability reserves and aggregate expense of $4.9 million for non-material items. c-Included for the quarter a charge of $3.2 million of expenses for environmental cleanup and plant consolidation activities, and also included a gain of $4 million, or 6 cents a share, due to reductions in LIFO inventories.The 9 months included a gain of $4 million, or 6 cents a share, due to reductions in LIFO inventories. The net for the 9 months also included a gain of $5.4 million, or 8 cents a share, from the sale of a portion of the company's investment in Max Co. Ltd. and expenses of $5.5 million for environmental cleanup and for plant consolidation.

title: In Connecticut, A Big Silence On Prison Crisis
description: Detailed proposals about crime and punishment have been few and far between in Connecticut's race for governor. Many people inside the state's overwhelmed criminal-justice system say the relative silence has raised the level of campaign honesty.

title: Smith Corona Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kent Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Imperial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Branford Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Latest quarter included a special addition of $8.7 million to the company's loan loss reserve.

title: United Technologies Up
description: The United Technologies Corporation said today that net income in the third quarter rose 22 percent, thanks in large part to a $46.5 million gain from the sale of its majority interest in two Italian automotive companies, Diavia and Aura. Without the gain, earnings would have risen 7.5 percent. Net earnings for the third quarter totaled $239.8 million, or $1.90 a share, on revenues of $5.3 billion, compared with earnings of $196.7 million, or $1.46 a share, on revenues of $4.8 billion in the same period last year.

title: People's Savings (Brockton) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: MCI Accused By A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today accused the MCI Communications Corporation and other long-distance companies of trying to steal its customers, but MCI said the problem had been exaggerated and was mostly due to honest mistakes by its sales staff.

title: Gilbert Sherman, Dentist, 83
description: Dr. Gilbert Sherman, a retired dentist and a former dental director of the Nassau County Departments of Health and of Social Welfare, died on Saturday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Madison, N.J., and in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Currents; Signs of the Other 90's
description: FOUR months ago, when Shoo Hale, an antiques dealer in Yarmouth, Me., paid $85 for a 30-year-old handpainted sign that read ''Eggs,'' she thought the price was too high. That day, she returned home and started painting her own signs.

title: Vitran Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $517,000, or 9 cents a share, from gains on the sale of property. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $140,000, or 3 cents a share, from gains on the sale of property. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Grand Valley Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Market Place;   The Merc's New Nikkei Futures
description: THE Chicago Mercantile Exchange, in its latest bid to provide the broadest array of tools to help investors control risk, introduced a new futures contract last month based on the level of the Japanese stock market. Market professionals say the new contract could be a welcome addition to the investment scene given the increasing amount of investment in Japanese stocks by institutional investors in this country.

title: Review/Dance; Energetic as Usual, Works by Molissa Fenley
description: Molissa Fenley remains one of the experimental dance scene's most independent choreographers, admirably beholden to no faction or fashion. She opened a week of solo concerts on Tuesday night with a program that included her amazing treatment of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring,'' which roused the audience into a frenzy of enthusiasm.

title: MacMillan Bloedel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Parker Hannifin reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,452,000, or 3 cents a share. Sales for 1989 have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Sundstrand Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $500,000 and $2,100,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; both periods included $6.6 million pretax from insurance proceeds in connection with the pending settlement of shareholder lawsuits as well as a charge of $1.9 million, after taxes, related to the closure of the company's Signatron operation. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $300,000 for the quarter; the 9 months included income from discontinued operations of $1,600,000, or 4 cents a share, and a gain of $10.3 million after taxes on the sale of a division. Year-ago share earnings figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1990. Net sales for 1989 included sales of $17.2 million in the first nine months for the company's Trans Com Systems division sold in June 1989; net sales included sales of $16.3 million in the third quarter, and $41.1 million in the first nine months for the company's Maco-Meudon operation acquired in January 1990.

title: Highland Buys Stake in Remy
description: The Highland Distilleries Company P.L.C. said today that it was taking a 30 percent stake in Remy Cointreau of France, blending the assets of Scotland's best-selling whisky maker with a world leader in cognac, champagne and liqueurs.

title: Television Commissions Works by Playwrights
description: The new prime-time season probably features more directors and actors seduced away from the stage than at any time since television's golden age during the 1950's, when the industry was New York-based and could be called an extension of the theater and radio. But recently NBC and Turner Network Television have begun commissioning works from some of the theater's most highly regarded writers - Horton Foote, George C. Wolfe and Arthur Kopit, among them.

title: Myers Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Wright Classic Is Ready for Public
description: In 1988, the Currier Gallery of Art in Manchester, N.H., received a rare and welcome gift: a Frank Lloyd Wright house. Today, it opens to the public after a year of work costing more than $250,000.

title: Trouble or a Challenge? The Whitney and Its Image
description: In its quest to replace Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the director dismissed seven months ago, the Whitney Museum of American Art is finding that its image as a troubled institution continues to haunt it.

title: Great Bay Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Nobels Given in Physics and Chemistry
description: The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded yesterday to two scientists from the United States and one from Canada whose experiments confirmed the existence of quarks, tiny packets of energy that are fundamental building blocks of all matter. An American was also awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing new ways to synthesize complex molecules ordinarily found only in nature.

title: Valmont Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
President Is Appointed By Nycom Information
description: Steven G. Chrust, a former Wall Street analyst of telecommunications stocks, was named president of Nycom Information Services Inc. yesterday.

title: Game 4 Adjourns as Kasparov Attacks Wildly but Survives
description: Gary Kasparov threw himself with the wild abandon of a berserker at Anatoly Karpov last night in Game 4 of the World Chess Championship Match in Manhattan and was lucky to survive a picket fence defense by the challenger. The game was adjourned in a position where the champion could force a draw by perpetual check. Pending the official outcome, the score remains: Kasparov 2, Karpov 1.

title: D.H., as in Designated Hee-haw
description: If any other sport dared to play under two sets of rules in its championship event, critics would scorn it as laughable. Embarrassment would force one rule. But the use and nonuse of the designated hitter in the same World Series is baseball's designated hee-haw.

title: Faldo Is Honored
description: Nick Faldo of England was named yesterday as Professional Golfers Association Player of the Year, the first non-American to win the award in its 43 years.

title: Oil Lifts Prices in Japan
description: More expensive oil pushed Japan's wholesale prices in September to the sharpest gains in a decade, increasing concern that the inflation outlook could be worsening. The domestic component of Japan's wholesale price index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in September from August, the Bank of Japan said on Tuesday, the highest since August 1980, when the rate also rose five-tenths of a percent. Despite that jump, the overall whole price index showed a rise of only two-tenths of 1 percent over the month before.

title: Meat Stolen at Soup Kitchen
description: Thieves broke into the Community Soup Kitchen on Monday night and stole 120 pounds of roast beef that was meant to feed lunch to more than 250 poor people. ''Stealing food from a soup kitchen,'' said William A. Sherry, a member of the soup kitchen's board. ''How low can you get?'' But the robbers left behind a small blessing. By leaving the refrigerator open, they thawed 150 pounds of frozen fish sticks that were served for lunch on Tuesday.

title: Bancorp Hawaii reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9 months' results reflected the acquisition of Firstfed America Inc. from July 24.

title: Fourth Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Health Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Milwaukee Woman Missing From Prison Is Seized in Canada
description: Milwaukee's most celebrated killer and fugitive, Lawrencia (Bambi) Bembenek, was arrested here today, ending three months of freedom with the fiance she met in prison.

title: U.S. Sealift Deficiencies Exposed in Gulf Crisis; Mariners' 'Road Test'
description: To the Editor:

title: United Technologies Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $46.5 million from the sale of the company's interest in Diavia SPA and Aura SRL. In the latest quarter the company reclassified certain components of its business segments as a result of a realignment of its radar activities and a refinement of corporate-sponsored research and development allocations. The segment data for prior periods has been appropriately reclassified.

title: Why Puerto Ricans Want Statehood
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Reds Stun A's Again, Winning in 10 for 2-0 Lead
description: In a World Series they were widely expected to dominate, the Oakland Athletics fell two games behind tonight when the Cincinnati Reds caught them in the eighth inning and passed them in the 10th, and even defeated the stopper supreme of the Oakland bullpen, Dennis Eckersley.

title: Stricken Children's Medicine: Circus
description: Eight-year-old Michael Poteat of Mamaroneck is looking forward to going to the circus this month. Michael and other children like him, all under treatment for malignant cancers, will be attending a special performance of the Big Apple Circus, sponsored for a second year by The Children's Brain Tumor Foundation.

title: 2 Sooners Convicted
description: A Federal jury in Oklahoma City yesterday convicted two former University of Oklahoma athletes of supplying cocaine to the former Oklahoma quarterback Charles Thompson in January 1989.

title: If Only the Jews . . .
description: The trouble with Israel is that it's a Jewish state.

title: Modine Manufacturing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
P.L.O. Alone and Troubled After Its Efforts in Gulf Fail
description: Ten weeks after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the Palestine Liberation Organization is in turmoil, unable to show any results for its mediation effort, isolated from Western governments and its former Persian Gulf benefactors and angry over new violence against its followers in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: How House Voted on a Plan By Democrats to Cut Deficit
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 227 to 203 by which the House of Representatives on Tuesday approved a Democratic deficit-reduction plan. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to pass the bill. Voting ''yes'' were 217 Democrats and 10 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 40 Democrats and 163 Republicans. X denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House.

title: First Citizens Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nothing, and Nobody, Can Save the Athletics
description: When Dennis Eckersley entered the second game of the World Series at the start of the 10th inning tonight, he was not in a ''save'' situation, as he had been 52 times this year. The Athletics' No. 1 relief pitcher, however, was in a ''lose'' situation,'' and uncharacteristically, he did lose the game.

title: Ameriana Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
