New York Unearthed at a New Museum
description: Near the southern tip of Manhattan, about 20 feet underground, Gary McGowan and Joan Schiff, conservators of the Archeological Collection of the South Street Seaport Museum, are hard at work in a glass-enclosed laboratory.

description: ''Arrived in good condition. Send telegrams to Chekhov.''

description: To The Home Section:

title: Lotus Settles Copyright Case
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said today that it had reached an out-of-court settlement with Paperback Software International and Stephenson Software Ltd. for the violation of Lotus's copyrights on its 1-2-3 spreadsheet software.

title: Currents; For Yard's Eyesore, An Eye-Deceiver
description: NOW the satellite dish, an eyesore on the suburban and rural landscape, can perch on a lawn disguised as a patio umbrella and table.

title: Bronx Ballot: An Insurgent's Odyssey
description: There is no better way to appreciate the absurdities of New York City's election system than from the outside looking in. This is a position that Agustin Alamo, a 45-year-old teacher, has occupied with tedious and undesired frequency for 10 years.

title: Treasury Issues Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in slow trading yesterday, as dealers wrestled with a number of conflicting developments.

title: Delphine Seyrig, 58; Actress Performed In European Films
description: Delphine Seyrig, an actress and feminist whose celebrity stemmed from her first film performance, in ''Last Year at Marienbad'' in 1961, died on Monday in Paris. She was 58 years old.

title: Wheelabrator Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary debit of $111.3 million from unrealized loss on investments in common stock for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income The latest periods' losses before items included pre-tax restructuring charge of $40 million related to merger with Waste Management Inc.

title: Home Improvement
description: FOR background and general lighting, the ultimate energy-saving light bulbs are fluorescent ones. The most familiar type are standard fluorescent bulbs, consisting of a single glass tube with metal prongs at the ends. These bulbs are usually straight, but one variety is circular; its prongs are situated where the ends of the tube meet.

title: Grove Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dipped last week by to a total of 1,056, Baker Hughes Inc. reported this week. In the corresponding week a year ago, there were 981 working rigs. Baker Hughes has kept track of the rig count, the widely watched index of drilling activity, since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs exploring for oil.

title: Cairo's Major Daily Calls Jordan's King A Party to Invasion
description: Egypt's most prominent newspaper assailed King Hussein of Jordan today as as a co-conspirator with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in the invasion of Kuwait.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Queens Bakery Owner Is Slain in Ambush
description: A woman who owns two Queens bakeries was ambushed in her car and shot to death at a stoplight on Tuesday night, the police said. Another woman in the car was seriously wounded.

title: Ashton-Tate Has a Profit
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation, a computer software company based in Torrance, Calif, said today that it had returned to profitability after a long string of losses.

April Deal for Hatcher Paying Off in October
description: The transaction barely beat the Reds out of spring training at the beginning of the season and caused few if any ripples at all throughout major league baseball. Cincinnati had acquired Billy Hatcher from Pittsburgh for two minor league pitchers, Mike Roesler and Jeff Richardson, on April 3, 1990.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL and LINDA McCARTNEY led a demonstration of hundreds of local residents on Tuesday through Rye, a bucolic English town, to protest the possible closing of Rye Memorial Hospital. Their daughter, Mary, was treated in the hospital's emergency room there earlier this year.

title: Nashua Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: The company said the sales gain was primarily attributable to the mail-order photofinishing business, Hedley-Taylor Plc., which was acquired in March 1990.

title: Personal Health
description: It is the rare child who does not know that brushing one's teeth every day is an essential part of dental health, and most nights most children probably do brush their teeth before going to bed.

title: Ads Aimed At Children Restricted
description: President Bush decided today to let a bill that limits television commercials on children's programming become law without his signature. He withheld his official seal of approval because of First Amendment concerns.

title: 'Productivity Gain' in Pact With Teachers Is Optional
description: A concession won by the New York City Board of Education in its contract with the teachers union - a speedier system for disciplining teachers - is not compulsory, officials have acknowledged. It is an option that teachers can choose.

title: Floyd Newman, 99, Oil Chief Who Gave Millions to Cornell
description: Floyd R. Newman, an industrialist who gave millions of dollars to Cornell University, died Oct. 10 at Medina Community Hospital in Ohio. He was 99 years old and lived in Medina.

title: Events: Homes of Brooklyn and Hoboken
description: Tour, With Music, Trinity Episcopal Church, Seventh and Washington Streets, Hoboken, N.J.; (201) 653-1999.

description: b-Net loss c-Included a $22 million pre-tax writedown of inventory.

title: Putnam Trust Co. of GreenFwich reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stepfathers: The Shoes Rarely Fit
description: MORE feared than loved in family fable, the stepfather in the American home of the 1990's is winning new respect for performing a role for which there is no script and the moments of applause and limelight are few.

title: Tax Or Spend?
description: These are glory days for American democracy. Congress is in an uproar, the wavering White House is acquiring a new sense of direction, and the American voter may soon be treated to a real campaign.

title: Judge Upholds Landmark Status of Interior of Four Seasons
description: The Four Seasons restaurant's striking interior architecture - its sweeping expanse of wide staircases, bronze railings, hanging sculptures and soaring balconies - can be preserved as a New York City landmark, a Manhattan judge ruled yesterday.

title: People
description: * Karlyn Armstrong has been appointed vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago.

title: 10-Year-Old Bronx Girl Is Found Dead a Week After Disappearing
description: The weeklong search for Jessica Guzman, a 10-year-old Bronx girl whose disappearance mobilized hundreds of people in her crime-ridden neighborhood, ended yesterday along the Bronx River Parkway. A passing parks worker found her body there in a stand of trees.

description: b-Net income and the 9 months included an extraordinary credit of $28,915, which consisted of credits from partial extinguishment of debt and tax benefit from tax-loss carryforward. The company changed its fiscal year-end from Aug. 31 to Nov. 30.

title: Civil Rights Bill Clears House
description: The House approved a bill to fight job discrimination. The measure now goes to President Bush, who has threatened to veto it. Page D25.

title: Unquenchable Folklore
description: To the Editor:

title: Bo Jackson Back With Raiders
description: Bo Jackson, who gained 950 yards rushing last season, is back with the Los Angeles Raiders, as, he says, the team's third-string tailback, behind Marcus Allen and Greg Bell.

Thomas F. Brigance Dies at 70; Designed Sophisticated Swimwear
description: Thomas Franklin Brigance, a sportswear and swimwear designer for four decades, died on Sunday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 77 years old.

title: He Took The Journal in New Directions
description: Slim, dapper and understated, Warren H. Phillips presided for 33 years over a sharp expansion of both The Wall Street Journal and its parent, Dow Jones & Company, while insisting that the company remain true to the principles with which the newspaper was founded 101 years ago.

title: Central Bancshares of the South Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reds 5; Athletics 4
description: A day after the mighty Oakland A's suffered an embarrassing 7-0 loss to the Reds in a Game 1 blowout, World Series drama returned to Cincinnati.

title: New Rule On Benefits Approved
description: In a move that financial experts say will eventually slash millions of dollars from corporate earnings, the board that makes the nation's accounting rules voted yesterday to require employers to subtract from each year's earnings reports a portion of the costs of the health benefits that they have promised to future retirees.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $52,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $119,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $361,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 9 months.

description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9-month results included a charge of $2 million from tentative settlement of litigation.

description: The Gannett Company today reported a 4.5 percent decline in earnings for the third quarter of 1990, primarily because of lower retail newspaper and classified advertising sales.

Pittsburgh & West Virginia Railroad reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Conferees Back Stiff Curbs on Chemical Emissions
description: Leaders of the House-Senate conference committee that is rewriting the Clean Air Act moved a step closer to a final package today when they agreed on new requirements for reducing emissions of toxic chemicals from chemical plants, coke ovens, incinerators and other industrial polluters.

title: Hard Cash Talks Loudly in Land of Grumbles
description: Redoubtable Muscovites bored with the Kremlin's agonizing over economic reform are taking their forbidden dollars out of hiding and openly putting their money on the free market at hard-currency stores long restricted to the city's Western residents.

title: Superior Surgical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bhutto Facing New Misconduct Charges
description: The President of Pakistan filed new allegations of misconduct today against former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.

title: Head of Dow Jones Sets His Retirement
description: Warren H. Phillips, the longtime chairman, chief executive officer and guiding spirit of Dow Jones & Company, announced yesterday that he would step down as chief executive of the publishing and information company on Jan. 1 and retire on July 1, soon after he turns 65.

description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $434,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,380,000, or 59 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $721,000, or 18 cents a share, and $2,064,000, or 51 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Policy Management Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A.T.&T. in Venture To Lay Cable to Japan
description: The largest international telephone companies in the United States and Japan announced plans yesterday to link the two countries in 1996 with a high-capacity undersea cable of radically new design.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHEVY CHASE was elected to the board of trustees of Bard College yesterday. Last year, Mr. Chase, class of '68, received an honorary doctorate from the college.

title: Ukraine Bows to Student Protests On Charter Backing Sovereignty
description: The Ukrainian Parliament bowed to protests by students today and voted to adopt a new constitution to support the Soviet republic's declaration of sovereignty.

title: Rangers Win With Two in 3d
description: It could not have been diagrammed more perfectly. The puck, in continuous movement and with impeccable marksmanship, was zipped from right point to left point, from there to deep in the left slot, and then in an instant in front of the goal mouth. From there, the geometry was elementary. ''Once you get the hang of it,'' Darren Turcotte said of the stuff shot he executed to record the decisive goal for the Rangers, ''it's like walking. It doesn't take much work.''

title: Dr. Death and His Wonderful Machine
description: With capital punishment in vogue, Fred Leuchter should be the man of the hour. He's a readily available source of technical support for states seeking new or improved execution machinery. When Missouri needed a lethal injection machine, he was not only the low bidder but the only bidder.

title: Florida Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SouthTrust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NCNB Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Los Angeles Forms An Offshoot Orchestra
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic announced yesterday the formation of the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra, an ensemble separate from but administered by the Philharmonic. The new orchestra, with John Mauceri as its conductor, will spend its summers playing at the Bowl and its winters touring. Philips Records will record the orchestra on 15 compact disks over the next five years in what the Philharmonic called ''mostly lighter fare.''

title: Review/Concert; A Soviet Violist Stars With Bow and Baton
description: For pianists, violinists, cellists, guitarists and singers, heroes and role models are abundant. But violists have had only a handful of great soloists to look up to, and the instrument's last true superstar, William Primrose, died in 1982.

title: Man Is Acquitted in Hunting Death
description: A hunter who mistook a woman for a deer, shooting and killing her as she walked behind her home, was found not guilty of manslaughter today in a case that has inflamed debate about a sport deeply rooted in this largely rural state.

title: Silvana Darlington Weds R. W. Safrin
description: Silvana Lubini Darlington, the daughter of Margherita Lubini of Geneva and the late architect Stefano Lubini, was married yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla., to Robert W. Safrin, the executive director of the Society of the Four Arts, a cultural organization in Palm Beach.

title: Cooks to Replace Injured Banks
description: Johnie Cooks started playing in the National Football League in 1982. Lawrence McGrew started playing in 1980 and thought he was finished when the Cleveland Browns waived him six weeks ago.

title: Technitrol Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Currents; For Designer, An Inspiring Subway Ride
description: FOR Jennifer Eno, an interior designer, the subway inspired the Lexington Avenue Line, a series of textile designs.

title: One Year Later, Bay Fans Still Can't Forget 5:04 P.M.
description: At 5:04 P.M. today, the earth stood still, but only until the Oakland Athletics scored a run in the first inning 2,000 miles away in Cincinnati. Then it shook again, figuratively.

title: Security Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater; Passing the Troubles To the Younger Irish
description: It has been more than 20 years since the arrival of British troops in Northern Ireland to quell rioting in Londonderry and Belfast signaled the beginning of the latest round of what the Irish so quaintly call the Troubles. The legacy of rancor, suspicion and hatred bred in those two decades of strife has now passed to the next generation, poisoning the lives of all it touches. Death still waits in driveways, at street corners or sometimes even knocks at the front door. Children who have grown to adulthood amid this terror assuage their sense of guilt with anger, and they spite their parents any glimmer of happiness.

title: C&S/Sovran Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the third quarter earnings were reduced by about $90 million in non-recurring charges, including: restructuring costs of $69 million; direct merger expenses of $10 million, and a valuation adjustment of $11 million related to a 1989 acquisition. On Sept. 1, Sovran Financial Corp. and Citizens & Southern Corp. merged.

title: Review/Music; Susan Palma, a Flutist Who Spans Many Idioms
description: Susan Palma has long been held in awe as a virtuoso flutist and a good musical citizen by followers of a wide variety of performing groups, including Speculum Musicae, Orpheus, the American Composers Orchestra, the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the Bach Chamber Soloists. Her program at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening may or may not have been planned to reflect that catholicity of associations, but it left the listener in little doubt as to her range of capabilities.

title: Payco American Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represents accounts received for collection. Share earnings figures are adjusted for the July 13, 1990 stock dividend paid in the form of a 2-for-1 split.

title: Maurice Chambers, Shoe Executive, 74, Is Dead After Stroke
description: Maurice R. Chambers, a retired shoe manufacturing executive, died Sunday at Bethesda-Dilworth Memorial Hall in St. Louis. He was 74 years old and lived in St. Louis.

title: Daisy Wilson Cave, The Last Surviving Confederate Widow
description: Daisy Wilson Cave, the last known Confederate widow of the Civil War, died Saturday at a nursing home here. She was estimated to have been 97 to 105 years old.

title: Life Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Park Avenue Show House Shows How
description: NEVER mind that a Snowdon portrait of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother and a favorite corgi decorate the cover of the catalogue. Nor that the Royal Oak Designer Showhouse is dedicated to her 90th birthday and benefits the Royal Oak Foundation, an American organization affiliated with the National Trust of England, Wales and Northern Ireland. So much for all that British stuff.

First Alabama Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TUTU TO CONVENE A BLACK SUMMIT
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu announced today that he would convene an urgent meeting of leaders of South African black political groups to develop unity among competing factions and coordinate their strategy for negotiations with the white minority Government.

title: Signet Banking Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Simpson Leads After First Round: Tim Simpson shot an eight-under-par 64 yesterday in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., to take the first-round lead in the Disney Golf Classic. Simpson, who has three PGA Tour victories in 13 years, made nine birdies and one bogey over the Lake Buena Vista Course. Bill Buttner was two strokes behind after his round of 66.(AP) SOCCER U.S. Team Loses in Yugoslavia: The Croatian all-stars, playing for the first time as a national team, beat the United States, 2-1, in an exhibition match yesterday in Zagreb, Yugoslavia. Two goals within four minutes midway through the first half put Croatia well in command. The first came in the 27th minute when the Croatian midfielder Marko Mlinaric broke through on the right and slipped the ball into the penalty zone. Two American defenders failed to clear the ball and Aljosa Asanovic pounced on it and beat the goalkeeper, Tony Meola, from close range.

title: Gateway Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sumitomo Bank of Calif.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Constant Jacquet, 64, A Church Statistician
description: Constant Herbert Jacquet Jr., an expert on statistics on religious groups, died Tuesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hortense Hirsch, 103, a Volunteer In Health and Civic Organizations
description: Hortense Hirsch, a volunteer for social-welfare, educational and civic organizations and a trustee of Mount Sinai Medical Center for more than half a century, died on Tuesday at her suite in the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan. She was 103 years old. During a career as a volunteer that began in the early years of the century, she was active in many organizations, including the Welfare and Health Council, now the Community Council of Greater New York; the National Urban League and the American Red Cross.

title: Northrop Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a $150 million pre-tax loss provision on a secret research and development contract. The latest 9 months included an after-tax gain of $67.1 million, or $1.42 a share, from sale of the company's headquarters complex.

title: Old Spaghetti Warehouse reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Critic's Notebook; Cincinnati Trial's Unanswered Question
description: For most of the art world, the verdict in the Cincinnati obscenity trial involving Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs came as a welcome relief. But the trial also raised some troubling issues that the verdict alone did not resolve. Foremost among them: What exactly is it that makes a photograph art?

title: Agency's Flaws Linked to Extinction of Endangered Species
description: An internal investigation by the Interior Department has found that the Government's program to protect endangered animals is so mismanaged that hundreds of threatened species face extinction without any Federal effort to save them.

title: Books of The Times; A Father, His Sons and Their Clinic
description: Menninger The Family and the Clinic By Lawrence J. Friedman 472 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: Philip Morris Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that during the latest quarter, it acquired over 99 percent of the voting rights and the equity of Jacobs Suchard AG, at a cost of approximately $4.1 billion; consolidated results of the company included the operating results of Jacobs Suchard AG since acquisition. Certain prior-year amounts have been reclassified to conform to the presentation of the latest year. The company also said that operating-companies income represented income before amortization of goodwill, unallocated corporate expenses and interest and other debt expense, net.

title: Expansion Is Not Taken Lightly
description: No final decisions are expected to be made today, but serious discussions are likely when the National Hockey League's franchise and market analysis committee meets in New York with representatives from nine prospective expansion franchises.

title: Bunnies Diaper Maker To End Benefit Claim
description: New York and nine other states reached an agreement with American Enviro Products Inc., makers of Bunnies Biodegradable Disposable Diapers, in which the company will stop its advertising claims that the product benefits the environment. The company will also pay a $50,000 penalty and has created a product that is less harmful to the environment because it is lighter and would take up less room in a landfill, said Edward Barbini, a spokesman for New York's Attorney General, Robert Abrams.

title: Pepsico Stock Is Downgraded
description: Two securities analysts yesterday downgraded their assessments of Pepsico, a strong stock performer and a favorite of institutional investors.

title: Vietnam Agrees to Expand Efforts on U.S. Missing
description: The Vietnamese Foreign Minister agreed today to expand efforts to identify and return to the United States the remains of American servicemen still unaccounted for after the Vietnam War, moving the United States and Vietnam a step closer to normal diplomatic relations.

title: Torchmark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results included realized investment gains of 3 cents a share for both the latest and year-ago quarters, and included realized investment gains of 9 cents a share and 8 cents a share for the latest and year-ago 9 months, respectively.

title: Berkeley Journal;   All Clowns? This Candidate Really Is
description: The candidate for City Council in Berkeley's Fifth District gives red rubber noses to campaign donors, organizes children's juggling workshops rather than the usual get-out-the-vote events and chides his opponent because she ''hasn't been to jail once.''

title: Pancho's Mexican Buffet Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Borg Is Considering Professional Comeback
description: Bjorn Borg, who has not played competitively since 1984, said yesterday in London that he was serious about making a comeback in professional tennis.

title: Currents; Architects Of Future?
description: TWELVE students are enrolled in a new graduate program in architecture at the Parsons School of Design in Manhattan. It is the first master's program in architecture to be established in New York State since 1979. The program was the idea of James Wines, who became chairman of the department of environmental design in 1984.

title: First Africanized Bees Are Trapped in U.S.
description: The first known swarm of Africanized bees has entered the United States from Mexico, and the bees were trapped and destroyed, officials said Wednesday.

title: Rijo Ignored a Blister
description: Jose Rijo pitched seven shutout innings against the Oakland A's in Game 1 despite a broken blister on the middle finger of his pitching hand.

title: Metro Matters;   Cuomo Tactics: Avoiding Curse Of Incumbency
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York is defying the odds against incumbents this year because: (a) - Republicans miscalculated by presuming that he was invulnerable. (b) - Even after serving for 15 years in state government, he manages to be regarded as a political outsider. (c) - The anti-incumbent tide may be greatly exaggerated. (d) - All of the above. The correct answer is (d). With Election Day less than three weeks away, almost nobody realistically doubts that Mr. Cuomo will win a third term - in sharp contrast to three other Democratic governors from the Northeast who chose not to run again and at least two Republicans who are considered vulnerable. About all that is left to ponder is whether Mr. Cuomo's victory margin will hit a record high and whether voter turnout will plummet to a record low, and why.

title: In Legal Moves, Battered Community Wins Bank's Aid
description: For years, many of the people of East Harlem have deposited their money in the Banco de Ponce branch on 116th Street. Now, some of them say, their battered community's commitment to the bank will finally be returned.

title: Germans Puzzle Over Defeat of Kohl's Foes
description: The overwhelming victory of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party on Sunday in the former East German part of the country has raised questions about why the Social Democrats did so badly in what was considered a leftist stronghold.

title: Paper Maker Posts Decline
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that its third-quarter profits dropped 46.6 percent as its interest expense soared and its building products business weakened.

title: Paul W. Bell, School Superintendent, 57
description: Paul W. Bell, superintendent of the Dade County public schools for the last seven months, died of heart failure Tuesday at Baptist Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: Avery-Dennison Merger Approved
description: The United States Justice Department has approved a $300 million merger between the office supply companies Avery International and Dennison Manufacturing. The merger is expected to increase the annual revenue of the companies, which have been suffering from depressed earnings. Avery's chairman and chief executive, Charles D. Miller, who will retain those titles at the merged company, said, ''It creates a very strong global competitor.''

title: Wallenberg Reported Shot in '47
description: A former K.G.B. official says he saw records indicating that Raoul Wallenberg, a Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of Jews in World War II, was executed at least 43 years ago, The Times of London said today.

title: Union Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Average shares oustanding for the latest and year-ago quarters were not available.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,079,000. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $111,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $357,000 for the 9 months.

title: Gasoline Price Near Peak
description: The nationwide price of a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded gasoline has reached an average of $1.379, up 30.4 cents since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the American Automobile Association said today. The highest price on record is $1.388, before the 1981 Easter weekend, the automobile group said on Tuesday.

title: Michigan National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $225 million pre-tax gain on the sale of the corporation's credit-card portfolio.

title: 5 Senators Agree on Futures Trading
description: After two months of negotiations, five key Senators agreed to a compromise proposal today that would allow the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to retain control over futures trading but give the Federal Reserve Board authority to set margins on trades.

title: House Approves Pact Relaxing Czech Trade
description: The House tonight unanimously approved a trade agreement between the United States and Czechoslovakia that would reduce tariffs and increase business ties and tourism between the two countries.

title: Union Pacific's Profit Up 17.5%
description: The Union Pacific Corporation reported a 17.5 percent increase today in its third-quarter profit, spurred by record volume on its railroad subsidiary.

title: Investor Acquires 9.6% of Worthen
description: Abdullah Taha Bakhsh, a Saudi Arabian investor, has acquired a 9.6 percent stake in the Worthen Banking Corporation, a bank holding company based in Little Rock, Ark. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Bakhsh said he had purchased the Worthen stock only as an investment. Curt Bradbury, Worthen's chairman and chief executive, said he welcomed Mr. Bakhsh's investment as an expression of confidence in the bank.

title: Now Reverse the Trend of Nullifying the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: South Carolina National reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $6,052,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Times Weekly's Plans
description: The New York Times announced two programs yesterday to broaden the audience for its Large Type Weekly. Random House Inc. the nation's largest publisher of general-interest books, will market its new large-print publications with The Times. Eschenbach Optik of America, a distributor of products for the visually impaired, will become The Times's agent in the ophthalmic market and provide subscription information in the offices of eye-care professionals. Large Type Weekly is a special edition of the newpaper's articles, published in type twice the usual size. It is available through subscription.

title: Many Fans Prefer a Mixture Of Night and Day Ball Games
description: It should come as no surprise to anyone who has ever sneaked out of the office to catch a playoff inning or two at a nearby bar or who has suffered through an otherwise agreeable dinner party on a World Series Saturday night, but when it comes to post-season play American baseball fans tend to prefer their workaday games at night and their weekend games in the sunshine.

Ames to Reduce Corporate Staff
description: Ames Department Stores Inc., the ailing discount chain that filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year, said it would lay off 250 corporate employees and close offices in West Hartford and Syracuse. The company said it had eliminated 200 corporate positions through attrition over the last four months. Ames has 1,600 corporate employees.

title: SENATORS DEMAND ROLE IN APPROVING ANY MOVE ON IRAQ
description: Expressing concern that the United States could go to war against Iraq while Congress is in recess next month, members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee demanded today that the Bush Administration obtain Congressional approval before initiating any military action.

description: Per share earnings restated to reflect 5-for-4 stock split paid April 16.

description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that if the State Legislature did not approve changes in pension earnings assumptions to finance almost half of a 5.5 percent raise for teachers, New York City would not be liable for making up the difference.

description: The University of Miami has announced that it will abolish athletic dormitories by next fall in an effort to integrate athletes more fully into campus life.

Fighting Erupts in the Salvadoran Capital
description: Fighting broke out between leftist guerrillas and Government troops in San Salvador tonight and loud explosions were heard in several sections of the city.

title: Navajo Leader Is Guilty In a Tribal Bribery Trial
description: Peter MacDonald Sr., the suspended leader of the Navajo Nation, the country's largest Indian tribe, was found guilty today in Navajo tribal court on 41 of 42 counts of accepting bribes, violating the tribe's ethics laws and conspiracy.

title: Soap in Hydraulic Systems Of Planes Found by Airline
description: Northwest Airlines grounded a dozen DC-9's today after discovering the hydraulic systems of some had been mistakenly filled with a mixture of liquid hand soap and hydraulic fluid, the company said.

title: Bears With Furniture
description: Some of the best comedians right now are women, and the best of the woman comedians is named Rita Rudner. She does great bits on men, and in one of them she says: ''Men don't live well by themselves. They don't even live like people. They live like bears with furniture.'' I always wondered about that furniture part. Since the observations of female comedians, women lawyers, my aunt Gloria, the entire membership of the Hadassah, the League of Women Voters nationwide and the woman who lives across the street from me don't count as empirical evidence, researchers at the University of California at San Francisco have done a study that shows that men need to be married or they starve to death. They studied 7,651 American adults to come to this conclusion.

title: Lattice Semiconductor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
An Old Tax on the Upper Income Takes Center Stage
description: As Congress works over the tax code in its rush to complete a budget agreement, a provision of current law called the alternative minimum tax is a favored target of opportunity among lawmakers who would give the very wealthy a big tax break and lawmakers who would slap them with a big new tax.

The show is at Thomas Moser Cabinetmakers in Philadelphia.

description: ANYONE who goes into Charivari at 16-18West 57th Street looking for a shirt or pair of pants can just as easily buy a candle, chair or table.

description: The House conducted a rare and bitter public debate today over a major Central Intelligence Agency program as critics of American-backed guerrillas in Angola sought unsuccessfully to end the agency's $60 million in annual support for the rebels.

description: With a base of support in this largely ethnic, racially diverse and heavily unionized city, George Voinovich, a Republican who is a popular former Mayor, seemed to start the campaign for governor of Ohio already holding the Democratic trump card.

description: Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus of Czechoslovakia, newly elected chairman of the Civic Forum, said today that he intended to move the mass organization founded by President Vaclav Havel in last year's anti-Communist revolution ''to the right'' and described himself as ''very conservative.''

description: The Philadelphia Electric Company priced $200 million in first and refunding mortgage bonds yesterday in two separate transactions through competitive bidding.

Halloween Chic: Venetian Masks And Pretty Faces
description: NOT everyone wants to look like a ghoul, George Bush or a Ninja Turtle on Halloween. Some people want to look faintly elegant, perhaps even glamorous.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mets' Johnson Is Set For Shoulder Surgery
description: The Mets announced yesterday that Howard Johnson would join Ron Darling at Roosevelt Hospital on Saturday for arthroscopic surgery: Darling on his right elbow, Johnson on his left shoulder.

title: Hindu Fundamentalist Threatens India's Government Over Temple
description: A right-wing party of Hindu nationalists threatened tonight to bring down the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh by withdrawing its vital parliamentary support if its fundamentalist campaign was stalled.

title: Fernandez Laughs at Rumors of Move to Spain
description: Half the 16-player field is in place for the $3 million Virginia Slims Championships to be played next month at Madison Square Garden, but there's a swirl of innuendo surrounding the eighth and latest qualifier, Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami.

title: Review/Theater; Some New Barbs From Jackie Mason
description: The setting for ''Jackie Mason: Brand New'' (at the Neil Simon Theater) is an approximation of a television studio. Behind Mr. Mason is a battery of television monitors on which are projected images of politicians, astronauts and - a bulletin from Israel - Charlton Heston parting the Red Sea. The stand-up comedian is now standing in for a television anchor. He is also doing his own commercials, as in his confident aside to the audience, ''It's a wonderful thing to see me in person.''

title: Brazil Comes Clean About Its Bomb
description: Brazil's new civilian President, Fernando Collor, has moved courageously in recent weeks toward a noble goal: keeping Latin America free of nuclear weapons. He has publicly confirmed what many long suspected - that his country's military has been working secretly for 15 years to build an atomic bomb. He's prepared to ban exports of nuclear and missile technology. And he's called for a ban on nuclear tests, even for peaceful purposes, across Latin America.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday misstated the new titles of two BBDO executives in New York. Bruce Meyers has been named director of strategy and business development, and Anthony Lenge director of finance and operations.

title: MCI Posts Large Loss In Quarter
description: The MCI Communications Corporation posted a large third-quarter loss yesterday because of a one-time charge against earnings, while three of the seven Bell regionals reported small changes in sales and earnings.

title: Pacific Gas & Electric reports earnings for 12mos Sept 30
Ryan's Family Steak Houses Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: Year-ago periods ended Sept. 27.

title: KEY RATES
JAPANESE OFFERS APOLOGY FOR SLUR
description: Japan's Justice Minister said today that he wanted to send ''my deepest apologies to the American people'' for comparing foreign prostitutes in Tokyo to American blacks who move into white neighborhoods and ''ruin the atmosphere.''

title: For Adobe, Whether Humble or Fashionable, It's Mud to Mud
description: It is the odd paradox of adobe that it serves at once as the fashionable choice of shelter for the rich in the American Southwest and as the promise for housing the poor in the third world. Common mud, or ''earthen architecture,'' to use the stiffer technical term, has come to the fore again as architects march backward in time in search of style and shelter.

title: On the Fiscal Stage, Rohatyn's Star Dims Among His Old Fans
description: In New York City, certain word associations are inevitable: bagels, lox; Russian, Tea Room; fiscal crisis, Felix G. Rohatyn. As the city once again faces economic hard times, the eminent investment banker's predictions (dire) and remedies (bitter) have returned him to center stage. As one former City Hall official put it, somewhat sourly, ''The cat is back.''

title: Vatican Approves 2 Married Priests in Brazil
description: A Roman Catholic Cardinal attending the worldwide synod of bishops has disclosed that two married men in Brazil became priests with papal approval.

title: Talking Deals;   Utility Merger Hits an Obstacle
description: AN agreement to take the Public Service Company of New Hampshire out of bankruptcy by merging it with another utility has hit a snag, with longtime opponents of Public Service and its troubled Seabrook nuclear plant saying they have found a way to scuttle the arrangement.

title: Imcera Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $1.7 million from compensation plans tied to the price of its common stock.

title: Youth Shot on IND Platform
description: A 15-year-old boy was shot in the right shoulder yesterday afternoon by another youth who tried to steal a gold chain from his neck as he stood on a subway platform in the Bronx, the transit police said. The wounded youth, who was not identified, was in serious but stable condition at North Central Bronx Hospital. The shooting occurred at 3:20 P.M. as the teen-ager waited for a D train at the IND Fordham Road station. The gunman fled emptyhanded, the police said.

title: Terzian's Knee Injured
description: Kristi Terzian, the top-scoring member of the of the United States women's team, suffered a knee injury yesterday during a training session in Switzerland to the same right knee she has had surgery on.

title: Stocks Close Mostly Lower; Dow Up 6.68
description: Nervousness over quarterly earnings, conflicting news on the Persian Gulf and the budget impasse combined yesterday to drive stock prices through a choppy day.

title: VIRGINIA EXECUTES KILLER OF DEPUTY
description: The killer of a sheriff's deputy was executed in Virginia tonight after the United States Supreme Court denied a stay and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder declined a request for clemency.

title: Accounts
description: * Quality Bakers of America Cooperative Inc., Greenwich, Conn., to GSD&M, Austin, Tex., for its Sunbeam and Sunbeam Lite breads business, with undisclosed billings. The account was previously handled by Buntin Advertising, Nashville.

title: Israel's Friends, and Enemy
description: In what conceivable way can it be in the interest of Israel, America or the global coalition against Iraq for the Israeli Government to persist in its petulant bluster about the killings on the Temple Mount? Let us put the incident behind us, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir now tells President Bush. Yet it is his own Government that keeps attention fastened on the tragedy.

title: Supporters Vow To Save Compromise On Arts Endowment
description: A move on Tuesday night by the Senate Appropriations Committee to reinstate restrictions on National Endowment for the Arts grants drew immediate opposition today.

title: National Debt, National Service
description: The points of light of George Bush, those little oases of civic-mindedness and philanthropy he spoke of during his Presidential campaign, have ended in Las Vegas comedy routines (''Mister, can you spare a point of light?''). Yet in 1988, 23 million Americans gave five hours per week or more in volunteer social work. Assuming that the labor of those who engage in such activity is worth only the minimum wage, we are talking about $25 billionworth of time already given to serve concerns other than one's own.

title: First Bank System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $37.5 million for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Illinois Tool Works reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Champagne Taking an Elite Turn
description: Nearly a decade ago, the centuries-old Champagne houses of France, beset by sluggish sales, decided that their business needed a bit more of the hustle and flash of modern marketing. Slick promotional campaigns featuring long-legged blondes and golden bubbles were created to lift Champagne sales. No longer, Champagne executives decreed, would their prestigious drink be restricted to what the French called the happy few.

title: In Land of Big Bucks, Even Bigger Bucks
description: NOT only has the cost of making movies risen sharply, but the budgets for advertising them have soared as well.

title: Tin Ceilings: Not Gone or Forgotten
description: A CENTURY ago tin ceilings were extremely popular, gracing countless restaurants, shops and kitchens all over the United States. They disappeared in World War II, when metal grew scarce. But in recent years, interest in these elaborately patterned ceilings has returned on a more modest scale, said John Shanker, president of Shanker Industries Inc., manufacturers of metal ceilings since 1912.

title: Bear Stearns's Profits Off 18.6% in Quarter
description: Citing a ''difficult environment'' that had hurt commissions, net interest income and risk arbitrage revenues, Bear Stearns Companies yesterday reported that first-quarter earnings were down 18.6 percent from the prior year's quarter and revenues fell 3.2 percent.

title: BUDGET MEASURE CLEARS 2 HURDLES IN SENATE VOTES
description: After Senate leaders from both parties struggled all day to line up votes, their budget package passed its first critical tests late tonight.

title: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: Soviet Plan in the Middle;   With His Caution on Economy, Gorbachev May Find Political Center Is a Whirlwind
description: Since late July, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin agreed to join forces in devising an economic program, hopes have soared for a grand political coalition that would lead this country peacefully away from the brink of chaos.

title: A Housing Solution
description: To The Home Section:

title: Sealed Air Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fox Stations Will Buy Warner Cartoons
description: Affiliates of the Fox network said today that they had agreed to buy three new cartoon programs from the Warner Brothers studio. Industry executives said the deal would provide added competition to the Walt Disney Company in the fast-growing market for children's afternoon television shows.

title: Tougher Policy in Effect
description: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said the National Football League was going to be vigilant in enforcing a rule mandating locker-room access to female reporters after games.

title: Seeing Bedford-Stuyvesant Brownstones
description: THE front door still wears the lace curtain hung by the home's first residents in 1895. For the visitor to Macon Street, it is like being transported back to turn-of-the-century Brooklyn.

title: Judge Declines To Raise Fines Against Nassau
description: A Federal judge today declined a Federal Government request that he find Nassau County in contempt or increase the penalties it must pay for violating an agreement to build a sewage-sludge treatment plant by the end of 1991.

title: Vote in House on Legislation to Combat Job Discrimination
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 273 to 154 by which the House of Representatives today approved a civil rights bill to combat job discrimination. A ''yes'' vote is a vote for the bill. Voting yes were 239 Democrats and 34 Republicans. Voting no were 15 Democrats and 139 Republicans. X denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House.

title: Herley Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Citizens Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Northrop Net Nearly Double
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that its earnings for the third quarter nearly doubled from the corresponding period last year, although the company's future remained clouded by the diminishing prospects for its biggest program, the B-2 Stealth bomber.

title: 'Desert Rats' Join the Buildup
description: The first units of the British Seventh Armored Brigade flew into Saudi Arabia today to join the buildup of military forces here in preparation for possible war with Iraq.

title: Coke's Net Up 9.1%; Sales Overseas Cited
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink company, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose to a record $394.2 million, or 58 cents a share. The 9.1 percent rise slightly exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Standard Pacific L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $1.5 million, or 6 cents a share, gain from the sale of an industrial building in Orange County, Calif.

title: Philip Morris Profits Rise More Than 25%
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest packaged-goods concern, said yesterday that earnings in the third quarter totaled a record $937 million, or $1.01 a share.

title: Mr. Dinkins Faces Fiscal Reality
description: Mayor David Dinkins and his advisers have finally awakened to reality. By ordering New York City agencies to plan for cuts of more than $1 billion, they are beginning to acknowledge the depth of the city's economic problems. At the same time, though, City Hall has saddled itself with an imprudent labor settlement that urgently needs to be modified.

title: CFSB Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Per share information is only available for the current quarter since CFSB converted from mutual to stock form on June 22. The company said unrealized losses on securities held for sale were recognized during the third quarter 1989.

title: INSIDE
description: Four Win Nobel Prizes

title: BRITAIN IS UNABLE TO SWAY ISRAELIS
description: Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain said today that he had failed to budge Israeli leaders from their refusal to receive a United Nations mission examining the deaths of 21 Arabs in Jerusalem last week.

title: Independent Bank Corp. of Ionia, Mich.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $265,000 on the sale of its credit cart portfolios for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $92,000 from partial redemption of convertible debentures for the 9 months.

title: MCI Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After an extraordinary loss of $10 million on early debt retirements less applicable income tax benefits.

title: Profits Up at Bristol-Myers
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had record sales and earnings in the three months that ended on Sept. 30.

title: HomeFed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: People's Savings Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Summit National Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: It's a Touch of Revenge As Devils Top Capitals
description: If the Devils spent any part of their summer dwelling upon a season that might have been, the Capitals were no doubt central to their thoughts.

title: 5 at Prairie View Are Arrested
description: A nine-month investigation into alleged financial wrongdoing at Prairie View A.&M. has resulted in the arrests of five people, including Barbara Jacket, the school's athletic director and the woman chosen to head the United States track and field team for the 1992 Summer Olympics, a prosecutor said today.

title: Notes Are Priced By Export Lender
description: The Private Export Funding Corporation, which makes medium- and long-term loans to foreign companies so they can finance purchases of United States manufactured goods and services, yesterday priced $100 million in secured notes, due 1997, through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities Inc.

title: Earnings at AMR Fell 52.1% in Third Quarter
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings fell 52.1 percent.

title: Talks by I.B.M. and Motorola On Advanced Chip Collapse
description: Negotiations between Motorola Inc. and the I.B.M. Corporation to license the computer maker's most advanced memory-chip technology have collapsed, dashing some people's hopes of an American alliance that would strengthen the nation's semiconductor industry.

title: Illinois Central Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago 9 months' results were not available. Illinois Central was acquired by Prospect Group Inc. in March 1989.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After 13 years as general manager of La Scala, CARLO MARIA BADINI has retired. In a farewell ceremony, Mr. Badini cited two of many accomplishments: engaging Vladimir Horowitz to play at the Milan opera house, and hiring RICCARDO MUTI as its music director.

title: Republic Health Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included non-recurring charges of $80,544,000, which included losses of $74,299,000 related to the sale and anticipated sales of certain facilities, and $6,245,000 associated with Republic Health's recapitalization. c-Net loss Earnings per share information prior to the company's reorganization on April 30, 1990 is not presented because it is not comparable to the company's post reorganization operations or capitalization. Earnings per share for the latest quarter were calculated using 5,932,000 shares. Revenue represents net revenue and included investment income of $2,247,000 and $5,185,000 for the latest quarter and year, respectively.

title: Stone & Webster Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credit of $75,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter; the 9 months included tax credit of $568,000, or 4 cents a share, and net of $2,853,000, or 19 cents a share, from the sale of investment securities. c-Included net of $2,774,000, or 18 cents a share, from the sale of investment securities. Revenue represented gross earnings and included gross earnings of $4,274,000 and $4,155,000 from the sale of investment securities for the latest and year-ago 9 months, respectively.

title: Cervical Cancer Linked To Smoking in a Study
description: Cigarette smoking has emerged as a powerful influence in the development of cervical cancer as well as distorted cells that are precursors of malignancy, researchers say.

title: Accord on Military Would Curb 'Star Wars' and Stealth Bomber
description: House and Senate negotiators today approved a $288 billion military budget for the 1991 fiscal year that limits financing for the Stealth bomber and cuts nearly $2 billion from the Bush Administration's request for the ''Star Wars'' program.

title: House Passes Rights Bill on Job Bias; White House Vows Veto
description: The House of Representatives today gave final passage to a civil rights bill intended to fight job discrimination, setting the stage for a confrontation with President Bush, whose veto threat leaves him in a political bind less than three weeks before the Congressional elections.

title: At Indian Point, No Second-Guessing After an Accident With Nuclear Fuel
description: Technicians at the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant probably did everything they could to avoid dropping a fuel assembly, according to experts at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, both of which supervised the work.

title: HDM Campaign Fights Crime in New York City
description: HDM New York has joined New York City's aggressive war on crime with a pro bono campaign for Crime Stoppers. It represents the New York City Police Department and Police Foundation's latest attempt to take on the silence of crime witnesses.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bekins Van Lines, Hillside, Ill., a subsidiary of Bekins Co., Glendale, Calif., promoted John Ainlay to vice president of operations in its household goods division.

title: Support Groups May Do More in Cancer Than Relieve the Mind
description: Psychological support not only helps cancer patients deal with the emotional distress of their illness but may also strengthen their immune systems, new studies suggest.

title: Bridge
description: Most tournament players are content to try for one victory at a time. Others are more hungry for success, as witness a foursome from New Jersey at the Summer Nationals in Boston in July. Leora and Richard Dubrovsky of Farmingdale, N.J., and Eli and Cynthia Schneider of East Brunswick, N.J., played in simultaneous knockout team events, one in the morning and one during the rest of the day.

title: Dinkins's Latino Chief, Feeling Stymied, Quits
description: The director of the city's Office of Latino Affairs resigned yesterday, saying he could not continue in the $65,000-a-year job because it did not come with enough access to the Mayor.

title: G.I.'s in the Saudi Desert Are Fitter Now, but Still Have Lessons to Learn
description: In the light of the setting desert sun, one of the United States Army's best armored units raced across the sand in a whine of engines and billowing outriders of smoke and dust.

title: Prime Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are not shown for year-ago 9-month period; the bank converted from mutual to stock ownership in July 1989.

title: Cambodia Troupe's Star Dancer Stays in U.S.
description: The star performer in a Cambodian dance troupe decided yesterday to stay in the United States after discussions with the State Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service. But 31 other members of the group left John F. Kennedy Airport to return to Phnom Penh.

title: Arlen Goldberg Is Wed to Miss Kramer
description: The Rye Community Synagogue in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kathryn Dee Kramer and Arlen Joel Goldberg. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony.

title: Environmental Bond Passage in Doubt
description: With less than three weeks to go until Election Day, strong opposition by upstate New York residents to the $2 billion environmental bond issue has put government and private supporters on the defensive and passage of the measure in doubt.

title: Soldiers Have Some Beefs for the Boss
description: The men of the headquarters supply platoon of the Second Squadron of the Army's Fourth Cavalry Regiment had a few things they wanted to get off their chests.

title: First Tennessee National reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: BILL COSBY has stopped using a mural designed for the opening credits of ''The Cosby Show'' because of a dispute with the school whose students created the mural that inspired the television version.

title: Continental Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $15.6 million from discontinued operations. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $27.4 million for the quarter and $58.4 million for the 9 months, and included a gain of $55 million on the sale of a London office building for both periods.

title: A Fullback Grows in Florida
description: When Steve McGuire endures the inevitable punishment his work creates these days, there is often a national television audience watching. The pounding, however, has been severe for a long time, back to the days when the goal line consisted of parked cars or light poles, the football field was a street in the East New York section of Brooklyn, and the audience was not as large.

title: Great Western Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Money-Fund Yields Down
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Thermwood Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
An Ex-Cook Becomes President of Shoney's
description: Shoney's Inc. named as its president and chief operating officer yesterday James W. Arnett, who started as a cook in the Nashville-based restaurant chain.

title: U.S. Output Climbed 0.2% In September
description: Industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Government reported today, with a 7.5 percent spurt in automobile production masking an underlying manufacturing weakness.

title: Society for Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ABC Plans to Close 3 U.S News Bureaus
description: ABC News announced yesterday that it would close three news bureaus in the United States and lay off or reassign 12 staff members on Dec. 31.

title: Evergreen Bancorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mr. Lincoln's Side In Budget Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists Offer Two Explanations Of Dark Streaks on Neptune Moon
description: After a year analyzing data and photographs from the Voyager 2 spacecraft, scientists are not sure they can explain the strange streaks that appear like dark brush strokes on the bright canvas of Triton, the large icy moon of Neptune.

title: Marion Merrell Dow Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' results are on a pro forma basis. The company was created in December 1989 through the combination of Marion Laboratories Inc. and Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc.

title: To Fix the Budget Mess, Restore Pre-'86 Taxes;   No Investment Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Lost 34,000 Jobs Over Summer
description: New York City lost 34,000 jobs this summer, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, and may be headed for its worst year since the dark days of the mid-1970's.

title: Romania Chief Acts To Speed Transition To Market Economy
description: Prime Minister Petre Roman, saying only shock therapy can save Romania, introduced a package of laws today intended to speed the country's transition to a market economy.

title: Bach by Tureck
description: The pianist and Bach specialist Rosalyn Tureck will play Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations in the main sanctuary of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, on Sunday at 4 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 744-1400.

title: Lockheed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Reflected about $165 million in charges related to certain fixed-price development contracts for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also reflected a $4 million loss on the disposal of certain discontinued operations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: House-Senate Panel Prepares for Endurance Test
description: In the wild and woolly no-holds-barred world of House-Senate conferences, a budget reconciliation conference is in a class by itself.

title: It's All Right to Laugh, Obscenity Jury Is Told
description: Jurors in the 2 Live Crew obscenity case, who have sat stone-faced during the trial but were seen laughing in the hall, have been told they can laugh in court, too.

title: On Stage
description: A Question on 'Funk'

title: Meadow Star Running for a Cause
description: There is a new reason to root for Meadow Star to keep on winning. From now on, she is running for homeless and troubled children.

title: A Small Price for Fine Art
description: Tax breaks for the very rich aren't easy to defend, especially in the current Congressional climate. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York knows that; he has endured endless flak for proposing a tax break for some wealthy families who give artwork to nonprofit organizations.

title: Bowater Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from retirement of debt of $9,046,000.

title: Super Food Services reports earnings for Year to Aug 25
Drug Maker On L.I. Is Fined
description: A drug company based on Long Island was fined $1 million today for making illegal cash payoffs to Federal drug reviewers and other law violations that were turned up in a two-year investigation of the generic drug industry.

title: Grim Crossroads: Rape, Retardation and Abortion
description: Debra Lynn Thomas does not understand that she was raped, that she is pregnant as a result of that rape, and that her baby is due in about three months. With the mental ability of an infant, Miss Thomas, who is 32 years old, does not even know what pregnancy is.

title: United Banks of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Thiokol Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that some figures have been restated in 1989.

title: For Dow Chemical, The Good Times Stall
description: In the last few years, the Dow Chemical Company has ridden a wave of expansion, driven by a strong market for chemicals. But now the wave may have crested for the nation's second-largest chemical company. A number of analysts contend that the company took on too much and will be paying too dearly.

title: SCEcorp reports earnings for 12mos Sept 30
Charles G. Daley, 80, Prosecutor and Lawyer
description: Charles G. Daley, a lawyer who served under Thomas E. Dewey in racketeering investigations in the 1930's, died on Sunday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Bronxville. He died of heart failure, his family said.

title: American Petrofina Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $23 million gain from an accounting adjustment.

title: Pizza Hut Plans Brazil Expansion
description: Pizza Hut Inc. plans to open at least 100 new restaurants in Brazil in an agreement signed with a South American investor, a spokesman said. The financial terms of the agreement signed on Wednesday with Ricardo Mansur, a prominent Sao Paulo business executive, were not announced.

title: Game 4 of Chess Match Ends in Draw
description: At 12:26 yesterday morning, almost two hours after play in Game 4 of the World Championship Chess Match had ended Wednesday night, Ron Henley, one of Anatoly Karpov's seconds, telephoned his draw offer to the champion, but it wasn't until 10:54 A.M. that Gary Kasparov saw fit to register his acceptance. Or had he already gone to bed?

title: Payco American Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represented accounts received for collection. Share earnings figures are adjusted for the July 13, 1990 stock dividend paid in the form of a 2-for-1 split. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Dolphins Overcome Themselves
description: Stingy defense and Mark Higgs's touchdown on a blocked punt helped the Miami Dolphins overcome five turnovers tonight as they handed New England its fourth consecutive loss, 17-10.

title: BankAmerica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: bIncluded tax loss carryforwards of $163 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Included tax loss carryforwards of $158 million for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also included net of $85 million resulting from Brazilian cash interest payments.

title: 7 Held in Mob Extortion of Clothiers
description: Two years ago, prosecutors established a dummy garment-manufacturing company in a factory on the edge of Chinatown. Their aim: to investigate persistent reports that organized-crime figures had a stranglehold over the trucking business in Manhattan's garment industry.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Hancock Fabrics Inc., Tupelo, Miss., named Jack W. Busby Jr. executive vice president and director of retail operations.

title: Boy Held in 12 Cab Holdups
description: A 14-year-old Queens youth, a suspect in at least 12 recent armed robberies of livery-cab drivers in the borough, was arrested yesterday after he was spotted in Corona by a driver who said the youth had held him up. The suspect, Shaheed Whiting of 34-73 111th Street, and a friend still being sought are accused of robbing the drivers at knifepoint over the last month and stabbing one driver twice in the leg, said Officer Alfonso Delligatti of the 115th Precinct.

title: Review/Film;   'White Palace': Love And the Class Struggle
description: Sex and snobbery form the foundation for ''White Palace,'' the story of a haughty 27-year-old and a slatternly hamburger-joint waitress 16 years his senior. The audience is expected to make significant character judgments based on the fact that Max (James Spader) has an orderly, well-appointed apartment and an extensive wardrobe, whereas Nora (Susan Sarandon) dresses tartily and throws Ring Ding wrappers on her floor.

title: Miscellany
description: * A new London-based agency has been formed by a former Saatchi & Saatchi managing director and joint chief executive, Paul Bainsfair, with John Sharkey and David Trott. The agency, Bainsfair, Sharkey, Trott, will be part of the network of the French company BDDP International.

title: Two-Month Sales Weak at K Mart
description: The K Mart Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, posted weak sales in August and September in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the company's chief financial officer, Thomas F. Murasky, said on Wednesday at a meeting of financial analysts. Total sales rose 11.1 percent in August and 10.2 percent in September over a year earlier. But when newly opened stores are eliminated, sales increased only 1.6 percent in August and seven-tenths of 1 percent in September.

title: Paul Seabury, 67, U.S. Authority On Foreign Policy and Educator
description: Paul Seabury, a professor of political science who was an authority on American foreign policy and the author or co-author of a dozen books, died Wednesday at Doctors Hospital in Pinole, Calif. He was 67 years old and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

title: American Telephone & Teleraph Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Consolidated results for 1990 reflect the acquisitions of ISTEL Group Ltd. in the fourth quarter of 1989 and two divisions of a subsidiary of PacifiCorp Financial Services Inc. in the first quarter of 1990.

title: A.T.&T. and 3 Regional Bells Post Slightly Higher Profits
description: A.T.& T. reported a 1.9 percent increase in third-quarter earnings yesterday despite a much higher tax liability. Three Bell regionals also posted slightly higher earnings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Wings Demote Hanlon
description: Glen Hanlon, the veteran Detroit Red Wings goaltender who won a reputation as a steady player with a ready wit, has been sent down to the minors. The only surprise was that it took so long.

title:
Second Homes;

Vacation Communities Rise in Catskills
description: LEAD: Once known primarily for its huge resort hotels, New York's Sullivan County has been evolving into a prime site for second homes over the last seven years. Vacation communities are springing up in clusters within the open fields, hills and thick woodlands of the Catskill Mountains.

title: Burmese Regime Sentences 2 Dissidents, Diplomat Says
description: The Burmese military government, making its toughest move since the opposition won a landslide election victory in May, has sentenced two dissident leaders to seven years in prison, a diplomat said today.

title: 'No Fighting,' Holtz Says, but He Adds 'Unless'
description: Nearly a year after establishing a strict, highly publicized stance against fighting, Lou Holtz, the Notre Dame football coach, has appeared to revise his policy.

title: Georgia Gulf Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lloyd H. Bailer, Economist and Arbitrator, 76
description: Lloyd H. Bailer, an economist and arbitrator, died at his home in Brentwood on Tuesday after suffering a series of strokes. He was 76 years old.

title: Quilts, Indian Artworks And Shaker Furnishings
description: At the nation's most important Americana fair, vintage versions of the Stars and Stripes brighten several booths, Uncle Sam appears as a whirligig, and an all-wire, eight-foot-high Statue of Liberty is a turn-of-the-century topiary form.

title: New York State Electric & Gas reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
WON'T CONDEMN U.S.;   Iraq Offers Cheaper Oil
description: In efforts to gain political ground by economic means, Iraq sought to beat one embargo today and the Arab League moved to enforce another.

title: Firstar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Arco Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a net pre-tax charge of $28 million from the incident at its Channelview, Texas plant. c-Included a $43 million gain from a change in accounting for income tax. The company said third-quarter results were hurt by the July 5 fire and explosion, and subsequent shutdown, at its Channelview plant.

title: NEW DEFENSE CHIEF IS NAMED IN PRAGUE
description: President Vaclav Havel today named his Deputy Foreign Minister to be Defense Minister a day after dismissing his predecessor, apparently in response to protests against the presence of Communists or former Communists in high office.

title: Panel of Scientists Dismisses Warning of Missouri Quake
description: Projections of a major earthquake in the Midwest in early December are without scientific basis, a group of scientists said today.

title: Coniston Settles Rift With UAL Managers
description: Coniston Partners L.P., a New York investment group that owns 11.8 percent of the UAL Corporation and that has threatened to oust the company's board, made peace yesterday with the airline concern.

title: HarperCollins Reports Profit
description: HarperCollins, the book publishing subsidiary of the News Corporation, which is headed by Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday that its operating profit for the year that ended on June 30 was $119 million on revenue of $1.13 billion.

title: Washington Talk;   F.B.I. Hoping to Erase Poor Image on Racism
description: Ask top officials at the Federal Bureau of Investigation what most worries the nation's premier law-enforcement agency, and they are likely to admit that the public enemies these days include not only drugs, corruption and organized crime, but also racism.

title: Review/Art;   In the Arena of the Mind, at the Whitney
description: ''Mind Over Matter: Concept and Object'' is a good exhibition for the Whitney Museum of American Art to have done. Most of its six artists are known in New York, but they continue to play to small audiences because of the difficulty and limits of their work. By exhibiting them as a group, the Whitney is not so much confirming their importance as recognizing the significance of the ideas Conceptual artists are helping to define and confront.

title: Top 5 in U.N. Council Near Accord Over Claims Against Iraq
description: The five permanent Security Council members are close to agreement on a plan inviting governments to prepare lists of financial claims against Iraq arising out of its occupation of Kuwait as well as lists of human rights violations by Iraqi forces there.

title: GATX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated. Share earnings for the year-ago quarter and 9 months reflected a 2-for- 1 stock split paid June 1990.

title: Viewing Chaos in the Capital, Americans Express Outrage
description: What will happen when Don Campbell, a 67-year-old farmer from Williamsville, Ill., enters the voting both in November?

title: Mobil Settles California Suit Over Toxic Acid at Refinery
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said today that it had settled a lawsuit directed at its refinery in suburban Los Angeles by agreeing to reformulate a highly toxic acid used in the plant or ban its use and to allow inspections by an independent safety adviser.

title: KEY RATES
Korea Sees Outflow
description: Foreign companies are leaving South Korea to escape rising wages, which have weakened the country's competitive edge, the nation's central bank contended today.

title: At Land's Edge, a Contentment of Light and Shape
description: SOUTH COVE, a three-acre, sea-shell-shaped public park on the Hudson River in Battery Park City, overflows with a quiet power so potent that first-time visitors can take the taste and feel of it home with them, and run it over in their minds, like a vivid childhood memory. A weekend visit to South Cove is as bracing and adventuresome as a walk across a wind-swept, unexplored sand dune, and at the same time it's cozy and private, and feels as utterly safe as an hour spent rocking back and forth on a favorite old back-porch swing.

title: Owens & Minor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Consumer Prices Rise 0.8% Again
description: With sharply climbing oil prices accounting for more than half the increase, the Consumer Price Index rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in September for the second straight month. That raised the inflation rate so far this year to 6.6 percent.

title: Six Men Wrestling With the Budget
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen...Chairman, Senate Finance Committee...Texas Democrat... his main effort will be to get a bill out of conference that can be supported by both Republican and Democratic members of the Senate...he personally has no objection to higher tax rates, but would like to maintain tax breaks for oil and gas producers.

title: Benefit Book Sale
description: Thousands of new and used books and records will be on sale this weekend at the Hudson Guild, 441 West 26th Street. Proceeds will benefit the guild, a 95-year-old social-service agency that helps families in the Chelsea area. Hours are 1 to 8 P.M.; tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., and Sunday, noon to 5 P.M. On Sunday, all books will be offered at half-price. Information: 760-9812.

title: Fruit of the Loom reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EG&G Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Claude Arpels Is Dead; Jeweler in U.S. Was 79
description: Claude Arpels, who headed the American operations of the Van Cleef & Arpels jewelers, died on Monday in Switzerland, his family said today. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Calfed Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $41,100,000 and $35,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and after a loss of $4,500,000 for the quarter and income of $2,500,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The company said the latest quarter's loss from discontinued operations reflects $42.8 million loss on the sale of the company's Beneficial Standard Life Insurance Co. The company also said the loss for the quarter reflects a $96 million addition to the company's allowance for losses on real estate held for investment in its real estate development subsidiaries. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: At U.S. Embassy in Iraq: Rituals and Precautions
description: At the United States Embassy, it has become an almost daily ritual: crowds of protesters bused in by the Government from across Baghdad to shout slogans against President Bush, against America and against what the demonstrators have been told is an American policy of starving Iraq because of its occupation of Kuwait.

title: Black & Decker Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss included one-time after- tax charge of $21.4 million for termination of interest-rate swaps. Year-ago results excluded revenues from Dynapert and PRC, whose results were reconsolidated in the 1990 second quarter.

title: Lewis Veraldi, Auto Executive, 60
description: Lewis Veraldi, a retired Ford Motor Company executive who helped create the futuristic look of the Taurus and Mercury Sable, died of a heart attack Saturday at William Beaumont Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Substitute At Helm of Syracuse Offense
description: Marvin Graves, Syracuse's freshman quarterback whose quickness and speed are so impressive, has a badly bruised shoulder and is unlikely to play against Rutgers tomorrow in the Carrier Dome.

title: Newhall Land & Farming reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
