description: b-Included gain of about $22 million, or 55 cents a unit, in both periods resulting from the sale for $43 million of 238 single-family lots. The units per share earnings and shares outstanding were restated to reflect 2-for-1 unit split on Jan. 29, 1990. Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: How Many in the Keating Crew?
description: The Senate Ethics Committee will soon disclose whether the ''Keating Five'' will be reduced to a smaller group of Senators accused of ethical improprieties in a major savings and loan scandal. Each Senator's involvement was different and each is entitled to an unbiased hearing, but if the committee plans to exonerate any of the Five, it had better be prepared to explain its action.

title: UST Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest 9 months included a pretax gain of $3 million, or 2 cents a share, resulting from the early termination of a licensing agreement for the distribution of certain imported pipe tobaccos.

title: Wilmington Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Waste Management Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss, net of income taxes, of $24,547,000, which reflected the company's percentage interest in the writedown by Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. of Wheelabrator's investment in the stock of the Henley Group Inc. and Henley Properties Inc. to market value. In September, Waste Management increased its ownership of Wheelabrator Technologies from 22 percent to 55 percent. Results for 1989 are after giving retroactive effect to the 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a stock dividend distributed in December 1989.

title: Brokerage Earnings Weaken
description: Soft investment-banking business hurt third-quarter earnings at both Paine Webber and Primerica, parent of Smith Barney, Harris Upham, but the downturn at Primerica was more than offset by healthy returns from its insurance business.

title: To Fix the Budget Mess, Restore Pre-'86 Taxes;   New Revenue Sources
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. Trade Plan Criticized
description: A top European Community official today criticized as unrealistic an American trade proposal for sharp cuts in Government payments to farmers.

title: ITT Earnings Rise 1.4%
description: The ITT Corporation, the diversified New York-based international concern, reported yesterday that its net income rose 1.4 percent in the third quarter, to $224 million, or $1.73 a share, from $221 million, or $1.55 a share, a year earlier. The increase in per-share earnings was aided by the company's share-repurchase program. ITT's revenue rose 2.2 percent, to $5.03 billion, from $4.92 billion. ITT's share price rose $1.75 yesterday, to $42.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 4 Charged in Deaths of 3 Vietnamese Youths
description: Four men were arrested yesterday and charged with the execution-style murder of three Vietnamese youths on Monday in a Manhattan parking lot, the police said.

title: Eaton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,900,000 for the quarter and $8,800,000 for the 9 months. c-Incuded income from discontinued operations of $100,000 and $5,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said share earnings for the latest quarter and 9 months reflects income from continuing operations of 96 cents a share, and $3.74 a share, respectively. Year-ago share earnings for the 9 months reflects income from continuing operations of $4.40 a share.

title: Intergraph Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $1,511,000, or 3 cents a share, gain on sale of long-term common stock investment. c-Included an $8,406,000, or 15 cents a share, gain on sale of an Intergraph subsidiary.

title: Wilhelm Magnus, Professor, 83
description: Dr. Wilhelm Magnus, who retired as a professor at the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences of New York University in 1973, died on Monday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: Gay Organization Sees Upsurge in Violence
description: The New York City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, and leaders of the gay and lesbian community said yesterday that figures compiled by a gay organization show an upsurge in violence against gay men and lesbians.

title: CHRONICLE
description: OSBORN ELLIOTT has been elected chairman of the Citizens Committee for New York City, which helps to better neighborhoods. He is not actually a new chairman;he had held the post for five years after it was founded in 1975 by Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: Revision for Williams
description: The Portland Trail Blazers have reached an agreement extending the contract of Buck Williams by one year, the team announced yesterday. Terms of the contract were not disclosed, but the extension was believed to have included a substantial raise in salary for the 1993-94 season, the final year of the contract. Williams was earning about $1 million a season on his existing contract.

title: Jordan Olivar, 75, College Football Coach
description: Jordan Olivar, former head football coach at Yale, Villanova and Loyola Marymount, died of lung cancer Wednesday at his home in Inglewood, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: Simmons Move On Lockheed
description: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons said today that he was considering seeking control of the Lockheed Corporation but cautioned that he had not made a final decision.

title: BankAmerica Profits Rise
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest bank-holding company, reported today that third-quarter earnings rose 11.4 percent despite an increase in the money put aside for problem loans.

title: Chrysler Mini-van
description: The Chrysler Corporation's successful mini-van officially became a part of the permanent collection of the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., taking its place among automotive milestones like the Model-T and the vehicle used by astronauts to traverse the moon. Chrysler Motors' chairman, Bennett E. Bidwell, said Chrysler would produce its 2.5 millionth van next week. A $700 million gamble on a market that did not exist at the time, the vehicle was introduced in 1983, just as Chrysler was emerging from its scrape with bankruptcy.

title: Independence Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Franco Autori, 87, Conductor, Is Dead
description: Franco Autori, a conductor who worked for a time with the New York Philharmonic, died on Tuesday at his home in Tulsa, Okla., the Associated Press reported. He was 87 years old.

title: S.& L. Outflow Slowed in May
description: Net withdrawals from the nation's savings and loan associations slowed to $7 billion in May after soaring to a record $15.1 billion a month earlier, the Government said this week.

title: UJB Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Militant Students in Ukraine Force the Party Into Retreat
description: A missing force in Soviet politics, student militancy, has coalesced with a vengeance here in the Ukraine, pushing the Communist-dominated Parliament into deep retreat and forcing the nationalist movement to put a more aggressive edge on its agenda.

title: Schering-Plough Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that a $150 million pretax gain on the sale of its Maybelline Cosmetics business was offset in the 1990 third quarter by provisions totaling $157 million stemming principally from the discontinuance of certain products, the rationalization of facilities and personnel restructuring actions.

title: Jets' Newest Player Feels Sting of Losing to Bills, Too
description: Even though he didn't arrive in training camp until today, Dennis Price, the newest member of the Jets, already has something in common with his new teammates.

title: West One Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lawmakers Drop Appropriation For Los Alamos Plutonium Lab
description: A House-Senate conference committee today eliminated money for a new $385 million plutonium processing laboratory that the Department of Energy has proposed building at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico.

title: Morrison Knudsen reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $3,084,000 from the sale of assets and business of the power systems division of the rail systems segment. In addition, $1,056,000 and $673,000 of net income from the power systems operations is included in the 9 months of 1990 and 1989 operations, respectively.

title: These Bills Defraud the Working Poor
description: With only hours to go before the Government is due to shut down again, House and Senate budget negotiators are racing to present a budget to the President for signature. Unless they are careful, however, they will end up balancing the budget at least partly on the backs of people who work full time but are still below the poverty line. If so, Congress will, in the name of prudence, defraud the working poor.

title: Cardinals Cashing In After Gamble in Draft
description: At San Jose State, Johnny Johnson acquired a reputation for unreliability. He missed football practices. He missed team meetings. He missed weight-training sessions. The coach finally dismissed him from the team.

title: Review/Music;   Boston Symphony Pays Tribute to Bernstein
description: Of all the individuals and organizations that have been dedicating programs to Leonard Bernstein's memory, none can claim a longer and closer association with him than the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The first orchestra concert he ever attended was played by the Boston Pops. The first concert he conducted was in Boston, on the Esplanade. In 1939, recently out of Harvard, he became a member of the first class of the Tanglewood Music Center and eventually a protege of Serge Koussevitzky, who was then the Boston Symphony's music director. Only two months ago, Bernstein made his final conducting appearance, again with the orchestra at Tanglewood. After half a century, the circle was closed.

title: People
description: * Steve Davis has been named general manager of J. Walter Thompson, Chicago. Paul Mead was promoted to chief financial officer of J. Walter Thompson North America, based in Toronto.

title: U.S. Presence in Gulf Also Keeps Out Sheep
description: Along with holding off Iraqi soldiers, the United States operation in Saudi Arabia is shielding the desert from another force that each year devastates Saudi rangeland: millions of Iraqi sheep.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Trinity Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sounds Around Town
description: Clayton's Big Band

title: Traffic Alert
description: George Washington: Eastbound traffic will be severely disrupted today through 6 A.M. Monday because of lane-closings.

title: For U.S. Park Information
description: For tourists worried about which parks and museums will be closed if the Federal Government runs out of money this weekend, the National Tour Association has an answer: a toll-free information number. A spokesman said the association, which represents hotels, airlines and bus touring companies, will pool information from Federal, state and local sources to benefit travelers. The phone number is 1-800-755-TOUR.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When JAN TRISKA steps onto the stage at Yale Repertory Theater next week, he will be playing a familiar role. VACLAV HAVEL created Leopold Nettles, the highly autobiographical lead character in ''Largo Desolato,'' and Mr. Triska and Mr. Havel, the playwright and President of Czechoslovakia, have been best friends for 35 years.

title: Caterpillar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Breaking the Litter Habit
description: Fifteen years after the last fiscal crisis, New York City's budget crunch has once again reduced the number of Sanitation Department street cleaners to a mere corporal's guard. To offset the loss, Mayor Dinkins recently sent out a notice with each of the city's 250,000 payroll checks asking the recipient to pick up someone else's litter at least once a day. New Yorkers who don't work for the city might heed the appeal as well.

title: Bausch & Lomb reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Amoco's Profits Rise 57.7%; Surge Reflects Asset Sale
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that its quarterly earnings rose 57.7 percent from the 1989 period. The profit surge reflected an unusual gain of $149 million derived from the sale by Amoco of its refining and marketing company in Britain, not sharply higher crude oil prices. Operating profits fell. Amoco said profits for the third quarter were $530 million, or $1.04 a share, compared with $336 million, or 65 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenues rose 19.7 percent, to $7.9 billion from $6.6 billion.

title: Less Time, More Music In Met Museum Series
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has been presenting concerts since the 1940's, first in its Great Hall and in the John Pierpont Morgan Wing, then in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, which opened in 1954, and more recently in some of its galleries when the programs have demanded something more expansive than a concert hall setting. For the most part, though, these concerts have taken place after hours, and concertgoers who have attended them have had no access to the museum's collections, beyond what can be seen on the way in and out.

title: Review/Art;   Combustible Paintings Of a Brooding Legend
description: It can be amazing to see the paintings of an artistic legend come to life, suddenly acquiring a born-yesterday freshness. This is what happens at the Mary Boone Gallery in SoHo, where 10 paintings by the Abstract Expressionist Clyfford Still, several borrowed from museums, are on view.

title: Penguin to Raise Prices Next Year by 4/ a Book
description: Penguin USA said yesterday that it would raise prices next year on all its mass market books, but by just 4 cents a book. Books that now cost $3.95 will be priced at $3.99; $4.95 books will be $4.99, and so on.

title: Ogilvy Wins In Kraft Shift Of Accounts
description: IN a surprise move, Kraft General Foods has realigned the agency roster for some of its leading brands.

title: No Buts or Ifs, Principal Plans a Dress Code
description: Some of the teachers do not wear neckties. But Frank Mickens, the principal of Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, a school once known more for fighting than for fashion, will soon require all male students to wear ties daily.

title: Pop/Jazz;   Very Private Jill O'Hara Once Again Goes Public
description: When Jill O'Hara strides to the tiny stage of Dannys' Skylight Lounge, the back-room cabaret at the Grand Sea Palace restaurant, it's hard to imagine that this vivid, confident performer in a bright red gown used to be so shy that she could barely bring herself to do an interview.

title: Leon Olinger, Psychiatrist, 82
description: Dr. Leon Olinger, a psychiatrist who was a former assistant director of Brooklyn State Hospital, died yesterday at his home in Wilmette, Ill,, where he had lived in retirement for the last four years. He was 82 years old.

title: Textron Posts Gain in Profits
description: Textron Inc. reported today that its third-quarter earnings increased nearly 12 percent, largely on improvements in its aerospace business.

title: Primerica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Film;   The Zombies Return, in Living (or Is It Dead?) Color
description: Who would have imagined, back in 1968, that this would become a landmark in the history of American film: seven people hole up in a farmhouse and fight off flesh-eating zombies. It's not ''Citizen Kane,'' but so what? George A. Romero's cheap little ''Night of the Living Dead'' may not have the heft of art, but it is an undisputed pop-culture classic. Without those zombies, there might not be a Jason on Friday the 13th or a Freddy Krueger on Elm Street - killers who became powerful forces in the movie industry, and who obviously touched some dank, sinister part of the mass imagination.

title: Where Best to Sate 101 Food Hankerings
description: IN Garrison Keillor's old radio program, ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' there used to be a fictitious advertisement for Ralph's Pretty Good Grocery that went, ''If you can't find it at Ralph's, you can probably do without it.'' That might well apply to people looking for their favorite dishes in New York City, which arguably has the world's greatest diversity of food.

title: AmSouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: The Nation Foundation and the Playboy Foundation, an odd couple on the face of it, are teaming up for a colloquium on censorship at the Donnell Library on Oct. 24. ''We have the First Amendment in common,'' said VICTOR NAVASKY, The Nation's editor and moderator of the program.

title: Gartner Takes on Role As Rangers' Rescuer
description: Mike Gartner smiled discreetly as the personal production portfolio was laid out before him for his inspection and remarks.

title: Court Urged by U.S. To Refuse Request For New Barry Trial
description: Federal prosecutors called on a United States District Court today to deny Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s request for a new trial on his recent conviction for drug possession.

title: Thomas R. Adam, 90, Expert on Colonialism
description: Thomas R. Adam, a professor of political science at New York University from 1945 until he retired in 1968, died on Saturday at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. He was 90 years old and had lived at the Mosholu Parkway Nursing Home in the Bronx for three years.

title: Rivers on Waivers
description: The San Antonio Spurs placed the guard David Rivers on waivers Wednesday, reducing the team's roster to 14 players. Rivers, a former reserve with the Clippers and the Lakers, had averaged 7.3 points in three exhibition games. (AP)

title: Storage Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $3,877,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter; the 9 months included an extraordinary loss of $1,304,000. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $11,300,000, or 43 cents a share.

title: Baxter International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax provision of $566 million to cover the cost of the company's restructuring program. c-Net income

title: Group Says Press Freedom Is Declining in Britain
description: An international human rights organization said in a report today that the Government had dramatically eroded press freedom in Britain over the last year and greatly increased its powers of censorship.

title: Channing as Narrator
description: Carol Channing will narrate Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf'' in the opening concert of the Little Orchestra Society's 42d season of children's concerts, tomorrow at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The program, which is to be conducted by Dino Anagnost, also includes Gail Kubik's symphonic setting of the Dr. Seuss story ''Gerald McBoing Boing,'' and Peter Schickele's ''Zoo Called Earth,'' for which the ensemble is to be joined by the Hudson Vagabond Puppets. Tickets are $15 to $28. Information: 874-6770.

title: Vaulx-en-Velin Journal;   Arab Youths of France: Their Anger Boils Over
description: The Mas-du-Taureau section here, a predominantly North African neighborhood, has had quite a facelift: there are newly planted chestnut trees, a new library and day-care center and a fresh coat of salmon-colored paint on the six-story apartment buildings.

title: To Fix the Budget Mess, Restore Pre-'86 Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Rwanda Accepts Cease-Fire Plan
description: President Juvenal Habyarimana of Rwanda said today that he had accepted a Belgian plan calling for neutral troops to supervise a cease-fire between his army and rebels invading from Uganda.

title: Digital Equipment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Illinois
description: Senate Race

title: McClatchy Newspapers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
State Grounds a Family's Barges It Says Fouled New York Harbor
description: New York State yesterday shut down what it said was the worst polluter of New York Harbor, a labyrinthine network of oil- and sludge-hauling companies owned by a single family from New Jersey and New York.

title: Economic Scene;   If a Recession, How Serious?
description: IT is probable, but not yet certain, that the United States is in a recession.

title: Fujitsu Introduces Portable Computer
description: Fujitsu Ltd. displayed a notebook-sized personal computer that is the lightest ever made in Japan and that the company hopes will win it a prime spot in the computer industry's fast-growing portable market. The machine weighs 2.2 pounds. Fujitsu and the Poqet Computer Corporation of the United States, in which it has a majority stake, have developed a one-pound model for the American market, a Fujitsu spokeswoman said.

title: U.S. Reserve To Pump Oil
description: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve will pump 75,000 barrels of crude oil on Friday from one of its Louisiana salt domes, the first shipment of oil in a test of the system ordered three weeks ago by President Bush, the Energy Department said today.

title: Union Camp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Panama Uncovers Plot to Topple President
description: Panama's Government said today it had uncovered evidence of a plot to topple President Guillermo Endara that was to start with a takeover by rebel police units of the northwestern province of Chiriqui.

title: Bush Says He Will Press Lenders To Widen Aid to Eastern Europe
description: Pledging to help Eastern European countries cope with the rising energy costs resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis, President Bush said today that he would work to arrange an additional $5 billion in international loans to those financially strapped nations.

title: ITT Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter's earnings included an after-tax writeoff of $26 million for the write-off of the company's investment in a Sheraton hotel. The latest 9 months' results included an after-tax gain of $139 million, or 99 cents a fully diluted share, on the sale of Alcatel and a gain on sale of the company's investment in Compagnie Generale d'Electricite of $47 million, or 33 cents a fully diluted share. The 1989 9 months' results included an after-tax gain of $18 million, or 12 cents a share, on sales of the European headquarters facility and an after-tax loss of $28 million on the sale of ITT Hartford's investment in Thompson McKinnon Inc.

title: Pinnacle West Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,476,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $62,236,000 and $131,728,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Net income for the quarter declined because of a $26 million increase in interest on long-term debt between 1989 and 1990. About half of the interest expense stems from the $450 million capital infusion into Merabank last March while most of the balance is for interest on real estate construction projects which had been capitalized in 1989 but charged to operating expenses in 1990.

title: The Tumbling Dollar Hits A Low Against the Mark
description: The dollar tumbled yesterday, breaking though the 1.50 level against the German mark and ending at its lowest level since the mark was created 42 years ago.

title: To Fix the Budget Mess, Restore Pre-'86 Taxes;   Portent in the Rough
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Soviets Jointly Urge Settlement in Salvador
description: In their first coordinated effort to end the civil war in El Salvador, the United States and the Soviet Union called today on the Salvadoran Government and the leftist guerrillas to intensify their negotiations to reach a cease-fire and political compromise.

title: Plastic Plus, Or the Art Of the Bag
description: THEY were the lap dogs of the 50's. But by the time the decade was over, they had all run away from home.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Desoto Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a restructuring charge of $12.5 million.

title: Shattered by Girl's Death, Neighbors Seek Answers
description: In the hours after 10-year-old Jessica Guzman's body was found by a roadside, one week after she disappeared, a group of mothers began climbing the stairs of her Bronx housing project to collect flower money. And as neighbors stuffed $1 and $5 bills into their glass jar, the women left a message.

title: Gorbachev's Reform Plan Is a Bust
description: LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev's new economic reform program is destined to fail. At the crucial moment, he flinched; it is not wholly clear why. For the moment, a historic opportunity to reform the economy, with far-reaching renovation of Soviet society, has been lost. But that opportunity may come again, for it is certain that even even worse political and economic chaos will follow.

title: Mattel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Southern N.E. Telecommuniations reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included for both periods a one- time after-tax charge of $19,200,000 for writedown of accounts receivable and increase in loss reserves and an extraordinary loss of $5,500,000 from refinancing of high-coupon debentures. Results for the latest quarter and 9 months included effect of $600,000 and $1.7 million tax benefits, respectively, on dividends to ESOP. Results for year-ago 9 months included one-time gain of $19 million, or 30 cents a share, from sale of Fibercom.

title: Amex-Europe Trading Accord
description: The American Stock Exchange announced agreements yesterday with the European Options Exchange and the Paris Bourse that expand the number of international products that can be traded in New York.

title: Ball Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings were calculated after preferred dividends of $1.4 million and $4 million in the 1990 quarter and 9 months, respectively, and $1.3 million in both the 1989 quarter and 9 months.

title: Progressive Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
750 Reported Killed in Lebanese General's Defeat
description: At least 750 people were killed in the Syrian-led offensive that toppled Michel Aoun, the Christian militia chief, and in reprisals after the attack on Saturday, military and hospital officials said today.

title: Addicted Parents' Children Pose Foster-Care Challenge
description: New York City's neediest children, the growing numbers of youngsters born to drug-addicted mothers, are in danger of suffering long-term emotional problems because the city's foster-care system is unable to move quickly to arrange permanent homes, child-welfare advocates said at a symposium yesterday.

title: Bell Atlantic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Seth Morgan, 41, Dies in Crash; His Novel, 'Homeboy,' Won Praise
description: Seth Morgan, who won acclaim last spring for his first novel, ''Homeboy,'' which drew on his experiences in the drug culture of San Francisco and in prison, was killed early Wednesday morning when the motorcycle he was driving struck a dividing post on a bridge in New Orleans, the police said.

title: May I Quote You in Some Way or Other?
description: To the Editor:

title: Central & South West Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said latest 9-month figures reflects restated first and second quarter earnings, resulting from regulatory action.

title: Amoco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $149 million net gain on sale of refining and marketing operations in the U.K. for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included a gain of $471 million from settlement with Iran and a $477 million charge for environmental programs. c-Included $100 million charge for environmental and work force reductions for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Textron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After extraordinary loss of $9.5 million. Year-ago periods ended Sept. 30.

title: MacArthur Was Right
description: The United States is working hard, doing its very best, to persuade Japan to make a momentous decision. If Japan finally agrees, generations to come will remember and study the great historic moment - and will curse the day.

title: Dow Soars 64.85 Points, To 2,452.72
description: Stable oil prices carried the stock market sharply higher yesterday, with transportation stocks a big beneficiary.

title: Coleman's Stance With Nets Becomes Pay Me or Trade Me
description: Derrick Coleman's agent said yesterday that he had asked the Nets to sign his client to a five-year, $15 million contract soon or trade him to another team. Coleman is threatening to sit out the National Basketball Association season or play professionally in Europe.

title: Vladimir B. Adzemovic, Banker, 63
description: Vladimir B. Adzemovic, a banker and president of the lay committee of the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava on West 26th Street in Manhattan, died on Monday at his home on Staten Island. He was 63 years old.

title: Western Digital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net loss Year-ago periods ended Sept. 30.

title: Languid Murder by Phone
description: ''The Kill-Off'' is perfectly Pinteresque, slow and filled with longueurs. Unfortunately, Maggie Greenwald's film is based on a down-and-dirty 1950's crime novel by Jim Thompson. Nothing could suit his swift, tangled story less than Ms. Greenwald's languid treatment.

title: TWO KOREAS AGREE TO FURTHER TALKS
description: Senior negotiators from North and South Korea said today that they had again failed to reach agreement on any steps to reduce mutual tensions, but that there was reason to hope that an accord could be worked out in the future.

title: TV Weekend;   NBC's Game: Lansbury vs. Baseball
description: One way or another, television viewers will be able to have their regular Angela Lansbury fix on Sunday. If the World Series does not go to five games, CBS will be offering ''Murder, She Wrote'' at 8 P.M., as usual. On the offensive, no matter what happens, NBC is counterprogramming, also at 8, ''The Love She Sought,'' a two-hour movie starring Ms. Lansbury who, faced with the possibility of competing with herself, may end up the night's only loser.

title: St. Paul Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,470,000 from the repurchase of notes. c-Net income

title: Review/Film;   Tom Selleck In 'Quigley Down Under'
description: Tom Selleck has such a friendly, easygoing manner that it's hard to know why he fades into the woodwork whenever he appears on the big screen. The qualities that make him such a natural television star become remarkably unhelpful against the larger backdrop of a feature film.

title: Arab League Rebuffs P.L.O.; Won't Condemn U.S.
description: A ministerial meeting of the 21-nation Arab League was thrown into disarray today after the Palestine Liberation Organization led a walkout to protest the refusal of a majority to condemn United States policy toward Palestinians.

title: A Budget Status Report
description: Proposals Almost Certain to Emerge From Congress

title: Kennametal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Restaurants
description: The Four Seasons

title: Dow Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months share earnings are after preferred dividend requirements of $2 million and $5 million, respectively.

title: Bradley's Star Appeal Lingers, Easing Way in Senate Race
description: Bill Bradley seems genuinely hurt that Senate staff members, in a recent Washington survey, said he was the nation's most overrated Senator.

title: Raise in Dispute as New York City Negotiates 3d Day With 2 Unions
description: New York City's municipal labor talks ground through their third day yesterday as city and union officials shuttled in and out of the presidential suite on the 21st floor of the Sheraton Centre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Norwest Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Norwest said results included those of First Interstate Corp. of Wisconsin, which merged with Norwest effective May 1, and has been accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: To Rescind Teacher Raise Would Be Admission of Impotence
description: To the Editor:

title: National Westminster Banorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Total Petroleum (North Aneria) Ltd.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1989 periods are after a pretax loss of $12 million relating to the planned disposal of the company's participation in the Peace River Fertilizer Plant. Net income per share for 1990 periods is after assuming conversion of the convertible preferred shares; net income per share for 1989 periods is after payment of preferred dividends.

title: Prosecutor's Apparent Suicide Tied to Slaying of Informer
description: The death of an assistant district attorney is being investigated as an apparent suicide, with friends saying he blamed himself for leading killers to a murder witness because of a mix-up by the police.

title: This Time, Testaverde Will Be on His Turf
description: On Oct. 7, Vinny Testaverde of Tampa Bay faced his former college coach, Jimmy Johnson of Dallas, for the first time, and the Cowboys edged the Buccaneers, 14-10. Only two weeks later, Testaverde will get another shot when Dallas (2-4) meets Tampa Bay (4-2) on Sunday in the Cowboys' first trip ever to Tampa Stadium.

title: THE SENATE PASSES A BUDGET ACCORD BY 54-TO-46 VOTE
description: With bipartisan support, the Senate approved a comprehensive budget package early this morning that would raise the taxes or cut the benefits of nearly all Americans.

title: U S West Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflected a 2-for-1 stock split distributed on May 2 and the issuance of 16.1 million additional shares during the second quarter of 1990.

title:
LAW;

What's in a Familiar Name Could Well Be a Judgeship
description: LEAD: Judges and political consultants say evidence continues to mount that many voters pay little attention to electoral races for state judgeships and simply vote for candidates with familiar-sounding names.

title: Baxter Net Rises 32%
description: Baxter International Inc., the giant medical-supply company, today reported a 32 percent increase in third-quarter profits, citing strong overseas markets.

title: Dana Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said 1990 third quarter were reduced by a $10 million charge for an increase in reserves at its Diamond Financial Holdings unit. The company said the 1989 quarter earnings included a $5.6 million, or 14 cents a share, gain from restructuring debt at a Mexican affiliate.

title: Soviet Circus Members Ask Political Asylum
description: Fourteen members of a Soviet circus stranded in an Atlanta suburb since May have filed for political asylum, their lawyer says.

title: Wherein a Law Firm Gets Caught in Its Own Publicity Ploy
description: Only a few years ago, law firms with embarrassing internal problems hunkered down and circled the wagons until the trouble passed. But the New York law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler recently demonstrated how completely things have changed.

title: Compromise May Limit Free Mailings in House
description: A compromise plan by Democrats and Republicans in the House would force members to reveal how much taxpayers' money they spend on mailings to their home districts.

title: New York Times Co. Posts 43.9% Drop in Operating Net
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that income from current operations fell 43.9 percent in the third quarter, to $9.2 million, or 12 cents a share. That compared with operating income of $16.4 million, or 21 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: Mapco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First Security Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results were restated to reflect merger March 2 with United Savings Bank, Salem, Ore.

title: Berlin Arrests 4, Alleging $328 Million in Swindles
description: The German authorities have arrested four people they say are connected with a major series of swindles that have cheated the Bonn Government out of at least $328 million since July, a Government prosecutor announced today.

title: Schlumberger Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain of $13 million, or 5 cents a share, from sale of Schlumberger Industries' defense systems business, and a gain of $22 million, or 9 cents a share, from an award by the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal.

title: Correction
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Richard J. Hummler, the theater editor of Variety, misstated his marital status. He and Marilyn L. Stasio were separated, not divorced.

title: Review/Fashion;   Young French Designers Stretch Fashion's Rules
description: In the opening days of the French ready-to-wear collections, before the big guns of fashion take the stage, a number of lesser-known designers hold shows. Some choose odd, out-of-the-way places to parade their styles - a smoky garage, or the Eskimo room of a museum - while others stick to the tents erected in a courtyard outside the Louvre, where most of the buyers go.

title: Soviet Aide Who Met the Iraqis Talks in Washington About Gulf
description: A senior Soviet official who recently met with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq discussed the Persian Gulf crisis with top American officials today, but offered no indication that he had brought a new proposal for ending Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.

title: Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of less than $1 million from the purchase of junior subordinated debentures for the quarter; the 9 months included a charge of $1 million from purchases of senior subordinated debentures and junior subordinated debentures. The latest periods fully consolidates the accounts of Fiberglas Canada Inc., while the 1989 periods is reported using the equity method of accounting.

title: Thomas Murton, 62, a Penologist Who Advocated Reforms, Is Dead
description: Thomas Murton, an outspoken advocate of prison reform who attracted national attention in 1968 when he accused Arkansas trusties and guards of abusing convicts, died on Oct. 10 at the Veterans Afffairs Medical Center in Oklahoma City. He was 62 years old.

title: Public Service of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Profits Scoreboard
MCA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,853,000 for the quarter and $12,999,000 for the 9 months.

title: Israel Retracts Pledge to U.S On East Jerusalem Housing
description: Foreign Minister David Levy today retracted a commitment made to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that Israel would not settle more Soviet immigrants in East Jerusalem.

title: Richard S. Miller, 68, Yale Ecology Professor
description: Richard Samuel Miller, an ecologist and a professor emeritus at Yale University's School of Forestry, died last Friday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in North Branford, Conn.

title: The New York Times Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included equity in operations of forest products group of $2,438,000 for the quarter and $3,927,000 for the 9 months. c-Included equity in operations of forest products group of $2,593,000 for the quarter and $9,212,000 for the 9 months; the periods were also after income from discontinued operations of $194,353,000, or $2.47 a share, for the quarter and $198,448,000, or $2.52 a share, for the 9 months.

title: SUPERCOMPUTERS BACKED FOR BRAZIL
description: House and Senate lawmakers took a step today toward allowing sales of American supercomputers to Brazil, a move that has been opposed by critics of Brazil's past military ties with Iraq.

title: First Hawaiian reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share figures reflected a 100 percent stock dividend paid in November 1989.

title: Texas Urges Quick Action to Halt Honeybees
description: Efforts to quarantine, search and destroy the Africanized honeybee are in full swing as state and Federal officials scramble to halt the newly arrived intruders' spread into the United States.

title: De Klerk Lifts Emergency Rule in Natal Province
description: President F. W. de Klerk lifted emergency rule in Natal today, following up on its removal in South Africa's other three provinces last June.

title: Mexican Phone Sale
description: Sixteen companies, including a dozen foreign concerns, qualified to bid for the Government-owned Telefonos de Mexico in a sale that could bring Mexico more than $4 billion, the Finance Ministry said late Wednesday.

title: Reds' Mission Not So Impossible Now
description: The 87th World Series headed for Oakland today with the Cincinnati Reds two games up on the defending champion Oakland Athletics, and halfway toward completing one of the long-shot upsets in modern baseball.

title: Athletics Are Looking Much Better on Paper Than on the Diamond
description: For the second time in three years, the best team in baseball has lost the first two games of the World Series. But are the Oakland Athletics the best team in baseball?

title: ASSAILING BEIJING, HOUSE VOTES A RISE IN CHINA'S TARIFFS
description: Protesting the continued restrictions on political dissent in China, the House of Representatives voted today to raise tariffs on billions of dollars of Chinese apparel, toys and other exports to this country and to set tougher conditions for tariff breaks for China next year.

title: China Buys U.S. Wheat
description: China has bought an additional 299,740 metric tons of United States wheat under a price subsidy program, the Agriculture Department said today. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said three private exporting companies had made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for the first three months of 1991, he said. It was the first wheat sale to China under the program since Aug. 1.

title: New York City's Elections Board: Who They Are
description: Jeannette Gadson: Joined board in 1990... represents Brooklyn Democratic organization ... Assemblywoman and former executive secretary to former Councilman Samuel D. Wright ...now district manager of Community Board No. 16 in Brooklyn.

title: Stuart Greenspan, 44, Art Writer and Editor
description: Stuart Greenspan, a writer on art and a former magazine editor, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 44 years old, and lived in Manhattan. He died of AIDS, said his father, Nathan. A familiar figure in the auction world, Mr. Greenspan was editor in chief of the magazine Art & Auction from 1983 to 1987, and then became a contributing editor. He also wrote for House and Garden and for the weekly newspaper The New York Observer.

title: Intertan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $876,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $579,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year. c-Net income and after an extraordinary loss of $220,000. d-After an extraordinary credit of $2,142,000, or 24 cents a share.

title: La Russa and Canseco Check Their Swings
description: It was clearly a difference of opinion late Wednesday night, but today - with the Oakland Athletics reeling in a one-sided World Series - Tony La Russa and Jose Canseco met behind closed doors and then attempted to play down their disagreement.

title: AIDS in Africa: Experts Study Role of Promiscuous Sex in the Epidemic
description: When a man here talks about going to ''le deuxieme bureau,'' the second office, he means he is going to visit a mistress, perhaps at a place like the Hotel Bikoumou. It is one of the many small hotels that have prospered in this capital by renting rooms for two hours at a time.

title: Political Might of Elderly Is Felt Again in Senate
description: Elderly people have once again demonstrated their political power by persuading Congress to abandon proposals for sharp increases in the fees they pay for Medicare. But most of the elderly will still be obliged to pay more for their Federal health insurance coverage under legislation emerging from Capitol Hill.

title: Apple Computer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Included $48 million, or 37 cents a share, from the sale of Adobe common shares.

title: Great Lakes Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gillette Profits Rise 41.4%
description: The Gillette Company, at last seeing profits from its expensive introducton of the Sensor razor earlier this year, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 41.4 percent, to $92.2 million, or 80 cents a share. The earnings were in line with analysts' expectations.

title: Reflecting Oil Cost, Trade Deficit Hits $9.3 Billion
description: The United States trade deficit continued to worsen in August, rising 2.4 percent, to $9.3 billion, the largest imbalance since January, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase chiefly reflected the higher cost of imported oil resulting from the crisis in the Persian Gulf.

title: Review/Film;   A Tokyo of the Future In Vibrant Animation
description: Katsuhiro Otomo's ''Akira,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is a phenomenal work of animation with all the hallmarks of an instant cult classic. Its post-apocalyptic mood, high-tech trappings, thrilling artwork and wide array of bizarre characters guarantee it a place in the pantheon of comic-strip science fiction.

title: Witnesses Fail to Link Milken to Wrongdoing
description: At Michael R. Milken's pre-sentencing hearing yesterday, Government witnesses testified about a number of unethical and possibly illegal actions involving executives of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. But they did not tie Mr. Milken to any of those activities.

title: Freddie Mac Reports Loss
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, an important home-financing concern, today announced $124 million in losses on its mortgage portfolio in the July-September quarter.

title: High Hopes of Defeating Simon Are Being Deflated
description: At a meeting a year ago, two of the biggest names in the Republican Party's stable of consultants, Robert Teeter and Roger Ailes, told Representative Lynn Martin of Illinois that if she could raise the money, she could unseat Senator Paul Simon, the avuncular incumbent whose liberalism seemed to make him an inviting target.

title: Proposal by Gorbachev Wins Committee Votes
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic plan sailed through parliamentary committees today after a presidential adviser insisted that it would not inhibit individual republics from creating free markets at their own pace.

title: Hong Kong Prison Term
description: A former chairman of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange was sentenced today to four years in prison for corruption.

title: Japanese Banker to Head A Morgan Stanley Unit
description: The Morgan Stanley Group said yesterday that it had hired a Japanese banker, Takeo Kani, to be chairman of Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd. and general manger of the firm's Tokyo securities branch.

title: Florida Progress Corp. reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: Latest share earnings included a 32- cent charge representing a reserve for the disposition costs and potential losses associated with the sale of the firm's Talquin Corp. unit's window manufacturing business. The amount is classified as ''discontinued operations.'' Year-ago share earnings included a gain of 6 cents a share from discontinued operations.

title: Mobil Accepts Safety Adviser
description: Mobil Oil, settling a lawsuit aimed at its suburban Los Angeles refinery, agreed to inspections by an independent safety adviser. Page D1.

title: Eastern Reports Success With Fares
description: Eastern Airlines has told its unsecured creditors that its new fares have been a success with business travelers and could enable the troubled carrier to survive, a spokeswoman said. ''The corporate fares are going over very well with business travelers,'' the spokeswoman, Karen Ceremsak, said.

title: Outwitting Ducks and Other Waterfowling Endeavors on L.I.
description: The South Shore Waterfowlers Association of Long Island is holding its 10th annual duck boat show and waterfowl calling contest from 9 A.M. to noon on Nov. 11 at the Heckscher State Park Boat Basin in East Islip.

title: Gain for Tokyo Stocks
description: A stronger yen and hopes for peace in the Middle East pushed stocks higher in Tokyo early today, but by the close much of the gain had evaporated. The Nikkei index of 225 issues, which at midday was up 483.47 points, or 2 percent, closed at 24,481.49, for a gain of 114.41.

title: MCA's Profit Rose 20.9% in Third Quarter
description: MCA Inc. said today that its third-quarter net income had risen 20.9 percent, paced by gains in music and broadcasting earnings.

title: Beverly Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a pre-tax restructuring charge of about $128,104,000.

title: Market Place;   Michelin Facing Problems as No. 1
description: WHEN a company becomes No. 1 in the world, it is usually good news, but the financial markets have not seen it that way for Michelin, the French tire maker. Michelin became the world leader in tire sales last May through its $1.5 billion acquisition of the Uniroyal-Goodrich Company, but since then its stock has tumbled.

title: Profits Down at Digital and Apple
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. reported yesterday that their earnings had fallen in the latest quarter. Digital's earnings plunged nearly 83 percent, while Apple's were down just under 39 percent.

title: Offer by Bonneau For Foster Grant
description: The Bonneau Company, a leader in the sunglasses business, has offered to pay $9 million for the assets of the Foster Grant Corporation, including its name and trademark. Foster Grant, which rode to prominence with ads asking what star was behind its sunglasses, sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in August.

title: Review/Photography;   Reminders of the 60's In Collage and Montage
description: In the 1960's, the West Coast generated its own brand of Pop Art. Artists like Wallace Berman, Bruce Conner and Edward Kienholz, while less attuned to Madison Avenue than their New York City counterparts, nonetheless brought artifacts of popular culture into play in their work. They did so largely through a process of accumulation, in a style that came to be known as California Assemblage.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BOXING

title: Devils Setting Out to Gain An Early Jump on First
description: Although it is still October and April is a long way off, first place is always important to teams in the Patrick Division.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Baker Hughes Inc., Houston, which services the oil and gas industry, said it had acquired Chemlink Inc., an oilfield and industrial chemicals company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Indonesia's Muslims See Gulf Complications
description: This is the largest Muslim country in the world, with more of the faithful than all the Arab countries combined. It is also one of the most relaxed and least doctrinaire, with Islam keeping a careful line between faith and ideology, between influence and political activity.

title: New Bond Request By Trump
description: Donald J. Trump is offering bondholders of his Taj Mahal casino new high-yield ''junk bonds'' in lieu of a coming interest payment and is trying to keep more than 80 percent of the equity in the casino while reducing the interest rate on $675 million of its bonds, the Trump Organization disclosed yesterday.

title: Surgery for Evans
description: Dwight Evans, who just completed his 18th season with the Boston Red Sox, had minor arthroscopic surgery yesterday to remove scar tissue from under his right kneecap. Evans was slowed during the past season by back problems. The knee surgery was performed at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester.

title: Grey New York Wins T.C.B.Y.
description: Grey Advertising, New York, was awarded the business for T.C.B.Y. Systems Inc., a yogurt franchise company.

title: Seafirst Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Seafirst is a unit of BankAmerica Corp.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 519 money market mutual funds increased by $3.76 billion, to $415.11 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday. The Investment Company Institute said yesterday that the assets of the 159 institutional funds increased by $2.48 billion, to $102.33 billion. The assets of the 255 general-purpose funds were up by $625.4 million, to $146.78 billion. The 105 broker-dealer funds increased by $652.8 million, to $166.01 billion, the institute said.

title: Santa Fe Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $13,100,000 attributable to a swap of company common stock for a portion of Santa Fe Pacific's 16-percent senior subordinated debentures. c-Included an after-tax charge of $115,000,000 from settlement of litigation and an accounting credit of $210,000,000, or $1.32 a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. d-Net income

title: Sports of The Times;   Billy Bates Joins Cookie, Gionfriddo
description: The World Series moves westward to Oakland, but before we depart from the Queen City of the Ohio, it is well worth going over Wednesday night's game, which just might be a raggedy classic of sorts.

title: Plan Would Raise Pay of Federal Workers
description: Federal workers' pay would be increased by as much as 5 percent a year through 1994 and employees living in high-cost cities would receive extra compensation under an agreement by House and Senate negotiators.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Haran's Songs

title: Critic's Choice
description: People don't play the piano the way they used to do. Oral tradition tells us this. Distant old recordings back it up. Up until World War II, style tended to begin and end with the personality of the pianist. A lot of music was manhandled in these fits of egocentricity, but there was a freedom - indeed, an extravagance - of expression at some distance from the freeze-dried correctness we tend to come in contact with today.

title: Nynex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Our Towns;   How to Finish A Census Count: Just Make It Up
description: Terry Ghazey and Mary Beth Scully used to believe in the census. They started working in the district office here last winter. Mrs. Ghazey at one point made three visits after dark to a motel for the homeless to try and count everyone. In time she was promoted to supervise 100 enumerators.

title: AmeriTrust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Trinova Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,087,000.

title: Home Shopping Network Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $311,000 for the quarter and $6,290,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year, which reflects an after-tax gain from repurchase of long-term obligations. c-Net loss and after extraordinary credits of $129,000 for the quarter and $7,136,000 for the year, which reflects an after-tax gain from repurchase of long-term obligations.

title: Savings Bailout May Be Hindered By Political Impasse Over Money
description: The Government bailout of the savings and loan industry may be forced to slow substantially for lack of money because neither the Bush Administration nor Congress wants to be seen as endorsing new spending for the effort right before the November elections.

title: Keystone Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books of The Times;   America's Top-Secret Sky Watch
description: Out There

title: Milton Sherman, Executive, 65
description: Milton Sherman, an advertising executive and an authority on Shaker furniture, died on Saturday at White Plains Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Armonk, N.Y.

title: INSIDE
description: Consumer Prices Up 0.8%

title: Diner's Journal
description: Book-Friends Cafe

title: Self-Inflicted Wounds
description: The Israeli Government's behavior toward the United States over the last two weeks appears to be based on a delusion. That is the belief that Israel can deceive the American Government, provoke it, injure its interests - and still get uncritical American support for whatever Israel wants.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Rise
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell yesterday, as a better-than-expected report on inflation and an early drop in oil prices inspired buying.

title: Keating Freed on $300,000 Bail Under Ruling by a Federal Judge
description: A Federal judge today reduced Charles H. Keating Jr.'s bail to $300,000, from $5 million, and hours later the former savings and loan official was freed, having spent a month in a county jail.

title: Macy Will Report Deeper Losses for the Fourth Quarter and the Year
description: R. H. Macy & Company's fourth-quarter loss deepened to $80 million, from $57.3 million a year earlier, and its losses for the full fiscal year ended July 28 more than tripled, to $215.3 million, from $63 million the year before, according to statements relayed to credit agencies and confirmed yesterday by sources close to Macy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is only one route to peace and reconciliation in our country and that is through peaceful negotiation. The door is now fully open and I am appealing to all leaders and all South Africans to accept the challenge of this open door.''

title: A Saudi Oil Windfall? If Prices Remain High and Fields Intact
description: Whether Saudi Arabia reaps a windfall from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait depends on two big ifs - if its oilfields are undamaged by war and if oil prices stay high.

title: B. P. Asset Sale For $217 Million
description: The British Petroleum Company agreed to sell the companies holding its exploration and production interests in New Zealand to Fletcher Challenge Ltd. for about $217 million. The company said the interests included an 18.75 percent stake in the offshore Maui field and a 37.5 percent ownership in the onshore Kapuni field. They produce natural gas and condensate for the local New Zealand market.

title: Confusion on Who Are Victims of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis Has Surgery On His Right Knee
description: Carl Lewis, the holder of the world record for the 100-meter dash, has undergone arthroscopic surgery on his right knee, and the procedure will delay his training schedule for the 1991 outdoor season, one of his coaches said yesterday in Houston.

title: Nominees for the National Book Awards
description: Two first novels and a novel completed in 1948 but published only last year are among the five finalists for the 1990 National Book Award in fiction. The finalists also include Joyce Carol Oates, who won the award in 1970.

title: Thomson TV Plant Still Going Strong
description: The Thomson Consumer Electronics Corporation celebrated the production of the 50-millionth RCA color television set by heralding the company's big assembly plant here as ''the color TV capital of the world.'' Bernard Isautier, the new chairman of the French-owned Thomson, challenged the workers at the world's largest television assembly operation to meet the challenges of global competition.

title: Lafarge Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Jump in Gasoline Price Feared
description: Even as crude oil prices descend from the $40 range, gasoline prices seem poised for another significant increase, industry experts say.

title: Review/Theater;   Caribbean Rhythms and the Blues
description: ''Once on This Island,'' first produced by Playwrights Horizons, has reopened at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. Following are excerpts from Frank Rich's review, which appeared in The New York Times on May 7.

title: First Fidelity Bancorp-N.J.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $1,750,000. c-Net income and after extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $6,950,000.

title: Ethics Panel Puts Focus On 3 Senators' Activities
description: Facing growing political pressure to act, the Senate Ethics Committee began deliberating today over a recommendation that the panel proceed to a full-scale investigation of three Senators who helped an important campaign contributor.

title: Harsco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
An Agency's Contracts: Friendship Pays
description: The New York City Board of Elections has squandered millions of dollars on contracts with companies that have financial and political ties to party leaders, from a long-term lease on a decrepit warehouse to an extravagant system of repairing voting machines.

title: The Anti-Tax Offensive of the 1980's Is Over, or So the Democrats Believe
description: As Congress moved toward completion of a budget package today, the Democrats who control both the Senate and the House of Representatives cast their bets that the Reagan era was really over.

title: A Renault Executive Is Taking Over Mack
description: Mack Trucks Inc., the money-losing heavy-duty diesel truck manufacturer owned by the French auto maker Renault is switching to a French chief executive. Mack, based in Allentown, Pa., announced yesterday that Elios Pascual had been named to the post.

title: Portland General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $788,000 and $3,207,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Study of Indians' Remains: Science or Sacrilege?
description: A small bag full of charred prehistoric bone chips locked inside the evidence cabinet of a district attorney is the focus of the latest and most peculiar twist in a nationwide debate over the status of American Indian relics.

title: Is Our High-Tech Military a Mirage?
description: LEAD: Like ancient Greek and Romandramatists, Americans often imagine that when it comes to war, a deus ex machina - literally a ''god from a machine'' - will descend at just the right moment to guarantee battlefield success. Their faith is not so much in the god as in the machine itself - high-technology weaponry that will tip the odds overwhelmingly in our favor.

title: At the Movies
description: A Dream Fulfilled

title: Colgate-Palmolive Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Salomon Unit Chosen
description: The Resolution Trust Corporation said today that it had selected Salomon Asset Management Inc., a subsidiary of Salomon Inc., to serve as its adviser for selling high-yield ''junk bonds.'' The Government inherited the high-yield portfolio from failed savings and loans institutions. Resolution Trust's inventory of junk bond instruments has a face value of about $3.3 billion and includes 439 issues held by 30 institutions that have been taken over by regulators. Since July, the Government said, it has sold about $500 million in high-yield securities.

title: Library of Congress Adds 25 Titles to National Film Registry
description: The Library of Congress announced today this year's selection of 25 American films to be included in the National Film Registry of works that are considered ''culturally, historically or esthetically significant.''

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 11.6% on Big Board
description: The latest figure is equivalent to nine-tenths of 1 percent of the total shares listed on the Big Board.Amex Short Sales Also at Record High

title: Paine Webber Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First Fidelity Profit Up 29%
description: The First Fidelity Bancorporation, the largest banking company in New Jersey, yesterday announced profits of $70.1 million in the third quarter, its most profitable quarter in two years.

title: Gillette Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Allied Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mark Twain Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Europe Hesitates
description: Western Europe's will to consolidate is faltering as Community members reach a moment of decision. Something happened during the summer to drain off momentum from the intense new drive to change and strengthen the Common Market's Treaty of Rome into the start of a real constitutional union.

title: Meredith Profits Jump on One-Time Gains
description: The Meredith Corporation said today that its earnings increased sixfold in the first quarter of its fiscal year, reflecting one-time gains from asset sales.

title: Zenith Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $11,000,000. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $15,000,000 and $20,100,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Results for 1990 periods included a pre-tax gain of $2.4 million relating to the termination of a defined-benefit pension plan. Results for year-ago 9 months included a non-recurring pre-tax gain of $1.1 million from the disposition of properties. Year-ago periods ended Sept. 30.

title: Cheney May Seek Veto Unless Pentagon Is Heeded on Arms Budget
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has informed Congress that he plans to recommend a veto of the $288 billion military budget bill unless lawmakers change it to take account of Defense Department objections, Pentagon officials and lawmakers said today.

title: National Sanitary Supply Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Politics, Kids, Fine Print
description: LEAD: The latest decline in reading skills measured and announced by the makers of the College Board exams will undoubtedly inspire many to call for various levels of government to take action. In doing so, however, I think we are asking the foxes to design a better security system for the henhouse.

title: Chips & Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it repurchased $10.9 million of its common stock in the latest quarter.

title: Affiliated Publications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $26,884,000.

title: Harrier Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a $1.4 million writeoff of a net license right receiveable. The writeoff reflects a change in the amount and manner of payment for the Harrier diesel cleaner under a license agreement signed in September 1988 and amended in March 1990. Since the renegotiated license fee is payable over two years commencing with the licensees successful testing of 10 units now underway, the balance was deemed to conditional and was therefore written off in its entirety. The company said the sum will be taken into income in the future as funds are received. c-Net income and reflects the sale of license rights in the amount of $2 million.

title: British Clear Company In 192 Deaths on Ferry
description: The trial of a British shipping company and seven employees, charged with manslaughter after a Channel ferry capsized and killed 192 people in 1987, ended abruptly today when the judge ruled that the prosecution had failed to produce sufficient evidence.

title: Review/Music;   Irish Fiddling In Curlicues
description: Fractal-geometry theorists have proved that natural contours like coastlines and mountain paths approach infinite length as the details of their kinks and curves are examined closely. The Sligo style of traditional Irish fiddling holds a similar paradox; the melodies take on all sorts of stutters and slides and turns and passing notes, so that a straightforward tune is, at the same time, a wildly convoluted zigzag.

title: Loss Leaves Islanders Alone in Patrick Cellar
description: Considering that it was an early-season battle to escape last place in the Patrick Division, the game here tonight between the Islanders and the Washington Capitals was better than might have been expected.

title: Oglebay Norton Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: As head of the Office of Financial Services and the chairwoman of both the Financial Services Corporation and New York City Industrial Development Agency, LERESSA R. CROCKETT has not been one of Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS's high-profile commissioners.

title: Cirrus Logic Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sisters Have Special Duty to Reflect Catholic Abortion Position
description: To the Editor:

title: Jason Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Asahi Gets Cut In Elders Price
description: Australia's privately held Harlin Holdings has accepted about $150 million less than originally negotiated in a deal to sell a stake in Elders IXL to Japan's Asahi Breweries.

U.S. TO SEND TANKS FROM NATO TO GULF
description: The Pentagon said today that it was shipping 400 to 500 of its top battle tanks to Saudi Arabia from storage depots in Germany.

title: Wrapped in U.S. Flag, Madonna Raps for Vote
description: Madonna, the crucifix-and-lingerie pop idol who has rapped for people with AIDS, the environment and other causes, waves the American flag for freedom of speech in her latest public-service video and wiggles in red panties, bra and combat boots to get out the vote next month.

title: 6 Nursing Programs Cancelled
description: In a slap at the New York City school system, State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol yesterday rescinded the registrations of practical nursing programs at all six high schools that offer them and ordered the programs to close by September.

title: Canada Closing Set By Kelsey-Hayes
description: A Kelsey-Hayes Canada Ltd. steel wheel plant in Windsor, Ontario, will be closed by the end of the month, resulting in the loss of about 450 hourly and salaried jobs, the company said. The company cited ''grave operational problems and mounting losses due to significant overcapacity in the steel wheels manufacturing industry.''

title: A Lantern-Jawed Comedian Travels the Literary Circuit
description: Jay Leno's new book, ''More Headlines,'' has been copyrighted in the name of a mysterious entity called Big Dog Productions Inc. That's the name printed on the title page. So just what is this big dog? ''Well, there is no anthropomorphic dog running things,'' he said the other day. ''That's me, the big dog. Don't I have that big-friendly-dog look?''

description: b-Reflects a second-quarter income tax adjustment of $728,000 and after- tax interest income of $269,000 on a related refund.

description: The owners of Madison Square Garden, which is in the process of an unexpectedly costly overhaul, are preparing a plan for luxury courtside and rinkside seats that could cost as much as $70 apiece for Knicks and Rangers games in the 1991-92 season, according to former executives at the Garden.

title: TAX RISE FOR RICH IS SEEN AS A PART OF A BUDGET DEAL
description: President Bush went to Capitol Hill today to rally Republicans around a plan that would cut the Federal budget deficit without raising income tax rates. But House and Senate negotiators predicted that a final budget deal would likely include some increase in income taxes on the wealthy, as well as a rise in gasoline taxes.

title: La Quinta Inns And Bass at Odds
description: An investment group that includes members of the Bass family of Fort Worth requested that the board of La Quinta Motor Inns Inc. allow its shareholders to vote on the company's ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan. The Bass group controls 14.9 percent of the La Quinta's shares. They are stymied from buying additional shares of the San Antonio-based hotel chain because the poison pill would be triggered if the group's holdings crossed the 15 percent threshold.

title: Nissan Examines Expansion in U.S.
description: The Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A. has bought options on about 900 acres in Tennessee and Alabama for a plant to build engines, a company executive said. The sites under consideration would be used to build components for the Japanese car maker, which builds Sentras and light pickup trucks at its Smyrna, Tenn., plant., near Nashville.

Power Still Out To Many Homes After the Storm
description: Hundreds of homes throughout the New York City metropolitan area were still without electricity or telephone service yesterday, as utility crews worked to repair lines downed by the powerful storm that slammed into the region Thursday night.

title: Your Money;   Taxes Complicate 'Junk Bond' Loss
description: With the pounding the ''junk bond'' market has taken this year, many investors now hold high-yield, high-risk securities that are worth far less than they paid for them. And in the fourth quarter, a paper loss always raises the question of whether to sell in order to lower taxable income, and, if one still likes the holding, of whether to invest the proceeds in a similar but not identical security.

title: Review/Music;   Slatkin Leads Philharmonic In a Tribute to Bernstein
description: By all reports, Leonard Bernstein didn't like the mornings, but on Friday the New York Philharmonic got him up early - wherever he may be - and serenaded their late laureate conductor with some of his own music.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about budget problems at the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road misstated restraints placed on their spending in 1991. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which supervises the railroads, has told them to limit spending increases to 3.7 percent in 1991, not to cut spending by 3.7 percent.

title: Review/Music;   The Shanghai Symphony
description: The Shanghai Symphony's appearance at Carnegie Hall last Sunday night was more a progress report than a recitation of accomplishments. This is an orchestra with a will to play well but not yet the means. The problems, at least for the moment, are not so much cultural distance from European music. These players and their conductor, Hou Run-yu, had the gestures of Berlioz's ''Roman Carnival'' Overture and the Rachmaninoff Second Symphony pretty clearly in their ears, and they respond to their sentiments genuinely. The Shanghai simply does not sound like a world-class ensemble. Even though it is known to have upgraded the quality of its instruments in the last few years, the replacements, especially the strings, are still thin and drab. The ensemble, moreover, becomes confused in rapidly moving music. Rachmaninoff's Scherzo movement was a bona fide mess.

Review/Pop;   After Several Generations, Blues Comes in All Colors
description: The first two shows of the Benson & Hedges Blues '90 series last weekend at the Beacon Theater produced a decent amount of good music and loads of clues to the nature of the blues today. Ranging from Ry Cooder's spectacular re-imagining of American vernacular music to the Saturday-night functionalism of Elvin Bishop to Bo Diddley's extravagant neo-primitivism, it was clear that what is labeled as blues comes in all colors and sizes. And in the predominantly white audience, it was clear that the blues - now a code word for older black styles of music - has jumped cultures and built new relationships with a new audience.

title: Corinna Marsh, 98, Poet and an Author Of Children's Books

She was 98 years and old and had lived in an apartment at Le Marquis Hotel on East 31st Street for more than 40 years before moving earlier this year to the Mary Manning Walsh nursing home.

title: Fewer Cars at Independent Pumps
description: The business of gasoline retailing has been turned on its ear since Iraq invaded Kuwait. Thousands of independent service stations, which have historically attracted customers by offering gasoline for a few pennies less than rivals flying the flags of oil giants like Chevron and Texaco, have been forced in the last few months to raise prices faster than the major brands.

After the Killing in Lebanon
description: At terrible cost, and with Syrian arms, Lebanon's makeshift Government has ended a rebellion by Christian hard-liners led by Gen. Michel Aoun. Some 750 people were killed in the latest battle in a 15-year civil war that has left Beirut a charred ruin. If there is a peace of sorts, it remains a harsh one imposed from the outside by Syria; hopes for achieving something more depend on what Lebanon has sadly lacked - realism and moderation.

Once feeding is started, keep it up daily until spring. If you take a winter vacation, get a neighbor to fill in for you. Avoid peanut butter and millet, and clean feeders often so the food does not become moldy. Here are some birds that stay for the winter and their favorite foods. $ Bird Food Evening grosbeak Sunflower seeds Woodpecker Suet Winter wren Nutmeats and stale bread Nuthatch Suet mixtures Titmouse Sunflower seeds Chickadee Suet and doughnuts Cardinal Scratch feed on the ground Bobwhite Cracked corn on the ground
