title: Soviet Capitalism? First, Stability
description: The biggest news in Mikhail Gorbachev's newest economic reform plan may not be economic at all but political. What started out as a 500-day plan to overturn Communism and install capitalism is now an 000-day plan, without deadlines or even a timetable. And his program makes clear that he's ready to rule by decree, if necessary, to restore order and compel change.

title: Girl, 10, Writes Pamphlet for Children in Hospitals
description: LEAD: TEN-YEAR-OLD Rebecca Whelan speaks with ease about complicated medical procedures that would confound many adults. Three years ago, Rebecca underwent three operations for a brain tumor that, fortunately, was not cancerous. Still, it was an experience most people would want to put behind them as quickly as possible.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts and Leisure guide today for the pianist Alexander Shtarkman at the 92d Street Y is outdated. The concert, part of a series, has been postponed until next fall.

title: MARIACHIS AT SUNRISE
description: TO ENJOY MEXICO CITY by dark, the visitor is advised to do as the Mexicans do, savoring the capital at their rhythm and their pace. That means starting not with dinner, but with a show downtown at the Palacio de Bellas Artes: a concert, ballet, the opera, or whatever happens to be on the bill. After all, the theater itself, with its Art Deco furnishings and glistening crystal stage curtain, and the elegant audience, some in tuxedos or formal gowns, are half the show.

title: Reinstated in Tennis
description: Four tennis players banned from the Stockholm Open 10 months ago have been readmitted into the tournament after pledging not to play in South Africa again.

title: Managing;   Business Meetings by Keyboard
description: Not long ago, about 30 executives from the Greyhound Financial Corporation sat in a meeting room and ''talked'' at once. Yet no one was shouted down; no one garnered Brownie points or demerits; no one was intimidated into silence, and everyone's comments were given equal weight.

title: Hanging Houses of Cuenca
description: Most Spanish towns faced with Cuenca's need to expand in the 18th century would have spread out along the surrounding countryside. But Cuenca, perched on the top of a hill, turned not to the earth but to the sky. Its improbable solution stands all along that part of the town that clings to the side of of the hill and that faces the River Huecar: its hanging houses. The flat-fronted dwellings in the Barrio de San Martin, so starkly simple a child could draw them, rise seven or eight teetering stories above a ravine and the River Huecar to the east.

title: Eccentric Companions
description: PROFILES. By Kenneth Tynan. (Cornelia and Michael Bessie/Harper Perennial, Paper, $14.95.) ''The final test of a man's stature is his capacity for proper exultation,'' writes Kenneth Tynan in his discussion of Graham Greene, one of 50 pieces that make up ''Profiles,'' a collection of Tynan's character sketches, some previously uncollected. For the reader, the final test of these portraits of some of this century's most accomplished personalities may be Tynan's own inexhaustible enthusiasm. A decade after his death, Tynan's theater criticism is still considered second only to George Bernard Shaw's; he brought the same penetrating mind and felicitous pen to his journalism. While he diligently addressed the whos, whats, wheres and whens of each of his subjects, it was the hows and the whys that proved to be Tynan's forte. Through his remarkably broad interests and clarity of expression, he was a master at making the complex easily understandable, be it the paradoxes behind Tom Stoppard's dramas, the intricacies of Ralph Richardson's acting or the typically eccentric compulsion to approach, say, Humphrey Bogart with insights from Seneca. And always to be savored is his way with a phrase: ''What, when drunk, one sees in other women, one sees in Garbo sober.'' ''Miles [Davis] found himself as a musician some seven or eight years ago; and those who find themselves are seldom objects of affection to those who are still seeking.'' Peter Brook ''was never a crusader, and he looks about as neurotic as a chipmunk. Snub, stubby and self-contained, he radiates nothing more alarming than confidence.'' His comment about Shaw - ''Though he took great pains to command respect, he took none at all to inspire affection'' - might be a bit of disguised apologia. But in his feature pieces, Tynan never pontificated or instructed. Rather he commented and informed, enriching his diverse subjects and the era he helped them define with his elegant observations and exquisite prose.

Usually, it has a high waist, though sometimes it has a low waist with a flounce or just flares out from the bosom. But always it's short, anywhere from midthigh to just above the knee. It might even be mistaken for a tunic.

To the surprise of many, the courts have on the whole taken on this task in a spirit of judicial independence.

title: Romania Stops Financing TV
description: The Government, responding to journalists' complaints it was trying to control the press, said today it would stop subsidizing the country's state-run television. A Government statement said it respected the right of the press to air divergent opinions, but that freedom of expression ''does not require irreverence toward the Government.'' The official news agency said the Government would release no funds to cover the state television's debt, estimated at $2.8 million. It said the money would go to welfare programs instead. After the announcement, the television appealed to viewers to support a doubling or tripling of the viewing license fee, currently about 2.5 cents a day.

title: Sports of the Times: The Locker Room Revisted ... Again;   What's He Doing Here?
description: The locker room can often be an unappetizing place. As a dewy-eyed cub reporter some years ago, I stood, probably agape, after a baseball game and watched a famous player, now in the Hall of Fame, eat. He hunkered naked over the buffet table set up in the middle of the room, scratched himself generously as he contemplated the meal, and then with those same nimble, itching fingers plucked a piece of fried chicken here, a slice of tomato there, and some strands of cole slaw, then threw back his head and masticated.

title: 'West Side Story': The Beginnings Of Something Great
description: Several years ago, as part of a book in progress, Mel Gussow began exploring the creative process behind the Broadway musical ''West Side Story,'' which had its premiere in 1957. Here are excerpts from several conversations with Leonard Bernstein, the composer of that show as well as ''On the Town,'' ''Wonderful Town'' and ''Candide.'' GUSSOW: What were the origins of ''West Side Story''? BERNSTEIN: In 1949, Jerry Robbins was excited about the idea of doing a musical version of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' and he asked Arthur Laurents and myself to come over and talk about it. He wanted to do it in terms of contemporary slums. His idea of the slums then was the Lower East Side, with the story taking place at the coincidence of Passover and Easter. We thought it was a fine idea. I was a little worried about the ''Abie's Irish Rose'' quality. But I didn't say so at the time.

title: 'Republic of Fear': The Dynamics of a Dictatorship
description: Iraq's Saddam Hussein has become the world's most notorious bully, but when ''Republic of Fear'' was published last year by the University of California Press, few people were aware of the extremely repressive nature of his regime. And few cared, evidently; the book met with a resounding silence. The invasion of Kuwait has predictably focused attention on Iraq, and Pantheon Books has bought the paperback rights to ''Republic of Fear.'' But readers should be cautioned: while Samir al-Khalil's study of Iraqi politics is definitely required reading for anyone with a serious interest in Iraq or in the political dynamics of dictatorship, it is hardly the sensationalist account of life under Mr. Hussein implied by its title.

title: Airline Tickets
description: To the Editor: Either Continental changed its policy recently or Sally Johnson was led down the garden path by their refund department in Houston. A year ago we had plans to fly to West Palm Beach in Florida, using nonrefundable tickets purchased in February of that year. A month later my husband became quite ill and was operated on under emergency circumstances and was told by his physician that he could do no traveling for many many months. I attempted for the next six months to obtain a refund. I was sent a voucher for similar travel to be used by the end of that year. I was told that the tickets that I had purchased were nonrefundable under any circumstances. I wrote many letters and sent all kinds of documentation - to no avail.

title: Justice Requires Judges

The city may or may not be able to afford to implement the whole plan. But even though the plan is otherwise imaginative and professional, it neglects a crucial need: for more judges.

He is concerned about his mother, who recently went on a liquid diet. At 5 feet 5 inches, she has dropped to under 100 pounds. ''Mom looks like a skeleton,'' he says. title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CANDLE IN THE WIND. By George Bernau. (Warner, $19.95.) If dragging defenseless Marilyn Monroe's already tattered reputation further down in a sleazy sex novel is your idea of reading fun, then George Bernau's second novel may be for you. ''Candle in the Wind is a work of fiction,'' says the author's note. ''Although it is set in what may seem to some readers as a recognizable historical context, its characters - their actions, dialogue and motivations as portrayed by the novel - are entirely imaginary.'' Oh sure; all fiction. Marilyn, the blond sex goddess who is found near death in her Brentwood, Calif., home in August 1962, is called Marilyn Lane. The young, handsome President of the United States is John (Jack) Kerrigan. The Attorney General is his younger brother Tommy, and their Hollywood connection is their brother-in-law, the British-born, alcoholic actor Paul Townsend. It is Townsend who finds Marilyn as she lies dying of an apparent drug overdose; he hires a private eye, Frank Galvan, ostensibly to learn who might have wanted her dead. Galvan and Marilyn (who, thanks to Galvan, has miraculously survived) then set off on a global junket that involves the C.I.A., Chicago Mafiosi and the occupants of the White House, as well as a plot to overthrow the American Government - and, of course, the requisite dose of mostly gratuitous sex. Mr. Bernau, a lawyer and a former film executive, is a proponent of the smash cut; his intricate plot shifts back and forth so fast that one might as well be reading 3-by-5 cards. All this would provide harmless escapism if it were not for the book's ethical ramifications. Even writers are entitled to make a buck, but to do so by exploiting someone who was so troubled is distasteful. Those wishing to read something trenchant about Marilyn Monroe should turn instead to Simone Signoret's memoir, ''Nostalgia Isn't What It Used to Be.'' The French actress, a powerful writer, was married to the actor Yves Montand, who was for a time one of Monroe's lovers.

title: The World;   Special Relationship Reaches Its Limits
description: The acrimony between the Bush Administration and Israel over the recent United Nations resolution on Jerusalem is more than just a passing tiff. It is the culmination of nearly two years of mounting mistrust and personal animosity between leaders in both countries. Oded Eran, the deputy Israeli Ambassador to Washington who ended his tour of duty last week, put it bluntly: ''There has been a massive failure of communication, the likes of which we have not seen between Israel and the United States for a long time.''

title: 'Possession'
description: As anyone who has read her previous novels, including ''Shadow of a Sun,'' or her stories or her critical studies knows, the British writer A. S. Byatt is a gifted observer, able to discern the exact but minor details that bring whole worlds into being. ''Possession'' begins in 1986 in the Reading Room of the London Library, where Roland Mitchell - a postdoctoral research assistant at London University and the novel's hero of sorts - is rummaging through an old book that once belonged to the man he worships: Randolph Henry Ash, a famous Victorian poet and obvious stand-in for Robert Browning.

title: Miriam Halpern Is Married

Rabbi Herbert Schwartz officiated at Temple Beth El in Springfield, Mass. Mrs. Sosnick, 27 years old, is an assistant vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York. She graduated from Cornell University. Mr. Sosnick, 27, is a first vice president of Lehman Brothers in New York. He received B.S. and M.B.A. degrees from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Headliners;   Star Exit
description: Controversy marked the final days of a Cambodian dance troupe's American tour - the first since the Indochina war ended in 1975 - when five performers stayed behind. Four chose political asylum, and the other, the star dancer, Kim Devi, said she planned to become a student. The dispute centers on whether Miss Devi had wished to defect earlier, but been intimidated by the troupe's American sponsor, the U.S.-Indochina Reconciliation Project. The Immigration and Naturalization Service was also criticized, for having demanded interviews with the troupe's 36 members before anyone could leave. The agency said it had acted to prevent a repetition of a 1985 incident when a Soviet seaman seeking asylum returned home without an interview. ''Far from frightening and intimidating anybody, the U.S. Government was trying to make sure that no one was being removed from the United States involuntarily,'' an I. N. S. spokesman said.

description: Twenty-four hours after their most complete game of the season in their triumph over the Rangers, the Devils had their problems in a 4-0 loss to Washington tonight at the Capital Centre.

title: Anne Starkweather Weds Michael Karfopoulos
description: Anne Vreeland Starkweather and Michael Haritou Karfopoulos were married yesterday in the Riverside, Conn., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James O. Starkweather. Ann Isaacson, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Review/Music;   Rameau's 'Castor et Pollux,' a Rarity By BERNARD HOLLAND
description: Any performance of Jean Phillipe Rameau's famous opera ''Castor et Pollux'' is welcome, even one as dim and confused as Concert Royal's unstaged version at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night.

title: A Suffocating and Demoralized Island
description: CUBA

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Danbury Mall Spreading Retail Ripples
description: A shoppers' bonanza generated by the Danbury Fair Mall on the outskirts of Danbury is expanding, fed by a stream of seemingly recession-proof customers - some 10 million a year.

title: Creative Marketing
description: To the Editor:

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

How a Village Defines Its Character
description: LEAD: IT used to be called ''low income housing,'' but the name has been changed to ''affordable housing,'' presumably to make the thought more palatable to the occupants of the houses in the community that sell for $400,000, $500,000 and more. After all, if one spends hundreds of thousands to buy and remodel an old house or builds a new million-dollar structure, no one wants a ''modest income'' house nearby.

title: Of Belts and Bags and Baby Seats
description: My daughter picked up her first new car last Wednesday. Her name is Jonalyn, and she and I spent a lot of time in the dealer's lot trying to figure out how well the mechanized seat belts would work with the child-safety seat.

title: Rezoning to Meet Silicon Valley's Housing Needs
description: LEAD: A quarter-century ago, San Jose designated 2,900 acres in the north end as an industrial zone, excluding all other uses save for existing farms and orchards that had not yet been converted to manufacturing, a few small retail areas providing services for local businesses and three mobile-home parks, which were considered temporary.

title: Flying Blind: An Unexpected Change of Airline
description: The airline name you see on your ticket may not mean you will be flying on a plane of that line, sometimes because of a practice the airline industry calls ''code sharing.'' Code sharing does not signify much to the average traveler. But like people with hotel reservations who are ''walked,'' or sent elsewhere because of overbooking, passengers quickly learn about code sharing when they end up on another airline.

title: Accents
description: To the Editor: Why is it when articles about Hungary or Hungarians appear in your travel pages, words for names, places, foods, sights, etc., are never properly marked? Do the great printing machines of The New York Times lack the proper equipment to spell and mark foreign names correctly? Do you know that the diacritical signs and marks in Hungarian can completely change a word: var - she sews; var - castle? Why do you show the proper diacritical marks for French, German, etc., but not for Hungarian?

title: BAY PARK TO GET A SEWAGE PLANT
description: Reversing itself once again, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors agreed today to begin building a sewage sludge treatment plant in the South Shore community of Bay Park.

title: The Sound of Brazil
description: BRAZIL'S MORNING WELCOME IS PERFECT: less a greeting than an overture, more like a wake-up call for the universe. The windows and drapes of my Rio de Janeiro hotel room are useless against the percussive onslaught of a marching band gone berserk. Though this first blast of samba comes from record store loudspeakers offering the neighborhood a free sample, I am not disappointed. It's not the song of the road that's brought me to Brazil, but rather the song itself. No other country makes so compelling a case for music as an excuse to travel.

title: To the South, Another India
description: Think of India. What does the mind's eye see? The Taj Mahal, the desert fortresses of Rajasthan, the teeming ghats of Varanasi?

title: Poll Shows Weicker Maintaining Strong Lead in Race for Governor
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the former Senator campaigning as an independent, continues to hold a commanding lead over his Democratic and Republican opponents in Connecticut's gubernatorial race, a poll released today by Quinnipiac College in Hamden concludes.

title: The World;   Meshing the Parts Of the Unwieldy War Machine In the Persian Gulf
description: If talking stops and shooting starts, the first battle in a war with Iraq is likely to be coordinating the unwieldy mix of international forces in Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states.

title: 'My Son's Story'
description: Throughout her career, the South African novelist Nadine Gordimer has wanted to explore the terrain where personal interests, desires and ambitions encounter (and, not rarely, contend with) the demands and trials of a politically active life. She has had a keen eye for the exceedingly precarious moral situation of her own kind - the privileged white intelligentsia that abhors apartheid, detests the exploitation of 25 million unfranchised, economically vulnerable citizens at the hands of five million people who, so far, have had a powerful modern army at their disposal, not to mention the wealth of a vigorous, advanced capitalist society.

title: Baseball Notebook;   Only Minor Talks; 202 Teams in 3 Countries Will be Affected
description: When the World Series traveled west, from Cincinnati to Oakland, the other day, a group of men moved east to continue a process that could have a far greater impact on many more cities throughout the country than the two whose teams are in the World Series.

title: Court Bars Ex-Dictator From Guatemala Race
description: An appeals court has eliminated a former dictator, Efrain Rios Montt, from the Nov. 11 presidential election by issuing a final ruling that his past activities disqualified him.

title: The Locker Room Revisted ... Again
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Nation;   This Year's Campaign Menu Of Venom and Platitudes
description: Nobody claims that 30-second television commercials can tell a voter much about a candidate, but if you watch enough of them, you can glimpse what this season's candidates or their consultants think about the voters. The opinion cannot be high.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Jesse Jackson Courts the Viewer/Voter
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the once and probably future Presidential aspirant who has lately taken up journalism, has quickly climbed the heights of the profession. Since the last Sunday in September, he has presided over a syndicated hour program called, yes, ''Jesse Jackson.'' The title is accurate. Mr. Jackson narrates the documentary passages, leads the panel discussions, puts questions to members of the studio audience and occasionally addresses the television camera, for instance, when announcing a pause for a commercial. He does not personally deliver the commercials for products, but causes are another matter. In New York, at 9 P.M. on Channel 11, the program finds itself up against Fox's popular ''Married . . . With Children'' and has not been doing nearly as well as Mr. Jackson did in the 1988 primaries.

title: Campus Life: Keene State;   Soccer Victory Doesn't Dampen Exchange Plans
description: The Keene State College Owls did not prove the best of hosts as they beat a visiting soccer team from the Soviet Union, 4 to 1, last week.

title: Is God a Man?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Women Wouldn't Dance With Her
description: DON JUAN IN THE VILLAGE

title:
Your Own Account;

Group Policies, Long-Term Care
description: LEAD: At a time when employers are cutting benefits and shifting more of benefit costs to employees, progressive companies are trying to offer something that might appeal to workers. This year, more have chosen long-term care policies for employees, their spouses and their parents.

title: Privacy in the Age of Information
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse Trounces Rutgers
description: Syracuse, still smarting from a 6-point loss to Penn State last week, catapulted back on the winning track this afternoon and used hapless Rutgers as its launching pad. The Orange scored three touchdowns in the first half, added three more in the second and crushed Rutgers 42-0.

title: Lisa W. Fuller Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Fuller of Rochester have announced December wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Wilcox Fuller and Peter Hargrave Sykes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Sykes of Rochester.

title: LOON OVER MIAMI
description: I enjoyed Peter Richmond's much too revealing article ''Loon Over Miami'' about humorist Dave Barry (Sept. 23). I read his column every Sunday in The Tulsa World. I was surprised Hunter Thompson wasn't mentioned as a possible influence on Barry. When it comes to illuminating human folly by means of animal scatology, H. T. has no peer. A former rock-and-roller like Dave Barry must have read Thompson's depraved scribblings in Rolling Stone in the early 1970's.

title: Corrections
description: The gazetteer accompanying an article on Todt Hill on Oct. 14 misstated the Staten Island neighborhood's distance from midtown Manhattan and the cost of the ferry between St. George and the Battery. The distance is 12 miles. The ferry ride costs 50 cents from the Battery to Staten Island and is free the other way.

title: 27 Artists Apply Their Talents to Home Furnishings
description: LEAD: IN the show called ''Decorative Concept II'' at the Elements, a crafts gallery in Greenwich housed in a livery stable, the works of 27 artists focus on contemporary accessories. Screens, rugs, mirrors, tables, chairs and lamps, one of a kind or of limited edition, suggest adding color, pattern, tongue-in-cheek whimsy and otherwise imbuing an environment with personal identity.

title: An Accolade for Hattie McDaniel
description: ''GIRL, don't you know actresses are beautiful and white?'' was what young Hattie's friends told her when she voiced her dream of going on stage.

title: The Generals Who Brought Dixie Down
description: MEMOIRS AND SELECTED LETTERS

title: J's Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Manager of Troubled Arms Plant Is Removed
description: The manager of the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant has been replaced amid revelations about management failures and employees' charges that managers are risking unsafe conditions in a rush to restart the plant.

title: Airline Tickets
description: To the Editor: Regarding airline refund policies in cases of personal emergency (Practical Traveler, Aug. 12): based on my experience with Trans World Airlines, it appears that Sally Johnson's information was incorrect.

title: Burmese Forces in Mandalay Ring Buddhist Monasteries
description: Burmese soldiers today cordoned off monasteries in Mandalay, the country's second-largest city, after the military Government threatened to disband Buddhist groups whose members are refusing to minister to soldiers.

title: Can 50 Million Frenchmen Be Wrong?
description: In France, he is famous. his name is pronounced reverently, much the same way that Peter Sellers's Inspector Clouseau said ''room,'' which is to say with trilled consonants, rich vowel sounds and extended gurgling. ''Rrrheurque.'' ''Rghoorque.'' Rourke.

title:
PERFECT EVENINGS;

FROM A BEACH TO A JAZZ CLUB
description: LEAD: HOW TO SPEND A perfect evening in Chicago? I would start by donning an old pair of blue jeans and walking through the sand of Oak Street Beach, the wide swath of Lake Michigan waterfront closest to downtown, not far from the John Hancock building. I have always marveled that there could be a beach smack in the middle of a city.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 21, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Signet, $5.95.) A writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, who then goes on a rampage. 2 1 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family. 3 3 CALIFORNIA GOLD, by John Jakes. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A young man from Pennsylvania makes his fortune in 19th-century California. 4 47 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $5.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 5 3 THE MINOTAUR, by Stephen Coonts. (Dell, $5.95.) title: BUSH TERMED OPEN TO TAX RATE RISE ON UPPER INCOME
description: In a break that could lead to a compromise in the budget negotiations, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has told lawmakers that President Bush could accept an increase in the tax rate for the wealthy to 31 percent from 28 percent now, staff assistants from both parties said today.

title: Can a Tarnished Northrop Regain Its Momentum?
description: Perhaps more than any other military contractor, the Northrop Corporation during the 1980's embodied both the accomplishments and the excesses of the nation's arms buildup. It grew rapidly and made stunning technological breakthroughs, but it also sank with distressing regularity into procurement scandals.

title: Miss Cuttita Wed To Dr. Mark Lee
description: Regina Marie Cuttita and Dr. Mark R. Lee were married yesterday at the Sacred Hearts Roman Catholic Church in New York by Msgr. Guy Vinci.

title: Headliners;   Decent Burial
description: ''We will bury you,'' Nikita Khrushchev warned the United States, back in the days when it still seemed that Communism had a fighting chance. Last week his son, Sergei Khrushchev, took back the threat. ''He proved to be wrong in the sense that socialism would triumph over capitalism,'' he said on a visit to Kansas with a delegation of 290 people from the Soviet Union. In fact, the weeklong series of ''people to people'' conferences on economics, science, trade and the environment could hardly have been friendlier. The visitors were honored at a football game and entertained in nearly 150 homes. The Lawrence Daily Journal-World provided a daily column of news from Tass, the Soviet press agency. At the opening assembly on Monday, it was announced that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had won the Nobel Peace Prize. The audience reacted at first with stunned silence, then a round of applause from both the Kansans and the guests who once counted each other as enemies.

title: Mutual Funds;   The Lure of Single-State Munis
description: As budget talks intensify in Washington, investors are diving for cover. But they don't have to stray far from home. The prospect of higher taxes has given new luster to single-state municipal bond funds, which invest in debt issued by a state, its municipalities or agencies.

title: Little Berries Are Big Business No Longer
description: LEAD: THE rich red of a ripening cranberry bog was once a common element of Connecticut's multicolored autumn patchwork. But all that remains of the state's extensive commercial cranberry bogs are three acres off Pond Meadow Road, in Killingworth. And a 20-acre patch of bright crimson in Portland is being preserved by volunteers from the Mettabeseck Chapter of the National Audubon

title: 'Syndrome' Hits the A's
description: A slump in the World Series never seems to go away.

title: The Executive Computer;   A Notebook That Can Provide Desktop Power
description: Reinforcing its reputation as the personal computer industry's technolog leader, the Compaq Computer Corporation has become the first company to fit the full power of a desktop PC into a laptop small enough to carry in a briefcase. In doing so, Compaq has come close to creating a single computer that can meet the needs of an executive both in the office and on the road.

title: Educating Children Without the 'Trip'
description: In ''Beowulf, Get Off the Sofa,'' (Opinion page, Sept. 9), a mother is surprised that her 9-year-old ''knows'' who Michelangelo is. Closer questioning reveals that he equates the name of one of the world's greatest artists, a sculptor, architect and poet, with a violent cartoon character.

title: Style Makers;   Judy Dearing, Costume Designer
description: She started her career onstage, dancing with Miriam Makeba and acting with The Negro Ensemble Company, but she now works behind the scenes as a costume designer. On stage and off, it was her style that first brought her notice. Ms. Dearing made her own dance costumes and many of her own clothes, a skill she learned as a child.

title: Fashion;   Sizing Up Giorgio Armani
description: Giorgio Armani is used to adulation - some would say he even thrives on it. But at the moment, he has had enough. ''I have never placed myself on a pedestal,'' he says with a finality that shears the morning mist.

title: Pound Ridge Rejects Fire Substation
description: LEAD: THE request by the Pound Ridge volunteer fire department to build a substation in a central area of town has been turned down by the Town Board.

title: A Pragmatic Idealist
description: THE COLONEL

title: Chopin Piano Jury Withholds First Prize; American Wins 2d
description: For the first time in the 63-year history of the prestigious Chopin piano competition, the jury has refused to award a first prize.

title: Thousands March in 16 Cities to Protest U.S. Intervention in Gulf
description: Thousands of people rallied in New York and 15 other American cities yesterday to protest the United States' military buildup in the Persian Gulf. It was the largest demonstration against the American presence in the gulf since President Bush first sent troops after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

title: David S. Mitchell Wed To Robin Leslie Karpf
description: Robin Leslie Karpf, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Karpf of Palm Beach, Fla., and Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening to David S. Mitchell, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Mitchell of New York. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in New York.

title: Is NC-17 an X in a Clean Raincoat
description: Picture the person in the trenchcoat, the one staring furtively at the marquee. The film he wants to see has been advertised as ''completely uncut in its original version,'' and he likes the way that sounds. So he sidles up to the box office, and he is preparing to buy a ticket when he spies something that rattles his composure. There it is: ''Henry and June'' is rated NC-17. It's not the X-rated film he expected. He changes his mind and skulks home.

title: Bronx Man Accused of False Suit in Bus Crash
description: A man from the Bronx has been charged with bilking the Transit Authority out of $25,000 for injuries he said were from a bus accident. Officials said he had only heard about the crash.

title: Review/Music;   Catherine Comet Conducts Mixed Bill
description: Catherine Comet opened the American Symphony Orchestra's 28th season - and her own first season as its music director - with a showy program that glanced back at the orchestra's history and put its current strengths fully on display. The concert at Carnegie Hall last Sunday afternoon was a fairly international affair, with works by American, French, German and Soviet composers.

title: Hunting Foes Charge Threats
description: A hunter Saturday morning fired three shots over the head of a woman, Klara Lucas, taking part in a group hunting protest at Darien Lake State Park, and he threatened to shoot her and to strike another demonstrator, the protesters said.

title: Where Londoners Seek Out Quality
description: Most shopping enclaves depend on passing trade. But Chiltern Street, off Marylebone Road and parallel to Baker Street, in London's West End, relies instead on its high-quality factor. Built at the turn of the century, the small Victorian shops that line the street retain a village atmosphere. Most have new picture windows and, between each of them, fluted, mock-Corinthian columns make curious dividers. Above are three stories of red-brick apartments whose drainpipes begin at the roof in the mouths of benign gargoyle heads made of ceramics.

title: Encouraging Prenatal Care With Gift Certificates
description: IN an area where infant mortality rates rank among the highest in the nation, an unusual program called Partners in Care is attempting to attract pregnant women to visit health clinics by offering gift certificates.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

Kings, Queens and Knights to Remember
description: LEAD: It has been almost 20 years since Bobby Fischer beat Boris Spassky, and 83 years since a world championship chess match has been contested on American soil (Lasker-Marshall, 1907). With the first half of the latest Kasparov-Karpov title match now taking place in New York (the venue for the second half is Lyons, France), chess is enjoying another day in the American sun - a perfect occasion for welcoming a modern history of this ancient game.

title:
DINING OUT;

Seasonal Ingredients Star in Eastchester
description: LEAD: PINOCCHIO has long been one of our favorite restaurants and, the plainness of the dining rooms notwithstanding, misses having a higher rating for only a very few flaws. Diners avoiding them can have an ''excellent'' if not memorable meal here. The high cost of fresh, seasonal ingredients, in particular the frequent and generous use of wild mushrooms, is reflected in the prices.

title: Campus Life: Bard;   Students Practice Language Skills In New Tutorials
description: Although Kiersten Sigurski's political science professor does not speak German, Miss Sigurski is reading her assignments on Marx in the original German and receiving academic credit for it.

title: Two in Tune in 'Tune in Tomorrow'
description: ''Tune in Tomorrow'' is a dervish of a film, its maddest doings designed by a radio writer who baits Albanians, impersonates a Hasid and stirs soap operas within soap operas with his roman a clef brand of audio theater.

title: Yet Another Incarnation for a Versatile Tax Credit: Child Care Aid
description: Embedded in the huge budget packages that have passed the House and Senate is a secret weapon that lawmakers have used for 15 years to give working poor people an income supplement intended to help them improve their economic state and stay off welfare.

title: Bush: No Mo Big Mo
description: No matter what kind of Federal budget finally comes out of the unseemly scramble that has so demeaned Congress and the White House in recent weeks, a long-suffering public is more likely to remember the process than the product. Seldom, if ever, has Washington looked more self-serving and less effective.

title: Headboard Flap Recalls La Guardia's 'Beaut'
description: To the Editor:

title: And Now a Blast From the Past: Stagflation!
description: Pornography, like beauty, may be in the eye of the beholder. If so, what is happening to the Federal deficit is patently obscene, says Mark L. Melcher, the director of Washington research for Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: Maria Rocco Is Wed To Zachary Lazarus
description: Maria Elena Rocco, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rocco of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Zachary Lazarus, the son of Judge Robert J. Lazarus of New York and the late Nona G. Lazarus. Rabbi Mordechi Genn and the Rev. Dennis Kean, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Blessed Sacrament Church in New Rochelle.

title: When Hutton Talked, Checks Bounced
description: LEAD:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: The World;   Arabs Ponder Ways To Fix Arab Problems
description: While most of the world is trying just to muddle through the crisis in the Persian Gulf, a few Arab thinkers - some would say dreamers - have begun drafting proposals to meet the widespread yearning of poorer Arabs in this undemocratic and inegalitarian region for greater democracy and a more equitable distribution of wealth.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: Dr. Henry C. Allen;

That Annual Cold May Be an Allergy
description: LEAD: FALL is the prime season for pollen allergies and cold viruses, but many sufferers may be incorrectly diagnosing and treating their ailments, says Dr. Henry C. Allen, a family practitioner in New Milford.

title: The View From: Bluff Point State Park, in Groton;   If Deer Are Killing Plants, Should Hunters Kill the Deer?
description: AS Connecticut's deer population continues to grow, new areas are being opened to hunting at a rapid rate. Nowhere is the debate over this policy more intense than at Bluff Point State Park, in Groton.

title: Lawmakers Agree on Immigration Rise
description: Congressional negotiators will meet early next week to work out final details of a bill that would allow a substantial increase in legal immigration to the United States.

title: Kathryn Gutwillig Is Wed
description: Kathryn Jean Gutwillig, 26 years old, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Gutwillig of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Michael Nick Sandler, 28, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack L. Sandler of Rockville, Md. Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum officiated at the Tamarack Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. Mrs. Sandler is a graduate of George Washington University. She is an electronic production supervisor for the Hearst Corporation in New York. Mr. Sandler is an assistant vice president of Ruesch International, a currency and precious metalstrading concern in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 7 about the play ''The Miser'' included a publicity agent's misidentification of the actor shown with Mia Dillon. He was Thomas Gibson, not Christian Baskous.

title: Martha Graham: Up to Her New Tricks
description: Martha Graham continues to be Martha Graham. She surprised us all with ''Maple Leaf Rag,'' a self-mocking humorous premiere in her company's unusually brief season at the City Center this month.

title: A Prophet Ultimately Honored
description: Leonard Bernstein's death brought into focus one of the many oddities and ironies of his career: he was the quintessential American cultural icon of this century and at the same time a musician who would have been completely at home in the high Romantic age. Like his idol Mahler, who outlived the 19th century but remained in the grip of the era's obsession with love and death, Mr. Bernstein dramatized his entire life in neo-Wagnerian Romantic terms. For both men, the most appropriate funeral music might be the ''Liebestod.'' Mahler made clear in the privacy of his scores his sickness unto death; Mr. Bernstein, less creative but just as driven by the confessional urge, invited the whole world to share his joys and sorrows.

title: Class Finding It Pays to Be Handy
description: LEAD: ONCE again, with homeowners weary of paying contractors, the ''Be Your Own Handyman'' class offered by Ridgewood's Community School has a waiting list.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

The Symbols That Substitute For Faith
description: LEAD: MOST of us in the course of our lives won't escape from a sudden shattering of the image of our own immortality. When it happens, sooner or later, the jagged pieces of ice-cold glass lie around our feet and create a paralysis that keeps us fixed to the spot, shaken, staring down into the distorted reflections of our former selves: our eyes, our limbs, our torsos, splintered; no longer whole, no longer ours.

title: The Danger of Short-Term Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;

A Historic Setting That's Full of Charm
description: LEAD: IT'S totally unexpected, after driving along a scruffy stretch of service road off the West Shore Expressway on Staten Island, to pass through the latticed gateway at Burke's Landing. You pull into what could pass for a tiny 18th-century settlement in New England with a gracious, two-story Greek Revival house as its centerpiece, complete with white picket fence.

title: Segregation Won't Work
description: LEAD: It is reported that the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, is considering the ''Milwaukee plan,'' which would put black boys in separate schools emphasizing African and African-American rather than European culture. My opinion may not be entirely irrelevant: I am a professor of European history, I am black, and

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Lindsley Raines Plans a Wedding
description: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John Curtis Raines of Philadelphia have announced December wedding plans for their daughter, Lindsley Anne Raines, and Dr. Steven Craig Linn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Linn of Madison, Conn.

title: Pro Hockey;   Islanders Fall to 1-4-3 Sabres
description: Rick Dudley, in his second season with the Buffalo Sabres, is the only coach in the National Hockey League who wears a beard.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Durability Down Through the Decades
description: LEAD: THE day I signed the contract on our new fence, my friend sent me a letter: ''Meg, I'm getting married for a second time after a horrendous first. What are my chances for happiness?''

title: Germans to Shut 5 Atom Plants Built by Soviets
description: The German Government has informed Soviet officials that it will shut down five Soviet-built nuclear power reactors in former East Germany by mid-December because they are unsafe and the cost of adapting them is prohibitive.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Fiove Landscape Plants That Will Make A Difference
description: LEAD: Gardeners like to invest in and grow choice plants. And one reason certain plants are not selected is that people do not know about them.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. JOHN E. HUTCHINSON 3D;

15,000 Heart Surgeries and Counting
description: LEAD: DR. JOHN E. HUTCHINSON 3d believes that open heart surgery has gone from the miraculous to the routine in the last two decades. He has performed more than 15,000 open heart operations, about three-quarters of them bypasses and the rest surgeries on diseased valves.

title: Budapest Winter's Tale
description: IT IS DECEMBER; THE SNOW IS indistinguishable from the fog. Cocooned in white swirling mists (bone-chilling; delicious to the lips), one sees Budapest -as through an occluded mirror, dimly - as a city of water. The sky is heavy with water; the Danube, which divides the city in two, is, while shrouded in metallic fog, always present to the senses, and the bridges that span it, from the hills of residential Buda on the right bank to flat commercial Pest on the left, daily claim one's gratified attention. One is subliminally aware of the thermal springs, 123 of them, that nourish Budapest's spas and give this east-west city a dreamy water life, democratically offering the soporific warmth of healing waters to all. Even the art nouveau and Secessionist - Viennese art nouveau - architecture of Hungary's capital, sinuous and curling, is like arrested liquid.

title: The Truth Behind the Mideast's 'Great Lie';   Israel, Look Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Economy Tightens, Towns' Tax-Collection Rates Fall
description: LEAD: A FALTERING economy has dropped municipal tax collections below expectations, and local officials say they are pushing property owners to pay delinquent tax bills. Tax collectors report that the real-estate slump, bankruptcies, business cash-flow problems and unemployment are being felt by municipal treasuries throughout

title: Campus Life: Swarthmore;   'Virus Free Week' Combats Spread Of Disk Disease
description: Swarthmore College held a Virus Free Week last week, but it had nothing to do with medicine. Instead students and faculty and staff members were invited to have their computer disks checked for contamination.

title: 'Spy Sinker'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater;   Of Convicts, the Stage and Australia's Beginnings
description: Timberlake Wertenbaker's ''Our Country's Good'' is an enlightening exploration of the inhumanity of the penal system in New South Wales, the British colony that became Australia. Ms. Wertenbaker's drama is now running at Hartford Stage in a perceptive production directed by Mark Lamos.

title: Correction
description: A report on the Business Diary page last Sunday referred incorrectly to the quarterly dividend at the Travelers Corporation. Travelers recently announced a cut in its dividend to 40 cents a share from 60, but did not eliminate it.

title: INSIDE
description: New U.N. Move on Iraq

title: A Georgia Island, Mostly Wild
description: In 1566, when the Spanish first dropped anchor off Cumberland Island, they found themselves in a place of almost primordial beauty. Broad white-sand beaches and fecund salt marshes of an impossible green ringed a dense forest of live oak. The island's salt-water sloughs and freshwater lakes supported hundreds of species of migratory birds and the inner forest was home to mink, bobcats, deer, armadillos and a small group of peace-loving Indians known as the Timucua.

title: The Elderly Should Pay Their Share
description: I was angry to read the article ''Elderly Worry About School Tax Revisions'' (Sept. 9). It quotes Warren Heide of the American Association of Retired Persons, who agrees with the basic premise of the Quality Education Act of 1990 but does not think the elderly should pay for it.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LIGHT CAN BE BOTH WAVE AND PARTICLE, by Ellen Gilchrist. (Little, Brown, $8.95.) In the title piece of this collection of short stories, a Chinese geneticist vacationing in Seattle falls in love with a teacher from Fayetteville, Ark. Last year our reviewer, Roy Hoffman, said the story ''bristles with new energy. . . . It brings together lovers from different cultures more spiritedly than any past Gilchrist story.''

title: Wall Street;   Why Trading Volume Is Up in Germany and Britain
description: London may be making good on its threat to become the European Community's dominant stock market. Numbers compiled last week by David Strongin, director of international finance at the Securities Industry Association, show that trading in foreign stocks is accounting for a sharply higher share of London's volume.

title: Israel
description: To the Editor: The chances of being mugged in Israel are slight, but there are other ways to relieve the unsuspecting tourist of his money. A friend and I were in the Old City of Jerusalem recently when she realized she needed Israeli currency. Signs proclaimed money changers, and we went into one near the Jaffa Gate. It was an Arab curio shop with a table in the rear.

title: Why Cole Porter Prevails - Be It Pop, Rock or Even Rap
description: Cole Porter's ''I've Got You Under My Skin'' has been recorded by scores of singers over the years, but the song, which was first heard in the 1936 movie musical ''Born to Dance,'' has never sounded anything like the new hip-hop interpretation by Neneh Cherry.

title: Control of the Ballot Box: For Parties or the Public?
description: Beyond the waste of money and appearance of unfairness, the machine politics and patronage of New York City's election system limit the ability of people to vote and the range of choices before them at a time of broad political evolution in the city.

title: Catherine L. Hogan Weds
description: At St. Mary Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Beverly, Mass., Catherine Lycett Hogan was married yesterday to Robert Revane Dutile. The Rev. Stephen Connor officiated. Mrs. Dutile, 32 years old, is the daughter of Helene Lycett Hogan-Speck of Montpelier, Vt., and the late William Hogan. A graduate of Amherst College, she is studying for a master's degree in screenwriting at the University of California at Los Angeles. Mr. Dutile, 32, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Dutile of Billerica, Mass. A graduate of Boston College, he is a freelance wilderness emergency paramedic.

title: Skyscrapers Battle It Out Near Carnegie Hall
description: Nothing is more outrageous - or more characteristic of New York - than the clash of new skyscrapers near the southeast corner of 57th Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan. Three huge towers rise together, two of them so close they almost touch, and each represents an entirely different set of beliefs about what urban architecture should be.

title: Ex-Premier Seeks Freeing of British Captives
description: Former Prime Minister Edward Heath of Britain today attempted to make progress toward securing the release of sick or dying Britons trapped in Iraq.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: SOUNDINGS;

Scaling Strauss's 'Alpine' Peak
description: LEAD: Among the many orchestral works by Richard Strauss, the ''Alpine'' Symphony of 1915 was long regarded as something of a black sheep. This portrait in music of the ascent and descent of a mountain in a single day used to be considered an elephantine score of orchestral brilliance but little substance.

title: The World;   Gorbachev Counsels A Prudent Revolution
description: Had Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented his latest economic reform plan a year ago, Western analysts say, it would have been hailed as a daring commitment to free markets, private property and fiscal federalism. Today, with the Soviet economy in free fall and a half-dozen of the 15 republican governments in open revolt, the new plan is being widely derided as a scheme for saving the bureaucrats and party hacks who led the economy to ruin.

title: Maillol's 'Ultimate Muse' Builds Him a Museum
description: Toward the end of his life, the French artist Aristide Maillol became so discouraged by his waning strength that he was considering abandoning sculpture, when a friend claimed to have found him the perfect model. Always in quest of the ideal female form in his art, and thus the ultimate muse, Maillol wrote to the young Parisienne. ''I am told that you resemble a Maillol and a Renoir,'' he said. ''I would be satisfied with a Renoir.''

title: An Economist Kicks the Clouds Away
description: Most economists, looking at the future, are gloomy right now. Not so Mark A. Miles, executive vice president and senior economist at H. C. Wainwright Economics, a consulting firm in Boston. In a conversation with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times, Mr. Miles, who has a doctorate in economics from the University of Chicago, outlined his forecast for strong growth in 1991.

title: Comparison Shopping: Which Costs the Environment Less?
description: AS guided tours go, this is an unusual one. One of the first stops is the aisle of peanut butter jars, comparing the merits of Smuckers to those of Skippy. But participants are not in the grocery store for a taste test: what is being judged here is the use of glass versus plastic packaging. This is an environmental shopping tour.

title: Picture Book Offers Help for Bed-wetters
description: LEAD: CHRISTOPHER, a top competitor in karate, has been invited by his teacher to attend karate camp. Although he wants very much to go, Christopher knows that, as things stand, he cannot.

title: One Good Laugh That Deserves Another
description: Normally, I don't keep track of protracted laughs in the theater, but the production of ''The Miser'' at the Circle in the Square provokes so few that I feel fairly safe in giving you my personal count.

title: Salvadoran Officials Criticize U.S. Aid Vote
description: Military commanders and Government officials here say the United States Senate's decision to halve military aid to El Salvador will harm the army's morale and effectiveness against leftist rebels.

title: Volunteer Lawyers Visit the Elderly As Interest in Living Wills Grows
description: LEAD: EVERY few months, about 200 elderly people gather at the Milford Senior Center and talk about the end of their lives.

title: Shaky in Cleveland?
description: As the coach of a team with a 2-4 record, Bud Carson of the Cleveland Browns would seem to have good reason to worry about his job as his team prepares to play the Cincinnati Bengals (4-2) in Cleveland tomorrow night.

title: Jordanian Economy Devastated by Effects of the Gulf Crisis
description: The port of Aqaba is still. Tourism, which brought in more than half a billion dollars last year, has evaporated. Fruit and vegetables intended for export are rotting at the border.

title: Laurie Kohn Weds J. B. Parkinson Jr.
description: Laura Beth Kohn and John Briggs Parkinson Jr. were married last evening at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Cantor Raymond Smolover.

title: The Dynamics of a Dictatorship
description: REPUBLIC OF FEAR

title: Subway Samaritans Came to Woman's Aid (at Least at First)
description: It was a case of good samaritans versus bad samaritans. The bad samaritans won.

title: Some Loudspeakers Reward the Bargain Hunter
description: In the present economic climate, budget crunching has become a favorite exercise wherever you look. Audio is no exception. These days, even formerly profligate audiophiles wonder how to shave costs without cutting quality - or, as one of them puts it, to be frugal without being stingy.

title: Its Uneven Nature Lends Drama to Show of Russian Works
description: ONE often runs across exhibitions that are uneven, but rarely does one find a show that has unevenness built into the drama of the subject. ''The Russian Experiment,'' the title of the current show at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle, embodies that exhibition's volatile character.

title: Joel McCrea, Actor, Dies at 84; A Casual, Amiable Leading Man
description: Joel McCrea, a tall, trim, ruggedly handsome actor who radiated a casual, amiable image in 80 movies, many of them westerns, died yesterday of pulmonary complications at the Motion Picture and Television Fund Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: Commercial Property: Upper Madison Avenue;   Three Modest Projects for the 'Best Street in the City'
description: Contrary to the growing quiet in real estate development, upper Madison Avenue may actually undergo a kind of building boomlet in coming months, with three projects approved for construction from 64th to 72d Street.

title: Where A World Ended
description: SANTORINI IS A COLOSSAL, BACKWARD letter C set in the Aegean. The island's black-brown-red cliffs are both gorgeous and eerie-sublime. Thera, the capital city, is ensconced like bright milk teeth on a giant mandible. But beauty defers here. While we stood 1,100 feet up mid-C, a stupendous notion had been forming itself in my mind: it formed gradually because it was beyond the proportions of human sense and belief. That letter C, I said to myself - that letter C enclosing a 57-square-mile bay . . . That letter C, in which huge double-funneled ferryboats seem built for bathtub play . . . That C - large enough to hold one full thunderstorm and both Nea Kameni and Palea Kameni islands . . . ''That C,'' I said finally aloud, ''IS A VOLCANO.'' And this volcano transformed Western civilization. For, somewhere in the second millennium B.C., Santorini - also known as Thera - simply blew apart. Half the island disappeared, leaving a vague, giant circle made up of Santorini and two outlying islets, Therasia and Aspronisi. One of the most powerful volcanic explosions in modern times was the 1883 eruption of Krakatoa in the Sunda Strait near Java. It displaced five cubic miles of rock fragments and sent at least one tsunami across to nearby Java. Day became night for 130 miles. Thirty-six thousand people died. Krakatoa was bought for a major motion picture. Yet Thera's crater is more than twice the size of Krakatoa's. And the tsunami generated by Thera was by some estimates as much as 100 feet high when it hit Crete broadside one hour later. Crete is more than 60 miles away.

title: Breaking Away From the Cult
description: FINAL ANALYSIS

title: Industry Prods Schools On Educating Students
description: GROWING concern that Long Island students are graduating from high school without the necessary skills to enter the work force is prompting educators and business leaders to look at what schools are doing and should be doing to better prepare their students, and how the schools and the business community can work together on the problem.

title: IN ATLANTA, THE BEST IS FREE
description: IN ATLANTA, FOR ALL ITS brassy status as the consumption capital of the New South, the nicest thing to do is free. My idea of a perfect evening begins with a drive at dusk around the gloriously lush neighborhoods, shrouded in oak and pine, magnolia and dogwood, crab apple and hickory, that snake off Peachtree Street, Northside Drive or West Paces Ferry Road. ''Gone With the Wind'' notwithstanding, Atlanta has about as much to do with the Old South as with the Ukraine, but it's always nice to remember that surrounding the city's manic, entrepreneurial bustle is a green, steamy natural world that could have been Faulkner's.

title: Restrained Corporate Political Speech
description: In one of last summer's Supreme Court decision - Austin v. Michigan Chamber of Commerce - the Court upheld a Michigan law prohibiting corporations from using their treasury funds for independent expenditures to advance or oppose political candidates. The case involved an attempt by the Michigan Chamber of Commerce to place a local newspaper advertisement in support of a candidate for state office. The Court held that corporations can engage in political speech only if they use segregated funds, voluntarily collected through such mechanisms as political action committees that accurately reflect the contributors' support for the corporation's political views.

title: Editors' Notes
description: An article in the Business section last Sunday described the recent performance of major automobile rental companies. It said the industry leader, Hertz, had lost market share and had been troubled by debt and computer problems. A major source of the information was an analyst of the car rental industry at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., a Baltimore brokerage; the comments should have been attributed.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Keep up with raking. Pile leaves for compost, but do not forget to sandwich layers of soil for microorganisms and a dash of fertilizer for nutrients; if the old compost pile has not been used up, it can be added to start the new one. Bulb planting goes on. Finish shrub planting and perennial dividing.

title: Pact Limits Timber Cutting in Alaska Forest
description: House and Senate negotiators have reached a compromise on a bill to protect an additional one million acres in the Tongass National Forest in Alaska from timber cutting.

title: The President: Read His Slips
description: Most Presidents run into unavoidable trouble by the time they reach midterm, but George Bush is different. Many of his troubles were not only avoidable but predictable, and this has hurt him because they raise questions about his judgment.

title: The Recorded Legacy
description: The recordings of Leonard Bernstein (at right, in a photograph taken earlier this year in his apartment) divide into two parts: those of his own music and those conducting the music of others. His recordings of the music of others fall into two periods: records made primarily for CBS Masterworks in the late 1950's and the 1960's during his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic, and subsequently remastered for compact disk, and those made in his maturity, mostly for Deutsche Grammophon.

title: Steinbrenner Lampoons the Boss
description: For someone who has often roamed beyond his more familiar surroundings, George Steinbrenner seemed right at home preparing to be the guest host of last night's ''Saturday Night Live'' on NBC.

title: Ideas & Trends;   A Critique of Pure Reason, A Passion To Survive
description: Suppose you are dying of AIDS and there is only one drug that you believe can help prolong your life. But this drug is still experimental, and the only way to get it is to enter a clinical trial, a formal study to determine whether a new treatment works. To make matters worse, you do not qualify for the study because you have already taken another drug that did not help you, but that might throw the test of the new drug out of kilter. Should you lie or ask your doctor to help you get into the trial by falsifying your records?

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this section on Oct. 7 misidentified the designer of the Auditorium Theater in Chicago. The architect was Louis Sullivan, not Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: Vowing to Veto Rights Bill, President Offers Alternative
description: President Bush said tonight that he would veto a major anti-discrimination bill on Monday, but he offered Congress an alternative measure that he said would avoid quotas and limit damage awards to victims of bias.

title: Bag With Body Parts Found Near a Parkway in Brooklyn
description: A large green plastic garbage bag containing a torso and body parts was discovered yesterday evening in the weeds alongside the Belt Parkway near Starrett City in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Lost Colony on Sakhalin Strives for New Dignity
description: Representatives of a forgotten colony of Korean slave laborers who were abandoned by the Japanese Army here on the Soviet island of Sakhalin 45 years ago have finally managed to journey out and confront long-grieving relatives in Korea and the Japanese conscience in Tokyo.

title: Rebecca Ascher to Wed C. J. Walsh
description: Rebecca Kathryn Ascher, a writer, and Charles James Walsh, a teacher, plan to marry in December. Ms. Ascher is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Ascher of New York. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Walsh of Pittsburgh.

title: Sarah Adams to Wed James F. Agnew 3d
description: December wedding plans for Sarah Goodhue Adams and James Franklin Agnew 3d, the son of Capt. Agnew 2d, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Agnew of La Jolla, Calif., have been announced by the prospective bride's father, Bruce C. Adams of Dataw Island, S.C.

title: Poor Nations Worried by U.S. Payout in Gulf
description: A plan by the United States to use about half of the roughly $22 billion it hopes to raise toward the costs of the Persian Gulf crisis to pay for American military operations there is causing increasing concern among developing countries and aid experts, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

title: Ada Amy Kolko Is Wed
description: Ada Amy Kolko, a social worker for the Jewish Big Brother and Big Sister Association of Greater Boston, and Michael David Chartock, an associate in the Boston law firm of Hutchins & Wheeler, were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Rochester. Rabbi Shamai Kanter officiated. Mrs. Chartock, 26 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mordecai Kolko of Rochester. She graduated from Brandeis University, as did Mr. Chartock, and received a master's degree in social work from Columbia University. Mr. Chartock, 27, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Chartock of Cincinnati. He received a law degree from Cornell University.

title: Hearty Dishes With Teutonic Flavor
description: IN the ethnic restaurant revolution that has hit Connecticut in the past 5 to 10 years, Asia has been the driving force, with new Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai and Indian restaurants at the forefront. Europe, except for France and Italy, has had short shrift. That makes the opening, earlier this year, of Restaurant Vienna, in New Milford, something special. It is in a high-ceilinged storefront that has been home to several other restaurants in recent years. Welcome touches include well-spaced tables, soft lighting and tapes of classical music played softly in the background. There is scant evidence of Vienna or Austria in the decor, save for a travel poster near the bar in the rear and a few decorative nutcracker soldiers.

title: 3 to Stop Racist Talks In 'Mister Rogers' Tone
description: Three men have agreed to destroy recordings of racist and anti-gay telephone messages that imitated the voice and speech of ''Mister Rogers'' from the children's television program.

title: Ecologists' Foe to Become Amazon Governor
description: Hoisting the banner of an Amazonian backlash against ecologists, Gilberto Mestrinho likes to boast, ''I wasn't elected by the trees.''

title: The Truth Behind the Mideast's 'Great Lie';   Let's Not Pretend . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Cabaret;   Julie Wilson's Melodious Glamour
description: One of the happiest blendings of a performer and a setting took place on Tuesday evening at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza), where Julie Wilson, who had not played there before, opened a three-week engagement. Now 66 years old, the singer may be the ultimate embodiment of a kind of sophisticated glamour that has all but disappeared from New York City nightlife. And to see this most theatrical of performers, reed-thin in a clinging red sequined dress, emote against the panorama of upper Manhattan, one could imagine for a moment that that world was still very vital.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

That's Entertainment: A Guide for the Guilty
description: LEAD: WE are heading into the autumn entertaining season, which, for women ages 35 to 62, is the leading cause of death by aggravation.

title: A TOUCH OF THE TROPICS IN PARIS
description: TO LIVE IN PARIS IS already a privilege. To plan a perfect evening in this gastronomical paradise seems almost self-indulgent. Yet to eat well in this city is no challenge, so my thoughts turn instead to music. There is ballet at the Palais Garnier and choral music at the church of St.-Germain-des-Pres, but my preference takes me straight to the new Opera Bastille. The curtain goes up at 7:30, and if it is Placido Domingo singing Verdi's ''Otello'' (as it will be five times in November), the evening has started rousingly. The opera house is starkly modern, yet its acoustics insure that not a sigh or a silence is missed. After four acts, it is no crime to think of dinner.

title: Usual Flurry of Election Ads on Television Becomes a Blizzard This Year
description: Feeling overwhelmed by political advertising this year? There's a reason: Candidates and their consultants say they are bombarding the electorate with more political advertisements than ever before.

title:
CRANBURY TOWNSHIP JOURNAL;

Fighting for Control of a Landmark
description: LEAD: CRANBURY'S old brick schoolhouse, saved from demolition in 1974, is again at the center of controversy in this historic community over who will maintain and manage it.

title: TRIAL AND TRIBULATION
description: Although Selzer tells us he will refrain from presenting an account of courtroom ''flash and clamor,'' that is all we have from him, except for his somewhat irrelevant reasons for becoming a doctor and his rather bizarre suggestion that any dispute he might have with his patient might better wait for adjustment in the next world. What we do not receive is an explanation of why his patient required 8 to 10 enemas a day, following his treatment of her. Was it the result of damage he inflicted?

title: Suriname, in Army's Ever-Tighter Grip, Skids From Tranquillity to Turmoil
description: Ten years after he overthrew the elected Government in this once-peaceful land, the former sergeant who is now commander of this country's small army is using violence to keep control of the country, Surinamese civic and human rights leaders and foreign diplomats say.

title: Valley Stream's Drying Brook
description: LEAD: WHEN Howard and June Wollman purchased their house at 13 Cloverfield Road in Valley Stream 35 years ago, they lived alongside a navigable waterway - a branch of Valley Stream Brook - where people went boating, children fished and at least one neighbor swam every day.

title: Carter Asks Guatemala to Investigate Abduction of Rights Workers
description: Former President Jimmy Carter has written a letter to the President of Guatemala asking for an immediate investigation of the kidnappings this month of two Guatemalan human rights campaigners.

title: Ruzimatov at Impasse With Ballet Theater on Pact
description: Faruk Ruzimatov, the 27-year-old former star of the Kirov Ballet who joined American Ballet Theater last spring, has failed to reach agreement with Ballet Theater's management on a new contract.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house is covered with a tan cement that is not supposed to be painted. The tan is now streaked with dirt, and there are gray patches that show. Can the cement be painted, or should it be steam-cleaned?

title: Sponsor Defaults
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

Tracing the Influence of Japan
description: LEAD: THE Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, on the campus of Rutgers University, is presenting another eye-opener. As is usual for this museum, it is conducted primarily through the modest medium of the graphic arts. ''Japonisme Comes to America: The Japanese Impact on the Graphic Arts'' shows how, at the turn of the century, Japanese art, especially woodblock prints known as ukiyoe, influenced

title: Layng Pew, an Intern Architect, Wed To Janet Amelia Chaplan, a Lawyer
description: Janet Amelia Chaplan, a daughter of Charmian Reading of New York and Dr. Abraham Chaplan of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to George Layng Pew 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pew Jr. of Villanova, Pa. Dr. Robert J. Berson, the leader of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, officiated at the Anchorage Museum at the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today about concert-hall music from Turin misidentifies a composer represented in the Settembre Musica festival. He is Riccardo Malipiero, not Gian Francesco Malipiero.

title: A Change in Procedures For Emergency Agency
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency, which in the last year has helped about 10 times the usual number of disaster victims, is revising its procedures and seeking new legislation to help it cope better in future crises.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A Ladder on the Mianus River Could Help Threatened Fish
description: LEAD: MENTION migrating salmon, and most people are likely to conjure images of icy Norwegian fjords or gushing rivers of the Pacific Northwest. But for a group of naturalists in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, the vision that comes to mind is a cool gentle river flowing 37 miles through their backyards and tracts of hemlock and deciduous forests on its way to its mouth at Cos

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: In her memorable previous novel, ''Grass,'' Sheri S. Tepper led the reader through a nearly book-length deception about a planet whose human inhabitants seemed fanatically devoted to the legendary male occupation of the hunt. When the truth was finally out, the reader, far from resenting the deception, felt an eerie bond with the hapless characters who were taken in by the same monstrous lie.

title: Morley StreetWins Easily
description: Morley Street, one of the best British jumpers ever sent to this country, humiliated a moderate field to win the $250,000 Breeders' Cup Steeplechase by 11 lengths yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Campus Life: Duke;   Scholars' Group, Accused of Bias, Divides Faculty
description: A group that says it is devoted to preserving the traditional Western curriculum has divided Duke University faculty members and students, provoking a sometimes bitter debate on academic freedom.

title: IN TOKYO, A SENSE OF INTIMACY
description: THE JOY OF DISCOVERING perfect evenings in the overgrown village that is Tokyo is that they cannot always be planned, or duplicated, but come in endless combinations that can produce the sense of intimacy that Tokyo, at its best, casts like a spell.

title: PAKISTANIS SEEING FEW HOPES IN VOTE
description: In the Murree Hills northeast of here, villagers have hoisted banners with a blunt message for candidates campaigning for elections next week. Roughly translated, the handmade signs say, ''Bring us water and electricity before you ask for our votes.''

title: Campus Life: U.C., Davis;   A Chance to See The Remaking Of Hungary
description: On their way to class here each morning, students from the University of California and the University of Wisconsin must pass an imposing life-size bronze statue of Karl Marx in the stately foyer of the Budapest University of Economics.

title: New Yorkers, etc...
description: Looking back, we're embarrassed at ourselves. Why in the world do we care about and remember such trivial, ridiculous things? Why haven't they been long forgotten?

title: Review/Cabaret;   Swing Piano by Carol Britto
description: Carol Britto has a strong, forthright approach to the piano. It is a manner that gives her showier pieces a sense of positive mobility and turns her faster selections into potential juggernauts, even in their delicate moments.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house is covered with a tan cement that is not supposed to be painted. The tan is now streaked with dirt, and there are gray patches that show. Can the cement be painted, or should it be steam-cleaned?

title: Bernstein on Music
description: Leonard Bernstein was not only a musical genius, but a noted teacher, speaker and writer. These excerpts are from collections of his works published by Simon & Schuster, except for the material from the Charles Eliot Norton Lectures, published by Harvard University Press.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HAVEL'S DARK COMEDY

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

The Atheletes Finally Get a Voice in the N.C.A.A.
description: LEAD: While being recruited as a high school athlete, I had heard of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, but I never knew what this organization was or what it did. I believe it was the same for many of my peers. All the N.C.A.A. meant to us was ''rules.'' There never seemed to be anyone who questioned those rules, either.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Oct. 6

title: Deborah Lupkin Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Lupkin of Bayside, Queens, have announced December wedding plans for their daughter, Deborah Eve Lupkin, and Emanuel Mark Gross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Gross of Monsey, N.Y.

title: Allies Say Budget Impasse Could Hurt World Economy
description: For America's allies, the budget fiasco in Washington has created an image of a rudderless, indecisive Government, the prey of special interests. It is not an image they savor.

title: The Region;   An Uproar Over Taxes in New Jersey - 55 Years Ago
description: Smarting from angry voter reaction to the $2.8 billion tax package enacted in his first six months of office, Governor Jim Florio now appears to be pursuing a strategy of damage control, hoping that his fellow New Jerseyans will, given time, forgive and forget.

title: Malaysia Ballot Offers a Rare Multiracial Contest
description: Malaysians began two days of voting today in the most contested and bitter election in 20 years.

title: Along the Thames to the Great Port of London
description: BY THE TIME IT REACHES Teddington, the Thames has come of age. It has left its birthplace 100 miles to the west, in the innocent hills of Gloucestershire; it has attended the university at Oxford, where it calls itself the Isis and carries undergraduates in punts to assignations under Magdalen Bridge; it has played an indispensable part in the Henley Royal Regatta, and visited Windsor Castle and Hampton Court Palace. At Teddington it feels the call of the sea - it becomes tidal.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Chappaqua
description: The area now known as Chappaqua was settled in 1720 by a group of Quakers who moved up from Purchase and Mamaroneck to establish a religious community. It got its name from an enterprising Indian chief who carried on a brisk trade with the early English settlers, some of whose names can still be found on mailboxes.

title: Ancient Beguinages Of Flanders
description: IN THE KLEIN BEGIJNHOF, THE SMALL BEGUINAGE, IN the Belgian city of Ghent, a child's beach ball drifts eerily back and forth across the deserted courtyard. The courtyard suggests the Flemish equivalent of a New England village green - a similar scale and a correspondent impression of an austere, pretty public space that in certain lights (or certain shadows) hints at the secretive and cloistered. Guided presumably by a breeze that one cannot hear or feel, the plastic ball drifts over the Small Beguinage's cobbled walkways, along the crooked rectangle of whitewashed, stepped-gabled 17th-century houses that surround and enclose the green. For hundreds of years these oddly diminutive dwellings were the homes of the Beguines: women who joined together to devote themselves to prayer and good works, to live apart from the world, but without taking vows to leave the world forever.

title: A Rare Underdog Sweep for the Reds
description: When the Cincinnati Reds were waiting for the National League Championship Series to begin, Lou Piniella addressed his players. ''The magic number,'' the manager said, ''is now eight.'' With the Reds poised last night for a World Series sweep of the Oakland Athletics, their magic number had been reduced to one. If the Athletics somehow were to win this Series, they would be the first team ever to return from 0-3 to do so. And as last night's fourth game approached, the defending champions were still talking bravely.

title: 2 Chances to See Anthony Newman
description: ANTHONY NEWMAN would seem to be the man of the week.
