title: Newspaper Group Formed
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau, in cooperation with the newspaper industry, has formed the Newspaper National Network, the final phase of a industrywide task force created three years ago to bring national advertisers back to daily journals.

title: Fernandez and Teachers Union: Are 2 Sides Too Close?
description: As New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez has maintained a relationship with the teachers union that strikes some educators as uncommonly close and visible given the city's history of often-fierce labor-management wars.

title: Delphi Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and 6 months included a loss of $ 1,712,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Atlantic Southeast Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The airline said that 1990 third quarter results were affected by a 23.7 percent increase in the per gallon price of jet fuel and a $ 1.8 million write-down of assets associated with the phase-out of an aircraft type, offset by the receipt of a $ 2 million sales tax refund.

title: New Sun Clones
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. is having some success in its effort to make its computers an industry standard. The LSI Logic Corporation, a semiconductor company in Milpitas, Calif., said 11 computer makers had agreed to use its chips in clones of Sun Sparcstation computers. The companies include some small American concerns like Compuadd and large companies from Taiwan and Korea that have made I.B.M. clones. The computers should be available in the next six months, LSI Logic said.

title: First National Pennsylvania Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS: Shooting Their Feet; Sure, Some Officials Can Exult Now, But Government Itself Lies Wounded
description: The Democrats won the political battle over the budget, almost all the Washington score-keepers were saying tonight, and gave President Bush some nasty bruises in the process, but in the deepest sense, there were no victors.

title: For Congress From Connecticut
description: There is hot competition for the seats of Connecticut's two U.S. Representatives who are running for governor: Bruce Morrison of New Haven, the Democrat, and John Rowland of Waterbury, the Republican. In the other four districts, capable incumbents face weak, underfinanced challengers. We support all four incumbents -- the Democrats Barbara Kennelly (First District) and Sam Gejdensen (Second), and the Republicans Chris Shays (Fourth) and Nancy Johnson (Sixth) -- and offer these choices for the open seats:

title: TLC Beatrice International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patriots Activate Mowatt for Sunday
description: Zeke Mowatt, who has spent the season on injured reserve and in hot water, was activated yesterday by the New England Patriots.

title: TLC Beatrice Net Doubles
description: TLC Beatrice International, the food company controlled by the New York financier Reginald F. Lewis, said yesterday that its third-quarter net income doubled as a result of higher sales of ice cream products in Europe and favorable exchange rates.

title: Complaints Overshadow The Draw
description: As 91 horses were entered yesterday for Saturday's seven Breeders' Cup races at Belmont Park, controversy continued to surround the field and the start for the afternoon's richest race, the $3 million Classic.

title: When Boys Clubs Meet Girls Clubs
description: They have been quietly accepted as members of the Boys Clubs of America since the late 1800's (no one knows the exact date). But now that girls have finally been included in the title of the 130-year-old organization, some of its 605 affiliates still prefer to do things the old way.

title: Procter & Gamble Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 81,000,000, or 23 cents a share, which represented a one-time, aftertax gain from settlement of litigation related to the company's Duncan Hines cookie business.Results for 1989 have been restated to include the operations of Noxell, which was merged with Procter & Gamble in November 1989.The company said the increased earnings from operations were primarily due to strong unit volume growth.

title: Dow Rises 10.15; High-Tech Stocks Strong
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, although a sharp rise in profits at Compaq Computer, a high-tech favorite, gave several technology stocks a lift.

title: Pacific Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $ 100-million provision for retailing losses, a $ 175 million writedown of oil and gas properties, and the reduction in depletion expense from the oil and gas properties writedown.c-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 16 about negotiations by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation to acquire a plant from the National Semiconductor Corporation referred incorrectly to Motorola Inc.'s manufacturing of static random access memory chips, or SRAM's. Motorola is still making the chips, which are used in high-performance computers.

title:
Currents;
In Pittsburgh, Reviving A Project by Wright
description: A WRITER'S unpublished novels often appear posthumously, but rarely an architect's unbuilt works. Different needs, sites and building codes create problems about how much of the original design can or should be kept. Nevertheless some of Frank Lloyd Wright's projects seem to be escaping dusty deaths on library shelves.

title: 5 Americans Return
description: An American former hostage who arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport last night described confinement in Iraq as a day-to-day struggle for survival, scrounging for food, and fighting depressing scenarios the imagination constructed.

title: Melee Follows Arrest of Hasid on Sex Charge
description: A melee erupted in Brooklyn's 90th Police Precinct Tuesday night when hundreds of Hasidic Jews surrounded the station house to protest the arrest of a Jewish man who, they said, had been falsely accused of fondling a teen-age girl.

title: Emergency Child-Care Program Grows
description: A program for emergency child care that was started a year ago as an experiment by seven large New York City companies is entering its second year with expanded corporate participation. It now comprises 14 major employers.

title: U.S. Raises a Question IN Brazil's Dept Talks
description: A top United States Treasury official told Brazil's central bank president yesterday that he was worried about the more than $8 billion in unpaid interest owed to commercial bankers.

description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 1,882,000 for the quarter and $ 3,180,000 for the 9 months.c-After extraordinary credits of $ 451,000 for the quarter and $ 9,381,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-After extraordinary charges of $ 766,000 and $ 1,414,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 76,000 for the quarter and $ 187,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months and extraordinary charges of $ 1,078,000 and $ 2,680,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.The company said the extraordinary charge in the latest quarter reflected the net loss associated with retirement of certain debt during the quarter, and an offsetting $ 1.3 million gain from repurchase of certain convertible debentures. Harley said the sales increase in the company's motorcycle and related products segment. The company's recreational and commercial vehicle sales showed a 21 percent decline.

title: Review/Television; Psychological Thriller Opens 'Mystery' Season
description: Helena Pratt is as nasty a bit of baggage as you are likely to find on television this year, and Diana Rigg brings her to lip-smackingly vicious life in the BBC's "Mother Love." The three-part, four-hour presentation opens the 11th season of public television's "Mystery," tonight at 8 on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channels 21 and 49. As Ms. Rigg, who also happens to be the regular "Mystery" host, notes in her introduction, "Mother Love" is not the standard whodunit usually featured on the series. It is a psychological thriller, offering, she adds pointedly, "a challenging role that's impossible for an actress to turn down."

title: Brunswick Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Iraq Bolsters Force, Saudi Says
description: Iraq has increased its forces in southern Iraq and Kuwait, amassing as many as 500,000 soldiers there as well as hundreds of anti-aircraft missiles and several thousand armored units, a senior Saudi official says.

Va., has privately placed $100 million in senior notes with a group of private lenders consisting mostly of insurance companies. * GTE Northwest Inc., Everett, Wash., a unit of GTE Corp., is offering $75 million in 9 3/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due 2030 at 97.545 to yield 10 percent through Prudential-Bache Capital Funding. Review/Theater; A Japanese Puppet Classic Is Reworked for People
description: As the author of 130 plays performed by both Kabuki and Bunraku theaters, Chikamatsu Monzaemon was the first Japanese playwright to make heroic figures out of common men. His tales often deal with acts of domestic violence, as is the case with "Gonza the Lancer," which opened Tuesday night in a misguided production at the Public Theater.

title: 6th Game Adjourned as Edge Seems to Belong to Kasparov
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov broke off play in Game 6 of the World Championship Chess Match last night in a position where the champion had attacking chances and the challenger, despite a pawn advantage, was confined to passive defense.

title: For Tables, Walls, Anywhere In the Darkening Evenings Ahead
description: TURN back the clocks this weekend and turn on the fun. Even the names are amusing: Scaragoo, Hot Dog, Riccordo un Giorno in Barena (Diary of a Day in Barena). They are all part of a menagerie of sculptural pieces that double as light sources. A ceramic striped rockfish, for example, can be used as a night light or to give the faintest warm glow to a wall or table. There is also a stylized chicken, an illuminated dachshund, a bird in flight and Eddy. Who knows what Eddy is? He can be man or beast. Laden with spirit, all these pieces were conceived with a sense of humor and a touch of whimsy, perfect to lighten the increasingly dark days to come.

title: Sears, Roebuck & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 10,500,000, or 3 cents a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 5,000,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 62,700,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.The company said the major factor contributing to reduced third-quarter earnings was significantly lower gains from sales of property in the Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group, which reduced comparative earnings by 20 cents a share.

title: Pathe Deal Is Expected
description: The board of the MGM/UA Communications Company said today that it had accepted the solvency opinion of an outside consultant concerning the Pathe Communications Corporation's $1.3 billion offer to acquire MGM/UA. The decision paves the way for the deal to be concluded Friday after a long and difficult period in which Pathe faced troubles arranging financing.

title: Talley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 598,000, or 7 cents a share, and $ 1,978,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 810,000, or 6 cents a share, and $ 1,307,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.Discontinued operations represented the operations of East-West Federal Savings Bank. The sale of the bank to Nuri Investments is pending.Series A, B and D preferred shares were anti-dilutive and accordingly were excluded from average share figures for the latest quarter. Series B preferred shares were antidilutive and therefore excluded from average share figures for the latest 9 months.Year-ago 9-month results included a $ 60-million pretax gain on the sale of the company's automotive air bag business, and a $ 36.6-million charge to establish reserves against realty assets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The limits on childbearing years are now anyone's guess; perhaps they will have more to do with the stamina required for labor and 2 A.M. feedings than with reproductive function." -- Dr. Marcia Angell, an editor at The New England Journal of Medicine. [ A25:1. ]

title: MCA Stock Trading Is Halted Twice
description: The New York Stock Exchange halted trading in MCA Inc. twice yesterday as reports circulated, and then were denied, that MCA's buyout talks with the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan had run into problems. Its last price was $50, down $8.875 from Tuesday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRESIDENT BUSH awarded ANDREW WYETH the Congressional Gold Medal yesterday, the first time the honor has been given to an artist.

title: Computer Associates Intl Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Panamanians File Suit Against Noriega Seeking $6.5 Billion
description: The Government of Panama filed a $6.5 billion civil racketeering lawsuit against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in Federal court today, contending that the ousted Panamanian leader betrayed his country through murder, fraud and theft.

title: Suburban Bankshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Federal Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9 months' per share earnings are from Jan. 26, 1989, the date of the conversion to stock form of ownership, through Sept. 30, 1989.

title: President for Tektronix Hired From Honeywell
description: Tektronix Inc., a maker of test and measurement products, said yesterday that it had hired Jerome J. Meyer from Honeywell Inc. to be its new president and chief executive.

title: A Freed British Hostage Tells of 'Sadistic Guards'
description: A British hostage who was freed by Iraq returned home to England today after asserting that Westerners held at an armaments factory outside Baghdad rioted over mistreatment by what he called "sadistic guards."

title: Blahoslav S. Hruby, Minister, Dies at 78; Led a Rights Group
description: The Rev. Blahoslav S. Hruby, a Presbyterian minister who headed a human-rights organization that monitors Eastern European countries, died on Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Alleghany Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest 9-month results reflected a pretax gain on investment transactions of $ 29.9 million, compared with $ 10.6 million in the prior year period.

title: Jackson and Vandeweghe Prove Hard Work Pays Off
description: Both Mark Jackson and Kiki Vandeweghe worked long hours during the summer, trying to recapture the confidence and effectiveness that once made them All-Stars. Clearly, that effort is paying dividends.

title: In Connecticut Race for Governor, the Focus Is Economic
description: In speech after speech the candidates for governor talk about Connecticut's bleeding economy, often to the exclusion of all else.

title: ALASKANS TO VOTE ON MARIJUANA USE
description: Fifteen years after the State Supreme Court legalized the possession of small amounts of marijuana, Alaska voters are caught up in a bitter fight over whether to make it illegal once again.

title: Let's Stop Spending To Fight Cold War
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bleak Numbers at Continental
description: Even as Continental Airlines appears at last to be overcoming a reputation for bad service, financial problems are catching up with it.

title: Toon Played 4 Games With a Broken Bone
description: Rob Moore, the Jets' rookie wide receiver, left practice today after spraining his left ankle, but it was a month-old injury to the Jets' All-Pro wide receiver, Al Toon, that drew more interest.

title: Boat People Lacking in Teachers of English
description: To the Editor:

title: Brunswick Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 46.7 million from the disposition of non-defense businesses of the technical segment.c-Net loss and included an after-tax charge of $ 79.2 million for the write-off of certain assets, primarily intangibles, and costs associated with the consolidation and reorganization of operations in the marine segment and the disposition of certain assets of the defense division.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; T.W.A. Said to Be Seeking Small Agency
description: AFTER Young & Rubicam resigned the estimated $45 million Trans World Airlines account three weeks ago, the airline searched for another large agency to handle its account.

title: Sendak Is Forming Company For National Children's Theater
description: Like the plucky young hero of one of his most famous children's books, "In the Night Kitchen," Maurice Sendak is about to plunge into a new and, he hopes, nourishing experience. After 40 years and many awards as an illustrator and writer, and more than a decade designing for opera and ballet, he is establishing a national children's theater, which he has named the Night Kitchen.

title: MAKING CARS SAFER IN SIDE COLLISIONS
description: The Department of Transportation issued new standards for automobile safety today that are intended to protect occupants when cars are struck from the side, saying the rule would prevent more than 500 deaths and 2,600 serious injuries a year.

title: BankNorth Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: BankNorth said 1989 results have been restated to reflect its merger with Howard Bancorp in December 1989.

title: 'East End Sniper' Convicted Of Killing in Riverhead, L.I.
description: A Long Island man known as the East End Sniper was convicted today of killing one man and wounding three others while pretending he was a commando on a military mission.

title: Bankers Face Increasing Skepticism Among Investors
description: The high dividend that Citicorp was forced to pay today on a preferred stock issue served as a reminder that many investors are skeptical about the strength of large banks despite assurances by bankers and regulators that they are solvent.

title: Student Charged in Stabbing
description: The police have charged a straight-A student with attempted homicide after he allegedly stabbed his high school physics teacher with a kitchen knife in an argument over a test grade. The teacher, David Pologruto, of Taravella High School, was listed stable at Coral Springs Medical Center, a nursing supervisor said. The name of the 16-year-old student was not made public.

title: Using 1975 Tool, Business and Labor Leaders Form Fiscal Council
description: Amid rising concern about New York City's financial health, a group of leaders of labor, finance and business met privately yesterday to try to help the city weather its financial problems.

title: American National Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Douglas Weighs In At a Surprising 246
description: When James (Buster) Douglas barefoot and in gray briefs -- stepped onto the scale at today's weigh-in for Thursday night's heavyweight title defense, he did not appear to have a conspicuous pouch or extreme ridges of blubber along his sides.

title: California State Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.B.A. Fines Bryant
description: The National Basketball Association fined a Portland reserve forward, Mark Bryant, $5,000 yesterday and ordered him to sit out the Trail Blazers' regular-season opener for fighting during an exhibition game against Sacramento.

title: Raytheon's President Is Elected Chairman
description: The Raytheon Company, a maker of air-defense missiles and other military electronics products, yesterday elected its president, Dennis J. Picard, to be chairman and chief executive effective March 1. He succeeds Thomas L. Phillips, who will retire in March after leading the company for 22 years.

title: Alberto-Culver Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Opera; Ghiaurov In His First 'Boris' At the Met
description: The Bulgarian bass Nicolai Ghiaurov took over the title role in Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening. It was, astonishingly, Mr. Ghiaurov's first Met appearance in a role that has been one of his specialties for 25 years.

title: USBancorp (Pa.) Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rangers Agree On New Ball Park
description: The Texas Rangers announced today that they had reached an agreement to build a new ball park in the city, ending speculation that the team would move to downtown Dallas.

title: Congress Votes Bill On Labeling of Food And Health Claims
description: Congress approved a sweeping bill today to curtail disease-prevention claims on food packages and require more nutrition information for virtually all foods in the grocery store.

title: Hocus-Pocus Is Always in Stock
description: WITH a graceful swoop of his hands, Tony Spina makes balls float and eggs disappear and plucks playing cards out of thin air. None of this is surprising because Mr. Spina, who owns Tannen's Magic Company in Manhattan, is a professional magician. But with a little hocus-pocus and the proper equipment, most customers who visit his upstairs shop can achieve the same feats.

title: Comparing Tax Provisions
description: Provisions of the plan reached by White House and Congressional budget negiotions last month, and a plan from House leaders that is serving as the basis for an emerging budget compromise. BUDGET SUMMIT PLAN -- Sept. 30 New taxes

title: Lexington Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: The Tax Plan: A Big Increase on the Highest Incomes, a Break for the Lowest
description: The compromise deficit-reduction plan that appeared tonight to be emerging from Congress would impose only modest tax increases on a broad range of taxpayers, from the lower middle class to many of the well-to-do.

title: Bridge
description: It is possible to construct a hand in which the only makeable game is in a 4-1 trump fit. Imagine, for example, that North-South have three small spades each and a 4-1 heart fit with all the honor cards. Add a bunch of winners in the minor suits, and give the opening leader a strong five-card spade suit and four hearts. Now four hearts is unbeatable and other games must fail.

title: Interface Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Cyprus Minerals Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Electronic Tele-Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oak Indus reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 7,282,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 7,980,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months.c-Net loss and after income of $ 184,000 for the quarter and a loss of $ 1,435,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.The latest 9 months' income from continuing operations included non-recurring income of $ 1 million.The year-ago 9 months' loss from continuing operations included $ 3.9 million of non-recurring expenses.

title: TransCanada Pipelines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 13,400,000.

title: Paperback Books Given For U.S. Military in Gulf
description: American book publishers, working through the U.S.O. and the Department of Defense, have donated more than 200,000 paperback books for American military personnel in the Persian Gulf. The first shipments are to take place on Tuesday.

title: Talking Deals; End of a Venture In Optical Disks
description: WHEN Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and the Du Pont Company announced earlier this week that they would end their four-year-old joint venture to manufacture optical disks, it reflected not only a divergence of interests but also a divergence within the disk market. Compact disks for music have experienced runaway growth, but growth of optical disks for computers has been sluggish.

title: BancFlorida Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Income from real estate operations included a gain of $ 2.8 million from the sale of Citrus Groves.c-Net income and gain on sale of investments and loans included $ 3.3 million from the sale of the firm's Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock; the year also included other income, which included a gain of $ 2.5 million from the curtailment of pension benefits under the firm's pension plan as of Oct. 1, 1988.

title: Cooper Championed Native Americans Against White Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: Busch Profit Grows 9.4%
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies today reported a 9.4 percent increase in third-quarter profits.

title: Community Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
William L. Wilson, Executive, 80
description: William L. Wilson, a retired vice president of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation in New York and a former mayor of Princeton, N.J., died on Monday at the Medical Center of Princeton. He was 80 years old and lived in Princeton Township.

title: Profit Slips 2.6% at Du Pont
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company today reported a 2.6 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings, with increases in its petroleum operations offset by slower growth in the company's chemicals businesses.

title: Why Did All Five Senators Pile On?
description: By order of the Senate Ethics Committee, five United States Senators -- the Keating Five -- will appear in an extraordinary session after next month's elections. They'll be together in the dock, required to explain the favors they did for Charles Keating, the once-imperious savings and loan operator. The Keating Five remain linked, kept together by a committee that refuses to lift the cloud of ethical suspicion from any of them.

title: Police Expand Student Escorts On the Subway
description: A pilot program in which transit police officers escort high school students home on the subways was expanded yesterday to serve almost all students who ride the trains.

title: Review/Dance; Choreographer's Growth Reverses His Priorities
description: At one point in "More Myth of Modern Dance," Douglas Dunn confided, "In New York you can do anything and someone will come to watch it." What audiences were watching when he said that on Sunday afternoon at St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery was a witty commentary on Mr. Dunn's own choreography. Presented by Douglas Dunn and Dancers under the auspices of the church's Danspace Project, "More Myth of Modern Dance" was simultaneously a treatise and a romp.

title: FPL Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 751,543,000. The company said $ 689 million of the charge represented reserve strengthening and write-downs related to its insurance subsidiary, Colonial Penn Group Inc.c-Net incomeThe company said third quarter results included a write-down of $ 63 million reflecting its decision to exit the real estate, cable televsion, and environmental remediation businesses.

title:
Currents;
A Very Expensive Butler
description: BUTLERS are expensive and take up space. More than that, they overhear too much. Stephen Owen, a furniture designer from Bramley in Surrey, England, has one solution.

title: Jack Henry & Associates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 23,000.

title: Cold-Fusion Scientist Missing as Key Review Nears
description: Dr. B. Stanley Pons, the University of Utah chemist who startled the science world with claims of achieving cold fusion, has vanished on the eve of a critical review by the State of Utah on whether to continue financing the disputed work, university officials said yesterday.

title: Five Journalists to Receive Cabot Awards at Columbia
description: Five journalists specializing in Latin American or Caribbean affairs are to be presented with Maria Moors Cabot prizes tonight by Columbia University.

title: Operating Net Up 15% At P.&.G.
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the maker of Tide detergent and Pampers diapers, reported a first-quarter profit yesterday of $555 million, or $1.57 a share. On an operating bass, that was an increase of nearly 15 percent from $483 million, or $1.36 a share, a year earlier. The results were in line with analysts' expectations.

title: Susquehanna Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Inbancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Revlon Accuses a Supplier Of Sabotaging Its Software
description: A software supplier involved in a contract dispute with Revlon Inc. brought some operations of the cosmetics giant to a halt last week by disabling some of Revlon's software.

title: Suncor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1989 have been restated to reflect the adoption of the deferral method of accounting for maintenance shutdowns.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Skills-Training Policy Opening Doors to Jobs
description: For the last eight years researchers have clocked and gauged the experiences of several thousand single mothers here and in three other cities, trying to answer one of the most elusive questions in social policy: how to turn welfare recipients into workers.

title: Reviews/Music; Tureck's 'Goldberg' Variations
description: Rosalyn Tureck, who has long played the keyboard works of Bach on the harpsichord as well as on the piano, chose the latter for a performance of the "Goldberg" Variations on Sunday afternoon in the great space of Temple Emanu-El. And appropriately, her approach was unabashedly pianistic much of the time, with dynamics ranging from a barely audible dying away at the end of the Aria to a hearty Rachmaninoffian crescendo at the end of the epic 25th Variation.

title: Tecumseh Products Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a nonrecurring provision for environmental cleanup after-tax charges of $ 19.2 million.c-Net income

title: Giants Might Revamp Defense
description: When the Giants squeaked out a 24-20 victory over the Washington Redskins two games ago, the Redskins, a better passing than rushing team, rushed for 162 yards. When the Giants squeaked out a 20-19 victory over the Phoenix Cardinals last Sunday, the Cardinals rushed for 125 yards.

title: Trieste Journal; Shades of Hapsburgs! City Sees Splendid Future
description: Vienna is closer than Rome, and Budapest and Prague are not much farther away. Local coffee distributors have names like Eisner and Hausbrandt, and in the heart of town it is easier to find beer from Munich than a pizza.

title: Language Bill Weighed as Slovak Separatists Rally
description: Demonstrators shouted for a separate Slovak state today as thousands poured into the streets and squares around Parliament for rallies held by opposing groups.

title: I.B.M. Unit Notes To Yield 8.36%
description: A $350 million note offering by the IBM Credit Corporation was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The size of the issue was increased from $250 million because of good investor demand.

title: Review/Cabaret; Love Songs of the 40's
description: Early in her engaging new act of World War II love songs at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (49 West 44th Street), Andrea Marcovicci reflects on how distant the romantic atmosphere of the 1940's seems from the present. "There were no co-dependency meetings," she says. "People liked being dependent. They called it falling in love."

title: Seacoast Banking Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hastings Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shawmut National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 13.6 million from tax loss carryforward.Shawmut said the latest quarter was negatively impacted by a higher level of nonperforming assets, lower level of interest earning assets and a higher provision for possible loan losses. Those factors were partially offset by securities gains of $ 8.5 million and a net gain of $ 7.8 million from the securitiztion and sale of certain assets.

title: Arctic Alaska Fisheries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Treasury Issues Post Small Gain
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher and interest rates dipped in light trading yesterday, as dealers bought some securities on signs that agreement on the Federal budget was imminent.

title: To Belgian Rebels, Life Isn't Seamless
description: With half the fashion world in Chanel uniforms, there was bound to be a youthful rebellion.

title: Aides Say Bush Faced Choice: A Deal on Taxes, or a Fiasco
description: In a tense Oval Office meeting late Tuesday night, the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and the House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, bluntly told President Bush that he had to choose between a deal or a fiasco.

title: Westamerica Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Having a Wonderful Time in Miami
description: LIKE an overgrown Venus flytrap, the village of Coconut Grove seems to engulf its houses. Here, along the Entrada Inlet that leads from Biscayne Bay, the landscape is a moist thicket of banyans, palms and royal poincianas, a haven for land crabs and the occasional parrot.

title: Greyhound Dial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 100,000,000.c-Net incomeThe company said the charge in the latest 9 months was to establish a reserve for losses related to the GLI Holding Co.'s Greyhound Lines Inc. bankruptcy. Greyhound Dial noted that it sold substantially all its domestic intercity bus transportation business to GLI in 1987, retaining 22.5 percent of the common stock of GLI. Greyhound Dial also holds GLI preferred stock, a junior subordinated note and other notes and accounts receivable, and has substantial assets leased to the bus line as well as other contractual relationships.

title: Old Memory Leads to a Murder Trial
description: A retired firefighter goes on trial here this week, accused of bludgeoning an 8-year-old girl to death 21 years ago. His accuser is his own daughter, who says she saw it happen, and his trial will test the credibility of her claim that she repressed her memory of the attack for two decades because it was so traumatic.

title: Wyoming National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Smith International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossShare earnings are after preferred dividend requirements of $ 437,500 in both quarters and $ 1,312,500 in both 9-month periods.

description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 8,825,000, or 20 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.

title: Enserch Exploration Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Dance; A Harmonious Union of 8 Finds Itself Disrupted
description: Jennifer Muller is seldom at a loss for clever choreographic ideas. But she is most satisfying when she is imaginative as well as inventive. And in "Refracted Light" her imagination was very much on display.

title: Home Improvement
description: MANY older sinks and tubs have compression faucets, the kind with a rubber washer at the base of the stem. Compression faucets are not as common as they used to be, perhaps because they are the ones most likely to leak.

title: Compaq Computer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $ 27.1 million from an increase in the carrying value of the company's investment in Conner Peripherals Inc., for an after-tax gain of 20 cents a share.c-Included a similar gain of $ 13.7 million, for an after-tax gain of 10 cents a share, and a gain of $ 7.6 million, for an after-tax gain of 6 cents a share, from the sale of Conner stock.Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared in May.

title: Meritor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $ 27,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.c-After extraordinary credits of $ 1,236,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 5,510,000, or 16 cents a share, for the 9 months, from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Times Mirror Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1990 were affected by one-time charges incurred at Newsday which reduced earnings per share by 3 cents a share, reflecting severance payments related to a voluntary early retirement program and lease costs.Results for 1989 included a gain of 11 cents a share from the sales of Timberlands recorded in the second quarter.

title: Met Opera Appoints An Operations Director
description: Robert Sirinek has been named operations director of the Metropolitan Opera, the Met's general director, Joseph Volpe, has announced. Mr. Volpe, who became general director in August, said the senior assistant position of operations director had been reinstated to "both strengthen and deepen the Met's senior management over the course of the next year."

title: Poughkeepsie Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Virginia First Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tariff-Cut Plan Is Reported
description: The United States offered drastic across-the-board tariff cuts today at the global trade liberalization talks and called on other negotiators to reciprocate, a person at the meeting said.

title: Merry Land & Investment reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net capital gains of $ 868,000 in the quarter, and $ 1,487,000 in the 9 months.c-Included net capital gains of $ 1,910,000 in the quarter, and $ 6,677,000 in the 9 months.

title: Dow Corning Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Dow Corning is jointly owned by Dow Chemical Co. and Corning Inc.

title: Regan Countering Attacks By Challenger With Vigor
description: Unlike New York's other statewide elected officials, Edward V. Regan seems to be living with fear as Election Day nears.

title: Avon Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
200 on Verge of Soviet Exit Are Stalled
description: More than 200 Christian fundamentalists who were supposed to inaugurate a new refugee system to America were trapped in a bureaucratic limbo at the airport today, having sundered all ties to the Soviet Union after years of religious persecution, but then finding departure denied to them at literally the last exit.

title: Metro Matters; Project Is Caught In a Crossfire Meant for Trump
description: When Ruth W. Messinger, the dogged Manhattan Borough President, puts the bite on a developer, that's not news. But Ms. Messinger has intervened on a builder's behalf against the wishes of some of her constituents, and therein lies a tale.

title: Exxon Net Unchanged; Unocal Up
description: The Exxon Corporation said today that its net income in the third quarter was unchanged from the period a year ago. Higher oil prices depressed profits in refining, marketing and chemical operations and increased profits in worldwide crude production.

title:
Currents;
International Designs, Not 'to the Trade Only'
description: FOR many years, the innovative furniture designed by architects and designers was not very accessible to the public.

title: Buster's Strength Of Will
description: In the days before Mike Tyson was to defend the world heavyweight title against James (Buster) Douglas in Tokyo, not many boxing people gave the challenger a chance. Tyson was thought to be invincible. Douglas was thought to be incapable. He had an undistinguished 29-4-1 record with 20 undistinguished knockouts. He also had a reputation for undistinguished desire and undistinguished training habits.

title: Syracuse a Giant Problem for Army
description: The Army-Syracuse game at West Point on Saturday will be one matching the large against the extra large and will be best exemplifed when the Orange has the ball.

title: National Intergroup
description: The holding company National Intergroup Inc. said today that it lost almost $1 million in the second quarter after settling with shareholders in a takeover bid. The $4.2 million settlement brought on a loss of $988,000, on revenue of $700 million in the quarter, National Intergroup said. That compared with a profit of $8.6 million, or 33 cents a share, on revenue of $561.5 million for the corresponding period in 1989. The company is moving its headquarters to Dallas.

title: Farm Banks Issues Total $2.15 Billion
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced at par a total of $2.15 billion in three-month, six-month and one-year consolidated systemwide bonds through various securities dealers.

title: Jerusalem as Tinderbox: Fury and Foreboding Prevail
description: Soldiers threw up scores of roadblocks at dawn today, barring all Palestinians from entering Israel. Immediately a tense and angry truce fell over the nation and its occupied territories.

title: Oriental Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ford's Credit Rating Drops a Notch
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday lowered by a notch the long-term rating on about $45 billion in securities issued by the Ford Motor Company, the Ford Motor Credit Company and subsidiaries.

title: Burlington Stake
description: The 26,000 employees and managers of Burlington Industries have acquired a majority ownership and voting control of the textile giant. The company established an employee stock ownership plan last year. The latest transaction, which was announced on Tuesday, gives employees and management all of the voting stock and 51 percent of the company's common equity.

title: UST Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Millipore Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Manischewitz Is Sued on Bid
description: A shareholder of the B. Manischewitz Company, the kosher food company that has received a buyout bid, said yesterday that he had filed a class action lawsuit and was seeking a court injunction to stop the tender offer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Affiliated Computer Systems Commercial Services Inc., Dallas, appointed John Cudworth and L. Thomas Olsen to newly created positions as senior vice presidents. * Chemical Waste Management Inc., Oak Brook, Ill., named Thomas E. Noel president and chief operating officer of its Chem-Nuclear Systems subsidiary. Dr. Rodger Henson will succeed him as vice president of the southern region. * Cimflex Teknowledge Corp., Pittsburgh, a producer of industrial robots, appointed Daniel R. Robusto chief executive officer. * Donnelly Corp., Holland, Mich., a manufacturer of glass products, named Paul G. Kalkman president and chief operating officer. He takes over the two positions from Dwane Baumgardner, who will continue as chairman and chief executive. * Insituform of North America Inc., Memphis, a pipeline reconstruction company, named William C. Willis Jr. chief executive, replacing James D. Krugman, who was acting chief executive and will remain chairman. * National Westminster Bank U.S.A., New York, a unit of National Westminster Bank P.L.C., London, appointed Morris Danon executive vice president, heading its newly formed Metropolitan Markets group. * Restaurant Associates Corp., New York, a restaurant and food-service subsidiary of Kyotaru Corp., Tokyo, promoted Nick Valenti to executive vice president, and Phillip Ratner to executive vice president. * A. Schulman Inc., Akron, Ohio, a producer of plastic and rubber compounds, named Terry L. Haines president and chief operating officer, succeeding William C. Zekan, who continues as chairman and chief executive. * Sirco International Corp., Mount Vernon, N.Y., a handbag and luggage manufacturer, appointed Yutaka Yamaguchi chairman and chief executive. Replacing him as president is Steven Wall.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Increase by 10.3% on Nasdaq
description: In a short sale, an investor, believing that a stock's price will decline, sells borrowed stock in anticipation of buying back an equal number of shares later at a lower price, thereby making a profit.Views of Analysts Differ

title: Another Spanish Event Occurred in 1492
description: To the Editor:

title: Grubb & Ellis Realty Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income decreased in the 1990 third quarter primarily due to a reduction in interest income following the initial liquidation distribution of $ 4,350,000 in June of this year.

title: Sterling Chemicals reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Suspects in Killing of East Side Businessman
description: Detectives searching for a motive sifted yesterday through the loves and business dealings of a millionaire killed on a quiet Upper East Side street on Tuesday morning.

title: Du Pont (E.I.) de Nemours & Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter included a gain of $ 21 million from the sale of an instrument systems business and a $ 37 million gain from the sale of an interest in North sea oil property.The latest 9 months also included charges of $ 27 million from the closing of two automotive finishes plants and other restructuring activities.The 1989 9 months included a $ 97 million supplemental amortization charge for certain producing properties, benefits of $ 56 million from adjustment of a prior-year tax provision and $ 38 million from the sale of a portion of an interest in a North sea natural gas property.

title: Article 399090 -- No Title
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, citing intense price competition, higher costs and huge debt, yesterday reported a third-quarter net loss of $61.4 million, in contrast to net income of $70.5 million in the period last year. The company also reaffirmed previous announcements that it planned to lay off 3,000 employees, or nearly 3 percent of its work force, by the middle of 1992.

title: Tee-Comm Electronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 786,000 and $ 1,588,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: OHIO REPUBLICAN QUITS HOUSE SEAT
description: Representative Donald E. (Buz) Lukens of Ohio resigned today rather than face a broadened ethics committee inquiry into charges of sexual misconduct.

title: Coffey Will Sign
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins averted a scheduled arbitration hearing last night by reaching agreement with their star defenseman, Paul Coffey, on a reported five-year, $6 million contract. The Penguins would not confirm the length or terms of the contract, only that Coffey had agreed to a multiyear deal.(AP)

title: First Bancorp (N.C.) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Pacific Mint reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Islanders Repeat a Horror Show
description: It was a case of repetition of the most embarrassing kind. One night after being shellacked at home, 8-1, by the Devils, the Islanders, looking and feeling very much like league whipping boys, absorbed an 8-2 thrashing from the Canadiens at the Forum tonight.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Beech Aircraft Corp., Wichita, Kan., said it would slow production of some models and stop hiring new workers. * Chase Manhattan Corp., New York, said it would cut costs by 20 percent in its Asian banking operations by the end of the year, partly through layoffs. * Consolidated Rail Corp., Philadelphia, requested binding arbitration to settle its dispute with the Delaware & Hudson Railway over 15 miles of Conrail's track in upstate New York. * Integrated Resources Inc., New York, a real estate, investment and insurance concern, received approval from Federal Bankruptcy Court to sell stock in its American Property Investors subsidiary to an entity controlled by Carl Icahn for $44 million. * Loral Corp., New York, a maker of electronic systems, has completed its acquisition of Ford Motor Co.'s Ford Aerospace unit for $715 million. * Ogden Corp., New York, an environmental services company that owns 68 percent of the shares of ERC Environmental and Energy Services Co., Fairfax, Va., an engineering company, has offered to buy the remaining stake in the company for $14.75 a share. * Poughkeepsie Savings Bank, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., will sell its banking operations in South Carolina to Republic National Bank, a unit of Resource Bancshares Corp., Columbia, S.C., for undisclosed terms. It is selling its North Carolina deposits for undisclosed terms to Robeson Savings Bank, Lumberton, N.C. * D. S. Revco Inc., Twinsburg, Ohio, a chain of discount drugstores, said a Federal Bankruptcy Court has denied its motion to extend past Oct. 31 its deadline to file a reorganization plan. * Summit Bancorporation, Summit, N.J., said its subsidiary banks would purchase two retail banking branch offices in New Jersey from Anchor Savings Bank FSB, Hewlett, L.I. Terms were not disclosed. * Sutton Holding Corp. said it would make an offer for the remaining detergent business of DeSoto Inc., Des Plaines, Ill., a maker of chemical coatings and specialty products.

title: Burmese Forces Raid Monasteries And Arrest 12 Opposition Leaders
description: The military Government has raided monasteries and rounded up opposition leaders in a growing crackdown on dissent, opposition contacts said today.

title: New Life for a 19th-Century Row House
description: It was built in 1832, but there is a spirit of youthful vigor at the Old Merchant's House, a museum in Manhattan that has been closed since July and will reopen on Sunday.

title: Court Upholds Shutdown of Barge Company
description: The family singled out by New York State as the worst polluter of New York Harbor failed yesterday to block the state in court from immediately shutting its oil- and sludge-hauling barge business.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Home Furnishings Council has signed Kathie Lee Gifford as a spokeswoman for its multimillion-dollar national advertising campaign, which is handled by Baron & Zaretsky, New York.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Jury selection in the murder trial of CHRISTIAN BRANDO , the 32-year-old son of MARLON BRANDO , begins Nov. 5 in Santa Monica, Calif. Judge ROBERT W. THOMAS of Los Angeles County Superior Court yesterday ordered a panel of 225 prospective jurors.

title: Anatole Broyard Memorial
description: A memorial service for Anatole Broyard, a book critic, essayist and editor at The New York Times, is to be held on Monday at 11 A.M. at the Southport (Conn.) Congregational Church. Mr. Broyard died of cancer on Oct. 11 at the age of 70.

title: Probert Deportation Decision Due
description: When Bob Probert of the Red Wings stands before a Federal judge in Detroit this morning, he faces several possibilities, two of which threaten his career and his freedom.

title: Kinetic Concepts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 6.5 million.

title: A Dispute Is Said to Cause Dismissal of Aca Joe's Chief
description: Mark Shulman, a retail-clothing executive who was formerly president of Henri Bendel in New York, has been dismissed as president and chief executive of Aca Joe Inc., the apparel chain that hired him earlier this year.

title: Landmarks of the Common Folk
description: "ANONYMOUS was a woman," feminists complain.

title: Bhutto Defeated in Pakistan Vote; President Sees Orderly Transition
description: Benazir Bhutto, seeking to return to power through the ballot after her abrupt dismissal in August on charges of corruption and mismanagement, was decisively defeated in national elections on Wednesday, according to early results.

title:
Currents;
Freud's 50-Minute Hour
description: ALONG with psychoanalysis, Freud invented the 50-minute hour. It has often driven analysts and therapy clients crazy. Just when one uncovers one's most repressed thoughts, the "hour" is up.

title: Reviews/Music; A Father And His Son Share a Style
description: Raphael and Peter Wallfisch, who are son and father, gave a robust afternoon of cello and piano music at the Frick Collection on Sunday. They live in London. This was their New York debut.

title: Give Tax Incentives to Hire the Unemployed
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp Closing Office
description: Citicorp Mortgage Inc. plans to close one of its processing offices in a move that will eliminate 180 jobs, the company announced on Tuesday. The office, 25 miles north of Newark, is one of three centers that process mortgage applications from Citicorp Mortgage's 68 offices nationwide. The office will be consolidated into Citicorp Mortgage's processing center at its St. Louis headquarters. The other center is in Shelton, Conn. Citicorp officials said it made the move to cut costs. All of the 180 employees were given the option to relocate to the St. Louis office, but only 40 chose to do so, officials said.

title: Help for Those With Bladder Trouble
description: It was not so very long ago that people would discuss their sexual woes, their family strife, even that most intimate of topics, their salaries, before they would confess to suffering from urinary incontinence.

title: Harris Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Infotechnology Gets New Top Executives
description: The board of the troubled Financial News Network and Infotechnology Inc., which owns 47 percent of FNN, announced a new management team for the companies yesterday in the face of severe cash-flow difficulties.

title: Horizon Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Joins in 2d Vote At U.N. to Criticize Israel Over 21 Slain
description: The United States voted with the rest of the Security Council tonight to deplore Israel's refusing to cooperate with an investigation of the killing of 21 Palestinians in a clash with Israeli security forces two weeks ago.

title: CNB Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Southwest National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Confidence Amid Contradictions
description: Wayne Levi may be blond, blue-eyed, flat-bellied and given to wearing garish colors, but he is also living proof that PGA Tour players are not predictable clones.

title: Grand Juries
description: Stupid prosecutor's trick of the month -- and the competition is fierce for this one -- goes to the assistant state attorney in the 2 Live Crew case who said one of the jurors, a 76-year-old retired professor, was trouble from Day One. "She was a sociologist, and I don't like sociologists," Pedro Dijols said. "They try to reason things out too much."

title: Peru Relaxes Emergency Rule
description: The Peruvian Government said today it has lifted an eight-year state of emergency in Ayacucho, the Andean city where the Maoist-inspired Shining Path rebels began their movement. However, the state of emergency was extended in rural areas surrounding the city, as well as in nine other provinces.

title: Advance Ross Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 2,438,000, or $ 1.25 a share, partially offset by a provision for loss on building of $ 400,000, or 21 cents a share.

title: John J. Tullman, Lawyer, 86
description: John J. Tullman, a lawyer who was an expert in medical malpractice litigation, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: Coleman's Agent Reports Accord With Nets
description: The Nets and Derrick Coleman have agreed in principle to a five-year, $15 million contract that will make Coleman the highest-paid rookie in the history of the National Basketball Association, Coleman's agent said tonight.

title: 'Great Books' Takes In Moderns and Women
description: Almost 40 years after the "Great Books of the Western World" was published to wide critical acclaim, the collection of many of the seminal works of almost 3,000 years of Western civilization has been given an editorial facelift. Homer, Shakespeare, Plato and John Stuart Mill are still represented, but for the first time they will share the grandeur with 20th-century writers. And for the first time, women will be included. The 60 volumes that make up the revised "Great Books," published by the Encyclopaedia Britannica , is to be introduced this morning at the Library of Congress. Later today, William F. Buckley Jr. is to lead a panel of scholars in a discussion of the impact of 20th-century authors on Western thought.

title: BankWorcester Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossc-Net income

title: Standing on Ceremony on Poison Gas
description: For years the United States did nothing while Saddam Hussein used chemical weapons, first in his war with Iran and then against Iraq's Kurdish citizens. Now U.S. troops face a chemically armed Iraq in the desert and Congress is about to vote to impose mandatory sanctions on countries that produce, acquire or use chemical weapons. How can President Bush, of all people, be threatening to veto the bill?

title: Youth Guilty of Setting Fire To Boy in a Brooklyn Cellar
description: A 14-year-old was convicted yesterday of setting fire to a Brooklyn boy, David Opont, in an assault that drew wide attention and an outpouring of sympathy because of its viciousness.

title: Review/Opera; Puccini's Passionate Westerners
description: Martha Thigpen seems on her way to becoming one of the New York City Opera's most appealing Puccini sopranos. This season, she gave a powerful, sensibly motivated performance in the title role of "Tosca." And on Tuesday evening, she joined the cast of "La Fanciulla del West" and offered a touching portrayal of that work's heroine, Minnie.

title: A Cabinet With Many Lives
description: IF there is such a thing as a lovable piece of furniture, the Hoosier cabinet is it.

title: PRESIDENT'S VETO OF RIGHTS MEASURE SURVIVES BY 1 VOTE
description: The Senate today fell one vote short of overturning President Bush's veto of a civil rights bill, giving a victory to those who contended that the legislation would have led to the widespread use of quotas in hiring and promotion.

title: Cooper Championed Native Americans Against White Injustice; May's Nationalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Bank Scandal Grows
description: A financial scandal widened today as officials from a second leading bank were arrested on charges of illegal financial dealings with a well-known takeover artist who was indicted earlier on share manipulation charges.

description: Possession By A. S. Byatt 555 pages. Random House. $22.95.

title: Peter Salm, 71, Dies; Literature Professor
description: Peter Salm, professor emeritus of literature and German at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, died Sunday at University Hospitals in Clevland. He was 71 years old and lived in Cleveland Heights.

title: 40 Killed in Muslim-Hindu Clash As Politician's Arrest Is Protested
description: More than 40 people were killed and more than 150 wounded today in fighting between Hindus and Muslims as Hindu revivalists and a right-wing party led a nationwide strike to protest the arrest of the party's president.

title: Exxon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 880,000,000 and a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 535,000,000, or 42 cents a share.The company said third quarter net income was flat because prices for petroleum and chemical products did not keep pace with the rising cost of raw materials during the period. The company said additional income from higher crude oil prices was offset by lower earnings in refining, marketing and chemical operations.The company also said the extraordinary charge represents a provision associated with the Exxon Valdez oil spill and clean-up operation.

title: Chicago Opera's Chief Has a Mission
description: Last October the Lyric Opera of Chicago shocked the American opera world with a bold announcement. Starting this season -- on Saturday, to be exact -- the company would present a decade-long "celebration" of 20th-century opera, offering 20 major scores from both Europe and the United States, including three commissioned American world premieres.

description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 791,000 for the quarter and $ 234,002,000 for the 6 months, and extraordinary credits of $ 66,000 and $ 406,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $ 4,565,000 for the quarter and $ 10,369,000 for the 6 months, and extraordinary credits of $ 6,554,000 and $ 12,015,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.The latest periods' results also included a $ 4.2 million charge in the second quarter from a settlement with certain shareholders relating to expenses incurred during recent consent solicitation and proxy contests.Year-ago periods were restated to reflect discontinued operations.The net loss for the 6 months also included reserves totaling $ 239.5 million established in the first quarter to cover anticipated losses on the sale of the company's Ben Franklin and Permian Corp. subsidiaries, a $ 26.7 million charge associated with the closing of its Pittsburgh office, and a $ 14.8 million non-recurring charge reflecting the market value of the preferrrd stock and expenses related to its National Steel transaction.The losses were partially offset by a $ 12 million gain on the sale of the company's Genix Enterprises Inc. subsidiary.

title: Senate Passes Compromise on Arts Endowment
description: After an emotional debate about the Government's role in the arts, the Senate today adopted a bipartisan compromise that would leave judgments about obscenity and pornography to the courts.

title: Review/Dance; A Folk Gem With Classical Facets
description: The Georgian State Dance Company from the Soviet Union has appeared so many times in the United States since the 1960's that one might wonder what this dazzling company could possibly add to the saber-rattling, dagger-throwing, male toe-dancing and serene gliding dances of past visits.

title: North Side Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeYear-ago quarter's figures included a gain of $ 608,000 from sale of loans, investments and mortgage-backed securities and a gain of $ 282,000 from the sale of bank property.Latest year figures included a loss of $ 1.8 million from the sale of loans, investments and mortgage-backed securities; year-ago figures included a gain of $ 692,000 from such sales. Year-ago figures also included a gain of $ 282,000 from sale of property.

title: Durable Goods Orders Fell by 1.7% Last Month
description: Orders to factories for "big ticket" durable goods fell 1.7 percent in September from August, the Government said today. Analysts said the report foretold a further slump in production and employment in the industrial sector, which has lost 500,000 jobs since January 1989.

title: Warsaw Pact Summit Talks Delayed
description: With its future in doubt and its membership divided over the last issue it may face as a military alliance, the Warsaw Pact has agreed to postpone indefinitely a meeting of its top leaders. The meeting had been scheduled to be held here early next month.

title: 19 New Names Bring Free-Agency List to 50
description: Willie McGee, Mike Boddicker and Bud Black were among 19 players who filed for free agency yesterday, and they are also among 21 players eligible for free agency who have been classified as Type A in the annual ranking statistics.

title: Star States Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 6.2 million writedown on real estate development projects and about $ 2.3 million in writedowns and costs of foreclosed assets.c-Included an accounting adjustment loss of $ 394,000 for the quarter and an accounting adjustment gain of $ 47,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months.

title: Sears's Net Fell 30.4% In Quarter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company released a third-quarter earnings report today that showed faint signs of improvement from a deep slump in its core retailing operation. But, over all, Sears's sales and earnings remained depressed, and most analysts said they remained unconvinced that the merchandising overhaul Sears began 18 months ago would produce a turnaround soon.

title: Freeport-McMoran Oil & Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Roberta Peters Recital
description: The soprano Roberta Peters is to sing melodies and arias by Antonio Lotti, Mozart, Schubert, Verdi, Richard Strauss, Tchaikovsky, Rimsky-Korsakov and Rachmaninoff in a recital at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 19 at 8 P.M., to celebrate the 40th anniversary of her professional debut. Warren Jones will be the pianist. Tickets, at $45 to $12, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: Solar Cell Plant For the Soviets
description: The Soviet Union and Energy Conversion Devices Inc. will build a factory in Moscow to make solar photovoltaic cells, the company said yesterday.

title: After Nearly 2 Years on a Tightrope, Elizabeth Dole Resigns Labor Post
description: There were not many workplace issues that Labor Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole failed to make a speech about: the rights of women and minorities, pension rights, child labor abuses, worker safety, worker training, the minimum wage. And to proponents of workers, she said most of the right things, too. But little of what Mrs. Dole said before she resigned yesterday as the highest-ranking woman in the Bush Administration brought noteworthy changes in Government policies.

title: International Flavors & Fragrances reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Big Upset for 19-Year-old Kulti Nicklas Kulti of Sweden, the 1989 world junior champion, earned the biggest victory of his pro career yesterday by upsetting third-seeded Andre Agassi, 6-3, 7-5, in the second round of the Stockholm Open. Agassi was playing his first match in three weeks after straining his lower back earlier this month. Stefan Edberg, the world's top-ranked player, rallied from a slow start to beat Mats Wilander, 6-4, 6-3. Boris Becker, seeded second, dropped only two games but John McEnroe was extended to three sets in other second-round matches. Becker routed Darren Cahill of Australia, 6-2, 6-0. McEnroe beat Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-7, 7-5. (AP) Graf Advances to Quarterfinals: Steffi Graf advanced to the quarterfinals of a tournament in Brighton, England, yesterday with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Nathalie Herreman of France. (AP) BASEBALL Seibu Sweeps Japan Series Orestes Destrade singled in the tie-breaking run and was named the most valuable player as the Seibu Lions beat the Yomiuri Giants, 7-3, yesterday in Tokyo to complete the first four-game sweep in 30 years in the Japan Series. (AP) HOCKEY Hull Stars as Blues Win Brett Hull scored three goals and set up another as the St. Louis Blues routed Toronto, 8-3, last night. The Blues put the puck past the goaltender, Peter Ing, four times on their first five shots. Hull's hat trick gave him a league-high 10 goals. Toronto is now 1-8-1. (AP) North Stars 3, Whalers 0: Jon Casey made 33 saves for his fifth career shutout and Dave Gagner scored twice as Minnesota snapped a seven-game streak without a victory. Gagner's second goal was the 100th of his career. Brian Bellows earned his 300th career assist with a superb goal-mouth feed. The game, in Bloomington, Minn., drew a season-low 4,646 fans to the Met Center. (AP) Jets 3, Oilers 1: Stephane Beauregard, a rookie goaltender, stopped 23 shots, including 11 in a strong third period, as Winnipeg won at home. (AP)

title: Analysis & Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Balkan Nations Gather to Improve Their Ties
description: The Foreign Ministers of the Balkan countries assembled here today for the first time since the vast changes that swept Eastern Europe in the last year.

description: b-Net lossThe company said year-ago quarter results reflect a $ 1.1 million reversal of prior period sales made to its German distributor with whom a joint venture was established, and certain other non-recurring charges.

title: People
description: * Carl Spielvogel, chairman and chief executive of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, has been appointed to the board of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, replacing William Youngclaus, managing partner of Tathum-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, who resigned. * Brian M. Kelly was promoted to vice president and senior art director at AC&R Advertising, New York. * Hans Zucker has been promoted to vice president at Korey, Kay & Partners, New York.

title: Art Dealer Told Again To Return Mosaics
description: In an opinion prefaced by a dozen lines from Lord Byron's lament for a crumbling temple, a Federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday that an Indianapolis art dealer must return four sixth-century mosaics to the church on Cyprus from which they were stolen.

title: Wicor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Frozen Food Express reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First City Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Losses at USAir and Delta; UAL Up
description: Blaming higher fuel costs and weak traffic, USAir Group and Delta Air Lines yesterday reported large third-quarter losses. But the parent of United Airlines, the nation's second-largest airline, reported a healthy profit, helped a lot by its lucrative Pacific routes.

title: Israel Again Rejects U.N. Investigation
description: Israel today firmly rejected the United Nations Security Council's latest resolution calling on the Government to reconsider its refusal to accept a United Nations mission investigating the killings at Al Aksa Mosque three weeks ago.

title: A.T.P. Fines Edberg, Lendl and Agassi
description: Stefan Edberg, Ivan Lendl and Andre Agassi were fined substantial amounts by the Association of Tennis Professionals Tour yesterday for failing to play in the required number of tournaments this year.

title: Early Vocal Music
description: Anonymous 4, an early-music vocal quartet, is to sing music by Johannes Ockeghem at St. Michael's Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 99th Street, tonight at 8. The works on the program were composed for the royal chapel at the French court between 1460 and 1497. Tickets are $10. Information: 781-7737.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday showing highlights of clean air legislation misstated a provision on chemical damage to the protective ozone layer. The ban on hydrochlorofluorocarbons in aerosol cans and other products by Jan.1, 1994, does not apply to foam insulation.

title: Durban Journal; Democracy Is Foretold and a Black Is Its Prophet
description: Oscar D. Dhlomo was quietly approached by Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha in September and invited to become the next South African Ambassador to the United States. Mr. Dhlomo was flattered but not tempted by the chance to be his country's first black diplomat.

title: Bush Tries to Quell G.O.P. Rebellion
description: Hoping to reverse weeks of damage to his political standing, President Bush embarked today on an effort to quell the rebellion in the Republican Party and to blame the Democrats for the tax increases blessed by Mr. Bush himself as part of the bipartisan budget deal.

title: Heritage Media Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 2.8 million writeoff of deferred finance costs and a $ 975,000 writedown of broadcast barter receivables.

title: Berthold Lubetkin; Architect, 88, Led In Modernist School
description: Berthold Lubetkin, an architect who played a leading role in founding the Modernist school in Britain in the 1930's, died on Tuesday in Bristol, England. He was 88 years old.

title: 4th-Largest Credit-Card Unit on Sale
description: The fourth-largest credit-card business in the country was put up for sale yesterday. Its owner, the largest banking company in Maryland, is raising cash to compensate for heavy losses on commercial real estate loans.

description: The 1989 results included the 9 months' results from BancTexas Dallas N.A., which was then a subsidiary of BancTexas Group.

title: Raychem Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Church & Dwight Co., Princeton, N.J., a maker of sodium products and detergents, said its board had authorized the intermittent buyback of up to a million additional common shares. * Cooper Cos., Palo Alto, Calif., which develops optometric products, has acquired substantially all of the assets of Spectra Pharmaceutical Services Inc., Hanover, Mass., a maker of ophthalmic drugs. Terms were not disclosed. * FPL Group Inc., the holding company for Florida Power and Light Co., Miami, said it would write down its investment in its insurance unit, Colonial Penn Group Inc., and three other non-utility subsidiaries. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, said its new Saturn cars officially went on sale yesterday. G.M. will also temporarily close plants in Michigan and Indiana because of low demand for its light trucks. Nearly 10,000 workers will be affected. The shutdowns take effect Monday. * Ivaco Inc., Montreal, a maker of steel and other products, has closed its sale of all outstanding shares of Niagra Lockport Quebec Industries Inc. and Niagra Lockport Industries Inc. The sale was to units of BTR P.L.C., London, a maker of industrial and energy products, for $85 million. * Maytag Corp., Newton, Iowa, has named William R. Foust, senior vice president of human resources, as managing director of its Hoover unit in Britain. He succeeds Anthony Williamson. * McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, said KLM Royal Dutch Airlines had taken options on five more MD-11 aircraft. Earlier this year, KLM took firm orders on 10 MD-11 aircraft for about $1.3 billion. * Pit Stop Auto Centers Inc., Oklahoma City, said its board had rejected a proposal by Grease Monkey Holding Corp., Denver, an operator of auto-lubricator services, to acquire Pit Stop in a stock swap. * Tambrands Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a maker of personal-care products, will sell its headquarters to Astoria Federal Savings Bank. No terms were disclosed. Tambrands will remain in Lake Success until it moves to a new headquarters in Westchester County next year. * Tosco Corp., Santa Monica, Calif., a petroleum products company, said its board had authorized the acquisition of up to an additional two million common share equivalents from time to time. * Turkish Airlines, Istanbul, will lease 10 new Boeing Co. 737-400's. The airline will obtain the aircraft under long-term lease-purchase arrangements from two leasing companies, GPA Group Ltd. of Ireland and International Lease Finance Corp., Beverly Hills, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Review/Art; Adrian Piper's Head-On Confrontation of Racism
description: If the fall season in New York can be said to belong to one artist, that artist is Adrian Piper. For some months now, her images and words about race and racism seem to have been everywhere: in galleries, in museums and in all kinds of publications. Her current exhibition of work on paper at Exit Art in SoHo is the second she has had in New York this fall (the first was at the John Weber Gallery). Her ambitious new video installation, "Out of the Corner," at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is based on "Cornered," a video that was shown at John Weber in March 1989 and at the New Museum of Contemporary Art last summer.

title: Imperial Chemical Industries Plc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for all periods have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $ 1.87 to the pound, the rate prevailing on Sept. 30, 1990.Share earnings are in American Depositary Receipts (ADR) and four I.C.I. 1 pound ordinary shares are represented by each ADR.The latest periods' results included extraordinary items.

title: Older Doesn't Mean Wiser
description: While some professors, like some wines, improve with age, there is little question that productivity and quality peak before 70, when most professors are required by law to retire. On Jan. 1, 1994, however, the retirement age at American colleges and universities, will be "uncapped." This would be a grave mistake.

title: Fidelity Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.F.L. Matchups: Week 8; Wyche and Glanville Square Off on Sunday
description: Sam Wyche, the Cincinnati Bengals' head coach, has a knack of becoming a storm center. From his no-huddle offense to his snatching a microphone at a home game last season and instructing the Cincinnati fans to stop throwing garbage because "you don't live in Cleveland" to his grabbing the banner in the women-in-the-locker-room issue, Wyche speaks his mind and loves to get involved. He practices the same philosophy in his tireless efforts to help the homeless in Cincinnati.

Court Asked to Rule Judge Guilty of Speech Curb
description: The Essex County Executive today asked a Federal judge to rule that New Jersey's Chief Justice violated the First Amendment when he refused to allow the producers of "Bonfire of the Vanities" to film scenes for the movie in the Essex County Courthouse.

title: Indians in Connecticut Get Casino Gambling
description: A 200-member Indian tribe in eastern Connecticut has reached a compact with the state permitting casino gambling on its reservation, including blackjack, poker and roulette, at whatever stakes the tribes chooses, beginning as early as next July.

title: Picket Signs and Cheers As Drivers Go on Strike
description: Looking grim, Michael Alvino, the head of the drivers' union at The Daily News, put a bullhorn to his lips last night to speak to more than 100 angry production workers outside the newspaper's Brooklyn plant. "This is not a happy day," he began. But the workers cheered when, moments later, he said, "We're officially on strike."

title: Lemieux's Rare Disease
description: Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguins' star center, is being treated for a rare bone infection that often leads to debilitating pain and cripples some of its victims.

title: Sam Dolgoff, 88, Dies; Organizer for I.W.W.
description: Sam Dolgoff, one of the few surviving members of the Industrial Workers of the World, a radical labor organization, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: Heritage Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In Last Days, Congress Acts on Blizzard of Bills
description: There was a now-or-never fervor on Capitol Hill today, and Congress responded with a burst of activity typical of the final days of a Congressional session.
