title: Under the Small Top in the Big Apple
description: When the Small Top comes to town today, it will not be circus as usual. The 140,000 people who flock to the Big Apple Circus in its billowy blue tent at Lincoln Center this season will be seeing the most ambitiously mounted extravaganza in the troupe's 13-year history: a lovingly re-created tribute to the one-ring European circuses of a century ago.

title: Power Play Falters a Bit But Devils Still Prevail
description: Except for the power-play units, which failed six times, all the other facets worked effectively for the Devils in tonight's game against the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Charges Dropped in Police Case
description: Criminal charges were dismissed yesterday against a Manhattan book editor who said she had been handcuffed, detained and harassed by police officers last month after criticizing them for taunting a taxi driver, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said.

title: Tax Protest, Fueled by Talk Shows, Is Getting Steamed Voters Organized
description: Mary Rothing, a housewife in Yonkers, says taxes have soared so high that "they're not taxes, they're extortion." So when she heard on Bob Grant's radio talk show about a big tax protest, she called the toll-free number -- 1-800-BE-ANGRY -- and signed right up. So, it appears, have a lot of other people.

title: Miami Journal; The Big Uproar Over Little Havana
description: Mercedes Rodri guez, a clerk, and Willy A. Bermello, a prominent architect, both showed up at a rowdy meeting of the Miami City Commission last week. Both spoke fervently about Little Havana, the neighborhood where they had begun their exiles from Cuba many years ago.

title: Avnet Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
THE 1990 Campaign; Races to Watch: An Update
description: Major races around the nation that polls how to be close or nearly even. CALIFORNIA GOVERNOR No one issue is the central battleground. A debate was canceled last night because the federal budget battle has kept Senator Pet Wilson, the Republican, in Washington. Another debate with Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat, is unlikely, so the main factor in the final days will be a new barrage of television advertising. FLORIDA GOVERNOR Lawton Chiles, a Democratic and former United States Senator, is running an anti-big money, anti-special interest campaign. The incumbent, Bob Martinez, a Republican, is using an expensive television campaign that portrays him as a dynamic governor from humble beginnings who can admit he made mistakes. MASSACHUSETTS GOVERNOR Things are turning nasty. John R. Silber, the Democrat, has accused his Republican opponent, William F. Weld, "back stabbing" for having left the Justice Department to protest the policies and leadership of Edwin Meese 3d. Mr. Weld is calling the Democratic a "Dr. Know-It-All" who is doing nothing bu "spewing venom." The economy remains the key issue. Mr. Weld supports a mandatory cut in taxes; Mr. Silber opposes it. NORTH CAROLINA SENATOR Harvey Gantt, the Democrat, has matched Jesse Helms, the three-term Republican incumbent, in fund raising over the past three months and has managed to do what none of Mr. Helms' other opponents have done - put him on the defensive on issues like education and the environment. TEXAS GOVERNOR The Democrat, Ann Richards, who was behind when she was short on funds, raised enough money to keep her ads on television. Clayton Williams, the Republican, seems to have trouble painting the race as a clear-cut choice between a conservative and a liberal.

title: At the Bar; An in-gathering of quotations from Marx (Groucho) to Musmanno on the profession.
description: Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. leads the hit parade, with Learned Hand and Benjamin Cardozo at his heels. But also represented are Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr., Woody Allen, Woody Guthrie, John Brown, Samuel Goldwyn, Art Buchwald, Groucho (and Chico) Marx, Albert Einstein, George S. Patton and Willie Sutton.

title: Months of Stalled Talks, Years of Rising Troubles
description: The labor dispute at The Daily News flared up after 10 months of stalled negotiations. But the paper's troubles had been brewing for years.

Quayle Promotes Limit On Lawmakers' Terms
description: Vice President Dan Quayle campaigned against Congress in the Philadelphia suburbs today, appealing to 1,000 people outside the Delaware County Courthouse to send Republicans to Washington. Mr. Quayle spoke favorably of limiting the terms of lawmakers.

title: Review/Photography; In Search of Perfection, Composites From the 60's
description: The best works of art accumulate interpretations over time, meaning one thing to one generation and something entirely different to another. This is the case with Ray K. Metzker's composites: montaged works consisting of strips of images that are often overlapped or double-exposed.

title: Critic's Notebook; Cheap Thrills and Fantasy From the Drive-In Era
description: OF all the silly images to be seen in American movies from the 1950's, few are more ridiculous than the 20-year-old Michael Landon made up for the title role in the 1957 cult film "I Was a Teen-Age Werewolf." Nowadays, the sight of Mr. Landon terrorizing the campus of Rockdale High School wearing khakis, a basketball jacket and a fanged werewolf mask doesn't so much conjure horror as suggest a Halloween reveler having a tantrum the morning after trick or treat because his head mask has stuck to his neck.

title: Sighting of Largest Galaxy Hints Clues on the Clustering of Matter
description: Astronomers have identified what they think is the largest galaxy ever observed, more than 60 times the size of the Milky Way. They believe that in its tremendous mass they may find clues to forces responsible for the clustering of matter in the universe.

title: New Group Makes the Case for Black Agencies and Media
description: SOME of the biggest black-owned advertising agencies and media companies have formed a trade organization, the African American Marketing and Media Association, hoping to increase advertising to black audiences, alter what it sees as stereotyping and find more work for its members.

description: James (Buster) Douglas was taller and heavier, his 246 pounds at Wednesday's weigh-in evidently much too heavy. But at 208 pounds, Evander Holyfield never blinked.

title: Breckenridge Ski
description: The Breckenridge Ski Corporation plans to nearly double its ski acreage in a 10-year plan costing about $75 million. The effort calls for the ski area to add 1,400 skiable acres to its 1,600 acres of skiing. The expansion would be able to accommodate 18,000 skiers a day, compared with 11,000 now. Besides adding the acreage, the plan calls for upgrading ski lifts and adding more of them, including an elevated rail system. Breckenridge is in the Colorado Rockies about 80 miles west of Denver.

description: PRESIDENT BUSH and the leaders of Congress have decided to end the bruising battle of the budget, though some right-wing guerrillas have vowed to take to the woods and go on fighting against any tax increases as long as they can hold out. But the President and Congressional leaders have grown increasingly wary of the anger of voters over the inability to reach agreement on governing the nation's finances. And they are worried about the danger that the protracted political warfare poses for the weakened national economy.

title: Images of a Self-Built Muscle Man
description: A QUESTION that immediately arises upon first seeing the photographic exhibition of Arnold Schwarzenegger, the muscle person, is: Can he walk? Do all those bumps and ridges and swellings and shimmering veins inhibit him in an ambulatory way? Or, when he is finished striking a pose, do a few people pick him up like a statue and transport him to another room?

title: Tibetan Bowls
description: The Tibetan Singing Bowl Ensemble is to perform Raphael Mostel's "Music for the October Moon," "Wyrd" and "Wave" at Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, on Sunday at 5 and 8 P.M. The ensemble's instrumentation includes Tibetan bowls and thighbone trumpets, a shofar and other ancient wind and percussion instruments. Tickets are $15 to $20. Information: 355-6160.

title: Merchants Bank of New York reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' per share earnings were adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split paid May 30, 1990.

title: Baker Standing Tall As a Giants Starter
description: In a world of 6-foot-5-inch, 290-pound behemoths, Stephen Baker is almost a put-on. He is 5-8 and, after dinner, maybe 160 pounds. When he was randomly chosen for a National Football League steroid test, a deterrent to indiscreet muscle-building, his teammates laughed.

title: RHNB Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eastern Chief Sees Break-Even Date
description: Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the court-appointed trustee running Eastern Airlines, said the carrier could break even by February. The Miami Herald reported on Wednesday that he had said Eastern's push for business travelers had "taken off like a rocket ship."

title: Heartfed Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Home Resales Decline 8%
description: Sales of existing homes in September fell 8 percent, to their lowest level in nearly three years, a real estate trade group said today. It attributed the decline to faltering consumer confidence in the economy.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Can

title: Review/Film; Sexy Corpse, Silly Siblings And a Tryst
description: What's even funnier than a corpse? According to "Sibling Rivalry," it's the sexy corpse of a long-lost brother-in-law, who spends his last moments creating a whopping problem for the formerly very nice Marjorie Turner (Kirstie Alley). Urged by her sister Jeanine (Jami Gertz) to cheat on her neglectful husband Harry (Scott Bakula), Marjorie obediently allows herself to be picked up for a hotel-room tryst by a stranger in a grocery store. A film with a premise like this is either uproarious or, like the brother-in-law, dead.

title: Pakistan's Choices, America's Interests
description: Even in a fair election, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto might have failed to win vindication in Pakistan. But her decisive defeat in Wednesday's vote also owed a good deal to her opponents' desperate tactics. A caretaker Government tried to disqualify her and poured money into swing voting districts. And she was unfairly assailed as favoring American meddling when a group of U.S. senators signed a letter urging that she be given a chance to run in a free election.

title: Alliant Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included charges totalling $ 24.8 million from writedown of investment in subsidiary and other assets.c-Net income

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 282,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 16,254,000, or 51 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The year also included a pretax gain of $ 10,998,000, or 27 cents a share, from the sale of equity interest in Agrion Corp.

title: Unum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Backing Bloodshed in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Cohu Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Oct. 17 about the endowment of Macalester College included an erroneous account provided by the college about the ownership of newly available assets. The assets -- 7.7 million shares of Reader's Digest stock and $50 million in cash, for a total value of some $254 million -- remain in the DeWitt Wallace Fund for Macalester College, an independent organization. The assets do not belong to the college's endowment, although the income from them benefits the college.

title: Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income of $ 156 million, which included $ 59 million from settlement of busines interruption insurance policy.Year-ago revenue figure included $ 155 million from settlement of business interruption insurance policy.Share earnings for the latest quarter are after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Discover Card Certificates Are Priced by Dean Witter
description: A $500 million issue of pass-through certificates backed by Discover credit card receivables was priced yesterday through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Discover Card Services Inc. and Dean Witter are both units of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Warts and All, a Budget Victory
description: It took four months, a Government shutdown and the threat of two more, and the pressure of public disgust to get the job done. But now, finally, Congress is about to approve a credible and fair budget bill that will drive the deficit downward over the next five years.

title: Calmat Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains from ongoing property sales of $ 116,000 and $ 664,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; gains from disposal of real estate assets of $ 1,942,000 for the quarter and $ 9,715,000 for the 9 months; non-taxable gain of $ 47,310,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and income from discontinued CPC operations of $ 694,000 and $ 3,089,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included gains from ongoning property sales of $ 3,023,000 and $ 8,085,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; gains from disposal of real estate assets of $ 204,000 for the quarter and $ 3,009,000 for the 9 months, and income from discontinued operations of $ 2,288,000 for the quarter and $ 8,268,000 for the 9 months.Revenues for the latest and year-earlier quarters excluded revenues of California Portland Cement (CPC).

title: Yemen's Chief Assails Saudis On Gulf Crisis
description: The President of Yemen criticized Saudi Arabia today for inviting American-led forces into the kingdom and accused Riyadh of trying to undermine his country's stability by enacting measures that have forced more than 500,000 Yemenis to leave Saudi Arabia and return home.

title: Japanese in Disarray Over Sending Troops to Gulf
description: Ten days after submitting legislation to send Japanese troops to the Persian Gulf, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Government has been thrown into disarray by widespread public opposition to the measure and growing indications that it will be rejected by Parliament.

title: Pulse Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Anchor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $ 3,403,000, or 20 cents a share.c-Net lossPer share figure reflected preferred dividend requirements.

title: Review/Film; When Soap Opera Imitates Life
description: To the imagination they are glamorous, impetuous, torn by forbidden passions. To the eye they are plump, dull, sedentary and by turns either bewildered or bored. These are the radio stars of "Tune In Tomorrow," a film that plays stylishly and at times ingeniously with the marriage of fiction and reality, a marriage it sees as fundamental to the creation of art. The film itself puts this somewhat more succinctly when Pedro Carmichael (Peter Falk), the flamboyant writer, declares: "Art is two cannibals on a desert island. Eat or be eaten."

title: The Founders Dreamt of a Classless Society; In Rich Company
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruno A. Marangoni, Cardiologist, 83
description: Dr. Bruno A. Marangoni, an internist and cardiologist, died on Tuesday at the Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: O New York: You're Mostly Still Fun, but Oh, So Costly
description: ALL the best songs about New York extol the little pleasures, those carefree, madcap things that lovers do. There are, for instance, potato chips, moonlight and motor trips. People still sing about New York, but one wonders whether the city can still be enjoyed for a song.

title: Ex-Owner Of S.& L. Is Indicted
description: The former owner of the Western Savings Association, who led the Texas institution through a period of stunning growth in high-risk ventures, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on 37 charges of bank fraud, misuse of funds and conspiracy. The failure of the savings institution is likely to cost taxpayers more than $1 billion.

title: Thorn Apple Valley reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 14
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 884,000, or 29 cents a share.c-Net loss

title: Bankers First Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Political Warfare in Japan
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has been battered by domestic criticism of his proposal to send Japanese troops to the Persian Gulf. Page A10.

title: Inspiration Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included non-cash charge of $ 16.5 million primarily related to closure of an offshore gold mining project.c-Included charge of $ 5.3 million from a product damage claim and clean-up of a chemical fire.The company said third-quarter results included a $ 16.5 million loss from the company's stake in a gold affiliate, compared with a loss of $ 1 million in year-ago period.

title: Ogden Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pre-tax gain on sale of stock by consolidated subsidiary of $ 25,580,000.

title: Brite Voice Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said third quarter results were affected by the continued lack of large system orders, and the settlement of litigation with 900 Service Inc. which caused a pre-tax charge of about $ 463,000 in the quarter.

title: Airlines Curbing Passengers Who Skirt Rules to Cut Fare
description: Like thousands of savvy fliers, Ronald Gelfuso knows that in the topsy-turvy world of air fares a longer flight can be cheaper than a shorter one. The New York fashion executive regularly saved $500 round trip by buying a ticket to San Antonio when he was going only as far as the first stop on the route, Dallas.

title: Bic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 464,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 962,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Moody's Upgrades Debt of Duquesne
description: The rating on about $2 billion of debt issued by the Duquesne Light Company, Pittsburgh, was raised yesterday by Moody's Investors Service Inc.

title: Firstbank of Illinois Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Acme Steel Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INSIDE
description: Resistance to Dinkins On Cutting the Budget On a day of confusion at City Hall, Mayor David N. Dinkins's effort to cut the city's budget by more than $1 billion encountered resistance.

title: Bhutto's Foes Win a Strong Majority
description: When final results were tallied today in an election that former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto had hoped to win to vindicate herself after her dismissal in August, her opponents in the Islamic Democratic Alliance had claimed a clear majority, with 105 seats in the National Assembly.

title: The Founders Dreamt of a Classless Society
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Securities Prices Up Slightly
description: With a batch of weak economic data and Congress approaching agreement on a new Federal budget, credit market participants were persuaded to buy Treasury securities yesterday. Another sharp rise in oil prices was all but ignored.

title: Church & Dwight reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pretax gains from disposal of product lines of $ 3,130,000 and $ 4,008,041 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included pretax loss of $ 6,400,000 from disposal of product lines and pretax gain of $ 3,055,267 from sale of equity investment.

title: J. F. Davis, 50, Dies; Lawyer Was Editor Of Amsterdam News
description: John F. Davis, a former deputy executive director of the Department of City Planning and former executive editor of The New York Amsterdam News, died on Monday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Harlem.

title: On Job Rights Bill, a Vow to Try Again in January
description: In the wake of the Senate's failure to override President Bush's veto of a major job discrimination bill, the measure's backers said today that they would introduce an even stronger version of the legislation when Congress reconvenes next January.

title: JWP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago periods were restated to include the results of Neeco Inc., acquired in July on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Xerox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 375,000,000.Latest 9-month net loss per share is after payment of preferred dividends.The company said its first 9-month income reflected the impact of the discontinuation of real estate operations in the first quarter.

title: Peter Gurtler, Vienna Hotel Owner, 44
description: Peter Gurtler, the owner of Vienna's most famous hotel and former husband of a former American Ambassador to Austria, Helene Von Damm, committed suicide on Wednesday, the police reported. He was 44 years old

title: NOTEBOOK: Breeders' Cup; Trainers Favor Local Jockeys
description: More than half of the 42 jockeys who will ride the 91 horses in the seven Breeders' Cup races at Belmont Park have only one mount on the card.

title: Experts Expect Stimulus to Economic Morale but Little Else
description: The budget agreement now before Congress might make the hard times engulfing the American economy slightly harder next year, economists say. But the damage will probably be too small to measure.

title: Sonat Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 6 million, or 14 cents a share, related to the settlement of Sea Robin's rate case. Results in the 9 months also included $ 6 million, or 15 cents a share, from the redemption of a debenture of the Coastal Corp.c-Included $ 34 million, or 83 cents a share, related to the settlement of Southern Natural Gas Co.'s rate case.

title: D&N Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeD&N said earnings for the latest third quarter were offset by a $ 5.3 million addition to its loan loss reserves.

title: Tenneco Net Edges Up 1%
description: Tenneco Inc. said today that its profit rose 1 percent in the third quarter, and it predicted lower fourth-quarter earnings than last year.

title: Holyfield Flattens Douglas and Takes the Title
description: Skinny legs or not, Evander Holyfield proved he was enough of a heavyweight tonight.

title: Clues Sought in Bronx Killing
description: Detectives searching for the killer of 10-year-old Jessica Guzman are looking again at the unsolved murders of four other young people found suffocated in lonely spots along Bronx highways in the last two years, hunting for a common thread.

title: 10 Writers Receive $30,000 Awards
description: Ten American writers were named winners of the 1990 Whiting Writers' Awards last night, for which each will receive $30,000. The annual awards are in recognition of writing achievement and writing promise.

title: Staten Islanders Brace for Vote on Secession
description: Waiting in line to drive onto the Staten Island ferry and go home, Gene Redondo drummed his fingers on his steering wheel and offered one indisputable fact about the island's referendum on secession that will take place Nov. 6. "Maybe it won't lead to secession," Mr. Redondo said, "but it will at least excite people to pay more attention to us."

title: Interlake Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included unusual charges of $ 6,368,000 for the quarter and $ 13,180,000 for the 9 months, related to planned divestitures, relocation costs and settlement of a lawsuit; the 9 months also included a loss of $ 8,908,000 from discontinued operations.c-Included a loss of $ 1,146,000 for the quarter and income of $ 265,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The periods also included unusual charges of $ 23,395,000 for the quarter and $ 24,049,000 for the 9 months, related to planned divestitures, restructuring and stock incentive costs.d-Net incomeThe year-ago periods were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Whistleblower Details Harassment on S.& L.
description: A former Federal examiner recounted today in vivid detail how she was harassed by superiors and ultimately dismissed for raising questions two years ago about the financial condition of a large savings and loan that regulators tried unsuccessfully to take over.

title: Simpson and Norman Charge to the Lead
description: The PGA Tour's hottest golfer and its richest both took an aggressive step toward the most lucrative prize in golf today in the first round of the Nabisco Championships, the season finale.

title: Review/Film; Crusading Journalist, or a Man Obsessed?
description: For a time in the 1970's, big-name journalists took on the aura of movie stars and enrollments at journalism schools soared. Students discovered soon enough that the drudgery of reporting far outweighs the drama, but even now most people envision Bob Woodward as Robert Redford in "All the President's Men."

title: Advanta Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 2,18,000 from the repurchase of debt for the quarter, and an extraordinary tax credit, as well as extinguishment of debt of $ 3,268,000 for the 9 months.

title: Court Orders Cook County To Allow Third Party Slate
description: With less than two weeks before the Nov. 6 election, the United States Supreme Court ordered officials here today to rewrite the ballot in Cook County and include a third-party slate of black candidates barred earlier by the Illinois Supreme Court.

title: Samuel Horowitz, Rabbi, 72
description: Rabbi Samuel Horowitz, retired spiritual leader of Temple Zion in Long Beach, L.I., died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: First National Corp. (San Diego, Calif.) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: HOPE SEEN IN CURB FOR LYME DISEASE
description: Researchers at Yale University say they have used a gene-engineering technique to develop a vaccine that protects mice against Lyme disease.

title: Top Albania Writer Seeks Asylum In France, a Blow to His President
description: A prominent Albanian writer announced in Paris today that he was seeking political asylum in France.

title: More Arabian Tales
description: Now let us please resume our studies of the Tales of the Arabian Nights.

title: Coleman, Landed by Nets, Finally Touches Down in Jersey
description: Derrick Coleman strolled through Newark Airport tonight and said he was glad that his days of playing basketball by himself were over.

New Lawyer Requested in Jogger Trial
description: The family of a defendant in the second Central Park jogger trial is seeking to replace its lawyer with C. Vernon Mason, a move that is likely to mean a much more confrontational defense and an aggressive cross-examination of the victim.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Atlantic American reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: It was a typical day's Babel of self-determination in the Soviet Union.

title: Delta Air Lines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $ 76,000 from the disposition of aircraft parts and a gain of $ 11,000 from foreign currency translation.c-Net income and included a gain of $ 3,747,000, or 7 cents a share, from the disposition of aircraft parts and a gain of $ 1,000 from foreign currency translation.

title: Puerto Rican Cement Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Soviets to Contribute $200 Million to Plan On U.S. Accelerator
description: The Soviet Union has agreed in principle to contribute $200 million for an instrument proposed for use with the Superconducting Supercollider particle accelerator, which is scheduled to be completed in Texas in the next decade.

title: Karpov, After Delay, Accepts Draw in Game 6
description: Gary Kasparov waited until 11:45 A.M. yesterday to offer Anatoly Karpov a draw in the adjourned Game 6 of the World Championship Chess Match, but his overnight efforts to squeeze blood out of a stone evidently came to nothing. Karpov, who had been under attack, accepted, of course, but only after delaying until 2:05 P.M. The score is now: Kasparov 3 1/2, Karpov 2 1/2.

title: BSB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 272,000 after tax, or 9 cents a share, for the latest period, and $ 707,000 after tax, or 23 cents a share, for year-ago period, resulting from loan recoveries related to settlements of the Boardwalk Marketplace litigation of 1986.

title: Home Port Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sounds of Ethiopia

title: Herr Signs With Mets For $1.4 Million Pact
description: Reluctant to offer him salary arbitration, the Mets reached agreement with Tom Herr last night on a one-year contract for $1.4 million.

title: American Ecology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $ 1,313,000 for the quarter and $ 3,937,000 for the 9 months.

title: Downstairs, Chess, but Upstairs a World-Class Kibitzer Match
description: The evening had the feel of a Manhattan cocktail party, with famous people and scintillating banter amid the canapes and clinking glasses. Around the room were some of the great chess luminaries, former world and national champions, and celebrity fans like the film director Milos Forman and the Spanish anarchist-playwright Fernando Arrabel.

title: Big East and S.W.C. Talk Football
description: The commissioners of the Big East and the Southwest Conference will meet in Dallas today to discuss plans for football competition between the two leagues. Fred Jacoby, the commissioner of the Southwest Conference, and Mike Tranghese, the new Big East commissioner, will hold preliminary meetings on scheduling football games between the eight S.W.C. schools and the four Big East schools that play Division I-A football.

title: Gleason Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 824,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 1,965,000, or 34 cents a share, for the 9 months.c-After a loss of $ 690,000 for the quarter and income of $ 5,227,000, or 92 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.Latest quarter's loss from continuing operations of $ 141,000 included an after-tax charge of $ 1,400,000 for early retirement and severance programs.Year-ago quarter's income from continuing operations of $ 2,203,000, or 38 cents a share, included an after-tax gain of $ 1,150,000, or 20 cents a share, from the sale of a building.The company sold its power systems division to Diesel Kiki Co. of Japan in June 1989. The results for the division and the gain of $ 7,725,000, or $ 1.35 a share, from the sale of the division are included as discontinued operations for the 1989 9-month period.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 519 money market mutual funds decreased $673.1 million, to $414.44 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds increased by $10.5 million, to $102.94 billion. The assets of the 255 general-purpose funds were down $478.3 million, to $146.3 billion. The 104 broker-dealer funds decreased by $205.3 million, to $165.20 billion, the institute said.

title: BCE Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued real estate operations of $ 20 million and $ 43 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.The company said its third-quarter results included a net provision of $ 224 million against loans with a net carrying value of $ 350 million to Kinburn Corp., and against a common share investment of $ 50 million in SHL Systemhouse, a subsidiary of Kinburn. It said the provision reduced the carrying value of the investments to $ 63 million.The company also said the results reflect a gain of $ 120 million after taxes from the sale of units in TransCanada Pipelines and $ 44 million on reduction of its interest in BCE Mobile.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There will be squabbling, shouts and table pounding tonightfri and tomorrow night when a dozen defense lawyers give free rein to their theatrical inclinations. Instead of playing to the jury, they'll play the jury, in a benefit performance of Reginald Rose's 1955 courtroom drama, "Twelve Angry Men," at the New York University School of Law.

title: Tuning In on College Radio Bands at Clubs Around Town
description: The college-radio industry is something like a small town: it's an insular, self-sufficient community with its own trends, rules, economy and morality. Within that community, there are different subgroups of musicians who find different ways of addressing what they feel is their particular audience. This weekend, the College Media Journal Music Marathon, an annual convention focusing on college-radio issues, brings dozens of college-radio bands to clubs throughout New York City. Some of them, like Redd Kross and Bob Mould, are favorites on the scene; others, like the Shams and Blackbird, are still at its fringes.

title: Doctors Perform Parent-to-Child Lung Transplant
description: In a historic operation that could offer new hope to parents of premature babies and children with severe lung disease, including cystic fibrosis, doctors at Stanford University Medical School in California have transferred a portion of a mother's lung to her dying 12-year-old daughter.

title:
MANHATTAN CONVERSIONS;
In a 12-Story Building, 3 'Town Houses'
description: Converting a 12-story, 12-unit Park Avenue apartment building into three town house-style residences with a common lobby may sound like a far-fetched idea. But just such a project is under way at 813 Park Avenue, between 74th and 75th Streets.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARGARITA PENON DE ARIAS, the wife of OSCAR ARIAS SANCHEZ, a former president of Costa Rica and a Nobel Peace Prize winner, has announced she will run for the Costa Rican presidency in 1994. Mrs. Arias, 41 years old, made the announcement in San Jose on Wednesday in a television interview.

title: Review/Theater; Edwardian Transplant From England to Boston
description: Devotees of television's prime-time disasters may well recall "Beacon Hill," the 1975 CBS series that tried to knock off public television's hit English import "Upstairs Downstairs" for fun and profit. Though lavishly produced with the best New York character actors that network capital could buy, "Beacon Hill" died a sorry Nielsen death in 13 weeks. The rigorous class distinctions of the British social order looked silly when superimposed even on the snootiest neighborhood of democratic Boston. As Sally Bedell Smith reports in her new biography of the CBS chairman William S. Paley ("In All His Glory," Simon & Schuster), network surveys revealed that "the American public just didn't believe that one household could have that many servants."

title: Drivers Strike at The Daily News, Ande Most Unions Honor Walkout
description: The 700-member newspaper deliverers' union local struck The Daily News last night, setting off a climactic labor showdown with the management of the financially ailing paper, the nation's second largest metropolitan daily.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Anita O'Day at Night

title: Robin Chu, Legislator And a Sociologist, 71
description: Robin Chu, a sociologist and a member of Parliament in Taiwan, died on Wednesday at the Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Taipei, customarily spending six months of the year in each city.

title: Arizona Commerce Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hitox Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said lower year-to-date earnings were due to softer demand for Hitox pigment and to a $ 500,000 writedown in the first quarter reflecting the discontinuance of zinc oxide operations in Spokane, Wash.

title: For Bruce Morrison in Connecticut
description: Republican Lowell Weicker, running as an independent, has complicated the contest for Governor of Connecticut. In 1988, he was defeated in his campaign for a fourth term in the Senate. Now, capitalizing on his popularity as a maverick, Mr. Weicker leads in the polls, but without clearly defining how he would govern.

title: Auctions
description: Poor Results in Two Sales

title: Xerox Profit Down 14.8%
description: The Xerox Corporation today reported a 14.8 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, partly because of a weak performance by the company's insurance and financial services businesses.

title: Rangers Run Home Winning Streak to 6
description: The night for the Rangers began with the streak at 5-0, a sequence of unblemished success at Madison Square Garden that owed itself to great goaltending, good fortune and inspired industry.

title: The French as They See Themselves
description: Fragile Glory A Portrait of France and the French By Richard Bernstein Maps. 349 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: 3 Lebanon Militias to Pull Out of Beirut, in Move to Aid Army
description: Lebanon's three major militias said today that they were ready to pull out of Beirut and its suburbs to help a Government plan to extend absolute army control over the capital, officials said.

title: St. Paul Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iraq Standing Firm, Soviets Tell U.N.
description: The Soviet Union told nonaligned Security Council members today that it does not believe that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is interested in a negotiated solution to the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Teradyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included charge of $ 2,009,000 related to severance costs from workforce reductions.c-Net income and included gain of $ 1,121,000 from sale of investment.

title: Review/Art; Baselitz and the Aftermath of War
description: Georg Baselitz, the German Neo-Expressionist known for painting his images upside down -- thereby challenging both his viewers and his own artistic skills -- is having his first New York exhibition of new work since 1987. It's a two-part affair divided between SoHo and 57th Street that inaugurates his new affiliation with the Pace Gallery. Unfortunately, the show is only one-part successful.

title: Framingham Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Key Rates
Financial World Will Give New York City Time for a Good Plan

Paul Wiesenfeld, Painter, 48
description: Paul Wiesenfeld, an American realist painter who specialized in portraits and finely detailed interiors, died on Saturday in a hospital in Munich, Germany. He was 48 years old and lived in Lanshut, a small town outside Munich.

title: Interchange Financial Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Accounts
description: * Billa-Heute, a food store chain in Austria, to Dr. Puttner & BSB, Austria, a unit of Backer Spielvogel Worldwide, New York, with a budget of $8 million to $10 million. * San-J International, a soy sauce-producing subsidiary of San Jirushi Corp., Kuwana, Japan, to Earle Palmer Brown, Richmond, for its industrial and food-service accounts. The agency's Atlanta office picked up CNET, Atlanta, a credit card processing company owned by the National Data Corp. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Fielder Joins Japan Tour
description: Cecil Fielder, who led the major leagues in 1990 with 51 homers after he played a season in Japan, was among 26 players named yesterday to go to Japan for an eight-game tour next month.

title: Greater New York Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $ 1,156,000, or 10 cents a share.c-After extraordinary tax loss carrforwards of $ 2,070,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 6,234,000, or 49 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Warren Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Weekend; Fearless Vampire Bats In 'National Geographic'
description: Are vampire bats, insects and snakes your cup of gore? If so, tune into "Halloween," the "National Geographic Explorer" hour on the TBS cable network at 9 P.M. on Sunday. It's an appetizer for the approaching spookery.

title: Jets Need Big Plays and Healthy Players
description: The clock was ticking in the last minute of the Jets' game against the Bills in Orchard Park, N.Y., on Sunday and unfolding on the field was one of those slow-motion scenes like the one from the movie "The Longest Yard."

title: California Republican Running Against Apple Pie
description: Ordinarily a four-term Republican incumbent like Representative Al McCandless could coast to re-election in this desert district, where Republicans outnumber Democrats by 47 to 44 percent and where the constituents include party stalwarts like Gerald R. Ford, Bob Hope, Frank Sinatra and Spiro T. Agnew.

title: U.N. Resolution on Israel
description: Following is the text of a resolution approved Wednesday night by the Security Council: THE SECURITY COUNCIL, REAFFIRMING the obligations of Member States under the United Nations Charter, REAFFIRMING ALSO its Resolution 672 (1990), HAVING BEEN BRIEFED by the Secretary General on Oct. 19, 1990, EXPRESSING ALARM at the rejection of Security Council Resolution 672 (1990) by the Israeli Government, and its refusal to accept the mission of the Secretary General, TAKING INTO CONSIDERATION the statement of the Secretary General relative to the purpose of the mission he is sending to the region and conveyed to the Council by the President on Oct. 12, 1990, GRAVELY CONCERNED at the continued deterioration of the situation in the occupied territories,

title: Detroit Says a Recount Puts It Over 1 Million
description: Canvassing by city workers and volunteers has yielded the names of more than 121,350 residents who say they were not counted by the 1990 census, Mayor Coleman A. Young announced today. If the number is accurate, it suggests that the preliminary population estimate for the city, 970,156, is 11 percent short.

title: Pan Am Had Route Inquiry By American
description: Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines, said yesterday that he would have paid more than United Airlines had to obtain Pan American World Airways' routes between the United States and London.

title: Plant Sale Aids Whirlpool Net
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said today that its third-quarter profits rose 27.6 percent but that the gain resulted from the sale of a Kentucky plant.

title: Cade Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included sales of $ 10,456,000 and a net loss of $ 26,000 from noncomposite businesses disposed of by the company in 1989.

title: Boston Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 15,824,000, or 41 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.Year-ago share earnings included gain of 14 cents a share from an eminent domain taking of certain company property.The accounting adjustment in the latest 9-month reflects the cumulative effect of a change in accounting priniciple to begin recording unbilled revenues, effective Jan. 1, 1990. The company said the accounting change provides a better matching of revenues and expenses by recording an estimate of customer usuage which is unbilled at the end of each month.

title: WLR Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: All figures reflected the acquisition of Cassco Ice & Cold Storage in April 1990, which is acquired for as a pooling of interests.The company said that after adjusting for the acquisition of Cassco Ice & Cold Storage in April 1990 and a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1990, year-ago second quarter net was $ 2,358,000, or 23 cents a share, on sales of $ 117,896,000; the company said its results for the second quarter this year are expected to be as strong.

title: Tandem Computers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Diamond-Star Plans New Cars
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan deepened their relationship today by saying they would build a new generation of cars at their joint-venture plant in Illinois.

title: Review/Music; Japan Philharmonic Tribute
description: The opening work on the Japan Philharmonic's program at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening, Toru Takemitsu's Requiem for String Orchestra, paid tribute to Akeo Watanabe, the orchestra's music director, who died three months ago at age 71. The son of a Japanese father and Finnish mother, Mr. Watanabe founded the ensemble and was for half a century a leading proponent of Western classical music in his country. The Japan Philharmonic, as a program note put it, is "his living monument."

title: Commercial Credit Prices New Notes
description: The Commercial Credit Corporation, a unit of the Primerica Corporation, yesterday priced $100 million in short-term notes due 1993 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Ohio Judge Dismisses Case Against Men Holding Hands
description: A judge has dismissed criminal charges against two men who were cited for holding hands in a parked car.

title: Inquiry Is Ordered Over Disclosure Of Data on Senators' S.& L. Ties
description: The Senate Ethics Committee announced today that it had ordered an investigation into the unauthorized release to the press of confidential committee documents in its inquiry of five Senators' ties to a savings and loan executive.

title: Miscellany
description: * Ivan Lendl will be the official spokesman for Snapple brand beverages, through a multiyear, million-dollar contract. Mr. Lendl will be featured in all television spots and promotional materials, and will wear a Snapple patch on the sleeve of his shirt during all tennis tournaments.

title: Crossing the 'T' in Taxes, Lawmakers Turn Eyes to Votes on Deficit Deal
description: With the end of the budget ordeal in sight, bleary-eyed lawmakers throughout the Capitol tied the last knots in a compromise tax and spending package today in preparation for votes Friday on the biggest deficit-reduction measure in history.

title: CFS Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; Mutual Funds Act To Bar Switchers
description: DECIDING that the fast money is not worth it, the nation's largest group of mutual funds, Fidelity Investments, has decided to begin treating some shareholders differently from others, refusing their buy orders if it believes they are following the recommendations of a market-timing service. Stein Roe & Farnham, a smaller group of funds, has taken a similar step.

title: Cal Rep Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In Pakistan, a Candidate Flees
description: Most news reports have interpreted the widespread presence of police and army units during the campaign and voting in Pakistan as evidence of generally impartial elections. According to one article, "reporters visiting a variety of polling sites in the hotly contested Punjab found few complaints of abuses or irregularities." Unfortunately, they missed Shakargarh.

title: Elmwood Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charges against net income for latest quarter of about $ 100,000 and for the 9 months about $ 125,000 in connection with canceled merger with Susquehanna Bancshares.

title: Bernstein at Camp

The company said 9-month results included realized gains of $ 126.8 million in 1990 and $ 19.8 million in 1989.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Fell Again in September
description: Magazine publishers anxious about ad dollars have received more bleak news: Advertising pages for magazines monitored by the Publishers Information Bureau continue to decline.

title: A NARROW ESCAPE FOR I.R.A. CAPTIVE
description: A Roman Catholic man said today that he thought he was driving to his death when gunmen of the Irish Republican Army strapped him into a van loaded with explosives and tailed him to a military base near Omagh.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * North Shore Gas Co., Chicago, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of $25 million in first-mortgage adjustable-rate bonds due 2020 through Edward D. Jones & Co. * Sears, Roebuck & Co., Chicago, filed for a shelf offering of up to $1 billion in debt securities to be sold from time to time. * Wackenhut Corp., Coral Gables, Fla., privately placed $25 million in senior unsecured notes due 2000 with two institutional investors.

description: b-Net income

title: Bird Is Sidelined
description: Larry Bird, who has had a strong preseason, will miss the next two games with a lower back strain but should return for the Boston Celtics' final preseason game Monday, the team said yesterday. The Celtics also announced the release of the forward Eric McArthur and the guard Carrick DeHart, two free agents from California-Santa Barbara. (AP)

title: Ruddick Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELDERLY SHIELDED FROM BIG INCREASE IN MEDICARE COSTS
description: House and Senate budget negotiators said today they had agreed on how to shield the elderly from any large increase in Medicare costs, one of the last outstanding issues in the deficit-reduction package Congress and the White House have been laboring on for nearly two months.

description: Net income per common share and average shares outstanding gave effect to the 2-for-1 stock split effective Dec. 1, 1989.Year-ago periods ended Sept. 30.

title: Tosco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: On June 30, 1989, the company completed its acquisition of Seminole Fertilizer Corp. (Seminole) for approximately $ 133.1 million, including transaction costs. Tosco accounted for the acquisition as a purchase; accordingly, the operations of Seminole have been included in Tosco's consolidated results of operations beginning July 1, 1989.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the effect of the budget compromise on people in various income brackets rendered a comment by Bruce Fisher, research director of the Citizens for Tax Justice, incorrectly in some copies. It should have read: "This House package makes the tax code more progressive for everyone except people who make the same amount of income as members of Congress. The plan would take money from the superrich in order to give a 2percent tax cut to those earning from $100,000 to $200,000." (He did not use the word "regressive.")

title: Advo-System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
State Lawmaker Is Found Guilty In a South Carolina Bribery Case
description: A Federal jury convicted State Representative Luther L. Taylor Jr. today on charges that he took $4,300 in bribes during a videotaped operation by undercover agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Keystone Heritage reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeYear-ago per share earnings were restated to reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: In Union Capital, War Among the Confederates
description: Four score and three years ago, at the historically incongruous address of 1322 Vermont Avenue N.W. in the heart of the Union capital, the Confederate Memorial Hall was established. As the aging rebel veterans who lived there died off, it became the museum and meeting place it remains today. There, looking down from faded amber portraits, Robert E. Lee, Jefferson Davis and Stonewall Jackson survey the legacy of the Lost Cause.

title: Carmike Cinemas Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wisconsin Energy Corp. reports earnings for 12mos to Sept 30
Price of Oil Surges by $3.17, Continuing on Erratic Path
description: Oil was up sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day, continuing on an erratic path.

title: Sending a $12.5 Million Message to a Hate Group
description: When jurors in Oregon assessed more than $12 million in damages against a white supremacist group and its leaders this week, they virtually indentured the leaders for the rest of their lives.

description: b-Net incomeThe company said that the losses included $ 44,000 in the quarter and $ 140,000 in the 9 months of unusual interest expense which arose in connection with the terms of the company's acquisition agreements in the U.K. and Germany.

title: Bailout Plan Is Approved
description: Federal regulators today approved a plan to sell or close about 192 failed savings and loan institutions.

title: Slovak Now Official Language
description: With thousands of angry nationalists besieging its building, the Slovak Parliament approved a bill tonight to make Slovak the official language of the Slovakia republic.

title: The Founders Dreamt of a Classless Society; Grow Up, America
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday on a brief article about the Japan Series, the championship of Japanese baseball, misidentified the winner. The Seibu Lions swept the Yomiuri Giants, four games to none.

title: Gen. Noriega: Though Out of Sight, He's Under More Scrutiny Than Ever
description: In the 10 months since his ouster as the leader of Panama, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has settled into the tedium of confinement at a suburban prison, his lawyers say. But even behind bars, the deposed dictator remains at the center of turmoil.

title: 'Cop Rock' Minus the Rock?
description: In an effort to improve ratings, ABC 's chief program executive suggested two weeks ago that the producer Steven Bochco consider dropping the rock from "Cop Rock," his much-praised but low-rated new series, which mixes police drama with musical numbers.

title: Restaurants
description: Long before bistromania held New York City in its clutches, Quatorze was packing them in down on 14th Street, where its shiny red door stood like a beacon on the seedy-looking stretch.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Troubles in 'Abundance'

title: India Sends Troops to Stop Hindu March
description: More than 150,000 paramilitary troops have been ordered to block Hindu nationalists from converging on the town of Ayodhya, where the marchers are demanding that a temple be built on a site now occupied by an Islamic shrine, a Government official said today.

title: Silicon General Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 59,000 and $ 75,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, not reflected in earnings a share due to rounding.

title: Mortgage Rates Drop
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.17 percent this week, down from 10.24 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.17 percent, down from 8.19 percent last week.

title: Navy Retires Battleship Iowa for Third Time
description: The battleship Iowa was decommissioned today, six years after she was taken out of mothballs for the second time and 18 eonths after a gun-turret explosion off Puerto Rico that killed 47 sailors.

title: DAILY NEWS DROPS UNION EMPLOYEES
description: The Daily News, struck by nine of its 10 unions, began dismissing most of its 2,400 unionized workers yesterday and then struggled to publish without them, gathering an army of nonunion employees, some from across the country, to write, edit, print and deliver the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily.

title: Yielding to Dinkins, School Board Agrees to Try for Deeper Cuts
description: After a tense meeting with Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Board of Education abandoned its resistance yesterday and agreed to seek the full $94 million in budget cuts requested by City Hall.

title: Celestine George Burke, Educator, 81
description: Brother Celestine George Burke, an educator who was a member of the Brothers of the Christian Schools for 63 years, died on Thursday at Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived at the Christian Brothers Academy in Lincroft.

title: Congressional Junket Is Filmed by TV Crew
description: While millions of Americans were spending last Easter weekend finishing their taxes, members of the House taxation committee were on a taxpayer-paid trip to Barbados -- on something like "Candid Camera."

title: Sprague Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a loss of $ 3.2 million from discontinued operations and a pretax charge of $ 39,200,000 related to restructuring.The net income for the year-ago quarter was breakeven after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,800,000.

title: Digital Systems International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AIDS, Abortion and Fairness
description: Being infected with the AIDS virus is tragic. It's more so for a pregnant woman; her fears for herself are compounded by the fear that she may pass on the virus. The City Commission on Human Rights now reports that many New York hospitals and clinics refuse to perform abortions on HIV-positive women, many of them poor minority members. That adds cruelty to tragedy.

title: Tibet's Borders Reach Beyond Beijing's Map; Against Their Will
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A listing by The Associated Press on Oct. 7 for the House of Representatives roll-call on a bill vetoed by President Bush -- to keep the Government running for a week and reopen agencies closed by the budget impasse -- misstated the positions of three California Republicans. Dana Rohrabacher, Norman D. Shumway and Bill Thomas indeed voted, to sustain the veto.

title: Loss Shown By Cummins In 3d Quarter
description: The Cummins Engine Company, citing a sharp decline in demand for its truck engines, said yesterday that it had a third-quarter loss of $33.7 million, compared with a loss of $39.7 million in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: Jail for Drunken Pilots
description: Three pilots who were intoxicated when they flew a Northwest Airlines jet were sentenced to a year or more in prison. "You are a good men who have done a bad thing," the judge told them. Page 6.

title: Intellicall Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hornbeck Offshore Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Reviews/Music; Clurman's Choral Group
description: The New York Concert Singers, a chamber choir started by Judith Clurman in 1988, offered its first program of the season at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening. As in seasons past, Miss Clurman offered a varied program that drew on the European literature but did not neglect contemporary American composers. This time, in fact, new music dominated.

title: Tax the 'Rich'? Just Who Are They?
description: To the Editor:

title: Anadarko Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Knicks Need Wilkins To Be More Consistent
description: Gerald Wilkins has been called many things in his career with the Knicks. He has been called talented. He has been called athletic. He has been called acrobatic.

title: BMW Lifts Prices
description: BMW of North America Inc. said its 1991 cars would cost an average 3.6 percent more than comparably equipped 1990 models. All of the West German-made luxury-performance cars will be covered by a four-year, 50,000-mile limited warranty, the company said. Prices for 1991 BMW cars range from $19,900 for the 318i to $73,600 for the 850i.

title: Uni-Marts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect 10-percent stock dividend paid Sept. 5.

title: Israeli Panel Faults Police Commanders, But Sees Provocation
description: A report published today by a Government commission on the stone-throwing and shooting deaths in Jerusalem's Old City this month sharply criticized senior Israeli police commanders, saying they had not adequately prepared for the possibility of trouble.

title: A Reminder
description: Standard time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow. Clocks are set back one hour.

title: Reviews/Music; Roy Hargrove's Youthful Jazz Trumpet
description: Roy Hargrove's set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night had youth going both for and against it. Mr. Hargrove, a 21-year-old trumpeter, is an explosive soloist with an infallible sense of time; piling phrases together, he can get an audience cheering midsolo. But in his tune selection -- jazz standards mostly -- and in the band's lack of arrangement, Mr. Hargrove puts himself in competition with the masters of the past. It is competition he is not quite ready for.

title: Surgical Care Affiliates reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Heritage Entertainment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said increased revenues reflect the acquisition of the Landmark and Seven Gables theater chains on June 29, 1989.

title: Independent Printers Provide Cheap Checks
description: Almost everyone has a personal checking account, but few people think about who prints their checks or what they cost. Now a battle is shaping up between banks and printers for control of the market, estimated at more than $1 billion a year.

title: NASA Weighs Mission to Correct Space Telescope's Blurred Vision
description: Under mounting pressure from astronomers, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is considering proposals for a repair mission by astronauts that could give full observational abilities to the malfunctioning Hubble Space Telescope.

title: Macy Says It Might Sell Sizable Stake to Trim Debt
description: R. H. Macy & Company told its investors yesterday that it might sell a more substantial stake in the debt-laden company than it had previously sold to other investors. Some speculation centered on a Hong Kong company as a possible buyer.

title: Curfew and Traffic Bans Set In Temple Dispute in India
description: Local officials tonight barred all traffic from roads leading to a site in northern India that is attracting Hindu fundamentalists intent on moving a Muslim mosque and beginning construction of a Hindu temple in its place by next Tuesday.

title: Ethicizationism
description: A new kind of bird is turning up on television. He is called an "ethicist." No television panel stewing over the rights and wrongs of public issues is complete these days without one.

title: 20 File for Free Agency
description: Zane Smith and Don Slaught, two players who were instrumental in the Pittsburgh Pirates' conquest of the Mets in the National League East, filed for free agency yesterday along with 18 other players.

title: Married With Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Lumex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: His Trainers Let Buster Be the Boss
description: On the morning after boxing's Humpty Dumpty heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, took a great fall, his trainers, J. D. McCauley and John Russell, were trying to put together what Evander Holyfield had put asunder. But the 246-pound dethroned champion's two trainers hadn't put him together in the first place because each was not what a trainer is supposed to be: the boss.

title: Tibet's Borders Reach Beyond Beijing's Map
description: To the Editor:

title: Fletcher Challenge Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $ 200,000 and $ 600,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Tokos Medical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Godfather III' Is Producing Unrest
description: Already the advertisements in the magazines and the trailers in the movie theaters are proclaiming that "The Godfather, Part III" is "coming soon." But in the corporate offices of Hollywood film studios and theater chains around the country, executives are asking only one question: how soon is soon?

title: Gulf States Utilities reports earnings for 12mos Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 205,015,000 from a litigation settlement and a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 21,783,000.c-Included a charge of $ 37,041,000 from an accounting adjustment.

(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Tentative Accord Reached on Child Care for Low-Income Families
description: House and Senate negotiators reached tentative agreement today on a measure that provides grants to states to subsidize child care programs and extends tax credits for low-income families with children.

title: Chronicle
description: PRESIDENT BUSH is doing his bit for the U.S.O. with a televised message that is being shown nationwide, starting yesterday. "At my request, they are putting together a massive effort to send caring and good cheer to our troops in the Middle East," Mr. Bush said of the 50-year old service organization. The President tells viewers to call (900) 820-2876 for more information. A call will cost $3, most of which will be given to the U.S.O., and will be charged to a caller's telephone bill.

title: Rabbit Software Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tuckahoe Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

Santa Anita Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Midway Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $ 1,174,000, or 11 cents a share, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: Patents; An Oriental Noodle Made More Cheaply
description: Americans have long nurtured a ravenous appetite for Chinese food. Now, an American chemical company wants to export a food idea back to Asia: a cheaper way to produce a popular Oriental noodle.

title: Ryan, Beck & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Opera; Trying to Unravel a Tangled Plot
description: Every new production of Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera" is an exercise in creative compromise, but the version presented by the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening was a reminder that too much exercise can be fatal. The Piero Faggioni staging, having begun with a feeble cliche (a commedia dell'arte troupe miming away during the overture), stumbled on to one absurdity after another. The intent may have been to straighten out a famously tangled scenario; the effect was to spotlight every inconsistency in one of the composer's greatest scores.

title: Reviews/Music; An Italian Festival Of Contemporary Work
description: Query an American, even a musically informed one, about contemporary Italian music, and after mention of a few works by Luciano Berio and another compositionless name or two, the response is likely to trail off. Despite an occasional flurry of interest, as in a week of Italian music presented by New York University two years ago, the field remains little known.

title: Psychemedics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chevron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a special credit of $ 80 million for the quarter, and foreign exchange gains of $ 20 million and $ 16 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Included a special credit of $ 7 million for the quarter, and foreign exchange gains of $ 14 million and $ 37 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.The company said special items increased earnings $ 144 million in the latest 9 months, but reduced 1989 9-month income by $ 4 million. Special items in 1990 consisted of net gains from property dispositions and favorable tax adjustments, partially offset by $ 117 million of charges for environmental , restructuring and other costs.

title: Superior Teletec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
Pathe and MGM Delay Deal Again
description: The MGM/UA Communications Corporation and the Pathe Communications Corporation said today that they had again delayed the closing of Pathe's $1.3 billion deal to acquire MGM.

title: Williams Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeLatest quarter results included a $ 10 million favorable credit for income taxes because Williams and the Internal Revenue Service settled audits through 1987.The company said results in the latest quarter included charges incurred by one of its Natural Gas Pipeline systems.

title: Your Money; Tax Plan Offers More Complexity
description: The complexity of the long-awaited tax package worked out by Congressional and White House negotiators could force many well-off taxpayers to scrutinize almost every facet of their finances for possible savings, even though there appears to be little they can do to cut much from their bill, the experts say.

title: Monsanto Net Off 41%
description: The Monsanto Company today reported a 41 percent drop in earnings for the third quarter and announced a wide-ranging reorganization at its second-biggest subsidiary. For the quarter, the company had profits of $74 million, or 59 cents a share, down from $126 million, or 94 cents a share, for the period a year earlier. Revenues of $2.14 billion were 4 percent higher than the $2.06 billion last year.

title: Baker Visiting Saudis Soon To Coordinate Next Steps
description: The White House said tonight that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would soon go to Saudi Arabia to coordinate with the Saudis on the next steps toward resolving the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Vote Near on Deficit Plan, $10 Billion Shy of Goal
description: As they approached final votes on a huge tax and spending plan that would affect nearly all Americans, lawmakers found today that the final negotiations had left them $10 billion short of their goal of reducing the Federal deficit by $500 billion over the next five years.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON RIDDING SKIES OF NOISY PLANES
description: After nearly a week of intense negotiations, Congressional leaders and the Administration agreed today on major legislation that would eliminate most of the airlines' noisier passenger jets from the nation's skies by the turn of the century.

title: Pilot in Mysterious Crash Gets Jail Term
description: Thomas Root, the lawyer who was found with a gunshot wound after his small plane crashed in the Atlantic off the Florida coast last year, pleaded no contest today to state charges of securities fraud and was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

title: Some Guild Workers Rush to Picket, Some Mourn
description: For most of the day, Daily News reporters were caught in a small, gloomy air pocket between organized labor and management. Unlike most of the paper's other nine unions, the Newspaper Guild had not been at war with management, nor had it been accused by the newspaper's owners of protecting unneeded jobs. So yesterday the Guild needed some time before deciding to strike.

title: Review/Music; De Larrocha, Olde Times And Mozart
description: On Dec. 29, 1965, a Spanish pianist named Alicia de Larrocha made her debut with the New York Philharmonic. To celebrate the 25th anniversary of that occasion, the orchestra on Thursday night offered the first of four concerts at Avery Fisher Hall in which Miss de Larrocha plays her debut vehicle, the Mozart Concerto No. 23 in A (K. 488), along with one of her best-known show pieces, Falla's "Nights in the Gardens of Spain."

title: Hooper Holmes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Beliefs
description: The Homecrest Presbyterian Church, at 15th Street and Avenue T in Brooklyn, stands only a block from the D train, but the white wooden structure carries its 90 years with an almost rural dignity. Set back from the street behind a lush yard, it is a relic of a time when this part of the borough was passing from farmland to suburban neighborhood.

title: Compuchem Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIC International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Betz Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Key Rates
New York City Will Rise Again
description: Confronted with a string of highly publicized crimes, a flagging economy and a potential budget gap of $2 billion for next year, New York City is facing new predictions of its imminent demise. Is its long-prophesied collapse finally at hand?

title: Two Big Cities
description: Whether or not it's true that New York is dying, as widely advertised, Paris can claim to be proof that big cities don't have to. It runs well, delivering the amenities and pleasures of urban life perhaps better than any metropolis in the world.

title: Slocan Forest reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeFigures are in Canadian funds.

title: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS: Not a Big Tilt In Tax Policy; Plan Doesn't Revive The Era of Loopholes
description: On first glance, the income tax changes cobbled together in Washington seem an ungainly mix of partly concealed rate increases and new fiddles for the wealthy -- a return to the old days when the only real issue in tax policy was who got soaked, and a thousand and one tax shelters made a mockery of the progressive tax system.

title: Educational Development reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Cash on Davis Squad
description: Pat Cash, a former Wimbledon champion, heads the six-man Australian squad that will oppose the United States in the Davis Cup final Nov. 30-Dec. 3 in St. Petersburg, Fla. Joining Cash will be Wally Masur, Darren Cahill, John Fitzgerald, Mark Kratzmann and Richard Fromberg. (AP)

title: Bridge
description: Slightly more than half a century ago a young man named Franklin Gould was playing in a duplicate game in Hartford and picked up this hand: [ DIAGRAM ]

title: Princeton Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Patroons Sign Daniels
description: Lloyd Daniels, the New York high school star whose career has been plagued by off-court events he would rather forget, has signed with the Albany Patroons of the Continental Basketball Association. The 6-foot-8-inch Daniels, whom Coach Jerry Tarkanian of Nevada-Las Vegas once called the next Magic Johnson, signed a nonguaranteed contract. If he makes the team, said Mark Kestecher, a Patroon spokesman, he will earn $580 a week.

title: Selas Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit $ 475,000, or 20 cents a share.c-Included a tax credit of $ 230,000, or 10 cents a share, and $ 266,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Books of The Times; Man, Nature and Everyday Activities in Verse
description: Collected Poems 1939-1989 By William Jay Smith 254 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95. The Eagle's Mile By James Dickey 66 pages. Wesleyan University Press/University Press of New England. 20 hard cover, $9.95 paper.

title: Aetna Life & Casualty reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $ 60 million related to severance, benefits and other costs of a reorganization of its domestic insurance operations.c-Included gain of $ 15 million from tax loss carryforwards.The latest quarter included an investment loss of $ 38,000,000 and an investment gain of $ 13,000,000 in the 9 months.Year-ago quarter and 9 months included investment gains of $ 48,000,000 and $ 81,000,000, respectively. The insurance company said $ 27 million of the $ 48 million of net investment gains was generated by the sale of federated investors. With the $ 15 million of tax loss carryforwards generated by the sale, Aetna said, the federated transaction added $ 42 million to its 1989 third quarter net income.

title: Major Legislation Moves Ahead in Both Houses of Congress
description: Clean Air

title: Schwitzer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Film; Underground Horror
description: Rats are a big attraction in "Stephen King's Graveyard Shift," about the crew hired for night work cleaning out the much too populous basement of a long-abandoned mill. But the film's human actors are a big attraction, too. Made as an unabashed B-movie, "Graveyard Shift" has an offbeat, well-chosen cast of unfamiliar-looking actors, and they help to give the film its gritty edge.

title: Allied-Signal reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 23 million, or 16 cents a share, related to Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc. business interruption insurance settlement.

title: George Nordmeyer, Professor, 78
description: George Nordmeyer, retired chairman of the Hunter College German department, died on Tuesday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 78 years old

title: Into Management Hands; Misjudgment and Accident Come Together To Force Strike Unwanted by News Unions
description: The strike by unions at The Daily News is just what the paper's management had been hoping for, and from the union perspective, even trying to provoke, but it is a disaster for the paper's labor leaders, who had sought desperately to avoid a strike if at all possible.

title: In Guatemala, No One Is Safe . . .
description: Political murder has once again reached epidemic proportions in Guatemala. This year more than 1,000 people have been murdered or have disappeared. With the upcoming election in Guatemala on Nov. 11, the United States needs to send an unmistakable message to Guatemala's civilian and military authorities that we are still concerned about human rights in Central America.

title: Niagara Mohawk Power Corp. reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Increased due to an August 1989 agreement that permits recovery of replacement power costs incurred because of the Nine Mile Unit 1 outage. The earnings included $ 115.5 million of expense deferrals provided under the agreement, including carrying charges.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: The Terror of Division III
description: When Jim Shuart matriculated at Hofstra in the fall of 1949, the college was only 14 years old and had just begun to expand from the 15-acre Hofstra family estate on Hempstead Turnpike.

description: b-Net loss

Reviews/Dance; Danspace Celebrates Itself
description: The dance theater at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery has witnessed remarkable work by ground-breaking choreographers in its 60-year history. But the emphasis was on the performers on Tuesday night when the resident Danspace Project celebrated itself in "Dance/Eats/Money," a pleasantly informal benefit gala at the handsome little theater.

title: Patents; Using Mung Bean Meal To Make Fried Chicken
description: The mung bean, which is a third the size of a pea and contains a yellow starch center, may find new opportunities in the United States. Satish C. Bhardwaj, a financial consultant in Brooklyn with a fascination for food, recently patented a way to use mung beans for making fried chicken and other batter-fried foods.
