description: b-Net incomeThe company said 1990 results were adversely affected by a number of non-recurring factors, including: $ 1 million in compensation granted in the form of warrants and options to certain individuals acting as guarantors of letters of credit; a $ 630,000 charge related to a major consolidation of operations; $ 1 million in selling, general and administrative expenses associated with the acquisition, operation and recently announced divestiture of the company's retail divisions, and a $ 1.4 million loss from these discontinued operations.

title: Accounts
description: * Omni Windows, a unit of Alside Corp., Akron, Ohio, to Christopher Thomas Associates, Garden City, L.I., with a budget of $1 million. * Continental Culture Specialists Inc., Glendale, Calif., to Coen, Kalis & Moiselle, Los Angeles, for its yogurt products.

title: Is Simon & Schuster Mellowing?
description: One publishing house has largely avoided the public bloodlettings that have wracked book publishing in recent years. Indeed, Simon & Schuster has been a model of relative publishing stability.

title: Barnes Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9 months are after preferred dividends of $ 169,000 and $ 1,259,000, respectively.

title: Ms. Woods Weds Peter M. Sanders
description: Donna Jean Wood, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Wood of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Peter Michael Sanders, the son of Madelyn Sanders of New York. The Rev. John T. Meehan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Graf Wins 9th Tourney of Season: Steffi Graf won her ninth tournament of the year yesterday, beating Helena Sukova, 7-5, 6-3, in Brighton, England, for her 17th consecutive victory over the Czechoslovak. Graf, who needed only 68 minutes to beat the third-seeded Sukova, won the $350,000 Brighton tournament for a record fourth straight time. She had shared the record of three consecutive victories with Chris Evert.

title: Israel's Cabinet Seems Split On Punishment in Shootings
description: The Israeli Cabinet today endorsed a Government commission's report on Palestinian unrest and fatal shootings by the police in the Old City of Jerusalem early this month. But opinion was divided on whether anyone should be disciplined over the incident.

title: The Bond Act: A Price Worth Paying
description: The spirits of Teddy Roosevelt, Averell Harriman and Nelson Rockefeller -- conservationists all -- must be restless. New York voters will vote next week on a $1.9 billion bond act to enhance the state's environment. New Yorkers have approved nine such measures in this century but this one is thought to be in trouble. Some critics call it a naked land grab. Others say it's an agreeable but frivolous luxury in a time of fiscal austerity.

title: Production Operators reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Graco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Andrew J. Propper Is Wed To Lesley Ann Friedland
description: Lesley Ann Friedland, a daughter of Josine Friedland of Charlotte, N.C., and the late Morton H. Friedland, was married yesterday at the Sutton Place Synagogue in New York to Andrew J. Propper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Propper of San Diego. Rabbi David B. Kahane officiated.

title: Tax Shifts Make Planning More Difficult
description: In its search for an additional $40 billion to throw at the Federal budget deficit, Congress approved a three-pronged attack on the nation's tax code on Saturday. The intent is to get that money from the upper class and upper-middle class through higher taxes for Medicare, a variety of income tax changes and additional excise taxes for gasoline, tobacco, alcohol and certain luxury goods.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
A Bicycle Primer For Beginners
description: After experiencing her share of the aches and pains that afflict dedicated runners, Caryl Hudson discovered the kinder, gentler approach of cross-training on a bicycle.

title: A HINDU MILITANT IS SEIZED IN INDIA
description: One of India's most colorful political personalities, Vijaye Raje Scindia, vice president of the Hindu party that has put Prime Minister V. P. Singh's Government in jeopardy, was arrested today on her way to Ayodhya, the site of a disputed shrine.

title: News Having Trouble Getting Paper Out
description: There were signs yesterday that management at The Daily News was encountering serious problems producing and distributing the newspaper in the face of a walkout by 2,200 unionized workers that began last week.

title: Wyman-Gordon reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Arkansas Freightways reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Roberta Milston Weds Samuel Kramer
description: Roberta Jane Milston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Milston of New York, was married yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue to Samuel Gideon Kramer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Kramer of Cincinnati. Rabbi David H. Lincoln and Cantor David Lefkowitz officiated.

title: Desert Jeopardy -- Or Desert Mirage?
description: As more hostages are released in Iraq and return home, we will be hearing many fantastic and harrowing tales, but none more fantastic than mine. After my arrest in Kuwait, three days after the Iraqi invasion, I was held hostage for several weeks in Iraq, along with several dozen other Westerners. We had no idea of our whereabouts.

title: Three Ways for Raising Taxes
description: Congress hopes to raise $40 billion by increasing income tax rates for higher-income people, Medicare levies and so-called sin taxes. Business Day, D1.

title: OPEC to Meet Dec. 12
description: The president of OPEC, Sadek Boussena, said last week that the group would hold a formal meeting on Dec. 12 in Vienna to discuss the oil markets, which have been thrown into disarray by the Persian Gulf crisis. Mr. Boussena, who is also the Algerian mines minister, said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would probably not be able to meet demand for its oil in midwinter. He predicted a gap of a million to 1.5 million barrels a day.

title: POLICE SHOOT MAN ROUSED FROM BED
description: Police officers checking a report of a prowler entered an apartment at 3:30 A.M. Saturday and shot a 24-year-old stockbroker to death when he got out of bed to see what was wrong.

title: Amwest Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it terminated a previously established reserve of $ 1,423,000 during the third quarter for potential premium rebates under California's Propostion 103. The termination of the reserve resulted in a one-time increase in net income of $ 797,000, or 34 cents a share, which is included in the latest third quarter and 9 months results.

title: Truth in Troth
description: Clark Kent has declared himself. Popped the Question. Asked the Big One. "Lois," he says in next month's D.C. Comics to the woman he has admired for 50 years, "Will you marry me?"

title: The Mystery of Milken: Why Didn't He Testify?
description: Why won't Michael Milken testify?

title: IRAQ IS DROPPING ITS FUEL RATIONING, BLAMING MINISTER
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq reversed a decision to ration fuel today and dismissed his Oil Minister on the ground that a miscalculation by the official had led to the announcement 10 days ago that the country faced a gasoline shortage.

title: Carpenter Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yellow Freight System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain from accounting change of $ 29,200,000, or $ 1.10 a share.

title: Taipei Journal; War on Crime Makes a Hero of a Hated General
description: Just a few months ago, Hau Pei-tsun seemed one of the most unpopular men in Taiwan. When he was appointed Prime Minister, protesters rallied in the streets and warned that his selection would threaten Taiwan's emerging democracy.

title: The Polygraph Purgatory
description: The man responsible for subjecting scores of his fellow State Department employees to the mental torture of polygraph tests confessed at a Senate hearing last week that "I took a lie detector test and did not do well on it, and what I learned from that is that they are very unreliable devices."

title: New York City's Budget Gap Is Even Worse Than It Looks
description: New York City has a budget of more than $28 billion and a projected gap in it for the coming fiscal year of perhaps $2 billion -- in other words, it is short one dollar for every 14. But the problem is really more severe, because the budget over which the city has full control is closer to $12 billion, and that means it is short one dollar for every six.

title: Jack Ruby's Executor And Heirs Battle for Gun
description: Millions of Americans still benumbed by the killing of President John F. Kennedy two days earlier caught a fleeting glimpse of the gun 27 years ago, when a short man in a hat darted from the corners of their television screens, ran up to Lee Harvey Oswald and fired it into his stomach.

title: Prosperous Town Braces for Leaner 90's
description: From the storefronts of Main Street to the shops along Franklin Turnpike, merchants here can see the end of the 80's across their counters, in sagging sales of everything from lumber to liquor, from bicycles to auto-repair equipment.

title: Alpha Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax benefits from tax-loss carryforward of $ 97,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $ 195,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: A Hilton Hotel Is Demolished
description: The Parkview Hilton, a modern-style glass-walled hotel that was just 36 years old, was demolished today after its owners were unable to find a buyer for the vacant building. A festive crowd estimated at 10,000 watched the explosion from Bushnell Park, a sloping green that stands between the hotel and the state Capitol and gave the hotel its name. The 16-story building was imploded -- exploded from within so that it would fall on itself -- by demolition workers who used 60 pounds of carefully placed dynamite. The Parkview had been vacant since Dec. 31, when it closed its doors, a victim of the sagging demand for hotel space in Hartford.

title: Court Papers Suggest Overcharges by Hughes
description: Recently declassified Government and corporate documents appear to support a whistleblower's accusations that the Hughes Aircraft Corporation overcharged the Pentagon on programs to develop in-flight radar systems.

title: Track Life Goes On After Day of Death
description: Life went on yesterday at Belmont Park. Nine races were run without injury or incident around the same oval on which two horses drew their final breaths a day earlier, turning the climactic day of the thoroughbred racing season into the sport's darkest afternoon.

title: About the Rest Of This Series
description: This is the last of five articles on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's record.

title: Rothmans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 7.1 million charge from closure of the Montreal plant.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Utility Deal Set in Kansas
description: The Kansas Gas and Electric Company said yesterday that it had signed a definitive merger agreement with Kansas Power and Light Company, ending a takeover bid that Kansas Power began in July.

title: Fingerhut Companies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9 months are not applicable; company made initial public offering in April 1990.

title: Wetterau Inc. reports earnings for 13wks Sept 29
description: Year-ago periods ended Sept. 30.

title: 76ers Obtain Suns' Williams
description: The Phoenix Suns traded their disgruntled first-round draft pick Jayson Williams to the Philadelphia 76ers today for a first-round selection in the 1993 draft.

title: Speaking About Spending Less, Cuomo Has Spent More
description: Early in his first term, when the state was faced with a debilitating budget deficit, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo adopted the slogan, "We must learn to do more with less." He recited it to anyone who would listen: to commissioners hoping to expand their agencies, to lawmakers looking to extend the state's largess, even to hospital workers seeking higher pay.

title: Courier Dispatch Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Supermarket Sweep
description: "The grocery store," observes Dr. Louis Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, "has become a Tower of Babel, and consumers need to be linguists, scientists and mind-readers to understand the many labels they see." New food labeling rules just passed by Congress offer hope for ending much of the confusion.

title: Promus Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: Net income comparisons are unavailable because of accounting methods employed prior to Promus Cos.' spinoff from Holiday Corp. in February.The company said it adjusted 1990 tax accrual to reflect a greater proportion of its earnings being generated in states with higher income tax rates; the cumulative effect of that increase is about 6 cents a share in the quarter.

title: U.S. Is Changing Its Tune On Liberalization of Trade
description: After years of pushing for an end to nations' restrictions on financial, engineering, communications and other services, Washington is losing some of its enthusiasm for liberalization.

title: Mental Patient Cleared After 'Admitting' Killing
description: Virginia Tooker was leading a reasonably content life in a group home for mentally ill outpatients in Queens when she was arrested for manslaughter in April.

title: Loss of Traditional Base Completes Bhutto's Slide
description: Provincial election returns announced today apparently confirmed the political eclipse of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Her Pakistan People's Party appears to have lost even its traditional base, Sind Province.

title: Caldwell Partners International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago results are pro-forma.The company said share earnings figures for the year-earlier quarter are not comparable due to a major reorganization last year.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Microcom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of about $ 2.5 million.c-Net income

title: Electromagnetic Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said the 1990 quarter included a $ 3.4 million pretax charge for restructuring of microwave operations.

title: Jaguar Battle at a Turning Point
description: The new leaders of Jaguar Cars Ltd. are hoping that their first major victories are at hand in the battle to turn the antiquated British company into one of the world's biggest, most efficient makers of luxury cars.

title: Ethics Crossfire in Regan-Bellamy Race
description: As the tight race for New York state comptroller neared its final week, the two main contenders attacked each other on ethical issues in a testy debate televised yesterday.

title: Treasury to Sell 2-Year Notes This Week
description: The schedule of Treasury financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed tomorrow by an auction of two-year notes that was postponed last week because of the Government's failure to raise the debt ceiling.

title: Outdoors: A Harvest Ripe for Pursuit
description: FOR those who both fish and hunt, the fall transition from the former to the latter is a time of sweet indecision. This is particularly true in a state as rich in natural resources as New York.

title: Let's Recycle More And Waste Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Suffer 8-3 Bombardment
description: For the third time in less than week, the Islanders failed to remember how the tortoise defeated the hare and, after giving up eight goals, were themselves defeated.

title: No Talks on Hostages, European Leaders Vow
description: European Community leaders said today that Iraq's selective release of foreign hostages would not erode their unity in the Persian Gulf crisis, and they pledged not to negotiate with Baghdad to bring their countrymen home.

title: How to Start Waking Up With a Smile
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; A Hallucinatory Voyage For an Artist at Sea
description: This evening's offering by the Lyric Opera of Chicago at the Civic Theater was notable in itself: the unveiling of a major new production of "The Voyage of Edgar Allan Poe," a 1976 work by the American composer Dominick Argento. What made the event truly remarkable was that this production is merely the beginning of a series, Toward the 21st Century, in which, over the next decade, the company is to present 16 more revivals of 20th-century operas, 6 by Americans and 10 by Europeans, as well as 3 new commissioned works by Americans.

title: Medstone International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Giants' Not-So-Secret Weapon
description: HE'S the Giants' weapon that's no longer secret. Reyna Thompson is slim and swift, a Plan B acquisition a year ago from the Miami Dolphins who has created a cult following at Giants Stadium for his special-teams coverage on kickoffs and punts. But he's unlike most special-teams tacklers, some of whom might be charitably described as suicidal. At least when wearing a helmet.

title: Ex-Contras, Citing Broken Promises, Seize Land and Talk Again of War
description: Dissatisfaction with President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro among many of her peasant allies has created a volatile, rebellious mood in the northern mountains of this country.

title: Old Communist Ways Slow Polish Capitalism
description: Almost 10 months after Poland's crash economic reform program began, the Government has yet to turn a single large state-owned enterprise into a private company.

title: Small Drop In Rates Predicted
description: The Federal Reserve Board will probably respond to the passage of the new Federal budget by reducing short-term interest rates, but credit market analysts said neither Congress nor the Bush Administration should expect a substantial reduction as a glittering prize for what the tortuous, confidence-shaking exercise has produced.

title: Critic's Notebook; How Much Should TV Tell, and When?
description: While Mehrdad Dashti was holding 33 people hostage in the bar of a hotel in Berkeley, Calif., last month, he could watch on the bar's television set reports of what the police outside were up to. Should the stations covering the action have taken that into account? For example, should they have reported, as at least one station did, that a police assault team had moved into position, even though it was known that a television set was on in the bar? Shouldn't it have occurred to somebody that the gunman, who had already wounded eight people, one of them fatally, might be provoked to shoot more of his captives?

Industry Acts Aggressively To Increase Prices of Books
description: PUBLISHING is a conservative business, still in the throes of adapting to such late 20th century practices as marketing and computerization. "We labor under numerous traditions, which I prefer to call false barriers and myths," said Marvin Brown, the president of NAL/Dutton, a subsidiary of Penguin USA.

title: Warmed-Over Smear
description: One of the low points of the McCarthy era was an attack made not by Senator McCarthy but by President Eisenhower's Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr. He charged that former President Truman had promoted a Treasury official, Harry Dexter White, knowing him to be a Soviet spy.

title: Review/Art; Titian and His Sublime Works Of Inevitability and Freedom
description: As soon as you enter the Titian exhibition here at the National Gallery of Art, you are in the presence of a great painter. Throughout the paintings he did in his 20's and 30's that open the exhibition, there is a justness, timing and feeling for pictorial relationships that cannot be taught. Titian seems to have been born knowing how to fix a head, knee or arm in space. Wherever he painted something, it belongs. Whatever he painted finds its place.

title: Merit Medical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: United Asset Management reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Merrill Lynch Revamping Is Expected
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is expected to announce a sweeping reorganization as soon as today that would dissolve the firm's separate consumer and capital markets groups, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: 2 Unions Said To Plan Halt To City Talks
description: A spokesman for one of two large municipal unions that have been negotiating together with New York City said yesterday that both unions planned to break off the stalled labor talks today.

title: Synergen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Versa Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Linear Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush Loses a Game, But Stays in Match
description: As the 101st Congress adjourned early this morning, Democrats were thanking no one more than George Bush himself for a sudden improvement of their political fortunes.

title: U.N.L.V. Presents Options to Lift Ban
description: Jerry Tarkanian, the basketball coach at Nevada-Las Vegas, offered to sit out the national collegiate championship tournament, forfeit a personal stake of as much as $100,000 in playoff revenue and abstain from recruiting for a year if the National Collegiate Athletic Association would reverse a ruling blocking the Runnin' Rebels from defending their national title.

title: Geodyne Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Seaway Food Town Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
Amy G. Borress Is Married
description: Amy Gail Borress, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Borress of New City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Abraham Harold Glass, a son of Ruth S. Earnest and a stepson of Allen J. Earnest of the Bronx. Rabbi David Fass officiated at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. The bride, 26 years old, graduated from Smith College and received a law degree from Yeshiva University. She is an associate at the New York law firm of Dreyer & Traub. The bridegroom, 30, a graduate of McGill University, is an energy analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York.

title: SFFed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 101st Congress Wraps Up Work Belatedly and a Little Battered
description: Finally, the 101st Congress adjourned early this morning, its legislative accomplishments in the last two years almost lost amid weeks of bitter tangling over the budget that kept lawmakers practically captive for weeks in the Capitol.

title: Congressional Poker Chips: Judges, Water, Oil and Beer
description: Nothing quite illuminates the way Congress really does business like the pre-adjournment scramble to cut a deal, save a water project or thwart the pet initiative of a political foe.

title: Gulf Talk: Gorbachev and Mitterrand
description: With the Soviet Union apparently frustrated in its latest effort to persuade Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met tonight with President Francois Mitterrand on France's ideas for ending the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Correction
description: An article on Friday about a Congressional agreement on immigration legislation misstated in some copies the number of additional immigrants who would be allowed into the United States as skilled workers or managers. The number would be 140,000 people a year, counting the workers and their families, not 750,000. The article also incorrectly named and dated the McCarran-Walter Act, enacted in 1952, which banned many categories of immigrants, including Communists. The article also misidentified the chief House negotiator in the House-Senate conference committee that worked out the agreement. The chief negotiator was Representative Bruce A. Morrison, Democrat of Connecticut. An article on further action on the legislation appears on page B10.

title: Helicopters for Mexico Draw Protests in Congress
description: As part of its war on drugs, the Bush Administration is scheduled to begin delivering military helicopters to Mexico this week despite accusations by three Senators that the aircraft will be managed by a law enforcement official who has been linked to drug corruption.

title: Nuggets Sputtering Amid Point Splurge
description: Paul Westhead was sitting in a Boston hotel lobby early last Thursday morning, answering more of what has become an avalanche of questions concerning the controversial style of play he is trying to introduce to the National Basketball Association.

title: Market Place; Cellular Stocks Lose Attraction
description: THE market for cellular telephone properties increasingly resembles the real estate market in the Northeast. Fewer properties are changing hands in both markets. Sellers are reluctant to accept lower prices, but buyers are bidding lower, if at all. And bankers are increasingly nervous about whether floor space in buildings or air time on cellular networks can be rented for enough to insure the repayment of loans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Iraq will not ration fuel, President Saddam Hussein decided in a reversal. Mr. Hussein also dismissed the minister whose apparent miscalculation led to the announcement 10 days ago that the country faced a gasoline shortage. Page A1

title: Universal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 2.8 million income tax credits on earnings permanently reinvested abroad for which taxes had been previously accrued.c-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $ 7,984,000, or 47 cents a share, which represented adoption of FAS 96, Accounting for Income Taxes.

title: INSIDE
description: A Ghost of Dallas, 1963 A legal tug-of-war in Dallas is focused on the revolver that Jack Ruby used to kill Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin of President John F. Kennedy. It is said to be worth $100,000. Page A12. Another Defeat for Bhutto Provincial elections in Pakistan apparently confirmed the political eclipse of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Page A6. Some Interest Rate Relief With agreement on the Federal budget, many financial analysts expect a modest reduction in interest rates. Business Day, page D1. Close Race in Texas Polls suggest that Ann Richards, the Democratic candidate for governor, has drawn even with the Republican, Clayton Williams. Page A14.

title: Final Votes in Congress on Key Measures
description: Crime

title: For Congress From New Jersey
description: Gov. Jim Florio, safe in the State House, is a major issue in New Jersey this year. Republicans rail against his unpopular tax increases while Democrats who supported him strain to focus voters' attention elsewhere. The Florio issue intrudes on all races, but particularly the two for open seats in Congress:

title: Review/Theater; Pearl Harbor for a Bit Of Fun and Games
description: Jon Shirota's "Lucky Come Hawaii" is a rambunctious, good-natured romp that deals with a most unlikely subject for comedy, the reaction of people to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. The play, which opened the Pan Asian Repertory Theater's 14th season on Saturday at Playhouse 46, somehow manages to avoid bad taste. For one thing, the author studiously keeps the war itself far offstage. The play benefits from both local color and period flavor.

title: Urcarco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Preserving Artistic Vision Struck Down by AIDS
description: The dance world has been hit hard by AIDS. Many in its ranks who have died in the last few years have been young, with promising careers as choreographers and performers. To capture their stories while there is still time, the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center has started an oral history project devoted to the lives of people in dance with AIDS.

title: More Blacks See Woes As Part of Conspiracy
description: A growing number of black Americans are turning to racial conspiracy theories to explain the ills affecting black America, including the rise of AIDS and the availability of illegal drugs in their communities. The theories vary widely, as do their believability, the backgrounds of those who support them and the degree of support each receives.

title: Auto Racing;   Indy Takes a Worldwide View
description: JUST as the Disney theme parks have expanded overseas in recent years, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway is trying to create a worldwide network of Indy 500's through licensing agreements in Europe and Japan.

title: Ceramics Process Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
Judge Allows Suit Over AIDS and Dentist
description: A woman who says her dentist gave her AIDS will be allowed to file a $1 million claim with his malpractice insurance company, a judge has ruled. The dentist died last month.

title: Engraph Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions
description: Basketball DALLAS (NBA) -- Waived Bob McCann, forward, and Kelvin Upshaw, guard. NETS (NBA) -- Signed Derrick Coleman, forward, to a five-year contract. Football MIAMI (AFC) -- Activated Shawn Lee, nose tackle, from injured reserve. Waived Jeff Faulkner, defensive end.

title: Executions Leave Blood on Society's Hands; When the State Kills
description: To the Editor:

title: McCann Names Head Of Special G.M. Office
description: McCann-Erickson has named Candace M. Robbins manager of its new Troy, Mich., office, McCann/SAS, which it opened to serve the GMC truck division of the General Motors Corporation. Ms. Robbins had managed truck advertising at the Chevrolet division at G.M.

title: Executions Leave Blood on Society's Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Money Is Keeping Central Park Healthy
description: In the late 1970's, the broken lamps and dusty lawns of Central Park were an apt metaphor for New York City's fiscal crisis, and its crime-prone backyard was a favorite target for late-night comedians.

title: Taunts but 'Good Money' for New Drivers at News
description: Obscenities, eggs and coffee cups bombarded a convoy of nine delivery trucks that roared past a phalanx of police officers in helmets and angry picketers early yesterday morning to deliver bundled copies of The Daily News.

title: Colombia Rebels Turn to Ecological Terrorism
description: The sunlit office of the nature conservancy group could have been in any country -- potted plants, desktop terminals, a poster of the endangered Pauxi Pauxi bird and a staff member wearing a shirt that said: "Plant trees -- plant hopes."

title: Homplex Mortgage Investments reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Minorities in Himalayan Bhutan Struggle
description: To the Editor

title: Lights, Cameras, Agassi
description: EVEN without the imminent arrival of Andre Agassi in an ultimate driving machine, there is already more than enough here to meet the eye.

title: Republican Quits Governor's Race in Minnesota
description: The Republican candidate for governor of Minnesota said today that he was dropping out of the race after a newspaper reported that he had had a sexual relationship with a woman while he was married to his first and second wives.

title: Ad Magazine Sale Reported
description: The Act Three Publishing Company sold Marketing & Media Decisions magazine to Affiliated Publications for an undisclosed amount, people at Act Three said yesterday.

title: Weirton Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected loss of $ 12,595,000 on early extinguishment of debt.

title: Fountain Powerboat reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said it changed its fiscal year to correspond with its model year, which is July through June, so the 9 months figures are now the year-end figures for fiscal 1990. It did not offer any comparative figures.

title: S. E. Levingston Weds Ms. Allard
description: Suzanne Mary Allard, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gilles G. Allard of Salem, Mass., was married yesterday to Steven E. Levingston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Levingston of Beverly Hills and Palm Springs, Calif. The Rev. Gary Seibert, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Mordecai Genn, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy E. Smith in Darien, Conn.

title: In Texas, Governor's Race Becomes a Horse Race
description: Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for governor of Texas, has been so confident of defeating his Democratic opponent, Ann Richards, that at one point he promised to "head her and hoof her and drag her through the dirt" just like a cow he would rope on his ranch.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "If my father was a lawyer, I might have been a lawyer. My father was a pressman, so I became a pressman." Howard Grantz, striking driver. [ B4:2. ]

title: Hungary Softens on Gas Price
description: The Government backed away from a 70 percent gasoline price increase today after two days of crippling nationwide blockades of roads by taxi and truck drivers. Industry and Trade Minister Peter Akos Bod said the Government was prepared to accept a 50 percent increase pending passage of a law allowing the market to set the price of gasoline. The Government had increased gasoline to about $3.80 a gallon.

title: Elderly Would Benefit From Curbs on Sale of Overlapping Health Insurance
description: The tough new Federal standards for private health insurance that Congress approved Friday would prohibit the sale of overlapping health insurance to people like Grace and John Kossow, an elderly California couple who were persuaded to buy 29 policies in a 30-month period and billed for $22,011 in first-year premiums, or more than twice the couple's annual income.

title: Miller Building Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: c-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 2,100,000, or 47 cents a share, related to a fire in a Saskatchewan operation.Figures are in Canadian funds.

BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Bridge
description: If the opening leader wins the first trick and finds that the dummy has a side-suit with three small cards, it will often be right to shift to it, hoping to develop tricks. But that play can also be disastrous, and each case must be considered on its merits.

title: General American Investors reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: The company said latest period net per share is after capital gain distributions of $ 1.46 a share paid in December 1989 and 10 cents a share paid in February. Also, latest period net is after income dividends of 22 cents a share paid in December 1989 and 1 cent a share paid in February.Assets represented net assets.

title: Invacare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Europe's Bank: Dream vs. Reality
description: Brushing aside Britain's objections, leaders of the European Community decided this weekend to set up a common central bank in early 1994, and thus greatly advance the hope of creating a single European currency. But many economists questioned whether unforeseen obstacles would prevent the bank's establishment so soon.

title: Customedix Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated for comparative purposes to correct an accounting error relating to a former unit.Revenue represents total revenues.

title: DEVICE IN AIR BAGS PROMPTS RECALLS
description: The Ford Motor Company and three other manufacturers are recalling more than 55,000 late model cars after the discovery that scores of air bag inflators may fail to work in a head-on crash and may also release dangerous gases.

title: Yemenis Ousted by Saudis Bring New Burden Back to Their Land
description: They are coming home. From this spot on the Saudi-Yemeni border, a caravan of cars, jeeps and trucks, laden with Yemenis and the possessions they have accumulated over years -- for some a lifetime -- of work in Saudia Arabia, winds its way through the port towns and villages and mountain outposts on the often unpaved roads of this stunningly beautiful, poor country.

title: A Scramble for New Bailout Funds
description: The Bush Administration began scrambling today for ways to finance the bailout of the savings and loan industry in the wake of Congress's decision in its waning hours over the weekend not to supply any more money to the limping rescue effort.

title: William P. Slichter, 68, Scientist; Helped Develop Semiconductors
description: William P. Slichter, a former executive director at A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., whose research contributed to the development of the semiconductor, died on Thursday at his home in Chatham, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: The Adopted Have the Same Rights as Others; Not in Child's Interest

Kenyon president and chief operating officer, replacing Thomas C. Nichols Jr., who is retiring.

Review/Fashion; A Breath of Spring in Dresses by Blass and Herrera
description: Another country, another show. The spring and summer fashion openings have moved to New York for the week, after making their bid for global attention in Milan, London and Paris. Around the runway at the Bill Blass show at noon yesterday were many of the same faces that had watched Yves Saint Laurent in Paris less than a week earlier.

title: Equitable Move Stuns Limited Partners
description: When 1515 Broadway Associates L.P. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection earlier this month, its 25-or-so limited partners were stunned. The partnership, whose sole asset was a Times Square office tower in New York City, had been forced to seek court protection by its general partner, Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc., a unit of the insurance giant.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about new Federal standards for health insurance for the elderly referred incorrectly in some editions to the timing of Congress's repeal of the law that expanded Medicare coverage for catastrophic illnesses. It was repealed in November 1989, not this year.

title: New Medical Research Tool: Human Tissues in Lab Mice
description: In a series of bold experiments, scientists have created laboratory mice with tiny samples of human organs growing in them: lungs, intestines, pancreases, lymph nodes, thymuses, and livers. The purpose is to study the viruses of human diseases in living human tissues.

title: Dow Drops by 5.94; Trading Is Sluggish
description: Stocks ran out of steam yesterday, with many traders waiting for better times.
